Just beyond the Elephant and Castle, in south London, is Pembroke College Mission, started by students and staff of the Cambridge college. The buildings look rather ecclesiastical, and the warden, the Rev Mark Williams, who is also a local vicar, has come up with an education project that would reinvolve its academic grandparent. As well as catering for pensioners and youth groups at the settlement, Williams is hoping to start a scheme to get more local boys and girls into higher education, using Pembroke students to coach and mentor them.

However, the most ambitious plan to relaunch a settlement has been devised by possibly the movement's best known: though it's still going strong after a century, Toynbee Hall, in London's east end, not only wants to renew its old bonds with Oxford, but forge new ones with the City, which is on its doorstep.

Toynbee, founded in 1884, is now a rambling, collegiate cluster of buildings. Many famous reformers - such as Clement Attlee and William Beveridge - were associated with it. But the warden, the Rev Professor Luke Geoghegan, says its current appeal goes across the political - and religious - spectrum.

"We're going to recreate our original roots," he says. "We're going to start a residential community for bright, young, talented people who want to go on and change the world." They will continue as students, or with their careers, but will live in. "Evenings and weekends, they'll volunteer and get involved in developing new forms of work," he says.

From September, the first batch of 15 will become residents. Their rooms are being refurbished as part of a grand redevelopment plan - IT sockets as well as TV sockets. Within three years, there will be 70 residents.

Geoghegan is determined that Toynbee should recover its early reputation as a think-tank, but he prefers to call it a "do-tank", to develop innovative programmes and try them out locally. "If they work in Tower Hamlets, they'll work anywhere," he says. "And if they don't work, we should be able to say: 'Don't try this; it's a waste of time.'"

Volunteers could find themselves doing everything from helping local elderly Bengalis in their homes to befriending persistent young offenders - as well as spending time thinking. And Toynbee is already getting applications. "A lot of young people come along with outstanding CVs and brilliant ideas and tell us: 'Nobody will give us space,'" says Geoghegan. fields.headline: Evelyn Joll
fields.standfirst: Art dealer and eminent scholar of the paintings of Turner
fields.trailText: Art dealer and eminent scholar of the paintings of Turner.
fields.body:
As a director of Thomas Agnew and Sons from 1955, and as chairman from 1982 to 1992, Evelyn Joll, who has died of cancer aged 76, was probably the Bond Street picture dealer's strongest asset. His skill never faltered; but by the age of 50, through unremitting, out-of-hours work, he had additionally won an academic reputation, chiefly through his work on JMW Turner.

Having shown a key exhibition of Turner's works at Agnew's in 1951, Evelyn became one of the triumvirate that selected the great Turner bicentenary exhibition at the Royal Academy in 1974-75; a quarter of a century later, he was closely involved in the matchless Turner: The Great Watercolours, which recently closed at the Royal Academy.

He collaborated with Martin Butlin, then keeper of the British collection at the Tate Gallery, in The Paintings of JMW Turner, a fully rounded catalogue raisonné of some 560 paintings (1977, revised edition 1984), justly awarded the Mitchell Prize for Art History in 1978. Each of Turner's paintings is now universally distinguished by its B&J number in this catalogue, a recognition of authoritativeness earned by few scholars. Butlin catalogued the paintings in public collections, Evelyn the (generally) less well- researched paintings in private collections. As Butlin recognised, Evelyn's was the more exacting task.

Agnew's conceded Evelyn six months' leave to complete work that might have occupied the average academic for a decade. He had years of observations to draw upon, but the greater part of the work was achieved through resolution and stamina.

With his flair for gamesmanship, but within the constraints of orthodoxy, Evelyn enlivened even the factual apparatus of this catalogue, discreetly inserting, for instance, an exclamation mark to note the length of time a dealer may have had a Turner on his hands before achieving a sale. While giving John Ruskin his fair share of quotation, Evelyn's commentaries are mercifully far from Ruskinian; invariably level-headed, he balanced admiration for Turner with keen analytical scrutiny of his works; and he was notably generous in acknowledging other scholars' observations. More recently, Evelyn was the driving editorial and contributing force behind The Oxford Companion to Turner, published earlier this year, while he was valiantly battling against cancer.

Born in London, the only child of the surgeon Cecil Augustus Joll and his first, sadly short-lived wife, Laura, Joll was educated at Queen's College in Harley Street, the Arnold House School in St John's Wood, the Dragon School in Oxford and Eton College. From 1943 to 1946 he was an officer in the King's Royal Rifle Corps, serving in Greece, after which he graduated in history from Magdalen College, Oxford.

In 1949 he married Pamela Kingzett, a great-great-granddaughter of the founder of Thomas Agnew and Sons. He settled for a job in the family firm, bringing to it an incisive brain and an engaging personality.

Turner by no means monopolised Evelyn's attention. Expert in most schools of art, he had a particular fondness for watercolours of the English school, and held annual watercolour exhibitions at Agnew's. These typically contained engaging works by minor masters, as well as great works by JR Cozens, Thomas Girtin, Peter De Wint, and Turner.

Evelyn was equally happy advising modest collectors or magnates. His own small, discerning collection of watercolours included many works by living artists. He had virtually completed a catalogue of watercolours in the Cecil Higgins Art Gallery, Bedford, when he died.

In his blend of cool common sense and jocularity, Evelyn was sui generis . Broad-minded, level-headed, free from snobbery and with a keen perception of the absurd, he boasted a sense of humour that ranged from the teasing to the mordant, according to his perception of what the traffic would bear. His sardonic nicknames for pompous acquaintances occasionally leaked out, paradoxically becoming much prized by their subjects, and he was a highly entertaining and unguarded correspondent. Evelyn frequently travelled abroad to attend foreign sales or to update valuations, and always made a point of walking off with the hotel bedroom's supply of writing paper. Months, even years, later, one might get a letter purporting to come par avion from Minneapolis or Monte-video, though undeniably postmarked London.

Evelyn had innumerable friends; but was never happier than at home, with his unutterably staunch wife Pam, writer and personality in her own right, and with their son, three daughters and seven grandchildren as the most welcome of all visitors.

webTitle: Lecturers threaten strike action over 'inadequate' 3.3% pay offer

fields.headline: Lecturers threaten strike action over 'inadequate' 3.3% pay offer
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The threat of industrial action in the education sector intensified yesterday, after university lecturers and teachers signalled a series of one day strikes over pay which could disrupt the courses of thousands of students as early as next month.
fields.body:
The threat of industrial action in the education sector intensified yesterday, after university lecturers and teachers signalled a series of one day strikes over pay which could disrupt the courses of thousands of students as early as next month.

The immediate threat comes from members of the National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education, representing staff in the post-1992 universities and higher education colleges, who have already backed industrial action to allow the first strike to take place on May 21.

Other sanctions being discussed include withholding students' exam and coursework marks and refusing to deal with exam boards.

The latest round of pay talks which began in the autumn has secured an offer from employers of 3.3% for 2000-01 - more than 1% below average pay rises and below the average for public sector workers and teachers.

Natfhe has rejected this and is recommending members take action unless the offer is improved. Talks are due to resume on May 10 and sanctions could begin seven days later.

Lecturers are also considering action over threatened job cuts, which they blame on government underinvestment and fluctuations in student demand for some courses.

The Association of University Teachers, which represents teachers in longer established universities, is also unhappy about the low pay offer, and made it clear yesterday that if a better deal is not presented on May 10 its annual conference shortly afterwards will consider a call for a ballot on industrial action. The threats of action come as the Easter classroom teacher conference season looks set to be dominated by debates about better working conditions, with a historic joint motion calling for a 35 hour week supported by the main unions.

Tom Wilson, head of Natfhe's higher education department, said a "summer of discontent" was looking likely. "We are certainly gearing ourselves up for industrial action," he said. "The pay offer on the table is plainly inadequate. Lecturers have been very patient but that patience is now running out. University lecturers have to cope with a double whammy - low pay and job insecurity. What kind of an incentive is that for young graduates considering a career in university teaching?"

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said: "Higher education staff have shown the patience of saints waiting for a serious pay offer from university employers.

"After many months of exhausting negotiation the employers have one more opportunity in early May to solve this dispute. Increasing demands on higher education and the expansion of university places will not again be funded out of the pocket of lecturers and staff."

 New "Harvard-style" PhD courses will be on offer at 10 leading universities from this September, it was announced yesterday, allowing students to learn new skills through coursework alongside specialist research.

The so-called "new route" PhDs, which were welcomed by the prime minister, are modelled on the courses offered by top American universities, but will not replace existing PhDs at English universities.

fields.headline: Malaysia for the single woman
fields.standfirst:
I am returning from New Zealand via Singapore this summer and planned to spend two weeks in Malaysia, possibly around Tioman Island. I have recently become aware, however, that travelling alone as a single female can be dangerous in Malaysia. I was hoping to combine visits to the jungle, snorkelling and cultural activities. Does anyone have any advice about making my visit safely?
Zoe Badcock
fields.trailText: I have recently become aware that travelling alone as a single female can be dangerous in Malaysia. I was hoping to combine visits to the jungle, snorkelling and cultural activities. Does anyone have any advice about making my visit safely?
fields.body:
 I travelled to Tioman island via Singapore with my best friend last summer. Both of us, female, were only just 18 at the time. We didn't encounter any problems there at all - the locals are very friendly and laid back about western travellers - after all, we are their source of income! Most of the time your main danger of theft is from monkeys, and even the mosquitos aren't that bad! You would get everything you say you want from your holiday on Tioman itself.

The east coast is less adapted to tourists, so religious considerations would be a bit more important (covering up away from the beach etc), but in general I think you shouldn't worry at all about safety beyond the normal guidelines. Go and enjoy!

Bridget Lingard, Edinburgh

 I visited Peninsula Malaysia alone and had no trouble. Exercise the same caution you would anywhere else and you should be fine. One piece of advice I would give is that you should pack a long sleeved top and long trousers or skirt. You should try to cover up away from the beach, particularly along the east coast. Bear in mind that some Malaysian men have a very poor image of the morals of western women, and this is not helped if we walk about half-dressed (or so it seems to them!).

I did not visit the jungle on my trip but if I had done so I would have tried to team up with other travellers and to go with a guide. You can probably organise this from a guesthouse/youth hostel fairly easily.
Katy Wynn

 I have just returned from my second visit to Malaysia, both to the Peninsular and Borneo. Don't believe the Lonely Planet guide - as a single traveller I always feel safe to wander everywhere. It is polite to to cover shoulders and wear a longish skirt or trousers in towns and villages. I understand that if flying longhaul with Malaysian Airlines from NZ or Australia, free internal flights are available in all of Malaysia as a stop off. The airports and service are excellent. Enjoy yourself.
Pat Hedger

 Tioman island is safe for women, it's further north than the islands around Borneo, where a group of tourists got kidnapped off last year. If you are worried, you should perhaps consider booking into a resort (can do this from Singapore) - they are still very laid back and not that touristy and then trek across the island from there and take a boat back to the resort. I found Malaysian's very friendly and maybe because it is such a strongly religious country, I never felt unsafe. It's a fantastic place, I recommend you just go for it!
Sarah

webTitle: Schools 'becoming dependent on vouchers to raise funds'

fields.headline: Schools 'becoming dependent on vouchers to raise funds'
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Pupils are being turned into consumers too early as schools rely on store vouchers to pay for essentials, teachers warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Pupils are being turned into consumers too early as schools rely on store vouchers to pay for essentials, teachers warned yesterday.

The Association of Teachers and Lecturers said schools were becoming dependent on the promotions run by Tesco, Walkers' crisps, Tetley tea and McVitie's biscuits.

Robin Bevan, a teacher at King Edward VI grammar school, Chelmsford, said that cash or in kind benefits from outside sources, including money raised by parents, were worth an average of £5,000 a year to each primary school - or £100m a year nationwide.

At the association's annual conference in Torquay, delegates backed calls for an independent government funded audit to establish how much schools rely on funding from elsewhere.

Angie Rutter, a special educational needs teacher at Aston Clinton primary in Buckinghamshire, said her school was well funded. But her school had a corridor crowded with dump bins for the vouchers collected by parents and children.

Often children as young as five were collecting vouchers. Parents would hand them to her in the pub if they met her out of work, she said.

"We are getting so that we are dependent. It's almost like an addiction: you do it for fun to start with and then you become dependent on it," she said.

"It is very sad that we have to rely on collecting bits of paper so we can adequately resource our school," Mrs Rutter said.

"There's a direct pressure saying, 'Eat this brand of crisps, shop at this particular supermarket, drink this brand of tea, eat this cereal and you will be helping your school'. Children are being turned into consumers too young."

Mrs Rutter said teachers also dipped into their own pockets to buy their own books to teach the literacy and numeracy hours.

In his speech, the ATL's president, Eddie Ferguson, said: "In the world's fourth wealthiest nation, we have schools collecting Tesco vouchers in order to buy books and basic equipment. We have teachers organising jumble sales to save their colleagues from redundancy. Is this the way to run education?"

A spokesman for the education department said: "The ATL is talking complete nonsense. We are spending £540 more per pupil in real terms between 1997 and 2001. The greatest proportion of that is spent in primary schools." The government was relaxed about companies offering aid to schools, which were offering "peripheral help".

A spokesman for Tesco, which runs a computers for schools scheme, said: "These things are available to Tesco customers and benefit their local schools."

The Association of Teachers and Lecturers said schools were becoming dependent on the promotions run by Tesco, Walkers' crisps, Tetley tea and McVitie's biscuits. Robin Bevan, a teacher at King Edward VI grammar school, Chelmsford, said that cash or in kind benefits from outside sources, including money raised by parents, were worth an average of £5,000 a year to each primary school - or £100m a year nationwide. At the association's annual conference in Torquay, delegates backed calls for an independent government funded audit to establish how much schools rely on funding from elsewhere. Angie Rutter, a special educational needs teacher at Aston Clinton primary in Buckinghamshire, said her school was well funded. But her school had a corridor crowded with dump bins for the vouchers collected by parents and children. Often children as young as five were collecting vouchers. Parents would hand them to her in the pub if they met her out of work, she said. "We are getting so that we are dependent. It's almost like an addiction: you do it for fun to start with and then you become dependent on it," she said. "It is very sad that we have to rely on collecting bits of paper so we can adequately resource our school," Mrs Rutter said. "There's a direct pressure saying, 'Eat this brand of crisps, shop at this particular supermarket, drink this brand of tea, eat this cereal and you will be helping your school'. Children are being turned into consumers too young." Mrs Rutter said teachers also dipped into their own pockets to buy their own books to teach the literacy and numeracy hours. In his speech, the ATL's president, Eddie Ferguson, said: "In the world's fourth wealthiest nation, we have schools collecting Tesco vouchers in order to buy books and basic equipment. We have teachers organising jumble sales to save their colleagues from redundancy. Is this the way to run education?" A spokesman for the education department said: "The ATL is talking complete nonsense. We are spending £540 more per pupil in real terms between 1997 and 2001. The greatest proportion of that is spent in primary schools." The government was relaxed about companies offering aid to schools, which were offering "peripheral help". A spokesman for Tesco, which runs a computers for schools scheme, said: "These things are available to Tesco customers and benefit their local schools."

webTitle: Crisis teachers warn of new shortages

fields.headline: Crisis teachers warn of new shortages
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers at the sharp end of this winter's staff shortages warned yesterday that the situation could get even worse later this year unless the government takes further steps.
fields.body:
Teachers at the sharp end of this winter's staff shortages warned yesterday that the situation could get even worse later this year unless the government takes further steps.

Phil Baker, assistant head teacher of Headlands school in Swindon which was forced to cut its timetable for three weeks in January because it could not fill six vacancies, said many applicants for jobs were often of very poor standard.

"Many of those who contacted us were - to say the least - totally unacceptable. We wondered how many of them had even got a teaching qualification," he told the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' annual conference in Torquay.

Mr Baker's school, one of two Swindon secondaries to introduce a short week temporarily because of vacancies, spent £100,000 in the last financial year on supply teachers.

Last Thursday he had to bring in eight supply staff into the 900 pupil school.

In his own school, most vacancies had been filled now. But he expected "a very difficult recruitment time" later this year. "I am not entering this phase full of optimism. It's a tight market and adverts bring in very little. There's very little of quality as well. Many of the teachers that have come forward are of extremely poor quality."

Across the country Mr Baker believes the sitation will be "even more serious" from September. "Some of the government gimmicks are attracting some people in but the teachers are going out the back door.

"The government has got to pay a decent wage but it's also got to improve the conditions of teachers so that more people will want to come into the profession."

Ann Boxall, ATL representative for Suffolk, said that 15 more staff could be leaving Holywells school in Ipswich, where two year groups were at school for only four days a week for the last six weeks of the spring term.

The school has told the unions that it will be back to normal next term after six vacancies were filled. But Miss Boxall said many staff would be leaving for new posts or retiring in the summer.

"The government needs to look at what teachers are being asked to do so that the haemorrhaging of good teachers is stopped. You have got to get the quality staff in."

John Howson, a teacher recruitment expert and adviser to the Liberal Democrats, said last night that the situation would probably be worse in some subjects, particularly maths.

"We've got a lot of schools running empty on balances, and they've been running some posts on reserves," Mr Howson said.

The government denies that recruitment is in crisis, although it accepts that some schools are experiencing difficulties, particularly in London and the south east.

"Because of what we've done to try and retain and recruit teachers we are pretty confident that these measures will give us the results that we want," an education department spokeswoman said last night.

She said the government was giving schools an extra £35m to pay recruitment and retention bonuses this year, and the same next year. Salaries for trainee teachers and "golden hellos" for teachers in shortage subjects were having an impact.

Eddie Ferguson, the ATL president, demanded that BEd students also received the £6,000 training salary in their fourth year of teaching.

fields.headline: Euthanasia
fields.standfirst: 'Mercy killing' is now legal in the Netherlands. Here's our guide to the best websites on euthanasia
fields.trailText: 'Mercy killing' is now legal in the Netherlands. Here's our guide to the best websites on euthanasia.
fields.body:
1. The Netherlands has become the first country in the world to legalise euthanasia.

2. The new law allows doctors to end the lives of terminally ill patients - but only under strict rules.

3. Euthanasia - or "mercy killing" - has already been taking place in Holland for decades. The laws simply formalise the process.

4. The bill was not passed without controversy, however. Pro-life groups such as Cry for Life protested last night as the Senate gave the bill its final assent, and the legislation has been condemned by the opposition Christian Democrats.

5. Some observers fear that the Netherlands could become a centre for so-called 'death tourism'.

6. Debates about the ethical issues surrounding euthanasia have been raging for decades. Some believe legalising assisted suicide will lead to a Brave New World scenario. Others see it as the best way to allow terminally ill people to die with dignity.

7. In the US, the controversy has been fuelled by a man known as 'Doctor Death', Jack Kevorkian.

8. In Britain, euthanasia is a criminal offence carrying a mandatory life sentence. However, a minority of doctors and the Voluntary Euthanasia Society would like to see the law changed.

9. In light of the Dutch decision, an Australian doctor has unveiled plans for the world's first floating euthanasia clinic circumventing the fact that euthanasia is illegal in his own country by buying a Dutch-registered ship.

10. And it is likely that other European governments, including Belgium and Sweden, will consider following suit.

fields.headline: New figures show crisis easing
fields.standfirst:
 Adviser says outbreak 'flattening out'
 Steady decrease in new cases
 £15m aid for rural businesses
 Blair meeting with farmers

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth outbreak is finally "flattening out", the government's chief scientific adviser said today.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth outbreak is finally "flattening out", the government's chief scientific adviser said today.

Professor David King said the latest figures on the crisis showed there was now a steady decrease in the average number of new cases being recorded each day.

He said the average number for the week ending April 8 stood at 32 a day, compared with 43 for the previous week.

The figures for yesterday and Monday - 41 and 29 respectively - were "in line with the declining trend", he said.

"The flattening out of the epidemic has now been confirmed, and the data even shows a possible downward trend since the end of March."

Earlier today, the head of the rural task force, Michael Meacher, announced a £15m package of short-term practical help for rural businesses in the areas hardest hit by the disease outbreak.

Mr Meacher said it already complemented the £8m pledged by the regional development agencies in these areas and built on the first package of short term aid for business launched on March 20, and the £120m extension of the small firms loan guarantee scheme announced on April 6.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, today met farmers in Devon, and said vaccinations were an option still being looked at. However, Mr Blair said: "It is something that would have to be done in the knowledge that it is not a substitute for the existing policy".

Faced with hostile questioning from one farmer over bureaucracy connected with disinfectant points, Mr Blair said he would address the problem tomorrow. He said he knew of the problems faced by all of the rural businesses in the area and added: "The single most important thing is that we beat this disease."

Mr Blair's visit comes as David Hill, chairman of the National Farmers' Union (NFU) in Devon, said he would rather people broke the law by moving animals than let them suffer and die in confinement.

The row over who is to blame for the epidemic erupted after a leaked report, drafted for Mr Blair, showed farmers had taken part in hundreds of unlicensed livestock movements since the start of the outbreak.

A few desperate farmers were even suspected of deliberately infecting their flocks with foot and mouth disease in order to claim compensation.

fields.headline: Iversen released from hospital
fields.trailText: Tottenham striker Steffen Iversen was discharged from hospital today after being knocked out for the second time in three weeks.
fields.body:
Tottenham striker Steffen Iversen was discharged from hospital today after being knocked out for the second time in three weeks.

The Norwegian international was left unconscious after a collision with Bradford defender Andy Myers during Tottenham's 2-1 victory at White Hart Lane last night.

Iversen, who scored the opening goal, left the field with his neck in a brace and was carried off on a stretcher. He was taken to hospital for precautionary examinations and kept in overnight for observation. He is unlikely to feature in Tottenham's Easter weekend fixtures.

Tottenham's assistant manager John Gorman said: "Steffen came out of hospital this morning and is now back at home resting. He is feeling a bit groggy and it looks like he will be out of action for a few days at least.

"As far as we know, it was just concussion, but he will see a specialist and will also be assessed daily by our club doctor. We shall take each day as it comes, and hopefully we shall have a clearer picture tomorrow."

Hoddle said: "He was knocked unconscious playing for Norway recently so it is a worry. He hit the ground hard but hopefully he will be OK."

webTitle: Charities must wait before Comic Relief's £40m is distributed

fields.headline: Charities must wait before Comic Relief's £40m is distributed
fields.trailText: Nearly £40m has been raised through Comic Relief's Red Nose Day this year but charities will not see any money until the end of June.
fields.body:
Nearly £40m has been raised through Comic Relief's Red Nose Day this year but charities will not see any money until the end of June.

The grant making charity is still deciding on its criteria and will not be sending out application forms until the end of May. A spokeswoman said it takes at least a month for applications to be processed.

Even then, Comic Relief will only distribute one fifth of the money raised as it prefers to hand out the money through a cycle of five grant making opportunities spread over two years. The charity invests the money in ethical funds managed by an internal investment committee.

Two-thirds of the £40m will eventually go to charity work in Africa and a third to UK voluntary organisations. No money is given to individuals, only to voluntary organisations registered as charities in the UK. The overall objective is to tackle poverty and promote social justice. The last five rounds of funding focused on young people, disabled people's rights, older people, refugees and domestic violence.

However, only 24% of applicants were successful in the past two years. The spokeswoman said: "We take each application on an individual basis and concentrate on what they are hoping to achieve, we want to provide long-term funding at grassroots level."

Each application goes through a panel of 25 experts before being approved by the board of trustees of Comic Relief. Christian Aid has been successful at obtaining money for more than 10 projects but the spokeswoman said: "It is hard work, with two stages of applications and a three to four-hour interview but it is good that they are stringent."

Comic Relief hands out money in six-month tranches and asks for reports before the next amount is issued. Successful applicants in the last two years included Tarian's women's refuge in Mid Glamorgan and VOYPIC, an organisation for young people leaving care in Belfast.

To register your interest in applying for a grant, send a stamped addressed envelope (57p for first class, 44p for second class) to UK Grants Team or Africa Grants Team at Comic Relief, 5th Floor, 89 Albert Embankment, London SE1 7TP.

fields.headline: Gilding the lilies
fields.standfirst:
Former Guardian Ireland correspondent Derek Brown explains the importance that symbols hold in Ulster
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Symbols are enormously important in Northern Ireland. They help to identify   communities and factions, and provide convenient targets for 'the other side'   to attack.
fields.body:
Symbols are enormously important in Northern Ireland. They help to identify communities and factions, and provide convenient targets for 'the other side' to attack.

That is the context of the bizarre spat in the Northern Ireland assembly this week, in which hardliners of the Democratic Unionist Party DUP forced an emergency debate over - a display of Easter lilies.

It was, many might think, a ridiculous waste of time and energy. But it is also possible to argue that the debate provided a telling insight into the current state of the peace process.

The republicans of Sinn Fein knew exactly what mischief they would stir up when they persuaded the cross-party committee responsible for such things to bedeck the main hall of the Stormont assembly building with lilies. Lilies are the universally recognised symbol of mourning. For Christians, they have an especial significance at Easter. But for Irish republicans, they commemorate the dead of the 1916 Easter Rising, bloodily put down by British soldiers.

Every year at Easter, there are republican marches and rallies in memory of the dead, and bellicose speeches pledging revenge. The lily features prominently on such occasions, usually in the form of a little oblong paper version, worn on the chest.

One of the curiosities of the early years of the Troubles was that the emerging Provisional IRA and its supporters favoured fixing their paper lilies with pins, while the old Official IRA preferred a gummed version. In consequence, the latter group became universally known - and derided - as 'stickies'. For a short time the Provisionals were correspondingly called 'pinnies', but the term never, so to speak, stuck.

So the lily is a powerful symbol of militant republicanism, certain to enrage the unionist members of the assembly. None more so than the perpetually enraged DUP, led by Northern Ireland's bellower-in-chief, Ian Paisley. Paisley knows a thing or two about symbolism: the bowler hats, furled umbrellas, and coloured sashes of the various loyalist marching orders, for example. His kind of unionists have no objection to lilies, so long as they are orange. They also venerate the red poppy which honours Britain's war dead. They know that Catholics find these symbols offensive, and that is exactly why they flaunt them.

The DUP's action in demanding the recall of the assembly from its Easter recess was itself a symbolic action. Paisley's men actually won the vote, with the aid of several Ulster Unionists, only to see it effectively vetoed by nationalist and republican members - as the DUP must have known it would be.

So tempers were frayed and sensibilities ruffled, and the lilies stay. No doubt there will be more of the same when Remembrance Day comes round in November, and members snarl at each other over the poppies.

But the debate was not entirely sterile. David Ervine of the tiny Progressive Unionist Party made a remarkable intervention, ridiculing the DUP and recalling that he had done more than Paisley's ranters ever did to fight the IRA. (Ervine was sentenced to 11 years in prison in 1974 for transporting a bomb.)

Ervine actually supported the display of lilies, but added: "I have no particular desire to appreciate or venerate the republican dead other than perhaps myself and some of my colleagues might have liked to have added to the ranks of republican dead."

On the face of it, that was a poisonous thing to say, and Sinn Fein members duly twittered with horror.

But, as Ervine made clear after the debate, he was only underlining how far he and other former paramilitary activists have moved. He was, as he candidly acknowledged, once in the business of killing republicans; now he was supporting their right to commemorate their fallen heroes.

If only the IRA could respond with similar candour and generosity, the peace process would look a lot healthier. In its current febrile condition, it can too easily be diverted by the forces of reaction and bluster into a debate about a floral display.

Paisley's men actually won the vote, with the aid of several Ulster Unionists, only to see it effectively vetoed by nationalist and republican members - as the DUP must have known it would be. So tempers were frayed and sensibilities ruffled, and the lilies stay. No doubt there will be more of the same when Remembrance Day comes round in November, and members snarl at each other over the poppies. But the debate was not entirely sterile. David Ervine of the tiny Progressive Unionist Party made a remarkable intervention, ridiculing the DUP and recalling that he had done more than Paisley's ranters ever did to fight the IRA. (Ervine was sentenced to 11 years in prison in 1974 for transporting a bomb.) Ervine actually supported the display of lilies, but added: "I have no particular desire to appreciate or venerate the republican dead other than perhaps myself and some of my colleagues might have liked to have added to the ranks of republican dead." On the face of it, that was a poisonous thing to say, and Sinn Fein members duly twittered with horror. But, as Ervine made clear after the debate, he was only underlining how far he and other former paramilitary activists have moved. He was, as he candidly acknowledged, once in the business of killing republicans; now he was supporting their right to commemorate their fallen heroes. If only the IRA could respond with similar candour and generosity, the peace process would look a lot healthier. In its current febrile condition, it can too easily be diverted by the forces of reaction and bluster into a debate about a floral display. webTitle: US says sorry, China to free crew

fields.headline: US says sorry, China to free crew
fields.standfirst:
 US 'regret' over pilot's death
 24 air crew to travel home
 China to question US surveillance

Special report: China
fields.trailText:
 US 'sincere regret' over pilot's death
 24 air crew to travel home
 China to question US surveillance

Special report: China
fields.body:
China agreed today to release the 24 detained US air crew after the US president, George Bush, said in a letter his government was "very sorry" for the loss of a Chinese fighter pilot who collided with their spy plane.

The 11-day-old deadlock ended after diplomats crafted a letter intended to satisfy China's demand for a formal apology while also accommodating Mr Bush's refusal to offer one for what his government believed to be an accident.

The American crew has been held on Hainan island in the South China sea since making an emergency landing there following the April 1 collision. The Chinese pilot, Wang Wei, is missing presumed dead.

Before today's breakthrough, Mr Bush had warned that if the impasse dragged on, it could harm US-Chinese relations.

Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Sun Yuxi said: "The Chinese government out of humanitarian considerations has decided to allow the crew members to leave China after completing necessary procedures."

Mr Sun said it "won't be long" before the 21 men and three women of the US Navy EP-3E plane would be allowed to leave.

Asked what would happen to the crippled American plane, Mr Sun said: "The Chinese side has all rights to conduct a comprehensive investigation into the foreign reconnaissance plane. We will handle the plane according to the results of the investigation."

There was no indication where the American air crew was. Reporters saw workers removing bed linen from the military guesthouse where the crew members had been staying, but there was no sign of the Americans.

The Chinese foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, urged Washington to cooperate in settling the dispute. In a statement read on state television and radio, Mr Tang appealed to the Bush administration to do nothing that would damage relations between the two governments.

China has accused the US pilot of illegally entering Chinese territory by making the emergency landing on Hainan without obtaining permission in advance.

The letter delivered today to China's foreign ministry by the US ambassador, Joseph Prueher, said Mr Bush and the secretary of state, Colin Powell, expressed "sincere regret" over the loss of the Chinese plane and the missing pilot, Mr Wang.

"Please convey to the Chinese people to the family of pilot Wang Wei that we are very sorry for their loss," said the letter.

The document letter appeared to be a complex linguistic compromise.

A Chinese-language copy of the letter released by the US embassy did not use the term Chinese officials had insisted on - "daoqian", a formal apology that admits blame.

Mr Sun said it expressed "shenbiao qianyi," translated by one official Chinese dictionary as "deep apology". However, that phrase does not appear in the letter released by the US embassy and the Chinese did not release a copy of their letter.

The letter released by the US embassy says the two sides will hold a meeting on April 18 to discuss "the causes of the incident, possible recommendations whereby such collisions could be avoided in the future and development of a plan for prompt return of the EP-3 aircraft".

It says the Chinese will raise the issue of US surveillance flights near China.

fields.headline: C5 scores hit with Dirty Dozen
fields.trailText: 5.30pm TV overnights: The oft-repeated film still pulled in 2.3m viewers and 13% of the available audience, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 scored its best ratings of the day yesterday with a repeat of the 34-year-old war movie the Dirty Dozen, which brought in 2.3m viewers.

The Dirty Dozen, in which Lee Marvin leads a team of convicted prisoners on a hazardous second world war mission, went out in Channel 5's 9pm movie slot.

The oft-repeated film still pulled in 2.3m viewers and 13% of the available audience, according to unofficial overnights.

It was followed at 11.55pm by the documentary Hard Bastards, in which Kate Kray met the 28-stone bouncer Glen Ross.

Hard Bastards had 800,000 viewers and a 15% audience share.

Elsewhere last night, ITV women's prison drama Bad Girls easily brushed aside BBC1 opposition Changing Rooms and the Investigators between 9pm and 10pm.

Bad Girls pulled in 8.6m viewers and a 38% share while Changing Rooms had 5.8m and the Investigators managed just 4.3m.

webTitle: Big names shamed by performance reports

fields.headline: Big names shamed by performance reports
fields.trailText: Some of the country's biggest and best known housing associations have been exposed for their poor performance in the first ever publication of regulation reports in the sector.
fields.body:
Some of the country's biggest and best known housing associations have been exposed for their poor performance in the first ever publication of regulation reports in the sector.

The housing corporation, the sector's regulator, has responded to calls for more openness and accountability by publishing performance assessments on 60 housing association for the first time in a pilot project

The reports will make worrying reading for a number of established names including Peabody trust, Guinness trust, North British HA - which is part of the country's biggest registered social landlord Places for People - and Anchor trust, the biggest provider of homes for older people.

The report into Peabody, which is known for its characteristic 19th century estates across London, revealed that the performance of the trust has been poor for two years. It says: "Peabody's performance in respect of housing management services, notably day to day repairs and voids servicing, has been and continues to be a concern to the housing corporation."

It adds that the trust, which is also known for series of award winning new estates, may not get funding for new schemes if it does not improve performance.

The Guinness trust, which was also founded in the 19th century, was shown to be in the worst 25% on six of the corporation's eight management performance indicators. Its assessment says: "Overall, performance in service delivery is disappointing."

Guinness took on average more than seven weeks to re-let its homes compared to a national average of 4.8 weeks.

The Anchor trust was criticised for the time it took to respond to repairs, which "significantly falls below the levels required by the housing corporation's standard and has substantially worsened compared with performance in the previous year".

North British's performance on rent collection is poor and has got worse. But the corporation acknowledges that rent collection has been particularly difficult for a number of housing associations because of delays and inefficiency in councils' housing benefit administration.

Peabody chief executive Richard McCarthy said: "There is room for improvement we hold our hands up to that." He added that publication of the report will help "sharpen the attention" of staff. "We are aware that when our reputation for transfers and new development is good then its particularly important that we get the basics right."

But he added: "It does not comment on elements of the trust's performance like customer service and care taking where there is a high level of performance which is greatly appreciated by tenants."

A spokesman for Anchor claimed that its report was "positive overall" and he blamed the poor response on repairs on the trust's system rather than performance.

Roger De la Mare, corporation director of inspection, said that publication of the reports was an "important step in our efforts to make our regulatory processes more open and transparent. Our long-term aim is to extend performance summaries to all of the larger registered social landlords".

webTitle: Premiership set to become first £1bn league

fields.headline: Premiership set to become first £1bn league
fields.trailText: The Premiership will soon become the world's first billion pound league, according to a new report by Deloitte & Touche.
fields.body:
The Premiership will soon become the world's first billion pound league, according to a new report by Deloitte & Touche.

The report reveals that TV deals, merchandising and sponsorship helped Premiership clubs generate £772m in turnover last season - an increase of 15% - and that average club turnover is now £38.6m, five times the level it was when the Premiership launched eight years ago.

Gerry Boon, head of Deloitte & Touche Sport, said the Premiership is now the world's wealthiest league.

"At this rate, and with new television deals secured for the 2001/02 season, the FA Premier League will soon be football's first billion-pound league, perhaps by May this year," he said. "England's premier clubs can legitimately claim to form the world's wealthiest league and its reach is extending."

The report also found that the average annual salary of a Premiership player was a staggering £400,000 last season. Chelsea have led the way in giving huge pay rises - they have taken over from Manchester United as the best payers - and there was a 20% overall increase last year compared to 1999.

The rise is smaller than in previous years, but Boon believes it could be "the calm before the storm".

"In the year under review, there were signs that a few chairmen and managers were making a stand against some player wage demands, but key developments over the last year suggest player salaries will continue to spiral," he said.

"The effects of the new TV deal are already apparent with players and their agents positioning themselves for contract negotiations. Likewise, the European Commission ruling on transfer fees, or Bosman 2 as it is known, will cause further upward pressure on wages - at least at the top end."

Chelsea now pay a staggering £47m in wages - a 56% rise - with their top player Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink earning a reported £35,000-a-week. Leeds and Sunderland also registered big rises in their wage bills.

The review expects the star players' salaries to go into orbit, while there will be downward pressure on the money earned by squad players.

A Premier League spokesman welcomed the review. He said: "The overall picture painted by the report is very much a healthy one with the FA Premier League now firmly established as the biggest in Europe.

"The future, it suggests, is even brighter with the substantial rise in broadcasting revenues, increases in stadium capacity and with the rate of increase in wages continuing to decline," he added. "The league looks set to continue its sustained growth for many years to come."

Key findings from 'England Premier Clubs' report by Deloitte & Touche

Arsenal returned the biggest pre-tax profit in 1999/2000, £21.2m, mainly as a result of transfer income.

Newcastle and Middlesbrough recorded the biggest losses, £18.9m and £17.4m respectively.

Salaries now account for 63% of all income earned by clubs.

In 1995/96, clubs spent 49% of 'player costs' on wages and 51% on transfer fees. Now the split is 70% wages, 30% transfer fees.

From 1995-2000, the total five-year wage bill for all Premiership clubs topped £1bn.

Over the past five years, Premiership clubs have spent nearly £1.1bn on transfers.

There was record expenditure of £141m on stadia.

Football clubs paid £251m in tax last year, up 64% on 1997/98.

webTitle: Goodnight American Samoa, Bye bye Barcelona, and Farewell competition

fields.headline: Goodnight American Samoa, Bye bye Barcelona, and Farewell competition
fields.trailText: BRUCE IS BACK
fields.body:
BRUCE IS BACK

G'day Pommies! Bruce Fiver here, from the land where the Shelias bang like a dunny door in a storm. That's Australia for you drongos at the back. Now, on Monday we tonked the Tongans 22-0 to set a new record for an international victory. But were you cobbers impressed? Were you buggery! Today our boys did even better, whipping those whipping-boys of world football, American Samoa (ranked 203rd and last by Fifa) 31-0 to set a new and improved world record!

With our star striker, Coventry reserve John Aloisi, having a little rest, it took us a while to get going. Eight minutes, if you want to be all English and precise about it. But with his replacement, Archie Thompson, flying faster than nectar from a shaken tinnie, it wasn't long before American Samoa had the cactus. They were 16-0 down at the break, and when Archie scored his 13th goal - which incidentally smashed the all-time individual scoring record in an international - they were flailing like a mozzie that's felt the back of my Aussie Times.

But before thoughts turn to the crunch game against Samoa proper, let's spare a thought for the plucky American Samoan boys. OK, they may have been robbed of 19 of their 20-man senior squad after Fifa decided that Samoans without US passports were ineligible. And yes, it's true they couldn't even draft in their U-20 squad - as they were involved in end-of-term exams. And yes, you would have a point if you reminded me they were forced to play 15-year-olds, one appropriately named Baby Mulipola. But don't forget our victory was well deserved - and don't let the fact that our keeper only got his first touch in the 86th minute fool you otherwise.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ON GUARD

Poor old Barcelona. The minnows from that second-grade seaside resort have been having a tough time of it lately. Bored to sleep by Gerard Houllier's moving sandbags, miles off the lead in La Liga, set to lose Rivaldo for nowt when his contract expires, and condemned forever to speak some derivative of Spanish just to show how different they are, things were bad enough. But today events hit a new low when Barca were linked with signing David James. At the same time as their talismanic skipper announced he was slinging his hook.

"I'm going to see out my career abroad," Pep Guardiola told a news conference at the Nou Camp today. "It's not an easy decision to make but after weighing things up I think it's for the best." The 30-year-old playmaker, who joined the club when he was 13, is off "to get to know a new league, another culture, new friends and new rivals". Which is very open-minded of him, although the Fiver imagines that driving to and from your mansion in a beamer to buy Gucci belts translates quite well across the continent.

The venerable Robby Bobson has already gone on record to say that, if Pep was to leave Spain, Robby would "have no doubt that he would be prepared to come to Newcastle". Maybe for a nice day out at the Metro Centre, for example. He might also want to go to Birmingham of course, in order to help Barca prise James away from the Villa.

The top keeper was linked with a move to Catalonia by the papers this morning, but came out straight away to confirm that he had higher ambitions. "I am happy at Aston Villa," he said. "I have just signed a long contract and can see the club going places." Again, the Metro Centre springs to mind. "The fact I am learning Spanish is completely coincidental!" Indeed, indeed.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It would have been interesting to see what they'd have been like if Terry Venables hadn't taken over, as he's come in and steadied the ship and they're still struggling. So God knows where they would have been if he hadn't come in. They're still struggling to score goals and I'm scoring goals. So I think I've proved a point!" - Ipswich and former Middlesbrough striker Alun Armstrong is not smug really.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

AN OFF LICENCE

Uefa, the organisers of banquets, media parties and the occasional football match, today announced their intention to ban clubs from European competition unless they can prove they are financially stable and soundly managed. In a move which is in no way designed to stitch up clubs from the poorer nations in Europe - ta-ta to 1986 Big Cup winners Steaua Bucharest, 1991 champions Red Star Belgrade, and fair competition - Uefa have decided to force every club to comply with "Uefa guidelines" on infrastructure, legal issues, administration and finance by the start of the 2003-04 season. And if clubs make it, they get a permit to play. Thanks!

"Our aim is to raise standards to improve the fabric of the game in Europe," Uefa chief executive Gerhard Aigner explained whilst browsing through Liberty's latest catalogue (some designs in lovely paisley, others fashionable Burberry). "We are delighted to be working with the eight pilot associations to begin the introduction of our new club licensing system," he continued, as he scribbled over everything on his map of Europe (apart from England, Spain, Germany and Italy) with a sea-blue pen.

Exactly what these "guidelines" will be is anybody's guess, but seeing Scotland are one of the "eight pilot associations" involved in the planning, every club will probably be told to build a ground fit for the World Cup final or sod off. Of course, with other possible measures including capping a club's total salary expenditure and setting a maximum level of debt, it could be argued that it's only Real Madrid who have to watch themselves. In truth, however, the only thing we're really concerned about is all this stuff about being "soundly managed". That's done for a certain big club in the midlands for a start.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea, Arsenal and Roma are all trailing Racing Santander defender Olof Mellberg, reports Planet Football. But the website claims the Swede is shutting out the transfer speculation. "I don't know anything," he told them. "I don't want to comment on the rumours now and I have left everything in my representative's hands."

The Spanish press are claiming that Barcelona striker Patrick Kluivert has signed a pre-contract agreement to join Chelsea this summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Gillingham and Crystal Palace have been fined by the FA following a mass confrontation during their Boxing Day match at Priestfield Stadium. The Kent club have been fined £15,000, while Palace have been ordered to pay £5,000. At least 12 players were involved in a melee in first-half injury time after Gills goalkeeper Vince Bartram gave away a penalty.

Francis Jeffers has been ruled out for the rest of Everton's season following an exploratory operation last night on a shoulder injury. The 20-year-old striker sustained the injury in Sunday's 3-1 home win over Manchester City. He may now have kicked his last ball for the club, with Arsenal, Leeds and Manchester United reputed to be ready to make summer bids of at least £8m.

Tottenham Hotspur have not ruled out injured defender Sol Campbell returning to action before the end of the season. The England international, already suffering with ligament damage to his left ankle, damaged his right ankle in the 2-1 FA Cup semi-final defeat by Arsenal on Sunday.

Steven Gerrard is set to miss at least one of Liverpool's three matches in the next eight days in a schedule described by manager Gerard Houllier as "absurd". Houllier said: "I can't see him playing Friday [against Leeds], Monday [against Everton] and then against Barcelona."

England defender Chris Powell has called on Sir Alex Ferguson to change his mind and allow Steve McClaren to continue working with the national side. Powell knows McLaren well from their days together at Derby and he says the United assistant manager has been a big hit with the England squad. He said: "I know Alex Ferguson has said he's done his three-game contract and that's it, but I'm sure there's room for Steve."

Nearly half the England squad have a posh bank account. Coutts & Co, who are known as the provider of discreet overdrafts for high-spending royals and bankers to the landed aristocracy, have said 40% of the England squad had joined its special football unit and been assigned their own private bankers. The client list is confidential, but is reputed to include Dave and Vicky Beckham.

A Brazilian footballer who stripped down to skimpy underpants and threw his shorts into the crowd has been arrested for indecency. Goalscorer Willian Pereira Farias pranced around the pitch twirling his shorts above his head as a goal celebration. He was immediately red carded then arrested by police after his minor league side, Ponta Pora played local rivals Andradina. Pereira faces a police charge and was fined by his club.

Pereira's girlfriend at first locked him out of their house when he returned from the police station. "I thought I was going to have to sleep in the street. It wasn't easy to convince her to let me in," the player said. He is now considering an offer to pose for a gay magazine. "I've hardly earned anything from football, and my salary is a joke," he said. "I'm going to think carefully about the offer." His side went on to lose the match 3-2.

fields.bodyText: BRUCE IS BACK G'day Pommies! Bruce Fiver here, from the land where the Shelias bang like a dunny door in a storm. That's Australia for you drongos at the back. Now, on Monday we tonked the Tongans 22-0 to set a new record for an international victory. But were you cobbers impressed? Were you buggery! Today our boys did even better, whipping those whipping-boys of world football, American Samoa (ranked 203rd and last by Fifa) 31-0 to set a new and improved world record! With our star striker, Coventry reserve John Aloisi, having a little rest, it took us a while to get going. Eight minutes, if you want to be all English and precise about it. But with his replacement, Archie Thompson, flying faster than nectar from a shaken tinnie, it wasn't long before American Samoa had the cactus. They were 16-0 down at the break, and when Archie scored his 13th goal - which incidentally smashed the all-time individual scoring record in an international - they were flailing like a mozzie that's felt the back of my Aussie Times. But before thoughts turn to the crunch game against Samoa proper, let's spare a thought for the plucky American Samoan boys. OK, they may have been robbed of 19 of their 20-man senior squad after Fifa decided that Samoans without US passports were ineligible. And yes, it's true they couldn't even draft in their U-20 squad - as they were involved in end-of-term exams. And yes, you would have a point if you reminded me they were forced to play 15-year-olds, one appropriately named Baby Mulipola. But don't forget our victory was well deserved - and don't let the fact that our keeper only got his first touch in the 86th minute fool you otherwise. * * * * * * * * * * * * * ON GUARD Poor old Barcelona. The minnows from that second-grade seaside resort have been having a tough time of it lately. Bored to sleep by Gerard Houllier's moving sandbags, miles off the lead in La Liga, set to lose Rivaldo for nowt when his contract expires, and condemned forever to speak some derivative of Spanish just to show how different they are, things were bad enough. But today events hit a new low when Barca were linked with signing David James. At the same time as their talismanic skipper announced he was slinging his hook. "I'm going to see out my career abroad," Pep Guardiola told a news conference at the Nou Camp today. "It's not an easy decision to make but after weighing things up I think it's for the best." The 30-year-old playmaker, who joined the club when he was 13, is off "to get to know a new league, another culture, new friends and new rivals". Which is very open-minded of him, although the Fiver imagines that driving to and from your mansion in a beamer to buy Gucci belts translates quite well across the continent. The venerable Robby Bobson has already gone on record to say that, if Pep was to leave Spain, Robby would "have no doubt that he would be prepared to come to Newcastle". Maybe for a nice day out at the Metro Centre, for example. He might also want to go to Birmingham of course, in order to help Barca prise James away from the Villa. The top keeper was linked with a move to Catalonia by the papers this morning, but came out straight away to confirm that he had higher ambitions. "I am happy at Aston Villa," he said. "I have just signed a long contract and can see the club going places." Again, the Metro Centre springs to mind. "The fact I am learning Spanish is completely coincidental!" Indeed, indeed. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "It would have been interesting to see what they'd have been like if Terry Venables hadn't taken over, as he's come in and steadied the ship and they're still struggling. So God knows where they would have been if he hadn't come in. They're still struggling to score goals and I'm scoring goals. So I think I've proved a point!" - Ipswich and former Middlesbrough striker Alun Armstrong is not smug really. * * * * * * * * * * * * * AN OFF LICENCE Uefa, the organisers of banquets, media parties and the occasional football match, today announced their intention to ban clubs from European competition unless they can prove they are financially stable and soundly managed. In a move which is in no way designed to stitch up clubs from the poorer nations in Europe - ta-ta to 1986 Big Cup winners Steaua Bucharest, 1991 champions Red Star Belgrade, and fair competition - Uefa have decided to force every club to comply with "Uefa guidelines" on infrastructure, legal issues, administration and finance by the start of the 2003-04 season. And if clubs make it, they get a permit to play. Thanks! "Our aim is to raise standards to improve the fabric of the game in Europe," Uefa chief executive Gerhard Aigner explained whilst browsing through Liberty's latest catalogue (some designs in lovely paisley, others fashionable Burberry). "We are delighted to be working with the eight pilot associations to begin the introduction of our new club licensing system," he continued, as he scribbled over everything on his map of Europe (apart from England, Spain, Germany and Italy) with a sea-blue pen. Exactly what these "guidelines" will be is anybody's guess, but seeing Scotland are one of the "eight pilot associations" involved in the planning, every club will probably be told to build a ground fit for the World Cup final or sod off. Of course, with other possible measures including capping a club's total salary expenditure and setting a maximum level of debt, it could be argued that it's only Real Madrid who have to watch themselves. In truth, however, the only thing we're really concerned about is all this stuff about being "soundly managed". That's done for a certain big club in the midlands for a start. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Chelsea, Arsenal and Roma are all trailing Racing Santander defender Olof Mellberg, reports Planet Football. But the website claims the Swede is shutting out the transfer speculation. "I don't know anything," he told them. "I don't want to comment on the rumours now and I have left everything in my representative's hands." The Spanish press are claiming that Barcelona striker Patrick Kluivert has signed a pre-contract agreement to join Chelsea this summer. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Gillingham and Crystal Palace have been fined by the FA following a mass confrontation during their Boxing Day match at Priestfield Stadium. The Kent club have been fined £15,000, while Palace have been ordered to pay £5,000. At least 12 players were involved in a melee in first-half injury time after Gills goalkeeper Vince Bartram gave away a penalty. Francis Jeffers has been ruled out for the rest of Everton's season following an exploratory operation last night on a shoulder injury. The 20-year-old striker sustained the injury in Sunday's 3-1 home win over Manchester City. He may now have kicked his last ball for the club, with Arsenal, Leeds and Manchester United reputed to be ready to make summer bids of at least £8m. Tottenham Hotspur have not ruled out injured defender Sol Campbell returning to action before the end of the season. The England international, already suffering with ligament damage to his left ankle, damaged his right ankle in the 2-1 FA Cup semi-final defeat by Arsenal on Sunday. Steven Gerrard is set to miss at least one of Liverpool's three matches in the next eight days in a schedule described by manager Gerard Houllier as "absurd". Houllier said: "I can't see him playing Friday [against Leeds], Monday [against Everton] and then against Barcelona." England defender Chris Powell has called on Sir Alex Ferguson to change his mind and allow Steve McClaren to continue working with the national side. Powell knows McLaren well from their days together at Derby and he says the United assistant manager has been a big hit with the England squad. He said: "I know Alex Ferguson has said he's done his three-game contract and that's it, but I'm sure there's room for Steve." Nearly half the England squad have a posh bank account. Coutts & Co, who are known as the provider of discreet overdrafts for high-spending royals and bankers to the landed aristocracy, have said 40% of the England squad had joined its special football unit and been assigned their own private bankers. The client list is confidential, but is reputed to include Dave and Vicky Beckham. A Brazilian footballer who stripped down to skimpy underpants and threw his shorts into the crowd has been arrested for indecency. Goalscorer Willian Pereira Farias pranced around the pitch twirling his shorts above his head as a goal celebration. He was immediately red carded then arrested by police after his minor league side, Ponta Pora played local rivals Andradina. Pereira faces a police charge and was fined by his club. Pereira's girlfriend at first locked him out of their house when he returned from the police station. "I thought I was going to have to sleep in the street. It wasn't easy to convince her to let me in," the player said. He is now considering an offer to pose for a gay magazine. "I've hardly earned anything from football, and my salary is a joke," he said. "I'm going to think carefully about the offer." His side went on to lose the match 3-2. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: Carlton Sport (London town only, 11.30pm) Sky Sports 1: The Last Word (6.30pm) Live First Division Football - Blackburn v Fulham (7pm) You're on Sky Sports! fields.headline: Amazon takes over Borders.com
fields.trailText:
5pm: Amazon.com has sealed a deal with arch-rival Borders to absorb its e-commerce operation, reports Amy Vickers.
Apr 10: Amazon bounces back on better sales
fields.body:
Internet retailer Amazon.com has sealed a deal with arch-rival Borders to absorb its e-commerce operation and develop closer ties with the high street.

Amazon will take over Borders.com, which had hitherto tried to compete against Amazon in the online book-selling arena.

The deal means that Borders will opt out of the online book business and work to promote Amazon in its high-street stores across the world.

The tie-up could also lead to Amazon using Borders stores for returns and book reservation and pick-up services.

Likewise, the planned Amazon/Borders branded website will plug details of Borders in-store events.

The existing Borders.com, a distant third in the US online book market after No 2 Barnesandnoble.com, is to be shut down with the loss of 70 jobs.

Amazon founder and chief executive officer Jeff Bezos made the announcement this lunchtime at a press conference held in New York.

"Borders is best-of-breed in the physical world and a company that shares our passion for serving book, music and movie lovers everywhere," said Mr Bezos.

Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

The deal with Borders is not the first alliance Amazon has made with a high-street retailer.

Last year, it launched a similar joint venture with Toys R Us in which Amazon ran the website toysrus.com for a fee on each sale, and the toy store provided all the inventory.

Amazon is also said to be working on a number of other "real-world" tie-ups with the likes of Wall-Mart and US firm Best Buy.

The latest deal with Borders might go some way to restoring Amazon's credibility with investors, who have become increasingly worried about its mounting losses.

This was calmed somewhat on Monday when Amazon reported stronger than expected results.

webTitle: Analysis: Bush has painted himself into a corner

fields.headline: Bush has painted himself into a corner
fields.standfirst:
The spy plane row with China may be over but now the US must resolve the tricky issue of whether to press ahead with arms sales to Taiwan, writes Martin Woollacott

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The spy plane row with China may be over but now the US must resolve the tricky issue of whether to press ahead with arms sales to Taiwan, writes Martin Woollacott.Special report: George Bush's America
fields.body:
The Hainan incident has given the Bush administration a sharp lesson in the limits of military power, while the Chinese have enjoyed the rare experience of holding, if only for a few days, a better hand than the United States. Now that it is on the way to being resolved, the questions are whether the United States will heed its lesson and whether China will overplay its hand.

In bargaining to get its servicemen released, Washington has had to use words which come very close to the apology which the Chinese were demanding, to stay silent as Chinese ministers and officials called for an end to all US surveillance of their coast, and, it seems likely, to accept that the American aircraft, with all its secret equipment, may be kept for some considerable time.

But as soon as the air crew are safely back home, there will be a temptation to burst out with the hard words which the US administration has no doubt been suppressing with difficulty over the last 10 days of diplomatic wrangling. Worse, there could be pressure to take action against Chinese interests in both small and large ways, and, in particular, to show China who is boss by going ahead with the sale to Taiwan of warships equipped with advanced radar.

The spy plane incident, it can be argued, has greatly changed the context in which this difficult decision will have to be made. Even had there been no incident, such a sale would have rocked the relationship between the two countries, and it would now have an even more dramatic effect. Whatever the Americans think of the way in which the incident has been resolved, the Chinese probably now see themselves as having behaved with a restraint that ought to be rewarded by the United States making the "right" decision on arms sales to Taiwan.

The Bush administration, with its redefinition of China as a "strategic competitor" rather than the "strategic partner" of the Clinton years, has painted itself into a corner. The tough rhetoric of the campaign and of the early weeks in power, coupled with the effect of the incident, will make it hard for the administration to present a decision to withhold the arms as anything but an act of weakness.

But a decision to sell could plunge relations with China to a low point not seen for many years. Adding to the problems is the fact that the affair has been dealt with on the Chinese side by Vice-President Hu Jintao, who is expected to be Jian Zemin's successor in 2003, and thus in all probability China's leader after that for a long time to come. The Bush administration, with Colin Powell to the fore, has handled itself well during the last two weeks, but the real test of its judgment and skill is yet to come.

 Martin Woollacott is a Guardian columnist and foreign affairs specialist

webTitle: Aussie Rules as Socceroos smash world record again

fields.headline: Aussie Rules as Socceroos smash world record again
fields.standfirst: 31 goals, two world records broken, and the home keeper doesn't touch the ball until the 86th minute. It's got to be an Australian World Cup qualifier
fields.trailText: 31 goals, two world records broken, and the home keeper doesn't touch the ball until the 86th minute. It's got to be an Australian World Cup qualifier.
fields.body:
Australia, a nation famed more for its rugby prowess than football success, today smashed the world record for an international football victory for the second time in three days. They racked up a rugby score of 31-0 against the whipping boys of world football, American Samoa.

And striker Archie Thompson single-handedly overloaded the vidiprinter with a personal haul of 13 - unlucky for Samoans.

The Socceroos shattered the record they set on Monday when they tonked Tonga 22-0 with a result which confirmed American Samoa's place at the very bottom of Fifa's world rankings: 203rd place. But despite the omission of Australia's Premier League stars, Harry Kewell, Mark Viduka, Danny Tiatto and John Aloisi, America Samoa were not given a prayer.

They were robbed of 19 of their 20-man senior squad after a decision by Fifa to declare players from neighbouring Samoa ineligible.

They could not even draft in their U-20 squad for this week's Oceania World Cup qualifying series as they were involved in end-of-term exams.

So the youth team squad had to called in to make up the numbers. To make it worse, they arrived without boots and lost two players to injury in the 13-0 defeat by Fiji this week. They were forced to play 15-year-olds, one appropriately named Baby Mulipola.

The coach of the deeply religious American Samoans, Tunoa Lui, sought divine intervention before the game. "Frightened is not the word," he said. "We are going to ask for help from above. We are asking the Lord to help keep the score down."

They prayed, cried and sang hymns after losing 8-0 to arch-rivals Samoa earlier in the week. God only knows what the score would have been against Australia - a comparative soccer superpower with a ranking of 75 - without their prayerful pleas.

The heavens opened and the American Samoanas were left on their knees once more. Hapless American Samoan keeper Nicky Salapu - the only member of the original squad with the necessary US passport - has now had to pick the ball out of his net a back-breaking 52 times after just three World Cup qualifying games.

And after all the furore over the American Samoan passports, it will rankle that 13-goal striker Thompson is not even Australian. His father is a Kiwi, his mother Papua New Guinean.

Thompson, who filled his football boots with a quadruple hat-trick, had only scored once before for his country. And he only got his chance because Australia coach Frank Farina did not call up his Premiership players for this round of qualifiers.

He is an unlikely hero, having only made his Australian debut in February against Colombia. He came off the bench against Tonga on Sunday but was one of the few players not to score in that game. He more than made up for that lapse to break the previous world record of 10 strikes set by Sophus Neilsen of Denmark in 1908 and equalled by Gottfried Fuchs of Germany in 1912.

Thompson currently plies his trade for NSL side Marconi Stallions, who he joined in February from Carlton. At the age of 22, he may forever be a record holder if, as expected, Fifa take steps to ensure this kind of humiliation never takes place again. Fifa Director of Communications Keith Cooper said: "There doesn't seem to be much point in playing these kinds of matches. It doesn't do anyone any good."

Spare a thought for Thompson's team-mate David Zdrilic. His own eight-goal haul, which would have propelled him to overnight world attention under normal circumstances, will now be relegated to an incidental aside. Others who got on the scoresheets - for there must surely have been more than one - were Con Boutsianis (3), Aurelio Vidmar (2), Tony Popovic (2), Simon Colosimo (2) and Fausto DeAmicis.

Surprisingly enough, Australia took a full eight minutes to open the scoring but were then 16-0 up by half-time, breaking the world record with their 23rd goal after 65 minutes.

Incidentally, the Australian keeper Michael Petkovic had his first touch of the ball after 86 minutes - when American Samoa put together their first attack of the match.

fields.headline: FT uncovers topless advertising stunt
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: The FT has scuppered an advertiser's plan to put a topless model in tomorrow's paper, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Financial Times has scuppered plans for a Page Three girl to appear in tomorrow's paper after it discovered an advertiser was planning to slip a picture of a topless woman into a full-page advert.

The paper has banned the advert promoting the Bank, a marketing consultancy whose clients include British Airways and Orange.

The consultancy booked page three of tomorrow's FT for the advert, which features a topless woman next to the words: "The art of selling in a bare market".

The company planned to get extra publicity out of the move by filming City workers' reaction to the advert.

Stuart Bradbury, business development manager of the Bank, described the advert as "tasteful" and criticised the paper for setting itself up as a moral arbiter.

"We deliberately chose the FT to showcase our ad in order to demonstrate that our thinking incorporates placing the usual in the unusual," he claimed.

"Placing a Page Three girl in the FT - albeit tastefully - illustrates this perfectly," he said.

An FT spokeswoman confirmed the paper had banned the advert but refused to comment further.
