fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: American Express now markets credit cards to US teenagers as young as 13. Would this be welcome here?
fields.trailText: The question: American Express now markets credit cards to US teenagers as young as 13. Would this be welcome here?
fields.body:
Madeleine Pym
Spokeswoman for the British Humanist Association

I can see there is a case for teaching children how to use credit cards responsibly. But there are disadvantages. The idea of allowing companies access to your child before they are old enough to make a reasoned choice is as undesirable as allowing your child to get hooked on any other form of instant gratification with long-term consequences. Good for the banks though: as tobacco companies discovered many years ago, trying to get people to switch brands once started is nigh on impossible. No wonder they want to get them young.
Verdict: No

Jonathan Bell
Independent financial adviser

This has to be just another way for credit card companies to make money, and there can be risks to young people in having these cards. My son is 18, and I know there have been gangs hanging around outside his school waiting to march students off to cash machines to withdraw cash for them. While having a credit card might get them used to managing money, my general feeling about the whole thing is a negative one. So many people I know fall into negative balances and debt problems because of credit cards.
Verdict: No

Nick Bell
Editor of online teenage magazine teenfront.com

These new teen credit cards sound similar to the Splash plastic scheme that allows teenagers to buy online with cards purchased at a newsagent's. I think these cards sound like a good idea: I'm always in favour of teenagers managing their own finances. Teenagers are not naive. They are very streetwise and grow up much faster these days; it's important that they should have more freedom and be able to take control of their lives. This kind of experience will set them up for managing money when they are older.
Verdict: Yes

Colin Hammond
Chief executive of No Panic

Our organisation helps people deal with stress and anxiety, which is often caused by getting into debt. Although parents can check up on their children's spending with these cards, what worries me is that they wouldn't know what their children had spent until after the things had been bought. We've seen how fast some children can run up huge bills with mobile phones, and parents need to be responsible to ensure that their children don't end up in too much debt. Giving youngsters credit cards will get them hooked on credit. Verdict: No

Sue Edwards
National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux

We have had some major concerns about credit marketing in the UK. This kind of move doesn't encourage people to save, and there has been a very worrying decrease in the ratio of spending to saving in the last year or so. This country has a very low rate of consumer financial literacy. We are being presented with ever more sophisticated financial products but have not been given the training to use them. The government has introduced financial literacy into the national curriculum, but we are concerned because all the pressure is to spend and not to save.
Verdict: No

Desirée Fish
Director of Public Affairs, American Express

It is important for teenagers to learn to be financially responsible as they become more independent. The Cobaltcard, which is a product offered in the US to the young adult market, is not a credit card but a "stored value card". The card is free of debt because the young adult can only spend the amount that was electronically loaded onto the card. Parents are able to ensure that their teenager is using the card responsibly through an online viewing option and, importantly, can play a more active role in supervising their child's spending than they would with cash pocket money.
Verdict: Yes

fields.headline: On the right wavelength?
fields.standfirst:
Maggie Brown and son tune in to Radio 4's new children's programme

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Maggie Brown and son tune in to Radio 4's new children's programme.
fields.body:
Knock, knock. Who's there? Cargo. Cargo who? Car go beep beep. On Sunday, Radio 4 launches a new weekly programme for children, called Go4It! - with classic bad jokes (as above) contributed by pupils at a Sevenoaks primary school setting a jolly tone. Regular Radio 4 parents on the afternoon school run have been warmed up for the event with cheery plugs and requests for their children to send in ideas.

Once the BBC announced in a u-turn last August that it would reinstate a trial speech radio slot for children, it's been full steam ahead. Boxing Day's continuous reading of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone reinforced the "open to kids" message.

But what will Go4It! sound like? And, after all these years of nothing for kids, will children tune in even if parents instruct them to? I listened to a preview with my son John, aged eight, who fits into the programme's target age group, of eight to 10 year olds - the Blue Peter band. Left to his own devices, he is a dedicated viewer of Robot Wars.

But he loves "Knock, knock" jokes, so the opening was spot on. I thought it only right to have him as a reality check in case sentiment misted up my judgment. Many BBC staff besides regard it as tragic that, for the past decade, radio managers stubbornly denied they had a public service duty to provide speech radio for children after a major experiment on Radio 5 ended in 1994.

Children's Hour was right there at the birth of the BBC in 1922 to provide "clean, wholesome humour". My childhood favourite, aptly named Children's Favourites, which was a request show with tunes like The Runaway Train, ended in 1967. Listen with Mother was axed in 1982 when small children were deemed lost to television. It's been a case of let them have story tapes ... until they grow into Radio 1 or a commercial pop station. As Olivia Seligman, executive producer of Go4It!, says: "My two eldest children have grown up without any radio heritage, just Kiss FM. So there is nothing to build on."

The key difference between Listen with Mother and Go4It! is that children's voices predominate. Children are brought in to quiz Hear'Say - "Who were your favourite pop stars when you were growing up?" - the feature on Sunday's show. Three children also question another celebrity guest, Sir Steve Redgrave, five-times Olympic gold medallist.

My son lost interest at this point, because, like most children, he has little knowledge of rowing, and Redgrave is an adult star. Audley Harrison might have been a better choice. Seligman is aiming for top footballers for future interviews.

But John perked up for another regular fixture, a film review called "Take your granny to the cinema", in which a boy called Sam and his granny gave their views of Spy Kids, a new film.

But again, a false note was struck: granny says to grandson as they settle down to discuss the film, " Here's your orange juice and I'll have a nice cup of tea." All the eight year olds I know would be panting for a Coke! And John laughed at Sam's conclusion: "Boys will especially like this film because it had gadgets and weapons."

John was more fired up by the competition, though, in which you were asked to guess who was a boy king, buried in a very big tomb, with the sound of hacking and tunnelling going on. Older children will get it in five seconds, but my son didn't and actually allowed me to help him look up Tutankhamen afterwards.

Where the programme really lost him was the story, called Clockwork: All Wound Up. This was an elaborate story within a story, which went straight over his head. Is this a sign that youngish children have lost the power to concentrate on well-crafted fiction, or was the programme being over-ambitious?

It was I, next, who was irritated by a brief announcement that the programme has a book club: presenter Matt Smith just swallowed up the title and the author, and gave no explanation of what regular listeners might expect in future.

Radio 4 is not a children's network; it belongs to parents and grandparents. Will eight year olds remember to switch on? It's also odd that there is no overlap with Blue Peter, the most successful children's magazine of all time. Its producers should lend a helping hand.

Overall, then, Go4It! was a mild success, a curiosity. The tone is not quite right, it isn't lively or naughty enough, you sense adults hovering over it. John picked up the Beano and started reading instead of listening."It's all right," he said afterwards. "Can I put on my WWF [wrestling] tape now?"

 Go4It! starts on Easter Sunday at 7.15pm.

webTitle: Should you lie to get into church school?

fields.headline: More tea, vicar?
fields.standfirst:
If the best school in your area is a church school - and you're an unbeliever - is it OK to pretend to be religious? Joanna Briscoe examines her conscience

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: If the best school in your area is a church school - and you're an unbeliever - is it OK to pretend to be religious? Joanna Briscoe examines her conscience.
fields.body:
As Tony Blair faces the palms-and-concrete holiday camp that is Torbay to appease disgruntled teachers' unions, my own vague educational plans become ever more confused. As the mother of a 14-month-old, I am being cautioned to lubricate my way to a decent school place without further delay. Industrial action and other hiccoughs aside, it is never too early to marry house-moving plans with league tables, or to undergo a religious epiphany. In fact, since the lad is already one, we may have missed the boat.

To my immense surprise, as I peep tentatively over the post-partum barricades at the real world, I am bombarded with dire warnings. It is, apparently, a jungle out there. A jostling, tussling, spitting cat fight featuring middle-class corruption and outrage over establishments with such names as "Beacon schools". An arcane and puzzling system of priestly favours and catchment-area gerrymandering. According to research published last week, we'll need to find at least an extra 20 grand to move to an area with a decent state school - and that'd be if we went to live in Coventry. Be it the building society or the church restoration fund, we're going to be in hock, it seems.

The first indication of my new life came when an acquaintance started pretending her daughter was Catholic: she targeted a primary school for four years hence, and had the infant Baptised. I thought she was simply eccentric. Recently, however, perfectly sensible friends of a casually atheist bent have come over all happy-clappy. Yes, they tell me, to stand any chance of a primary school place half-way free of illiteracy and syringes, one must target some shiny centre of excellence, drag one's toddler to the adjacent church's Sunday school for three years, and assiduously drum one's presence into the vicar's consciousness.

My God.

Surely, surely there are other ways. Can't one just cheat, for instance? Be hit by a clap of religious conversion some time shortly before September 2004? Invite a headmistress round to dinner? Feebly brandish a press card? Shag a vicar? No. Apparently not. These churches have registers. Blair is investing more money in church schools. Other normal-to-neurotic types are prepared to buy overpriced flatlets with playground views in order to get their offspring into St Something's, the league table conqueror.

I simply cannot do it. It would fill me with repulsion, horror, and, indeed, Catholic-style guilt. That the church - an institution I've rarely thought about since sobbing over The Nun's Story at the age of eight - towers thus over our secular age, affiliated with so many good schools, fills me with startled bewilderment. According to friends with four-year-olds, we have to move to the leafy, middle-class London suburb of Muswell Hill next month, measure the inches to the school with a ruler, leap on to a parish register, and, quite possibly, take a Discover Christianity course.

So, the paths fork here: it's Muswell Hill or backpacking to Kathmandu and an innumerate hippie upbringing. You make a choice now about the next five years. In fact, about your whole life. It feels repulsively grown-up, as though a Baby on Board sticker and all those grim parenty tokens one so doggedly avoids are an inevitability. And yet, perhaps there really is no choice. That rather lively academy of head-butting and dyslexia round the corner may ultimately propel one, recanting, into the church.

I feel as though I have entered a feudal system, a previously misunderstood fandango of fetlocks, boons and tithes. The staggering hypocrisy, so readily accepted, the rules and regulations, so meekly submitted to, seem reminiscent of earlier and more worrying eras. In a supposedly multi-cultural, inclusive society, what are parents of mixed religious backgrounds, or those who simply can't be arsed, supposed to do? Why should quality of education depend on how effectively parents can feign devotion? Is the church so desperate for bums on pews, even fraudulent bums will do?

The alternative, of course, is to invest the last vestiges of savings reserved for the Eurostar and dining out at Yo! Sushi in some poncy little prep school, all boaters and under-aged oboe lessons, then call in the Eton prospectus. I'd rather take to the Nepalese foothills and be left with an idiot savant.

My main problem now is that when I panic upon celebrating my son's second birthday and sign up for my Discover Christianity course, I, unlike my freshly-minted Catholic and Anglican friends, will be rumbled. At that trembling second before I become a Bride of Christ, someone might, Victorian novel-style, step forward and produce, instead of a bigamous marriage licence or a record of hotrodding, this very column. Clearly, then, I am damned.

Um, do they sell Bibles at Waterstones?

webTitle: Fern Lloyd on her graffiti-spraying son

fields.headline: Fun lovin' criminals
fields.standfirst: As Farrah Fawcett escorts her dope-smoking son Redmond to court in California,  Fern Lloyd offers her sympathies. She has just been dragged into a world of lawyers and social workers by her graffiti-spraying teenager
fields.trailText: As Farrah Fawcett escorts her dope-smoking son Redmond to court in California, Fern Lloyd offers her sympathies. She has just been dragged into a world of lawyers and social workers by her graffiti-spraying teenager.
fields.body:
I've never had big hair, or even been blonde. And I've never tried karate-kicking in flares, let alone brandishing a pistol while wearing a bikini. But I know exactly how Farrah Fawcett feels when she accompanies her 16-year-old son Redmond to court in Santa Monica, California, where he has to sign in every week following a conviction for using cannabis. I know because my son, too, has recently been in trouble with the law.

Here's the scenario: it is a Saturday morning, at 6am. The doorbell rings, followed by loud knocking. Denial turns into acceptance - I realise, with a sinking heart, that it's not the postman. I stumble downstairs and yes, it's the police. Our 17-year-old son Joe has been arrested, for the second time, for graffiti - criminal damage in the eyes of the law. He's still in the cell, they're just checking out his bail address.

We veer between fury at him and desperate worry over what's going to happen next. Now that the old system of cautioning juveniles has been phased out because of its lack of deterrent effect - kids used to get six, seven or even more cautions, often for the same offence - ending up in court and getting a criminal record, even a custodial sentence, is frighteningly easy. These days, you get a reprimand for a first offence and a final warning, if you're lucky, for a second or more serious one. After that, it's see you in court, sonny Jim. And magistrates can no longer give conditional discharges. The government's plans to build at least five new young offenders' units suddenly seem horribly relevant.

At about 8am, my husband, Don, rings the police station. Joe hasn't even been interviewed yet. He's been there since 1am, having been caught in the act of spray-painting some shop hoardings, but was too drunk to give a statement. Because he's 17, they treat him as an adult - parents don't have to be present. He's also been charged with possession of a small quantity of cannabis. At least it wasn't the much more heinous "with intent to supply", I say, adopting my "always look on the bright side of life" pose in opposition to Don's despair mode. These crises always result in us taking out our rage and sadness on each other.

A few hours later, statement made, we learn from the sergeant, who is very polite and helpful, that Joe has been released on bail, to return three days later to learn his fate. In the meantime, the police will talk to the shopkeepers. We express our willingness to repair or pay for the damage. Surely that would be the most useful option, and might teach Joe a lesson. Though you'd think a night in the cells might have done that, too.

But when Joe comes home he's in an angry mood: police are idiots and he's a sort of hero/victim because he was the only one that got caught or searched. He didn't grass on his mates, though they were all spraying too. As for the cannabis, it was such a small amount he doesn't consider it worth discussing.

As he cooks himself a fry-up, he explains, after reasonably gentle cross-questioning from me, that boozing followed by graffiti is done in response to boredom. I try to refrain from telling him that he doesn't know what boredom means. Loads of friends, TV, PlayStation, clubbing, music, exciting Saturday job - at his age I would have killed for a life like that. Instead I concentrate on practicalities - how a criminal record would affect his future. Travel plans and job applications, for example.

I don't know if any of it sinks in. He retires to bed; we go for a long walk and agree that grounding him wouldn't work. We don't know what will. Of course, these aren't terrible crimes, but his attitude is so negative. Is it all our fault for being too laid-back? Not laid-back enough? Who knows where, or if, we went wrong.

A few days later, we're at the police station bright and early, prepared for the worst. The day before, I tried to extract information from a PC who told me a charge was more or less inevitable because Joe had been done before for the same offence. And this time, there's the drug possession as well.

A solicitor meets us there, and we're relieved we decided, after a lot of agonising about whether it might count against us in some way, to make use of this free service. She takes Joe round a corner and coaches him on how to comport himself to best advantage. I catch the words "appear fully remorseful". She and the desk sergeant remark at the amazing sight of one, let alone two parents.

"Most parents just don't want to know," says the solicitor.

Incredibly, after an interview with the inspector - what a lovely man - Joe gets a final warning with compulsory attendance at a youth offending team. They seem to have overlooked the cannabis possession. We try to contain our joy until we're out of the door. Joe goes to school, Don and I go for a coffee. "Do you think he understands how lucky he's been?" asks Don. I think the solicitor may have helped him take in that this really is his last chance. Next time - oh God, please let there not be one - without a doubt, he'd go to court.

But it's not over yet. A week later, after school, Joe and I are with the youth offending team.

"So you're an artist?" says Chris, the youth worker, affably. "Do you just tag or do you spray as well?" Obviously, he understands and is part of this world that Joe desires. If he'll listen to anyone, it's this guy. They talk about the recent tragedy in Camden, when a 16-year old stabbed an 18-year old to death over a dispute about lining out tags (crossing out graffiti signatures that mark territory).

Chris asks if Joe offered to clean his own art work off and tuts in disappointment when he hears that no one followed this up. He feels that, if only "artists" like Joe were given the chance to make amends, graffiti need not reach the criminal justice system. But he's realistic. "If you go on doing it, you will end up with a sentence," he says. He also mentions Jack Straw's enthusiam for locking up young offenders.

As for the cannabis, he reminds Joe that tobacco in joints damages your lungs more than cigarettes, because of the lack of filters.

"Now I'm not going to tell you to eat it," he elaborates, "because the trouble with that is you've no way of controlling how mashed you're going to get, as you can with a joint. Most people, like myself, have enough of it after a while and grow out of it."

He treats Joe with respect, as an equal, a man of the streets. "You seem very together," he tells him. I'm not sure whether to laugh or cry. "You obviously know what you're doing."

And although he doesn't feel the final warning programme on offer at the unit would be suitable for Joe - he'd be older than the other kids and it would bore him - he's very welcome to drop in at any time, or to paint the outside of the unit with some of his friends. I wonder if he will. Maybe this scheme is one part of the government's crackdown on crime that really might work.

I make a note of Chris's direct line, and feel a glimmer of hope. I wonder if Farrah has that.

 Some names have been changed.
fields.bodyText: I've never had big hair, or even been blonde. And I've never tried karate-kicking in flares, let alone brandishing a pistol while wearing a bikini. But I know exactly how Farrah Fawcett feels when she accompanies her 16-year-old son Redmond to court in Santa Monica, California, where he has to sign in every week following a conviction for using cannabis. I know because my son, too, has recently been in trouble with the law. Here's the scenario: it is a Saturday morning, at 6am. The doorbell rings, followed by loud knocking. Denial turns into acceptance - I realise, with a sinking heart, that it's not the postman. I stumble downstairs and yes, it's the police. Our 17-year-old son Joe has been arrested, for the second time, for graffiti - criminal damage in the eyes of the law. He's still in the cell, they're just checking out his bail address. We veer between fury at him and desperate worry over what's going to happen next. Now that the old system of cautioning juveniles has been phased out because of its lack of deterrent effect - kids used to get six, seven or even more cautions, often for the same offence - ending up in court and getting a criminal record, even a custodial sentence, is frighteningly easy. These days, you get a reprimand for a first offence and a final warning, if you're lucky, for a second or more serious one. After that, it's see you in court, sonny Jim. And magistrates can no longer give conditional discharges. The government's plans to build at least five new young offenders' units suddenly seem horribly relevant. At about 8am, my husband, Don, rings the police station. Joe hasn't even been interviewed yet. He's been there since 1am, having been caught in the act of spray-painting some shop hoardings, but was too drunk to give a statement. Because he's 17, they treat him as an adult - parents don't have to be present. He's also been charged with possession of a small quantity of cannabis. At least it wasn't the much more heinous "with intent to supply", I say, adopting my "always look on the bright side of life" pose in opposition to Don's despair mode. These crises always result in us taking out our rage and sadness on each other. A few hours later, statement made, we learn from the sergeant, who is very polite and helpful, that Joe has been released on bail, to return three days later to learn his fate. In the meantime, the police will talk to the shopkeepers. We express our willingness to repair or pay for the damage. Surely that would be the most useful option, and might teach Joe a lesson. Though you'd think a night in the cells might have done that, too. But when Joe comes home he's in an angry mood: police are idiots and he's a sort of hero/victim because he was the only one that got caught or searched. He didn't grass on his mates, though they were all spraying too. As for the cannabis, it was such a small amount he doesn't consider it worth discussing. As he cooks himself a fry-up, he explains, after reasonably gentle cross-questioning from me, that boozing followed by graffiti is done in response to boredom. I try to refrain from telling him that he doesn't know what boredom means. Loads of friends, TV, PlayStation, clubbing, music, exciting Saturday job - at his age I would have killed for a life like that. Instead I concentrate on practicalities - how a criminal record would affect his future. Travel plans and job applications, for example. I don't know if any of it sinks in. He retires to bed; we go for a long walk and agree that grounding him wouldn't work. We don't know what will. Of course, these aren't terrible crimes, but his attitude is so negative. Is it all our fault for being too laid-back? Not laid-back enough? Who knows where, or if, we went wrong. A few days later, we're at the police station bright and early, prepared for the worst. The day before, I tried to extract information from a PC who told me a charge was more or less inevitable because Joe had been done before for the same offence. And this time, there's the drug possession as well. A solicitor meets us there, and we're relieved we decided, after a lot of agonising about whether it might count against us in some way, to make use of this free service. She takes Joe round a corner and coaches him on how to comport himself to best advantage. I catch the words "appear fully remorseful". She and the desk sergeant remark at the amazing sight of one, let alone two parents. "Most parents just don't want to know," says the solicitor. Incredibly, after an interview with the inspector - what a lovely man - Joe gets a final warning with compulsory attendance at a youth offending team. They seem to have overlooked the cannabis possession. We try to contain our joy until we're out of the door. Joe goes to school, Don and I go for a coffee. "Do you think he understands how lucky he's been?" asks Don. I think the solicitor may have helped him take in that this really is his last chance. Next time - oh God, please let there not be one - without a doubt, he'd go to court. But it's not over yet. A week later, after school, Joe and I are with the youth offending team. "So you're an artist?" says Chris, the youth worker, affably. "Do you just tag or do you spray as well?" Obviously, he understands and is part of this world that Joe desires. If he'll listen to anyone, it's this guy. They talk about the recent tragedy in Camden, when a 16-year old stabbed an 18-year old to death over a dispute about lining out tags (crossing out graffiti signatures that mark territory). Chris asks if Joe offered to clean his own art work off and tuts in disappointment when he hears that no one followed this up. He feels that, if only "artists" like Joe were given the chance to make amends, graffiti need not reach the criminal justice system. But he's realistic. "If you go on doing it, you will end up with a sentence," he says. He also mentions Jack Straw's enthusiam for locking up young offenders. As for the cannabis, he reminds Joe that tobacco in joints damages your lungs more than cigarettes, because of the lack of filters. "Now I'm not going to tell you to eat it," he elaborates, "because the trouble with that is you've no way of controlling how mashed you're going to get, as you can with a joint. Most people, like myself, have enough of it after a while and grow out of it." He treats Joe with respect, as an equal, a man of the streets. "You seem very together," he tells him. I'm not sure whether to laugh or cry. "You obviously know what you're doing." And although he doesn't feel the final warning programme on offer at the unit would be suitable for Joe - he'd be older than the other kids and it would bore him - he's very welcome to drop in at any time, or to paint the outside of the unit with some of his friends. I wonder if he will. Maybe this scheme is one part of the government's crackdown on crime that really might work. I make a note of Chris's direct line, and feel a glimmer of hope. I wonder if Farrah has that.  Some names have been changed.

fields.headline: 'Remember your condoms, mum'
fields.standfirst: Watching your middle-aged mother enter the dating game can be unnerving, as  Susannah Conway  discovered
fields.trailText: Watching your middle-aged mother enter the dating game can be unnerving, as Susannah Conway discovered.
fields.body:
Parents watch their teenage children rush head-long out into the world of dating, spying from a distance as they grapple with the highs and lows of their first romance: holding sweaty hands in the back row of the cinema; a tooth-shattering kiss outside McDonald's. But how is one to feel when that teenage love-explorer is actually your own 50-something mother?

My mother had remained single since her divorce in 1985, feeling unable to start another relationship when so busy with two children and a full-time job. But four years ago she finally plunged into the dating whirlpool and started a romantic affair; after so many years alone, my sister and I secretly hoped that maybe she would meet The One.

With just the three of us together, our upbringing had been cosy, the closeness of our family unit not fading as we moved away from home. Yet as her relationship developed - slowly and tentatively at a pace she could handle - it became apparent that within this new phase of her life there was also a shift occurring within our relationship. Our weekly phone chats were metamorphosing into nightly calls to dissect the minutiae of her boyfriend's every move.

I started to question whether I was still the daughter in this equation as I rapidly became her confidante and personal Relate counsellor. It hit me one night after an hour long session of reassuring advice down the line: I was now the mother figure and she was my teenage daughter, rediscovering the world.

She was plagued with the usual love angst - will he call? Does he really like me? I know I'm doing something wrong - and I sympathised because I had been there myself. "Testing the water in the first couple of relationships since my divorce was disastrous," she told me recently. "But they were the beginning of a whole new chapter that had been denied me as a young woman thanks to my strict Victorian-style upbringing." With our roles reversed, I became the experienced "parent" able to offer wise counsel which, unlike a legitimate teenager, she was willing to take onboard.

This change in roles is not restricted to mother-daughter relationships as Stephen O'Connell, 26, knows only too well. He counselled his mother continuously after his parents divorced when he was 19: "The parent-child cross-over between my mother and I manifested with her not being aware of what to do in relationships. She's had to learn about being responsible with other people's emotions and not doing the teenage thing of leaving when she gets bored."

O'Connell found he needed to advise his mother about the basics in the dating game. "I had to say, 'you are using condoms aren't you?' because she was running around being this wild thing and I wanted to make sure she was safe."

As children, we become so accustomed to being the most important person in our mother's life that if that equilibrium changes we can be left feeling abandoned. While her mother, Caroline, was enjoying her new-found freedom after her divorce in 1986, Madeleine Greenhill, now 27, resented the changes to their relationship. She felt her mother was only interested in discussing her own relationships problems, forcing Greenhill into the role of unwilling advisor and sounding-board.

"Even when I had my own daughter in my early 20s there wasn't a granny around for her. Instead there was this 'teenager' in our lives who wasn't interested in becoming a grandmother yet." With time, the role changes returned back to their familiar, if somewhat altered, groove. "My mother eventually settled down with her partner and five years on she's happily established in her grandmother role," says Greenhill.

Dr Gill Dunne, senior research fellow in Sociology at the LSE, believes that these newly defined relationships reflect the gulf in generational experience between mother and child and reflect the breakdown in hierarchy between them. "Within this new relationship one has to examine our own expectations and question how realistic they are in terms of what we want and expect from our mothers. It now requires negotiating a relationship between two people."

Women of my mother's generation married for life just as their own parents had done. Living through two decades of social change, however, gave them the confidence to leave an unhappy marriage.

After a few trial runs, my mother met her now long-term partner, and she found herself having to relearn the relationship rules, frequently turning to me for insider information. When our swapped roles coincided with a particularly trying time in my own life, I'd lament not having a mother's ear to bend over the phone.

But as she relinquished her immediate mothering duties, I learned to acknowledge that she was a woman first, and then my mother. A month ago, as she drove me to the train station after a weekend visit - and an afternoon's heart-to-heart - my mother said softly, "you know, you're more like a big sister to me, but I'm the one who's supposed to be the mother." And, thankfully, she still is. But for a short time I'd had to look after her as she had once done for me and a door has now opened between us that will always be kept ajar.

fields.headline: Tanks attack Palestinian refugee site
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli tanks today bulldozed a refugee camp in Palestinian territory, wrecking 30 homes and triggering an exchange of fire that killed two Palestinians.
fields.body:
Israeli tanks today bulldozed a refugee camp in Palestinian territory, wrecking 30 homes and triggering an exchange of fire that killed two Palestinians.

The assault was retaliation for a mortar attack on Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. It was the first time that Israeli troops had entered Palestinian controlled territory since the outbreak of fighting.

Residents of the Khan Yunis refugee camp said the attack began when tanks, armoured personnel carriers and bulldozers advanced as helicopters hovered above.

Shells were fired at the camp, drawing return fire. The army said Palestinians also fired more mortars at nearby Jewish settlements.

"We started running from our homes ... while they were firing toward us and bulldozers started destroying our homes without giving us a warning," said Imad Abu Namous, a father of seven who lost his home in the assault.

By daybreak, hundreds of camp residents were sifting through the rubble. One man tried to retrieve a ceiling fan still linked by an electric wire to the remains of the ceiling.

A policeman and a civilian died from shrapnel injuries and 27 people were wounded.

Palestinian officials complained that Israel had re-entered areas under full Palestinian control. Israel troops withdrew from two thirds of Gaza in 1994, as part of interim peace agreements.

However, the Israeli defence minister, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, said his country had no interest in reoccupying Palestinian territory.

He said troops attacked an area from which mortar shells were repeatedly fired at Jewish settlements.

"The order was to go in and destroy the same posts from which our communities were shelled. These are points we don't want the Palestinians to return to," he told Israeli radio.

Tel Aviv says the Palestinians have fired more than 50 mortar shells at Jewish settlements in recent days.

Nabil Aburdeneh, a senior adviser to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, denied that mortar shells were fired from the razed homes. He called for immediate US intervention.

"The situation has now crossed a red line," he said.

fields.headline: 'Our prayers are with the pilot's family'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America

Text of President George Bush's statement today on the agreement with China over release of the US spy plane's crew
fields.trailText: Text of President George Bush's statement today on the agreement with China over release of the US spyplane's crew
fields.body:
Good morning.

I'm pleased to be able to tell the American people that plans are under way to bring home our 24 American servicemen and women from Hainan island.

This morning the Chinese government assured our American ambassador that the crew would leave promptly. We're working on arrangements to pick them up and to bring them home.

This has been a difficult situation for both our countries. I know the American people join me in expressing sorrow for the loss of life of a Chinese pilot. Our prayers are with his wife and his child.

I appreciate the hard work of our ambassador to China, Joseph Prueher, and his entire embassy team who worked tirelessly to solve this situation.

The American people, their families and I are proud of our crew and we look forward to welcoming them home. Thank you.

fields.headline: The real Captain Corelli
fields.standfirst: The retired Italian car enthusiast who provided part of the basis for Louis De Berni&#232res' music-loving second world war officer has been reminiscing to the press about his ordeal on Cephalonia, says Philip Willan
fields.trailText: The retired Italian car enthusiast who provided part of the basis for Louis De Bernires' music-loving second world war officer has been reminiscing to the press about his ordeal on Cephalonia, says Philip Willan in Rome.
fields.body:
In recent days the world's press has begun beating a path to the Florentine home of a retired director of the Italian automobile club. The reason for their interest lies in the wartime adventures that made him a model for Louis de Bernières' character of the music-loving Italian artillery officer Captain Antonio Corelli.

With the film of Captain Corelli's Mandolin - starring Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz - about to be released in Britain on May 4, events that have been obscured for almost 60 years have been thrust back to centre stage.

The "real" Captain Corelli is now aged 90 and enjoying his moment in the limelight. Lucid and courteous, Amos Pampaloni vividly recalls the days in September 1943, when he participated in the tragic revolt of Italian soldiers against their former German allies on the Greek island of Cephalonia.

Some 9,500 Italians, of a garrison of 11,000, lost their lives in the fighting that followed Italy's withdrawal from the war on September 8. Five thousand of them are believed to have been executed by the German army after surrendering.

Mr Pampaloni speaks in a husky whisper, the result of a recent operation for throat cancer rather than of his own failed execution. But he still bears the marks on his neck where a German officer shot him from close range with a pistol.

His memories of the fighting can now be compared with the accounts of two German Alpine soldiers, whose war diaries came to light in Germany last month, as well as with the film version and de Bernieres' novel.

Alfred Richter, a corporal in the inaptly named Edelweiss division, describes the wholesale execution of Italian prisoners. In the town of Frangata he witnessed the extermination of two companies of Italian soldiers, hearing bursts of machine gun fire that continue uninterrupted for two hours: "Everyone is shot, without regard for rank or role, even the medics and the chaplains."

In a scene that might have been invented by De Bernières, Richter tells of an Italian soldier who saves his life by breaking into song. "A prisoner cuts a tragicomic figure by getting onto an improvised podium before us and singing opera arias with a beautiful voice and the appropriate gestures, saving his life, while his compatriots are being shot," he wrote.

The man went on to work as a cook for the Germans. In an entry dated September 23 1943, Corporal Richter registers the execution of Italian soldiers in Argostoli harbour, in full sight of Greek civilians and with the bodies left to rot in the autumn heat. "In one of the small streets the smell is so bad that I can't even take a picture," he reports.

Two days earlier, the corporal was fighting at Dilinata, the village where Captain Pampaloni's 80 gunners were slaughtered. Outnumbered and suffering under accurate mortar fire, Pampaloni decided to surrender. The captain protested that it was against the rules of war when his men were systematically robbed of their wallets and watches, only to be told by the German commanding officer that those rules applied to prisoners, not to traitors.

The officer then shot the captain through the back of the neck, and the rest of his men, including the wounded, were mown down with machine gun fire. Miraculously still alive, Pampaloni remained conscious as a German soldier removed his own watch from his apparently lifeless body.

Captain Pampaloni was not, in fact, the only soldier from his company to survive. "The mule handlers were spared, because every mule responds best to his own master," he said. "Ten minutes after the massacre the German soldiers left, singing."

Captain Pampaloni went on to fight for a year with the Greek resistance on the mainland. Having witnessed the brutality of the conflict on Cephalonia, he was still shocked by the sight of partisans slitting the throats of German prisoners with their daggers - ammunition was too precious to be wasted on executions.

The decision of the Italian troops on Cephalonia to refuse to hand over their weapons to the Germans after their government signed an armistice with the allies is sometimes cited as the first act of the Italian resistance.

It was taken after an extraordinary democratic consultation among the soldiers, rather than being imposed from on high, and ended in a tragic sacrifice of human lives. It has been virtually eliminated from Italian remembrance, swallowed up by cold war imperatives that discouraged the recollection of atrocities committed by the German army - as opposed to those of the SS - so as to avoid embarrassing one of the pillars of postwar western defence.

Today Mr Pampaloni hopes that the controversies over De Bernières' novel, and now John Madden's film, will serve to remind the world of one of the most savage passages of the war and of the courage of his lost comrades.

The decision of the Italian troops on Cephalonia to refuse to hand over their weapons to the Germans after their government signed an armistice with the allies is sometimes cited as the first act of the Italian resistance. It was taken after an extraordinary democratic consultation among the soldiers, rather than being imposed from on high, and ended in a tragic sacrifice of human lives. It has been virtually eliminated from Italian remembrance, swallowed up by cold war imperatives that discouraged the recollection of atrocities committed by the German army - as opposed to those of the SS - so as to avoid embarrassing one of the pillars of postwar western defence. Today Mr Pampaloni hopes that the controversies over De Bernières' novel, and now John Madden's film, will serve to remind the world of one of the most savage passages of the war and of the courage of his lost comrades. fields.headline: We are very sorry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America

Text of letter released by the White House from the US ambassador to China, Joseph W Prueher, to the Chinese minister of foreign affairs, Tang Jiaxuan.
fields.trailText: Text of letter released by the White House from the US ambassador to China, Joseph W Prueher, to the Chinese minister of foreign affairs, Tang Jiaxuan, which effectively ended the diplomatic row over the US spyplane
fields.body:
Dear Mr Minister,

On behalf of the United States government, I now outline steps to resolve this issue.

Both President Bush and Secretary of State Powell have expressed their sincere regret over your missing pilot and aircraft.

Please convey to the Chinese people and to the family of pilot Wang Wei that we are very sorry for their loss.

Although the full picture of what transpired is still unclear, according to our information, our severely crippled aircraft made an emergency landing after following international emergency procedures.

We are very sorry the entering of China's airspace and the landing did not have verbal clearance, but very pleased the crew landed safely. We appreciate China's efforts to see to the well-being of our crew.

In view of the tragic incident and based on my discussions with your representative, we have agreed to the following actions:

Both sides agree to hold a meeting to discuss the incident. My government understands and expects that our aircrew will be permitted to depart China as soon as possible. The meeting would start April 18, 2001.

The meeting agenda would include discussion of the causes of the incident, possible recommendations whereby such collisions could be avoided in the future, development of a plan for prompt return of the EP-3 aircraft, and other related issues. We acknowledge your government's intention to raise US reconnaissance missions near China in the meeting.

Sincerely,

Joseph W Prueher

fields.headline: Ardent profit important milestone, says chairman
fields.trailText: 11am: The Earl of Wessex will face down his critics and announce today his loss-making TV company has turned the corner, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
As if by magic, the Earl of Wessex will face down his critics and announce today that his loss-making television company has turned the corner.

Just as Buckingham Palace draws up new rules for royals in business, Prince Edward will reveal that Ardent TV has made a "small operating profit" for the year to December 2000.

It is the first profit the company has made since it launched nine years ago.

However, the company is still deep in the red with losses of £1.9m accumulated over the previous eight years.

Ardent struggles to maintain credibility, despite Prince Edward's confident prediction back in 1993 that the company would become "one of the top 12" British TV production companies by 2000.

Ardent TV chairman Malcolm Cockren said today it was still an important milestone for the company.

"This is our first operating profit. It does not mean we are in the black, but it is an excellent situation.

"It is nothing to do with good fortune, it is to do with the sensible running of the business. It has taken us a lot longer than we anticipated because we wanted to concentrate on quality programming," said Mr Cockren.

The company is holding its annual general meeting today at its headquarters in the earl's home, Bagshot Park in Surrey.

Ardent has made substantial losses for eight years running - last year it recorded a deficit of £222,000, up from £122,000 last year.

When he set up the company back in 1993, Prince Edward was determined to prove he could make an independent living.

Despite his insistence that he is not using his family, the prince has been frequently accused of trading on the royal connections.

His portfolio of programmes include a documentary on the restoration of Windsor Castle featuring interviews with his father and brother; a two-part documentary about his great-uncle which won critical acclaim; Crown & Country, a six-part series on the monarchy's links with towns in Britain; and the A-Z of Royals for American TV.

Attempts to diversify into non-royal programming making have had a mixed reception.

Annie's Bar, a political soap, was dropped by Channel 4 after one series and ITV did not commission any more Inspector Pitt Mysteries despite a successful pilot of the drama.

The company is now concentrating on non-heritage programming with plans for a new drama series about arranged marriages in Britain.

A documentary about expatriates in Singapore made by Ardent will be screened by Channel 5 in June.

fields.headline: US 'take full responsibility'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America

The full text of the report by China's official Xinhua news agency on the delivery of a US apology letter over the spyplane incident and China's promise to release its crew
fields.trailText:
The full text of the report by China's official Xinhua news agency on the delivery of a
US letter of regret over the spy plane incident and China's promise to release its crew
fields.body:
While receiving a letter that US Ambassador Joseph Prueher, the representative plenipotentiary of the US government for handling the incident of a US military reconnaissance plane ramming into and destroying a Chinese military aircraft, handed over to Minister

Tang on behalf of the US government this afternoon, China's Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan pointed out that the US side must take full responsibility for the incident, provide convincing explanations to the Chinese people, stop its reconnaissance activities above the Chinese coast and take measures to stop the recurrence of such incidents.

Ambassador Prueher said in the letter that both President Bush and Secretary of State Powell have expressed their sincere regret over China's missing pilot and aircraft.

He said on behalf of the U.S. Government that they were very sorry to the Chinese people and the family of pilot Wang Wei and that they were very sorry for the US plane entering China's airspace and landing without a verbal clearance.

The US side also expressed its appreciation of China's efforts to see to the well-being of the American crew.

Minister Tang pointed out that it is a serious incident that the U.S. military reconnaissance plane rammed into and destroyed a Chinese military plane on the morning of 1 April off the coast of China's Hainan Province, leading to the missing of the Chinese pilot, and entered China's airspace and landed at the Chinese airfield without permission.

The said US plane intruded into China's territorial airspace and encroached upon China's sovereignty in violation of international law and the provisions of relevant laws of China as well as the consensus that China and the US reached last May on avoiding dangerous maritime military activities. Its act has thus constituted a threat to China's national security.

The US side must take full responsibility for the incident. It is entirely reasonable and legitimate for the Chinese side to ask for an apology to the Chinese people from the US side.

Minister Tang emphasized that ever since the US military reconnaissance plane rammed into and destroyed a Chinese military plane, the Chinese side has all along handled this incident with calmness and restraint and in accordance with international law and the provisions of relevant laws of China.

The competent departments in China have, out of humanitarian considerations, treated the 24 crew members of the US reconnaissance plane well and arranged for their meetings with US diplomatic and consular officers.

He said he noted that the US side expressed in the letter its appreciation to the Chinese side for all this. He told Ambassador Prueher that the Chinese side understands the American people and the families of the crew are eagerly looking forward to an early return of the crew and a reunion with them.

As the US government has already said "very sorry" to the Chinese people, the Chinese government has, out of humanitarian considerations, decided to allow the crew members to leave China after completing the necessary procedures.

He also pointed out that this is not the conclusion of the case involving the US military plane ramming into a Chinese aircraft, causing the missing of the Chinese pilot, entering the Chinese airspace and landing at a Chinese airfield without permission.

The two sides will continue with the negotiations on the matter and other related issues. The Chinese Government and people demand that the US side provide convincing explanations to the Chinese people on this incident, stop sending aircraft to the vicinity of the Chinese coast for reconnaissance activities and take effective measures to avert the recurrence of similar incidents.

The US side must understand fully the seriousness of the incident, take seriously the solemn position of the Chinese side and properly handle this incident. It must not make an erroneous judgment and further damage the bilateral relations.

Minister Tang finally stressed that China's sovereign independence, territorial integrity and national dignity brook no infringement.

It is China's consistent position that state-to- state relations, including China-US relations, must be based on such basic norms governing international relations as mutual respect for sovereignty and territorial integrity, mutual non- aggression and non-interference in each other's internal affairs.

The Chinese side attaches importance to China-US relations. To develop friendly relations and cooperation between China and the US serves the interests of both countries and the world at large. It is hoped that the US will strictly abide by the three China-US Joint Communiques and the basic norms governing international relations and will refrain from doing anything more to impair the bilateral relations.

The US should take a constructive attitude and work with the Chinese side to bring the bilateral relations onto the track of normal development.

fields.headline: Fries with that curry, sir?
fields.trailText:
3pm: McDonald's is launching the McCurry in a bid to cash in on the popularity of Britain's favourite food. By Julia Day.

See the McMenu
Mar 27: McDonald's designs meal for older kids
Mar 22: McDonald's attempts to woo back French
fields.body:
First there were McBurgers, then McHotels, now McDonald's is launching the McCurry in a bid to cash in on the popularity of Britain's favourite food.

In an extraordinary diversification, the chain known the world over for burgers and fries is extending its range of food in Britain to include traditional Indian takeaway dishes.

On the menu, alongside milkshakes and Big Macs, will be chicken tikka masala, lamb rogan josh, tandoori chicken, vegetable samosas, onion bhajis and banana and mango coolers.

The indian menu will change weekly and "The Spice of Life" promotion is set to run from today until May 22.

The move is a departure for McDonald's, which often themes its burgers, chicken nuggets and dips around different types of world cuisine, but until now has not sold the dishes themselves.

An advertising campaign for the indian menu promotion breaks on TV tonight featuring a cast of "ordinary" people singing traditional British songs.

As part of its attempt to bolster revenues, McDonald's is launching a chain of hotels, piloting American-style diners within its restaurants and is investing in companies such as Pret A Manger.

fields.headline: Express swamped with redundancy requests
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: The Express's fast-track redundancy programme has been suspended because it has proved so popular, writes Jessica Hodgson.

Click here for latest Express news
fields.body:
The Express group's fast-track redundancy programme has been suspended because it was so over-subscribed, according to sources.

The decision comes as the woman in charge of the redundancy programme, group managing editor, Lindsay Cook, resigns.

Four senior general reporters and the showbusiness editor have applied for the scheme, only to be told they will have to wait until the newspaper opens the book for voluntary redundancy.

Dennis Rice, Adrian Lee and Anthony Mitchell, senior reporters on the Express, and showbusiness editor Shekhar Bhatia, have all put their names forward.

David Dillon from the Sunday Express is also believed to have applied.

Ms Cook, who was one of Lord Hollick's faithful lieutenants and is believed to have been one of those who received the £40,000 farewell bonus that the former Express proprietor bequeathed on many senior staff after selling the paper to Richard Desmond.

She will leave next month as part of the fast-track programme.

Saturday magazine editor Sally Ferrari and her deputy David Allsop have also applied for the scheme.

One senior journalist there said: "The place is disintegrating before our eyes."

Insiders say 130 reporters applied for fast-track redundancy before the full voluntary consultation period had begun.

The latest planned departures plans threaten to leave the Express with only five general reporters, and sources say morale is "rock bottom".

fields.headline: ITV in talks with prince
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Exclusive Prince Edward's beleaguered TV company has won a timely morale boost after ITV showed interest in his latest project, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Ardent profit important milestone, says chairman
fields.body:
Prince Edward's beleaguered TV company has won a timely morale boost after ITV expressed interest in a new project that does not trade on his royal connections.

He is due to meet network chiefs in the next two weeks to discuss his company's idea for a new drama series about arranged marriages in Britain.

The series, Honour Me, is already in the early stages of development and would be set in the UK and India.

ITV network chiefs, who can barely squeeze new dramas into the schedule because of ongoing hits including Peak Practice and London's Burning, are already talking with excitement about the project.

The diversification into such a sensitive cultural subject as arranged marriages and the Asian community in Britain will be seen as an unusual move for the Earl of Wessex, who has come under fire for using his status to drum up business.

Last week the prince was accused of using a business trip to the Far East to further his television business.

But sources say the earl cannot take personal credit for the drama project.

That goes to Nigel McCrery, the man who created a string of TV hits including the BBC series Silent Witness starring Amanda Burton.

He has been hired by the earl's company to develop new drama and is highly thought of in TV circles.

Sources say he has caught the eye of ITV and BBC chiefs because of his unorthodox background.

After leaving school he became a police officer, but quit the force to further his education at King's College, Cambridge.

"There are very few people in TV who aren't Tristans. Nigel simply doesn't do the TV circuit," said one TV executive who has worked with him.

"He doesn't live in London, keeps his feet on the ground in Nottingham and has no interest in the endless rounds of parties and networking in places like the Groucho or Soho House, He brings a fresh eye to things."

Mr McCrery was executive producer on All the King's Men, a BBC1 drama about the first world war Norfolk regiment recruited from among Sandringham's royal servants, grooms and gardeners.

Starring David Jason, it was also made by the earl's TV company, Ardent Television, but was based on an original book by Mr McCrery.

Ardent Television chairman Malcolm Cockren confirmed Honour Me was being developed but said it was "at early stages".

"We are looking for a writer and beyond that I can't really say without giving away trade secrets," he said.

If the deal comes off it will mark a significant boost for Prince Edward, who has struggled to gain credibility as a serious player in the television market.

He has been frequently criticised for falling back on his royal connections to make programmes ranging from Edward on Edward, a documentary about his great-uncle King Edward VIII, to a current documentary for American television, the A-Z of Royalty.

Related story

fields.headline: Russia goes Gagarin
fields.standfirst: Cosmonaut Day, the 40th anniversary of man's first space flight, lifts off tomorrow, says Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: Cosmonaut Day, the 40th anniversary of man's first space flight, lifts off tomorrow, says Amelia Gentleman in Moscow.
fields.body:
When state television announced on April 12 1961 that Yuri Gagarin had soared through the earth's atmosphere to become the first man in space, there was an explosion of patriotic delight in Russia.

Thousands of people hurried to Red Square to join the celebrations; among them a group of medical students who lined up in the centre of the square with words "Gagarin! Hurrah!" painted on their white coats. Those who attended remember these events as spontaneous demonstrations of enthusiasm - very different in atmosphere from the annual party-organised revolution parades.

The 40th anniversary of his achievement is to be marked in Russia with celebrations of a more muted variety. President Vladimir Putin will meet space officials and cosmonauts in the Kremlin to remember Gagarin on April 12 - which has been designated as Russia's annual Cosmonaut Day.

Ceremonies are to be held in the city named after the cosmonaut in western Russia; dozens of Gagarin statues throughout the country are being restored; previously unreleased photographs of his have been published; and documentaries about his short flight into space have been prepared for broadcast on the day.

Gagarin remains a national hero. His death, aged 34, in a plane accident has left a smiling, youthful image seared on the national consciousness. The story of how a country boy was transformed overnight into the most famous man in the world is still taught in schools and chapters from his life are familiar across the generations.

Every episode in the build-up to his flight has achieved mythical status. According to some versions of his life, it was Gagarin's skill at keeping still that guaranteed him his place on the Vostok 1 capsule, taking him on a 108-minute journey around the world. On the night before the journey, both he and his rival for the task, Gherman Titov, were wired up to a sleep monitoring system to check who slept most soundly.

Officials were anxious to ensure that the first person in space would be fully refreshed after a good night's sleep. Gagarin said later that he spent much of the night awake trying to keep still so that the sensors would not register abnormal tossing and turning - leaving him abnormally tired on the day of his flight. He later attributed the decision to pick him for the task to the fact that "Titov turned over in his bed".

Other versions suggest that it was Gagarin's modest background that gave him the edge over Titov, who came from a more bourgeois, intellectual family. But Titov, who died last year, had his own explanation for the selection of his rival. "Yuri was loveable, but no one could love me," he said.

The more scandalous incidents in Gagarin's life - his drinking binges, his alleged adultery, picked over in western biographies of the cosmonaut - have not been revisited in the adoring articles published in his honour in Russia this week.

Instead the anniversary offers Russia's space community an opportunity to remember its huge achievements at a time when international attention has been focused on the end of the nation's human space programme, with last month's public dumping of the ageing and cash-starved Mir space station. Russia's space agency will now focus on unmanned space projects - less glamorous but cheaper and, according to officials, more efficient.

Amid all the undiluted veneration being offered to Gagarin this week, there is one sour note. Moscow city planners, constructing a new ring road for the capital, have encountered an irritating obstacle. The massive, soaring monument to Gagarin - one of the capital's architectural landmarks - is in the way. Gagarin is set to be removed from his pedestal and cleared away to a less obtrusive resting place.

Thousands of people hurried to Red Square to join the celebrations; among them a group of medical students who lined up in the centre of the square with words "Gagarin! Hurrah!" painted on their white coats. Those who attended remember these events as spontaneous demonstrations of enthusiasm - very different in atmosphere from the annual party-organised revolution parades. The 40th anniversary of his achievement is to be marked in Russia with celebrations of a more muted variety. President Vladimir Putin will meet space officials and cosmonauts in the Kremlin to remember Gagarin on April 12 - which has been designated as Russia's annual Cosmonaut Day. fields.headline: Microsoft cuts 'Mr Clippy'
fields.standfirst: Click here to see the campaign
fields.trailText: 3pm: Microsoft is killing off its unpopular Word office assistant and spending £300,000 to promote the move, writes Claire Cozens. Click here to see the campaign
fields.body:
For years Microsoft's pop-up office assistant has infuriated Word users with its helpful hints.

So much so that the software giant has decided to kill him off and is launching a tongue-in-cheek campaign to promote the move.

The £300,000 promotion forms part of the launch campaign for Microsoft's new Office XP programme, which will not include the offending tool.

The pop-up paperclip, which goes by the nickname of "Mr Clippy", is one of the most unpopular features of Microsoft's software and his demise will be welcomed the world over.

A new website devoted to Mr Clippy gives users the chance to vote on what should become of the anthropomorphic paperclip when Microsoft's new system is launched.

A short film shows the character being killed by a furious Word user and the site includes an interactive game in which users can zap the paper clip with a staple gun.

The site even has Mr Clippy's "to do" list, which includes a reminder to send out his CV and ask Bill Gates for a reference.

The interfering paper clip's most common question, "Are you writing a letter?" is also tackled in a spoof version that shows him ask, "Are you writing a letter? Is it a love letter? Can I read it?".

"Clippy is a character that people feel very strongly about - they either love him or hate him," said a Microsoft spokeswoman.

"With Office XP's ease of use we don't think customers will need to use Clippy."

Office XP launches at the end of May backed by a major global advertising and marketing campaign.

Customers who want to use an office assistant will still be able to access Clippy if they want to, but he will no longer be as in-your-face as he once was.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth in Europe
fields.standfirst:
Apart from the United Kingdom, three other countries in the European Union have reported outbreaks of foot and mouth disease since February this year. Simon Jeffery reports

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Apart from the United Kingdom, three other countries in the European Union have reported outbreaks of foot and mouth disease since February this year. Simon Jeffery reports.
fields.body:
France

Number of cases: Two

First outbreak: March 13

How it happened: France imported 47,000 British sheep in the month before the crisis. The first outbreak, in the north-western Mayenne region, was next to a farm that had imported animals from the UK.

Action: 20,000 British sheep were quarantined at the beginning of the crisis to prevent paying out large amounts of compensation to farmers for their slaughter. They were later slaughtered, along with 30,000 French sheep that had come into contact with them. Potentially infected farms were put under close surveillance and effectively quarantined. When the disease was discovered, the authorities stopped livestock movement and culled infected herds.

How it ended: At the time of writing, France had not reported a new outbreak for more than three weeks and the EU ban on meat, livestock and dairy exports is scheduled to be lifted tomorrow.

Link: French ministry of agriculture: foot and mouth information (in French)

Ireland

Number of cases: One

First outbreak: March 22

How it happened: The infected farm, at Proleek, County Louth, was within the surveillance zone of Northern Ireland's single case at Meigh, south Armagh.

Action: Dublin postponed major sporting fixtures and stopped its horse racing teams from travelling to Britain before the Proleek outbreak. After it was announced, 49,000 sheep together with some cattle, deer and goats were slaughtered. Vets, hauliers, farmers and others in agribusiness had to disinfect themselves from the time of the first case in Britain and the Republic employed strict border controls.

How it ended: If there are no new cases, the export ban will be lifted on April 19. Artificial insemination will be re-introduced from the same day.

Link: Irish department of agriculture: foot and mouth information


The Netherlands

Number of cases: 21

First outbreak: March 21

How it happened: No cause has yet been established.

Action: Soon after the first British outbreaks, the Dutch slaughtered 3,400 imported animals. When its own cases were reported, the authorities sealed off a 80 sq mile contamination zone in the east of the country and vaccinated 115,000 animals to prevent further spread in the time before they were slaughtered. All movement of animals and their products is forbidden.

How it ended: The Dutch outbreaks are the second worse in the EU. Containment has failed to stop the spread of the disease to a farm in Friesland, more than 88 miles from the centre of the infected zone. The crisis shows no sign of ending yet.

Link: Dutch ministry of agriculture: information for visitors


Action in clean countries

Spain killed 540 British pigs in the first week of the crisis and, after the disease spread to the continent, announced an immediate inspection of all animals from France; Germany banned livestock markets when it discovered animals from an infected Devon farm were exported to the north Rhine region and slaughtered the British sheep (which were later found to be carrying foot and mouth antibodies); Belgium set up strict controls along its border with the Netherlands and cancelled all livestock movement and markets; Italy slaughtered 392 sheep from France with foot and mouth antibodies in their blood.

An EU ban on UK livestock exports prevented the spread of British animals on the continent. The ban was extended to all countries infected with foot and mouth. Visitors to EU airports and ferry ports are disinfected and barred from bringing foodstuffs if they come from contaminated countries.

Outside the EU, Poland and Norway closed their borders to the union's meat.

fields.headline: Napster still kicking
fields.standfirst:
The song swap service's users are finding sneaky ways around the restrictions placed on the service by the recent court injunction, says Neil McIntosh

More net news
fields.trailText: The song swap service's users are finding sneaky ways around the restrictions placed on the service by the recent court injunction, says Neil McIntosh.
fields.body:
"This is disgraceful," fumed San Francisco judge Marilyn Hall Patel yesterday, when faced with evidence of how business continues as usual on the court injunction-bound Napster song-swapping service.

Business, of course, is not quite the word to use, given that Napster makes no money and that most of the songs swapped through it are pirated duplicates of copyright music.

But, regardless, Napster's popularity remains strong and filtering procedures put in place are failing to put the brakes on the violations the website makes so simple to carry out.

Logging on this morning, it was easy to find any tune from this week's chart. Even brand-new singles from well-known artists were there: the soundtrack album for Bridget Jones' Diary is all there for free, as is Janet Jackson's new single, All for You. The latter is on rotation at MTV and is pretty popular on Napster as well; I quickly found dozens of fellow users ready to share the file.

How are they getting round Napster's filtering efforts? Quite easily. The song-swapping service is asking copyright holders to verify they own rights to songs before it puts a simple block on the name of the track. So, look up that Janet Jackson song as "All For You" and nothing will appear. But search for "Janet Jackson" and you'll find hundreds of available files, including lots called "all4you" or "alll4u", or some similar arrangement of characters which makes it quite clear to the human searcher what the file contains, but which foxes Napster's filter.

As you might have guessed by now, Napster has hardly pulled out the technological stops to stop the illegal file-swaps. As Cary Sherman of the Recording Industry Association of America pointed out yesterday, "There are so many things that they aren't doing right now that they could be doing tomorrow." Like applying blocks by artist name, rather than song title.

"Maybe the system needs to be shut down," said Judge Patel in conclusion, but that is essentially already what she is demanding Napster do to itself by blocking all those copyright songs. Of course this turkey is reluctant to vote for Christmas and surely now it is only a question of how - rather than if - Napster as we know it now will simply have the plug pulled on it.

Will that be the end of Napster, or online music piracy? The answer to both questions is most likely: no. Napster's core song-swapping technology has done a great favour for the neanderthal record companies by showing what would work best for them online. Napster has already signed a deal with Bertellsman, the German media conglomerate, to launch a legal version of its service to paying customers. If it works as well as Napster does now (even under injunction), it will be very successful indeed, as the otherwise law-abiding majority of Napster users migrate to doing the honest thing, and others , put off by the moral conundrums of using Napster today, sign up too.

And what of online music piracy? The record companies would be stupid to think that, by stopping Napster, they will stop the music pirates. There are several alternatives to Napster (none, it must be said, with quite the same functionality or ease of use - so far) and we can comfortably predict that songs will continue to be copied and distributed illegally just like, for instance, expensive bits of software like Word and PhotoShop are in various "warez" newsgroups.

But the pirates will eventually return to being, once again, the minority, because most people accept that paying to be allowed to listen to music is a fair way of rewarding artists for their creativity. The only doubt is over exactly when the record companies will get round to allowing us to pay for digital music. Many online music fans will be wishing they would hurry things up by ending the pointless legal wranglings with Napster, and working instead to develop an effective, legal song swapping system.

webTitle: England move up to 14th in Fifa rankings

fields.headline: England move up to 14th in Fifa rankings
fields.trailText: England have moved up two places to 14th in the latest Fifa football rankings.
fields.body:
England have moved up two places to 14th in the latest Fifa football rankings.

Scotland's run of good results has pushed them up five positions to 23rd and the Republic of Ireland have also risen five places to 30th.

Wales are unchanged at 109th in the world, while Northern Ireland's poor form has seen them fall two places to 98th.

The top three of Brazil, France and Argentina remain unchanged.

Fifa rankings (last month in brackets): 1 (1) Brazil 807 points; 2 (2) France 792; 3 (3) Argentina 770; 4 (5) Italy 750; 5 (4) Portugal 735; 6 (6) Czech Republic 732; 7 (7) Spain 725; 8 (11) Germany 714; 9 (8) Paraguay 713; 10 (9) Holland 709.

fields.headline: Amazing technicolour Janet
fields.standfirst: Despite her colourful image, Janet Street-Porter's editorship of the Independent on Sunday has been surprisingly low-key
fields.trailText: 2.30pm comment: Despite her colourful image, Janet Street-Porter's editorship has been surprisingly low-key, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie's observation that Janet Street-Porter's resignation from the Independent on Sunday was "a great day for bus tickets" is oddly inappropriate.

When Ms Street-Porter joined the IoS, many doubted the woman famed for wearing wacky spectacles and dating "yoof" TV presenters was up to editing a broadsheet Sunday newspaper.

Whether she took the former Sun editor's original jibe that she "couldn't edit a bus ticket" to heart is unclear.

But an article last week by the former Observer editor Donald Trelford suggested that, if anything, Ms Street-Porter's crime was that she had not been wacky enough.

Media watchers have speculated that Mr Trelford - a former boss of Independent editor-in-chief Simon Kelner - is likely to have had an inside track on Mr Kelner's motives.

In the article, he claimed Ms Street-Porter had failed to provide enough "fireworks" in the paper.

The IoS has struggled to keep up with its rival the Observer since Ms Street-Porter took the helm in 1999.

If anything, Mr Trelford said, her sober, relatively gaffe-free reign is likely to have been a disappointment to those who wanted some of Ms Street-Porter's colour to seep into the pages.

Mr Kelner is currently defending Ms Street-Porter's record at the paper, claiming she "proved [her detractors] wrong".

Certainly, she didn't give any of her critics the chance to show she was incompetent.

When she took over, Ms Street-Porter said she wanted to make the paper "a polymorphous journal" for a multicultural society.

But beyond a launching the Reality magazine and executing a low-key redesign, she has not made radical changes to the IoS.

The paper's circulation has not changed significantly since 1999.

In spite of a general slump in Sunday newspaper sales, reader numbers at the IoS have risen slightly from 242,238 when Ms Street-Porter joined to 251,124 in February this year.

But it is widely accepted that the growing use of bulk sales and price cutting hides a decline in sales.

Ms Street-Porter's image is a strident one: she is known for her role in the creation of "yoof" TV show Network Seven, her tempestuous directorship of Live TV and her dalliance with former TV presenter Normski.

But her technicolour personality has obscured some quieter and more considered interests, such as her interest in rambling, which manifested itself in a book and the TV series Coast to Coast.

More recently, her interest in the countryside has drawn her to focus on the foot and mouth crisis and publish impassioned editorials on the plight of British farmers.
