Whether she took the former Sun editor's original jibe that she "couldn't edit a bus ticket" to heart is unclear. But an article last week by the former Observer editor Donald Trelford suggested that, if anything, Ms Street-Porter's crime was that she had not been wacky enough. Media watchers have speculated that Mr Trelford - a former boss of Independent editor-in-chief Simon Kelner - is likely to have had an inside track on Mr Kelner's motives. In the article, he claimed Ms Street-Porter had failed to provide enough "fireworks" in the paper. The IoS has struggled to keep up with its rival the Observer since Ms Street-Porter took the helm in 1999. If anything, Mr Trelford said, her sober, relatively gaffe-free reign is likely to have been a disappointment to those who wanted some of Ms Street-Porter's colour to seep into the pages. Mr Kelner is currently defending Ms Street-Porter's record at the paper, claiming she "proved [her detractors] wrong". Certainly, she didn't give any of her critics the chance to show she was incompetent. When she took over, Ms Street-Porter said she wanted to make the paper "a polymorphous journal" for a multicultural society. But beyond a launching the Reality magazine and executing a low-key redesign, she has not made radical changes to the IoS. The paper's circulation has not changed significantly since 1999. In spite of a general slump in Sunday newspaper sales, reader numbers at the IoS have risen slightly from 242,238 when Ms Street-Porter joined to 251,124 in February this year. But it is widely accepted that the growing use of bulk sales and price cutting hides a decline in sales. Ms Street-Porter's image is a strident one: she is known for her role in the creation of "yoof" TV show Network Seven, her tempestuous directorship of Live TV and her dalliance with former TV presenter Normski. But her technicolour personality has obscured some quieter and more considered interests, such as her interest in rambling, which manifested itself in a book and the TV series Coast to Coast. More recently, her interest in the countryside has drawn her to focus on the foot and mouth crisis and publish impassioned editorials on the plight of British farmers. webTitle: Livingstone under fire over PR millions

fields.headline: Livingstone under fire over PR millions
fields.standfirst: Labour's letter to Ken
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Ken Livingstone is under attack over the £20m he is spending on PR for London's proposed traffic congestion charge. By Julia Day.
Labour's letter to Ken

Apr 10: PR firm defends massive payment for London traffic advice
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone is under attack from the London Assembly's Labour group about the millions of pounds his transport chiefs are spending on PR and advertising for the capital's proposed traffic congestion charge.

The GLA's Labour members believe the £20m earmarked for publicity surrounding the introduction of the charge is "a massive sum for a relatively simple exercise" and is demanding an independent audit of the spend.

A spokeswoman for the Labour group said there was no evidence that consultations being carried out by PR firm Fishburn Hedges at a fee of £100,000 a month were effective.

In a letter to Mr Livingstone, the GLA's Labour transport spokesperson John Biggs said: "Within the total scheme costs of £182m, no less than £20m is earmarked for communications and advertising.

"Given concerns expressed at the Assembly both about the cost and nature of your publicity campaigns, can you provide details of what Londoners will be getting from this budget?

"It seems a massive sum, over 10% of the scheme costs, for a relatively simple exercise. Our concerns are about value for money, about whether and to what degrees the campaign is advertising or consultation, and whether it effectively gauges the views of Londoners?

"We also seek confirmation that this part of the project in particular will be independently appraised and audited to ensure it is good value and achieves clearly defined objectives."

The letter also seeks assurance that the scheme's projected £168m annual profit is not clouding the mayor's judgement about traffic solutions in the capital.

In the proposed scheme, motorists would be charged for driving in central London on weekdays between 7am and 7pm.

webTitle: Bend Coke's ear on Kyoto, say MPs

fields.headline: Bend Coke's ear on Kyoto, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday launched a campaign to persuade Coca-Cola's customers to strongarm the soft drinks company into backing the Kyoto protocols against global warming. By Michael White.
fields.body:
A cross-party committee of MPs yesterday launched an unprecedented campaign to persuade Coca-Cola's customers around the world to strongarm the global soft drinks company into backing the Kyoto protocols against global warming.

They appealed to young customers to bombard both Coca-Cola - initially in Britain - and the White House directly.

"We turn not to the foes of President Bush, but to his friends, those whose wise counsels have influenced the president, those whose wide pockets have sustained him," said the former consumer affairs minister, Nigel Griffiths.

The MPs are targeting Coca-Cola because it gave nearly $1m to George Bush's campaign for the presidency last year. They are also incensed that Coca-Cola has borrowed the environmentalists' slogan "think globally, act locally" but think it can be persuaded to act upon it.

Though they are in touch with MEPs at Strasbourg, with French greens and with Joe Lieberman, Al Gore's running mate in November, the MPs believe that Coca-Cola's marketing image as a drink for young people makes it vulnerable to pressure from precisely that group of consumers.

Tory backbenchers such as Peter Bottomley and Liberal Democrat Tom Brake have joined 30 Labour MPs in launching what they hope will turn into the global email campaign, directed at Coca-Cola's "ear, not its wallet" .

The National Union of Students is also backing the campaign. Tony Blair and his ministers have signalled their dismay that Mr Bush has reversed his campaign pledge to back Kyoto.

But there are signs that American public opinion is shifting towards seeking to implement the Kyoto deal - stalled in December - which will be discussed in Berlin in July. It would commit the US to cut carbon emissions by 7% below 1990 levels by 2012.

fields.trailText: April 12: Virgin Mobile has made Virginstudent.com managing director Brenda Ross its first international marketing director.
fields.body:
Virgin Mobile has made Virginstudent.com managing director Brenda Ross its first international marketing director.

Ford, Unilever and L'Oreal are among the advertisers to have reduced their spend on ITV this year. This has contributed to double-digit deflation on the channel, according to Optimedia.

The Incorporated Society of British Advertisers has accused the government of rushing through unnecessary changes to legislation that could undermine UK advertisers' self-regulation.

Marks & Spencer's head of advertising Matthew Chambers is poised to leave the company after more than 15 years.

Just 13 of the UK's FTSE-100 companies have chief executives who are marketers, while 26 are led by accountants.

Beatrice Lafon, Homebase's managing director of e-commerce, has quit the DIY retailer after less than a year in the job.

Queercompany.com has dismissed its advertising agency and both its PR agencies as it channels funding into other areas.

New Look has recruited Mothercare marketer Jim Fraser to be its new marketing director.

Barclays has hired Simon Gulliford, marketing director of Emap Consumer Magazines, to be its first group marketing director.

webTitle: New front in war against virus

fields.headline: New front in war against virus
fields.standfirst: The government's fight to control foot and mouth is causing serious political and administrative problems, says John Vidal
fields.trailText: The government's fight to control foot and mouth is causing serious political and administrative problems, says John Vidal.
fields.body:
Day 51 in the crisis and journalists covering foot and mouth are witnessing a new front in the war against the virus: everyone blaming everyone else; open revolt mounting against the administrative chaos and the shambles that has accompanied the epidemic; and worrying new outbreaks popping up everywhere.

The Labour government, notorious for its control freakery, is now clearly battling a virus which defies control and is still spreading.

In its desire to appear in charge, it is now in danger of splitting its cosy alliance with leaders of the NFU by openly blaming farmers for illegal movements of livestock. The farm leaders respond by blaming ministers for not being in control of the situation, which is worsening in areas like Gloucestershire.

Meanwhile, the NFU is itself starting to split with the grassroots beginning to blame the leadership for not consulting them over vaccination or giving them the full facts, and large farmers are calling for vaccination for the first time.

At the same time, No 10 has infuriated us by taking over news management of the crisis and whipping away open government by refusing to allow briefings or question and answer sessions with the chief vet and ministers.

Local councils are being slapped on wrist for not opening footpaths and are in turn being accused of insensitivity by some rural communities, Michael Meacher's rural task force is accused of doing nothing, and the treasury of being penny pinching and mean for charging interest on the tax breaks it has agreed to.

The hoteliers are blaming everyone, the vets are split between those who think vaccination is a good idea and those who don't and the public does not know what is open or closed, where they can go, when it will end or what they should do.

No one in authority has a real overview of what is happening any more because the government is censoring the facts, and admits it cannot be certain any more of its figures.

We may never know exactly how many outbreaks there were because the government is literally burning the evidence, and we may never know how far it has spread because no one is testing. The stress is getting to everyone and the end is far from over.

webTitle: Official: jobless number below million mark

fields.headline: Official: jobless number below million mark
fields.trailText: April 11: Ministers now hope that the jobs under threat at Motorola's Bathgate plant and the difficulties at the Cammel Laird shipyard will not send the figure bouncing back above six figures before a June poll.
fields.body:
Unemployment in Britain fell below the million mark for the first time in 26 years last month, figures from the Office for National Statistics confirm today.

The drop below the "magic million" mark, which was trumpeted by the government in February, had been expected to provide a springboard for a May 3 election.

Ministers will now be hoping that the 3,000 jobs under threat at Motorola's Bathgate plant and the difficulties faced by the Cammel Laird shipyard do not send the figure bouncing back above six figures before a June poll.

The ONS figures published today show that the number of benefit claimants dropped by 5,500 in March to 995,200 and that average earnings increased by 5% in February, up 0.5% from the previous month.

However, the other measure of joblessness - the International Labour Organisation count which Labour used as a true measure of unemployment whilst in opposition - placed the number of those without work at 1.53m, even with a drop of 42,000 between December and February.

The employment minister, Tessa Jowell, welcomed the fall, but warned that foot and mouth may have an effect on future job figures. She said: "These figures show how well our employment policies are working, and that we have created an environment for stability and steady growth.

"This month's figures largely relate to the period before the outbreak of foot and mouth disease. We will continue to monitor the situation carefully, and today we are launching Rural Skills Action to provide support for anyone whose job is affected by the outbreak."

Education secretary David Blunkett expressed concern about the level of earnings growth, but said the figures could still "even out" once the bonuses were out of the way.

"We are concerned about the earnings levels. We believe it is to do with bonuses, but it is quite a big jump on the revised figures," he said.

He welcomed the continuing fall in the jobless total, despite the slowdown in world economic growth. "We are very pleased indeed that the figures are showing that stability and continuing potential for jobs growth," he said.

The drop in the jobless figure was also welcomed by the TUC general secretary John Monks. "The further improvement in the labour market is very welcome," he said.

But he warned against a Bank of England interest rate cut. He said: "The unexpectedly big jump in average earnings in February should not deter the Bank from further interest rate cuts.

"We expect earnings growth at this time of year to be distorted by City bonuses. But for all the talk of City belt tightening, the bonus rise this year seems to have been even more excessive than usual. In contrast, earnings growth for the vast majority of the workforce who do not get bonuses remains moderate and non-inflationary."

fields.headline: The demise of Industry Standard Europe
fields.standfirst: Why America's internet bible failed to plug into the European market
fields.trailText:
Comment: why America's internet bible failed to make it over here. By Amy Vickers.
Apr 6: Industry Standard Europe seeks buyer
Feb 19: Industry Standard cuts more jobs
fields.body:
When it was launched six months ago, it signalled that the internet in the UK and Europe had finally come of age.

America's internet bible the Industry Standard had talked for years about coming to Europe, but it wasn't until the end of 1999 that the building blocks were put in place for a London-based operation.

In no time at all, a wealth of accomplished journalists were signed up - and it was a constant subject of envious bar chat that the ISE paid ridiculously high salaries and had too many chiefs.

By the time the ISE got off the ground, however, it was October 19 2000, and not a good time to be launching a multimillion-pound venture.

The market had lost its footing and everyone was already concerned that the wind had been taken out of the sails of the internet economy.

Many people, especially the glut of wannabe dot.com entrepreneurs, had lost interest in the internet.

ISE had to prove itself and build a market.

While it did manage to raise the standard for new media trade titles and received widespread industry respect for its quality of in-depth coverage, reports suggested that it wasn't selling anywhere near what it had hoped for.

Figures claimed that the European edition was scoring average sales of 30,000 each week, despite the low price of £1.95, good point-of-sale distribution in WH Smith and the millions of marketing bucks being thrown at it.

When cracks began to show in parent company Standard Media International, the only cosmetic change to the European edition was an immediate staff freeze, although rumours soon started to emerge that IDG, the largest shareholder in Standard Media International, was putting pressure on the European office to seal a financial deal with a European partner.

Deadlines began to get shorter. Initially it was the end of 2001 when ISE was supposed to break even. But after a series of cutbacks in the US, the deadline to find new funding was moved forward to June, then to May, and then to yesterday.

Sources close to the company blame IDG for pulling the plug too prematurely, especially since ISE had only recently started up talks with potential buyers and partners.

Reports suggest that ISE chief executive Neil Thackray had instigated talks with all the major outfits - such as the Economist, Dow Jones, Reed Elsevier and United Business Media - when he had the rug pulled from under him.

To sell a business like ISE at a time like this, Mr Thackray needed more than just a few weeks.

Compounding the problem facing Mr Thackray was the news that broke at the weekend suggesting the European edition of Red Herring was also up for sale, and Business 2.0 is still on the market after being put up for sale earlier this year.

And so yesterday became D-day. Staff were told that this week's edition would be the last, Mr Thackray will leave at the end of April, and all except eight of the 64 staff have been given redundancy.

The remaining staff - including editor-in-chief Jim Ledbetter; writer Rick Wray; a website manager; a copy editor; and correspondents in Paris and Berlin - will become the "London bureau", writing copy for the US edition of the magazine and keeping the European website going.

The US edition will now be distributed in the UK.

But after a series of cutbacks in the US, the deadline to find new funding was moved forward to June, then to May, and then to yesterday. Sources close to the company blame IDG for pulling the plug too prematurely, especially since ISE had only recently started up talks with potential buyers and partners. Reports suggest that ISE chief executive Neil Thackray had instigated talks with all the major outfits - such as the Economist, Dow Jones, Reed Elsevier and United Business Media - when he had the rug pulled from under him. To sell a business like ISE at a time like this, Mr Thackray needed more than just a few weeks. Compounding the problem facing Mr Thackray was the news that broke at the weekend suggesting the European edition of Red Herring was also up for sale, and Business 2.0 is still on the market after being put up for sale earlier this year. And so yesterday became D-day. Staff were told that this week's edition would be the last, Mr Thackray will leave at the end of April, and all except eight of the 64 staff have been given redundancy. The remaining staff - including editor-in-chief Jim Ledbetter; writer Rick Wray; a website manager; a copy editor; and correspondents in Paris and Berlin - will become the "London bureau", writing copy for the US edition of the magazine and keeping the European website going. The US edition will now be distributed in the UK. webTitle: The Scotsman suffers in bloody circulation battle

fields.headline: The Scotsman suffers in bloody circulation battle
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Scotsman, owned by the Barclay brothers, has begun to feel the effects of the bloody circulation battle in Scotland, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
The Scotsman, owned by the Barclay brothers, has begun to feel the effects of the bloody circulation battle in Scotland.

The newspaper, engaged in a fierce fight for readers with the Herald, has been ordered by executives to cut editorial budgets by around 10%. The number of pages is also expected to be reduced, chiefly in the business and tabloid sections. The newspaper, which is run for the brothers' Press Holdings by Andrew Neil, has also frozen recruitment.

Similar cuts will be imposed on Scotland on Sunday.

A spokesman refused to discuss the retrenchment. He said: "Certain budget refinements have been made to ensure the continued competitiveness of the newspaper in what is generally regarded as one of the toughest markets in the world. But this does not involve job losses."

The newspaper is also considering recalling its Washington correspondent, Robert Tait, as it struggles to take £1m out of the editorial budget.

The Scotsman has gone through a turbulent period in the past 15 months or so, with a large number of staff defections, a relaunch, and three editors, the latest, Rebecca Hardy, arriving in June last year.

The paper has also been strongly criticised for shifting its editorial stance. Mr Neil cut the cover price six months ago to 30p to repair a circulation that had slumped to 72,000. Sales reached 103,000 but have since fallen back again. The most recent figures published showed sales in January at just under 84,000.

Mr Neil recently admitted that the cut in cover price, associated promotion and relaunch to restore the title had cost the company £5m.

fields.headline: M&S pins hopes on sponsorship deals
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Marks & Spencer is to throw itself into heavyweight sponsorships to boost its battered image, writes Julia Day.
10am: M&S in brand rethink
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is to throw itself into heavyweight sponsorships in an attempt to boost its battered image.

M&S has never been a big sponsorship player, whereas other brands reap valuable brand awareness and acceptance from sponsoring TV shows or sports and music events.

Cadbury's sponsorship of Coronation Street, Carling's title sponsorship of the Premier League and Virgin's annual music festival are examples of the trend for brands to create a buzz among their target audience through sponsorship rather than traditional TV advertising.

Last year, M&S sponsored the British Olympic and Paralympic teams by providing the athletes' uniforms for the opening ceremonies.

The retailer also sponsored the New Generation award for young designers at London Fashion Week.

But sponsorship is to take a leading role in turning around M&S's brand as part of a shakeup of the company's marketing strategy.

"We are definitely looking to increase our use of sponsorship," said an M&S spokeswoman.

"We have always done bits and pieces but now we are looking at the big things that can make a difference. Sponsorship is very important to us."

M&S is restructuring its marketing department and is hunting a top marketer to take charge of sponsorship and advertising.

Related story
Apr 11: M&S in brand rethink

fields.headline: Labour's letter to Ken
fields.standfirst: Letter to Ken Livingstone from London Assembly Labour group.
fields.trailText: Letter to Ken Livingstone from London Assembly Labour group.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone
Mayor of London
Romney House
Marsham Street
London SW1

April 9 2001

Dear Ken

Labour members are reviewing our position on the proposed Congestion Charge for Central London. As you know, we have no problem with the principle of a scheme, but are concerned that the details of it are properly thought through and that full and genuine consultation takes place with Londoners on the proposals.

To assist our review, I would be grateful if you would answer three questions about the proposals, in the light of recently published scheme details.

The first is about the provision for publicity and consultation. In a document provided recently to members of the Assembly's Transport Policy Committee by Derek Turner (TfL Street Management, Project Overview for the proposed Congestion Charging Scheme, dated 31st January 2001) it is revealed that within the total scheme costs of £182 million, no less than £20 million is earmarked for Communications and Advertising. Within this year's scheme budget of £64 million, this implies about £6 million, with the remaining £14 million spent next year.

Given concerns expressed at the Assembly both about the cost and nature of your publicity campaigns, can you provide details of what Londoners will be getting from this budget? It seems a massive sum, over 10% of the scheme costs, for a relatively simple exercise. Our concerns are about Value for Money, about whether and to what degrees the campaign is advertising or consultation, and whether it effectively gauges the views of Londoners?

We also seek confirmation that this part of the project in particular will be independently appraised and audited to ensure it is good value and achieves clearly defined objectives?

The second is about the genuineness of consultation. We note from the project plan published in the same document that the Congestion Charge Scheme is a complex and tightly driven project. Within this, a period of roughly three months is provided for consultation on the detailed scheme proposals, in the middle of this calendar year. What provision is being made to amend the scheme, or to abort it, in the light of public representations? Clearly, the extent to which consultation is genuine can be gauged by its ability to change in response to public views and concerns.

Thirdly, we note that the projected net surplus of the scheme when operating will be £168 million annually. This is clearly an attractive source of transport funding. However, the primary objective of the scheme is presented in your Draft Transport Strategy as being the reduction of congestion. Yet traffic within the zone is projected to decrease by only 15%, and outside of the zone to marginally increase in some areas. Can you assure us that the attraction of income is not clouding the need for a scheme that delivers real solutions to London's traffic problems? As a test of this can you indicate:

 your willingness to amend the scheme in the light of experience, even if this requires a loss of income
 your amenability to delaying its implementation, in the event that serious concerns arise in consultation that require amendments to it
 your amenability to operating a grace period on the scheme's introduction, in which period offenders would be sent notice of their infringement but would not incur a penalty. Such an 'amnesty' period has been tested elsewhere, such as where parking zones are introduced, and can increase public understanding and acceptance of a new traffic measure.

I await an early reply.

Sincerely

John Biggs
GLA Labour Transport Spokesperson

webTitle: 'Rent rises show Church is abandoning principles'

fields.headline: 'Rent rises show Church is abandoning principles'
fields.standfirst: The Church of England's Octavia Hill estates shine out as good examples of social housing, says the Rev Benny Hazlehurst, but the decision to charge tenants market rents means the Church is turning its back on its commitment to help people on low incomes
fields.trailText: The Church of England's Octavia Hill estates shine out as good examples of social housing, says the Rev Benny Hazlehurst, but the decision to charge tenants market rents means the Church is turning its back on its commitment to help people on low incomes.
fields.body:
Almost 100 years ago the Octavia Hill estates were built in London with a Christian vision of providing low cost, quality housing for people on low incomes.

Since that time, the Church Commissioners have continued to manage around 1,500 homes on these estates according to that vision. As a result, they have helped produced strong communities of local people in areas of considerable poverty, and have been a credit to the Church of England in its mission and vision.

These estates have never been seen by the commissioners simply as an investment. In 1904 and again in 1964, the commissioners clearly stated that by recognising their responsibility for large land ownership in London, it was appropriate to utilise some of it to provide affordable housing, a status acknowledged again in the 1998 annual report.

Now however, as the centenary of these estates approaches, there are signs of a shift in the commissioners' approach, which is causing great concern to local tenants and clergy.

The commissioners claim that their first duty is to seek to maximise returns on their assets and have therefore set out plans to commercialise the estate as part of an improvement plan. They propose to increase rents on over 1,000 of the homes to full market rents of up to £1,500 per month. The remaining 500 homes will be reserved for key workers but rents on these homes are still likely to rise.

In particular, the Octavia Hill estate in Walworth, which was the largest and most complete realisation of her vision, will be completely commercialised with no homes allocated for key workers, and all future vacancies being let out at full market rents.

The land on which these estates are built has been Church land for centuries, and by the 19th century most were leased out to landlords who were not particularly ethical or scrupulous in their dealings with their poorer tenants. Consequently the properties had degenerated into slums so bad that the Times and others accused the Church of being slum landlords themselves.

So a debate ensued about what to do when the leases expired. Highly influential in this debate was Octavia Hill. Heavily influenced by Christian Socialists, but with good political connections and wealthy friends, she had become a leading social campaigner in London for improved accommodation for the poor, open spaces, and improvements in public health and quality of life.

She had already formed a number of small housing societies for the poor with financial backing from her contacts. Miss Hill then persuaded the Ecclesiastical Commissioners that the right thing to do with their slum estates was to redevelop and use them to supply quality housing to the "industrious hardworking poor".

As a result the commissioners conceded their moral responsibility to set aside some land for what is now know as social housing. A 1904 report on the estates "recognised the moral obligation imposed upon the commissioners by the possession of very large areas of land that the claims of the working classes to be provided with healthy homes in places convenient for their occupations and at reasonable rents should not be neglected".

The report acknowledged that this task could not be trusted to private landlords so the commissioners asked Ms Hill herself to redevelop and manage these estates.

The 1904 report said that rents on the homes would be "fixed with a view to their being within the means of the class of persons for whom the accommodation is designed".

Since the early 1900's these estates have been managed with that vision, and strong local communities of people on low incomes have developed in areas of considerable poverty. These estates still shine out (on the whole) as good examples of social housing, and are sought after by local people.

But the proposed commercialisation will mean the wholesale abandonment to that vision.

At the very time when central and local government are seeking address issues of social exclusion, and the Church of England is being asked at all levels to support these initiatives, these proposals will exclude people on low incomes from Church properties. Social housing in all its forms is under immense pressure, with huge waiting lists and inadequate resources.

Furthermore, market rents of £1,000-£1,500 per month are not likely to attract long term tenants who would envisage settling down and bringing up their families there. What is much more likely is that young highly paid professionals will take up tenancies but will move out when they want to settle down.

Key worker rents that are being proposed (I estimate £400-600 per month) are too high to attract key workers to settle there long term, and I actually have serious doubts about whether they are low enough to be truly affordable to someone on income of, say £1,200 per month.

Recently, a classroom assistant at a local church school, living in overcrowded local authority housing inquired about a flat on one Octavia Hill estate but was unable to make a formal application because she knew she could not afford the £500 per month quoted to her.

With the exclusion of new tenants on low incomes, the effect on family members of existing tenants, and the introduction of market rents, I believe that the stability of these communities will be seriously undermined. The existing community will be gradually squeezed out by the commercialisation of the estates and the limits this will put on them.

Abandoning the Christian vision which created these estates and under which they have been managed for almost 100 years will also have a serious effect on the way in which the Church of England is perceived, both locally and nationally.

Clearly the commissioners first duty is to "seek maximum returns from [their] assets, consistent with ethical and practical guidelines". But if the commissioners have been able to be satisfied with a modest return on these estates for the past 100 years, then there is no substantial difference in their duties today which would require them to change this policy.

To argue any other position would be to accuse successive generations of commissioners of breaking the law and failing in their fiduciary responsibility.

The important point to recognise here is that the commissioners are not considering creating a new social housing project, or disposing of land at under market value. Such a course of action would now be prohibited under the Oxford judgment of 1991, when the commissioners opposed attempts by the Bishop of Oxford to ensure that ethical considerations play a greater role in their investment decisions.

What the commissioners are considering here is the changing of a very old, established policy, and even the Oxford judgment makes it clear that trustees are entitled to (if not required to) consider the effect of their decisions in these cases on the charity as a whole.

Furthermore the Oxford judgment provides a number of considerations under which the Commissioners may forgo maximising returns. For example it said: "Trustees are not required to behave in a fashion which would bring them or their charity into disrepute."

Any decision on the future of these estates which increases social exclusion, leads to the break-up of stable established communities, compromises the Church of England's mission and which could be perceived as greed by many of its existing financial donors, is bound to fall foul of the above criteria.

Clearly the rise in property values in inner London presents a temptation to increase the potential revenue from these estates. But to abandon a historic commitment and to dishonour the Christian vision which created these estates is too high a price to pay.

 Benny Hazelhurst is an estate outreach worker in Southwark and a member of the Church of England general synod

fields.headline: 'Rent rises will pay for projects with the poor'
fields.standfirst: Responding to claims that the Church of England has betrayed the poor  over its decision to raise rents on more  than 1,000 London homes that have had affordable rents for almost a century, Andrew Brown explains that the Church needs the money to support its work
fields.trailText: Responding to claims that the Church of England has betrayed the poor over its decision to raise rents on more than 1,000 London homes that have had affordable rents for almost a century, Andrew Brown explains that the Church needs the money to support its work
fields.body:
The truth is that the estates need rejuvenation and the commissioners believe their tenants should benefit from an improved environment.

The mayor of London's housing strategy also calls on all landlords to consider how it can provide homes for "key workers", many of whom cannot afford to live in the very city they serve. We are committed to doing our part.

We cannot rely on the wider Church to pay for renovating our estates. We must do it ourselves. The proposals will not affect rents paid by existing tenants.

The Church Commissioners are also not shying away from the fact that, after the improvements are set in train, the market rents will directly help support the Church's mission in poorer areas of England.

We are beginning an open consultation process, which is expected to take three months, after which the commissioners will take a formal decision about what shape the project will take.

 Andrew Brown is the Church of England's chief surveyor and head of property

fields.headline: Emap marketing chief joins Barclays
fields.trailText: Barclays has poached Emap marketing boss Simon Gulliford to become its first group marketing director.
fields.body:
Barclays has poached Emap marketing boss Simon Gulliford to become its first group marketing director.

Gulliford is quitting as marketing director of Emap Consumer Magazines, a position he has held since 1997, where he was responsible for FHM, Red and Heat.

He takes up the new role at Barclays on May 14.

At Barclays, Mr Gulliford will be responsible for developing and managing Barclays's overall brand positioning and marketing strategy along with the portfolio of the group's brands.

In addition to his group responsibilities, he will also take control of marketing across Barclays Retail Financial Services businesses.

He will report to chief administration officer Gary Dibb in his group-wide capacity and to deputy group chief executive John Stewart in his retail capacity.

"The Barclays Group has embarked on a complete overhaul of everything we do for customers to achieve superiority in service quality and value proposition," said Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays Group. "Simon brings deep and varied experience in marketing across a range of products and markets, a track record of building new products and businesses, proven commercial acumen as well as a deep understanding of brands.

"He will contribute a fresh perspective and innovative thinking as we transform Barclays into a customer-led organisation."

Mr Gulliford said: "At a time of unprecedented change within the financial services industry, brand and marketing strategy itself is undergoing profound transformation and has assumed greater importance for banks than ever before."

fields.headline: A little local difficulty
fields.standfirst: Greater centralisation is necessary if we want to avoid a postcode lottery for public services. But is it a price we are prepared to pay?
fields.trailText: Greater centralisation is necessary if we want to avoid a postcode lottery for public services. But is it a price we are prepared to pay?
fields.body:
Failures - real or perceived - in Britain's health service, schools, railways and, most recently, in the regulation of agriculture have led to demands for improved public provision and standards that more nearly equate to those enjoyed in other European countries. Overseas commentators cast baleful eyes over our waiting lists, derailments and pyres.

But spending is only part of the story. The distribution of services from area to area has become a matter of high politics. Regardless of whether the quality of services is up to scratch, we have seen successive governments struggle to ensure that there is a fair allocation of hospitals, universities and, now, publicly funded scientific research facilities around the country.

Throughout the 20th century governments refined the complex methods used to assist local authorities where property values were low, preventing them wielding the rates to pay for their spending. From 1945 new grants were paid to support schools and social services. In the 1970s, a resources allocation working party generated a formula that implied a major redistribution of health resources away from London to the rest of the country. The Thatcher and Major governments - perhaps without realising what they were doing - further refined the measurement of local government spending needs.

All this effort to pay grants to support councils and health authorities with high needs and/or low resources was largely to achieve a single objective: territorial equity. Today's public service agreements (PSAs) and the increased targeting of public resources through such schemes as Sure Start, designed to improve the lot of the disadvantaged, attest to the Blair government's desire to bring everywhere up to common standards of educational achievement, public health and even freedom from crime. The PSAs seek, by a given date, to secure minimum levels of achievement by all local authorities. Once again, the assumption is that wherever people live, they have a right to expect a minimum (or average) public service outcome.

The electorate's expectation that public service levels should be broadly similar throughout the country has led to frantic efforts to find distribution formulae and targeting methods that are "fair". The results of one such redistribution, for education, are shown in the chart. Poorer areas such as Manchester and Tower Hamlets get bigger needs assessments (and spending levels) for their schools than their richer counterparts Stockport and Richmond-upon-Thames. But don't the children deserve equal treatment? Few politicians of any party would be willing to defend the proposition that service levels should vary from one authority to another simply because the people who live there have different income or need levels.

Behind all this lies a profound question: do we need more centralisation in order to secure equal access to public services? It cannot be avoided any longer. Ministers feel they are under pressure to ensure that standards in schools, libraries, playing fields and transport are as equal as possible in every council, constituency and region. There must be no postcode lottery for operations, prescription drugs or, indeed, anything else.

But if we want this level of equal access to public services (whether or not it is actually achieved) is there any way of delivering it other than massive central intervention? In a new paper for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation* we have set out how, in the past, supporters of local government asserted that more local control and the freedom to determine taxation should be the main driver of the reform of council finance. Yet if local authorities were given such freedom, it would inevitably result in widening differences in local service provision and tax levels.

Ask yourself these questions. First, would it be acceptable for a child who lives on one side of a street to have access to a nursery school, while another on the opposite side (in a different council area) did not? In other words, should the accident of location dictate whether or not a three-year-old goes to a decent school or not? Is it acceptable if the City of Westminster council could have far higher service levels at the same time as setting far lower tax levels than any other council in the country (which is approximately the case)? The corollary of this is that Liverpool has far higher tax levels and considerably lower spending.

Unless the public accepts that it is reasonable for the three-year-old to go without a nursery place and for Westminster to be rich and low-taxed, it is hard to see how central meddling and control can be avoided. For a number of reasons, the British have come to expect far greater efforts to achieve territorial equity than virtually any other advanced country.

Studies show that measures taken by the centre to secure "equalisation" in local authority services are complex and sophisticated. Similar central formulae are used to allocate money for health, what is now called learning and skills (until recently further education and the training and enterprise councils), universities and now the regional development agencies. Within council areas themselves formulae are used to allocated money school by school.

As the government ponders the future of public provision - its own future - it needs to think seriously about whether it wants to have local variation between essential services. Other countries manage to get by with rather less top-down central control. On the other hand, expectations in those countries do not extend to all-embracing demands for precise territorial equity.

As the public expenditure machine pushes the new money announced last July into hospitals, schools and transport, perhaps we should stop to wonder whether our extreme centralisation is a price we really want to pay for our aspirations of fairness.

*A new account? Choices in Local Government Finance, by Gerry Stoker and Tony Travers, Joseph Rowntree Foundation, to be published April 27

A.Travers@lse.ac.uk

fields.headline: The European Rapid Reaction Force
fields.standfirst:
A House of Commons committee has described plans for a European rapid reaction force as confused and lacking democratic accountability. Derek Brown, Guardian correspondent in Brussels from 1983 to 1987, explains

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
What do the MPs say?
The foreign affairs committee says that the planned new force is mired in contradictions with existing commitments to Nato by most EU states. In particular, MPs have latched onto a pledge by EU leaders to deploy the new force only "where Nato as a whole is not engaged".
fields.body:
What do the MPs say?
The foreign affairs committee says that the planned new force is mired in contradictions with existing commitments to Nato by most EU states. In particular, MPs have latched onto a pledge by EU leaders to deploy the new force only "where Nato as a whole is not engaged".

Why should Nato be worried about the new force?
Nato as a whole isn't, but the Americans are. Washington fears that its influence over European strategic defence thinking may be diluted. The US is particularly concerned about French insistence that the EU should have an independent military planning apparatus, which could draw on military resources presently at the disposal of Nato.

Is the new Commons report a Tory plot to subvert an EU initiative?
No. The committee is dominated by Labour members.

Is the EU force really such a radical idea?
It's as old as the EU itself. After the European Community became a Union thanks to the Maastricht Treaty of December 1991, member states agreed to adopt a common foreign and security policy. It has been an uphill struggle: the formal decision to create a rapid reaction force (ERRF) was taken only in December 1999.

Is it the start of a European army?
Yes, say the Eurosceptics. No, say the people actually doing it. Tory critics seem especially worried about the notion that troops in the force will be obliged to wear a common EU badge on their uniforms. Supporters of the ERRF point out that it is not a standing army, and that national governments will retain the power to decide if their forces will take part in any particular operation.

Who will be in command?
The first director general of the small central headquarters will be a German, Lieutenant General Rainer Schuwirth. His deputy will be a Briton, Major-General Graham Messervy-Whiting.

How big will it be?
Up to 60,000 soldiers will be contributed by member states, to come together for specific operations and for training. The biggest contingent will be from Germany, which has promised to make at least 13,500 troops available. France is offering around 12,000; Italy and Spain 6000; the Netherlands 5000; Greece 3000; Finland and Sweden 2000 each; Belgium, Ireland and Portugal 1000 each, and Luxembourg 500.

And Britain?
The government is likely to offer up to 12,500 troops, plus a sizeable chunk of the Royal Navy and up to 72 combat aircraft. Some military analysts believe that a full scale commitment to the force would involve 24,000 personnel from all three services.

What will the ERRF actually do?
It will have three main roles. One is to give assistance to civilians threatened by a crisis outside the EU. Another is to respond to UN calls for peacekeeping forces. The third is to intervene to separate warring factions. In all three scenarios the EU would deploy its forces only if Nato decides not to get involved.

But isn't this precisely Nato's job?
Critics are worried that the creation of the ERRF will undermine Nato, discourage American involvement in European peacekeeping operations and that endanger Britain's special relationship with Washington. Supporters of the new force say exactly the same. That, they say, is why it's a good thing.

And what is Washington saying?
There have been rumbles of unease in the State Department and in the military establishment, which, for more than half a century, has ruled the Nato roost. But there is also a widespread view in America that Europe should do more - and pay more - towards its own defence interests. The deployment of US forces in the Balkans is especially unpopular.

Why should Europe be paying attention to Washington?
Nato is a huge element in European defences and America is a huge element in Nato. None but the most the most fervent Europhiles would want to drive the US out. But many think that Europe should indeed be forging a defence strategy based more on common European interests, and less on the transatlantic connection.

Why the new urgency?
During the US presidential campaign, George Bush revived echoes of isolationism by suggesting that, if elected, he would make a priority of removing American forces from the Balkans. Though he has trimmed his position and reassured America's Nato allies that there will be no hasty decision, European defence planners have taken the hint.

fields.headline: Guardiola to leave Barcelona
fields.trailText: Pep Guardiola has announced he will leave Barcelona at the end of the season.
fields.body:
Pep Guardiola has announced he will leave Barcelona at the end of the season.

"I'm going to see out my career abroad," Guardiola told a press conference at the Nou Camp. "It's not an easy decision to make but after weighing things up I think it's for the best."

Guardiola has already been linked with a move to the Premiership. This morning, Newcastle manager Bobby Robson told the Star: "If the Barcelona skipper Josep Guardiola was willing to leave Spain and we could afford him, I think he'd be prepared to join Newcastle."

The 30-year-old playmaker has been at Barca since he was 14, breaking into the B team in 1989. He has been a regular in the Barcelona and Spanish national teams ever since.

The highlight of his career came in 1992, when he won the European Cup with his club and the gold medal in his "home" Olympics.

fields.headline: Rivals refuse to copy Express tactics
fields.trailText:
12.15pm update: Trinity Mirror and Associated say they will not give papers away through WH Smith, reports Jessica Hodgson.
8.30am: Express promotion angers rivals
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror and Associated Newspapers have said they will not - in the short term - follow the Express by giving away free newspapers through WH Smith.

"We are not interested in negotiating or brokering a sampling deal with WH Smith at all," said Nick Inkpen, circulation manager of Trinity Mirror.

He refused to confirm or deny whether WH Smith had offered Trinity Mirror the opportunity to do an identical deal, saying only there had been "a conversation" with WH Smith about promotions.

His statement contradicts remarks made yesterday by WH Smith insiders, who appeared to be fairly confident a similar sampling deal would be done with the Mirror.

Meanwhile, an Associated Newspapers circulation executive said: "We would have to decide whether it's coherent with our long-term strategy.

"At this point in time, it would not be."

fields.headline: Street-Porter quits Sindy
fields.trailText: 12pm:Janet Street-Porter is to step down as editor of the Independent on Sunday after the election, the newspaper confirmed today. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Janet Street-Porter is to step down as editor of the Independent on Sunday after the general election, the newspaper confirmed today.

Ms Street-Porter leaves after two years on the paper.

It is expected that Chris Blackhurst, former deputy editor of the Daily Express, will take over.

Ms Street-Porter will take on a new role as editor-at-large of the Sunday paper, contributing a weekly column and regular feature articles from home and abroad as well as writing for the daily paper.

Ms Street-Porter, 54, said: "I have thoroughly enjoyed my two years as editor of the Independent on Sunday and would like to thank all the staff for their support.

"I am looking forward to my new role with great enthusiasm."

Simon Kelner, editor-in-chief, said: "I am very grateful to Janet for all her hard work as editor of the Sunday paper over the past two years.

"I am delighted we have been able to persuade her to continue to work with us in her new role as editor-at-large."

The appointment of the new editor will be confirmed shortly.

Ms Street-Porter set up Channel 4's influential teenage magazine Network 7 in 1986 and was the BBC's head of youth from 1988.

In 1995 she worked with Kelvin MacKenzie to start up Live TV, a 24-hour network focusing on celebrities and fun lifestyles.

fields.headline: Express promotion angers rivals
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Daily Express has boosted its sales figures in a deal with WH Smith in which the newsagent gave copies away free. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Daily Express has been boosting its circulation figures in an extraordinary deal with WH Smith in which the newsagent "buys" copies of the paper and then gives them away free to anyone who buys a magazine.

The deal has enraged rival papers including the Daily Mail and the Mirror and could take the mid-market tabloid circulation wars to a new height.

One baffled Guardian reader who contacted MediaGuardian.co.uk was flabbergasted when the cashier at the WH Smith till asked her if she would like a free copy of the paper.

"When I said okay, she charged me 35p for it and then gave me my money back. However on the receipt it was still listed as a sale," she said.

In a week-long promotion starting on April 2, WH Smith is believed to have spent £10,000 a day on copies of the Daily Express to give away as a promotion free with any magazine purchase.

In an unprecedented promotion the paper was given away free with any magazine purchased.

And because this falls within ABC rules, the sale will be recorded as a "bulk sale" figure and will be counted as part of the Express's overall sales.

Martyn Gates, the ABC's director of newspapers and consumer press, said that technically the promotion was "quite legitimate".

But he added that the WH Smith promotion would not be separated from other bulk newspaper sales in the published figures.

This means newspapers, consumers, advertisers and agencies will have no way to tell how the promotion has boosted the paper's circulation.

"I think that the use of bulk sales will be more and more debated," said Mr Gates when asked whether the ABC thought this was a legitimate promotional tactic.

"If you want to start splitting bulk sales out so there's more transparency then that is certainly something we can do," he said. "This promotion would certainly move the debate in that direction."

The inclusion of "bulk" sales - sales to hotels, airlines and other companies - in a newspaper's circulation figure has proved controversial as critics claim they distort perceptions of the market.

Sales of the Express fell below 1m in January for the first time since 1924.

Mr Desmond is desperate to boost circulation to take on the Daily Mail, which had an audited circulation of 2,394,889 in March.

WH Smith is understood to have mooted the deal in a bid to boost their end of month magazine sales.

Mike Newman, director of circulation at Associated Newspapers, denied that Associated was annoyed that WH Smith had approached Express Newspapers first.

"These figures will be included in the bulks, but they will be short-term rises," he said.

Asked whether Associated would be interested in running a similar promotion, he said "the ball is definitely in Smith's court."

WH Smith refused to comment.
fields.bodyText: The Daily Express has been boosting its circulation figures in an extraordinary deal with WH Smith in which the newsagent "buys" copies of the paper and then gives them away free to anyone who buys a magazine. The deal has enraged rival papers including the Daily Mail and the Mirror and could take the mid-market tabloid circulation wars to a new height. One baffled Guardian reader who contacted MediaGuardian.co.uk was flabbergasted when the cashier at the WH Smith till asked her if she would like a free copy of the paper. "When I said okay, she charged me 35p for it and then gave me my money back. However on the receipt it was still listed as a sale," she said. In a week-long promotion starting on April 2, WH Smith is believed to have spent £10,000 a day on copies of the Daily Express to give away as a promotion free with any magazine purchase. In an unprecedented promotion the paper was given away free with any magazine purchased. And because this falls within ABC rules, the sale will be recorded as a "bulk sale" figure and will be counted as part of the Express's overall sales. Martyn Gates, the ABC's director of newspapers and consumer press, said that technically the promotion was "quite legitimate". But he added that the WH Smith promotion would not be separated from other bulk newspaper sales in the published figures. This means newspapers, consumers, advertisers and agencies will have no way to tell how the promotion has boosted the paper's circulation. "I think that the use of bulk sales will be more and more debated," said Mr Gates when asked whether the ABC thought this was a legitimate promotional tactic. "If you want to start splitting bulk sales out so there's more transparency then that is certainly something we can do," he said. "This promotion would certainly move the debate in that direction." The inclusion of "bulk" sales - sales to hotels, airlines and other companies - in a newspaper's circulation figure has proved controversial as critics claim they distort perceptions of the market. Sales of the Express fell below 1m in January for the first time since 1924. Mr Desmond is desperate to boost circulation to take on the Daily Mail, which had an audited circulation of 2,394,889 in March. WH Smith is understood to have mooted the deal in a bid to boost their end of month magazine sales. Mike Newman, director of circulation at Associated Newspapers, denied that Associated was annoyed that WH Smith had approached Express Newspapers first. "These figures will be included in the bulks, but they will be short-term rises," he said. Asked whether Associated would be interested in running a similar promotion, he said "the ball is definitely in Smith's court." WH Smith refused to comment.

webTitle: Interview with Mexican director Robert Rodriguez

fields.headline: 'I'm probably the only guy who really enjoys being in the movies'
fields.standfirst: Robert Rodriguez, director of From Dusk Till Dawn and the smash hit Spy Kids, talks to  Will Hodgkinson
fields.trailText: Robert Rodriguez, director of From Dusk Till Dawn and the smash hit Spy Kids, talks to Will Hodgkinson
fields.body:
Discovering that Robert Rodriguez, director of such postmodern blood'n'guts classics as El Mariachi, Desperado and From Dusk Till Dawn, has made a children's movie is rather like finding out that Sam Peckinpah once had an option on the sequel to Bambi. It just doesn't seem right.

But after seeing Spy Kids, Rodriguez's Willy Wonka-meets-James Bond tale of the children of retired spies who follow in their parents' footsteps and end up saving their lives, it begins to make sense. All Rodriguez's films, even the ones where everyone dies at the end, suggest he's the sort of person who checks for secret doorways whenever entering someone's house. Spy Kids, now topping the charts in America and about to open in the UK, is simply that mind revealed in perfect clarity.

"This is the kind of movie I used to make before Mariachi for 10 years, from the age of 12," he explains. "I'm from a family of 10 kids, and I always used to put my siblings in my movies because they were there. And the films would always win contests - people loved the combination of little kids doing action and comedy. The only reason Mariachi was an action movie was that the Spanish video market, which it was originally made for, wanted action. Even then we made it goofy - it was about a guitar guy, not an ex-cop or a road warrior type. If you watch this and then see the other movies, you can see how similar they are in tone, in the way that nobody could take them seriously."

Rodriguez's career sounds a lot more fun than that of most Hollywood directors. Having rented his body for medical tests to fund El Mariachi while still at film school, Rodriguez shot the film in a Mexican border town with no crew and no professional actors and relied on a lot of favours to make it happen.

For the opening sequence, set in a jail, the warders took all the prisoners outside so he could shoot inside the cells. (One prisoner made the most of the situation and bolted.) He says the whole thing cost $7,000. The Spanish never bought the film, but Columbia Studios did, and since then Rodriguez has resisted the lure of the big-budget movie to make films that cost next to nothing, on condition he has complete artistic freedom - almost unheard of in Hollywood.

"Even with Spy Kids, the same approach I took with Mariachi applies," says Rodriguez. "Inspector Gadget cost $90m, 102 Dalmatians was $85m, and this was $36m, with more than a third of the movie being effects. The first person you usually hire on an effects-based movie like this is an effects supervisor. I didn't - I wanted to figure out how to do it myself. It's just a case of being more creative: it looks like an expensive movie, but it's all magic tricks. I edited it in my garage, and it had to feel personal or it would be like one of those studio-made kids' movies that are just awful. It's a big home movie, basically."

Rodriguez is still determined to keep it personal. On his second movie, 1994's Roadracers, he got a crew, and didn't like it. "I thought, why are all these guys standing around doing nothing? I'd rather have the money to buy more time and get rid of them. And even though I produce my pictures now, there's still too many people. But now the studio just gives me the money and I go make the movie, and I use so little of their money they don't gripe."

When El Mariachi came out in 1992, Rodriguez was asked how on earth he could make an action film for $7,000; now all he's asked is how he could make Spy Kids for $36m. It all comes down, he says, to growing up in the kind of family where every cent was accounted for. "We always figured out how to get around spending money in our house - it was in our blood. Now I can't even spend other people's money."

When Columbia first signed up Rodriguez and gave him a $2,000 weekly allowance for a smart Hollywood hotel and expensive restaurants, he asked if he could sleep on his office floor, eat burgers and keep the money to put his brother through college. "Film-makers screw themselves when they think they need to get as much money as they can," says Rodriguez. "The studio starts changing things to make sure it gets its money back, the film-maker ends up compromising it so much that he hates it, and the audience thinks it sucks, so it's no good for anybody."

Rodriguez has turned down a series of big-budget movies - X-Men, Superman Lives and Planet of the Apes - because "they weren't going to be fun", and gone back to his roots. El Mariachi was always intended as the first film in a series of three; Desperado was the second in 1995, but since then nothing has been heard from the music man. Finally he's coming back. "We're making it - I was writing it in bed this morning. Antonio Banderas is in it, and it's kind of The Good, the Bad and the Ugly of the Mariachi series, a big, sprawling movie called Once Upon a Time in Mexico. It's awesome. I can't wait."

Even El Mariachi himself, Carlos Gallardo, is to return to star and direct in a film Rodriguez wrote for him. "It's called Curandero, and he's a Mexican witch doctor. It goes into the bowels of black magic in Mexico City. Anything goes there - it's so cool."

All this from the mind of a big kid, who admits freely that the little boy in Spy Kids - nervous, physically awkward, lost in his own world - was based on himself at that age. Rodriguez is living proof that never growing up can have its advantages. "I'm probably the only guy who really enjoys being in the business, because I get to make my own rules. I cut my own trailers, make my own ads, live and work at home in Texas... It's ridiculous. What did I do in a past life?"

 Spy Kids is released on Friday.

webTitle: Cleverly conjuring up a new notion of public services

fields.headline: Cleverly conjuring up a new notion of public services
fields.standfirst: Language is increasingly being distorted to change the concept of public services and alter its role from promoting the common good into that of a business
fields.trailText: Sanjiv Sachdev: Language is increasingly being cleverly distorted to change the notion of public services and alter its role from promoting the common good into that of a business.
fields.body:
The language of public service is changing. Last week, Kirklees metropolitan council became the first local education authority to take an equity stake in a private finance initiative scheme. In local government, "equity" used to have connotations of fairness and social justice. But will it increasingly come to mean stakes in profit and loss accounts?

As the general election approaches, a consensus seems to have emerged. The logic of the market appears to have triumphed. The new orthodoxy proclaims that the public sector should function in the same way as a business. The notion that the public sector is a cooperative venture to promote the common good is banished to the margins. A new language and vocabulary accompanies this shift.

Words matter. George Orwell wrote of the connection between dubious thoughts and the corruption of language, of "the long, vague words [that] express the intended meaning and at the same time blur the moral squalor of what is being said". Language can be used to cloak unpalatable truths and obscure realities. Market imperatives not only degrade the values of public service, they also debase its language.

The lexicon of the market abounds with euphemism and evasion. Thus the French (socialist) government uses the term "capital opening" instead of privatisation. In practice, staff "flexibility" has often meant insecurity and short-term contracts (13% of council workers are on temporary contracts, nearly double the rate in the economy as a whole).

"Efficiencies" and "cost savings" in competitive tendering have really meant cutting staff hours, bonus payments and pension provision. "Value for money" has meant cost considerations have taken precedence over those of quality. The competitive tendering system introduced a plethora of terms - outsourcing, sub-contracting, market testing, externalisation and contracting out - for essentially the same activity.

The critic Raymond Williams noted that: "Community unlike all other terms of social organisation seems never to be used unfavourably." Hence, the preference for "community charge" over "poll tax" and the liberal use of "community" in policy documents. The same can be said of "partnership", a warmly persuasive word that is difficult to contest or object to. Yet so-called "private-public partnerships" endanger the very basis of public service provision.

The report of the national policy forum to the last Labour party conference reflects the new vocabulary. It states that: "Public services need to meet the rising expectations of their customers and the wider community." The "customer" replaces the "citizen". Passengers, viewers, students and patients are all homogenised into customers, who, presumably, consume "products".

But the importance of customers is that they spend. The capacity to be a citizen should not depend upon spending power. Whether such terms are appropriate for health, personal social services and education are highly questionable. An accident victim lying in accident and emergency is not in a position to be a "knowing" consumer making decisions as a customer, nor are most of us when we are vulnerable and in need of health and social care support.

But, more importantly, sound public services are not products to be consumed. They have a value beyond that which the market places upon them, they represent the values of a civilised society. Reducing all this to a cash relationship distorts and impoverishes the service and the user.

As the US academic Benjamin Barber notes: "Education is unlikely ever to win an 'open market' competition with entertainment because 'easy' and 'hard' can never compete on equal ground To grow into our mature better selves we need the help of our nascent better selves, which is what common standards, authoritative education and a sense of the public good can offer. Consumption takes us as it finds us, the more impulsive and greedy the better."

Public services have their root in shielding citizens from the vagaries of the market, promoting values that were often at odds with the market - equity among them. That is eroding. The assumptions of the market are commonplace. Being alert to and challenging the new language is difficult. Yet, without such awareness, the decay of distinctive qualities of public service will continue.

 Sanjiv Sachdev is a senior lecturer in human resources management at Kingston University.

fields.headline: Blair to meet farmers' leaders
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was facing farmers' leaders today amid fury at government suggestions they may be to blame for the rapid spread of foot and mouth.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was facing farmers' leaders today amid fury at government suggestions they may be to blame for the rapid spread of foot and mouth.

The prime minister was expected to meet farmers' leaders, tourism bosses, vets and the army in Devon this afternoon to see how the fight against the disease had progressed since his visit last month.

Mr Blair's visit comes as David Hill, chairman of the National Farmers' Union (NFU) in Devon, said he would rather people broke the law by moving animals than let them suffer and die in confinement.

Mr Hill told this morning's edition of BBC Radio 4's Farming Today that he "could not condemn" farmers who moved animals illegally rather than see them dying in appalling conditions. "I would rather they did that than let animals suffer," he said.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) said today that while 50,000 licenses for movement had been granted and that there was sensitivity to welfare issues, farmers must desist from illegal moves. The spokesman added farmers must observe the "tightest possible precautions".

The row over who is to blame for the epidemic erupted after a leaked report, drafted for Mr Blair, showed farmers had taken part in hundreds of unlicensed livestock movements since the start of the outbreak.

A few desperate farmers were even suspected of deliberately infecting their flocks with foot and mouth disease in order to claim compensation. Trading standards officers have investigated 309 cases of alleged illegal livestock movements since the outbreak began, it emerged yesterday.

West Mercia police also announced an inquiry into alleged fraudulent compensation claims involving unauthorised animal movements. The NFU south west regional director, Anthony Gibson, said there was no justification for blaming farmers and accused ministers of trying to "take the heat off themselves".

He said: "They have been making these insinuations almost from the start of the epidemic, suggesting it was farmers themselves who were responsible for spreading the disease rather than their own incompetence for not bringing it under control."

Mr Blair was likely to face a similar message during his visit today, which comes as ministers launch an action plan to boost employment in stricken areas.

With London's royal parks reopening to pedestrians and the culture secretary, Chris Smith, meeting tourism chiefs in London, Mr Blair was expected to say there were bright spots.

But the Tory leader, William Hague, warned thousands of tourist firms face bankruptcy after the Easter break because of government inaction and he argued interest-free loans need to be made available now.

There were 41 new outbreaks recorded across Britain yesterday bringing the total number throughout the UK to 1,205.

Meanwhile, the organisers of Scotland's premier agricultural event, the Royal Highland Show which attracted 150,000 people last year, were today expected to decide whether or not it will go ahead as planned this year.

Elsewhere, firefighters in County Durham who were called to a blazing municipal skip found it contained lambs which had been deliberately set alight, a brigade spokesman said today.

fields.headline: Vauxhall puts brakes on Rhys-Jones
fields.trailText: 12pm: Vauxhall may ditch Griff Rhys-Jones after his advert was voted worst of the year by an industry magazine, Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Vauxhall may ditch Griff Rhys-Jones after his advert was voted worst of the year by an industry magazine.

Sources say the campaign, in which Rhys-Jones plays a mad professor, is facing the axe just two years into a three-year contract.

Rhys-Jones is thought to earn £600,000 a year from the adverts.

"At the moment Rhys-Jones is still appearing in our adverts. What will happen in the future is still being decided," said a Vauxhall spokeswoman.

Media coverage has been unrelentingly negative, and last year, Campaign magazine voted it worst commercial of the year.

The Telegraph's motoring correspondent went so far as to say that Vauxhall "could readily be accused of having taken careful aim at its own left foot, and smartly pulling the trigger" for continuing with the campaign.

Rhys-Jones was introduced in November 1999 to introduce more continuity to advertising for the brand.

But sales have faltered since the campaign began. Sales fell nearly 13%, from 49,219 in September 1999 to 43,880 last year.

webTitle: In brief: Gangs of New York shoot about to wrap

fields.headline: Gangs of New York shoot about to wrap
fields.standfirst: Plus: Widow of killed stuntman sues Proof of Life backers; Brooke Shields marries; O finally set for US release; Steven Seagal redeems himself in song
fields.trailText: Plus: Widow of killed stuntman sues Proof of Life backers; Brooke Shields marries; O finally set for US release; Steven Seagal redeems himself in song
fields.body:
 Miramax chairman Harvey Weinstein arrives in Rome this morning to oversee the final days of Martin Scorsese's turbulent production of The Gangs of New York. "It's the most expensive movie ever made by Miramax - $90m (£62.64m)," Weinstein told reporters, although many insiders privately estimate that the film's cost has far outstripped its agreed budget. A tale of Italian immigrants and the genesis of the American Mafia, The Gangs of New York has been hit by on-set accidents and rumoured tensions between Scorsese and star Leonardo DiCaprio. The film finally wraps on Friday and is due for a US release this Christmas. "On Saturday we go to the synagogue and pray we have a hit," says Weinstein.

 The widow of a stand-in who died on the set of the Russell Crowe thriller Proof of Life is suing the film's backers - Castle Rock and Warner Bros - for negligence. William P Gaffney was standing in for the actor David Morse when the truck he was travelling in plummeted into a ravine while filming in Ecuador. His widow, Karine, claims that filming conditions were unsafe and recent admissions by the film's director and actors may have inadvertently lent weight to her charge. In promoting the movie, director Taylor Hackford admitted that conditions were "no Cole Porter cocktail party." Meanwhile co-star David Caruso claimed that: "Taylor is very interested in authenticity. We probably could have filmed in Central Park, but he wanted the location to be a rough one."

 Brooke Shields has married her TV writer boyfriend Chris Henchy, it was announced yesterday. The actress wed in a private ceremony last Wednesday on Catalina Island, off the coast of California. In recent years Shields has largely worked on TV, though she did have a small role as a dreadlocked documentary film-maker in last year's Black and White.

 The controversial Othello update O has been sold by Dimension Films to Lions Gate, who plan to release it in the US in August. Directed by Tim Blake Nelson, the film was completed two years ago but was sidelined in the wake of the Columbine massacre. The picture climaxes with a killing at an American high school (see earlier story).

 Square-jawed action hero Steven Seagal is taking a break from machine-gunning international drug dealers in favour of making sweet music. The Exit Wounds star is currently in Kingston, Jamaica, recording his debut album with the aid of producer Wyclef Jean. "Doing movies took up all my time, but music has always been my first love," says Seagal, whose album will include a cover version of Bob Marley's Redemption Song.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 13
fields.trailText: April 13: RTL is fighting to keep Pearson Television International chief executive Brian Harris and president Joe Abrams.
fields.body:
RTL is fighting to stop Pearson Television International chief executive Brian Harris and president Joe Abrams from leaving over programme strategy.

Independent TV producer RDF Television has sold a stake - believed to be 20-25% - to venture capitalist Sagitta Private Equity for £3.2m, valuing the company at around £15m.

Channel 5's hopes of relaunching its peaktime schedule have been dashed after the Independent Television Commission blocked the proposed move of its main news bulletin to 5.30pm.

Ardent Productions chairman Malcolm Cockren has rejected calls for Prince Edward, the company's managing director, to resign in the wake of the recent "Sophiegate" debacle.

Speculation Sky is poised to dump its interactive shopping brand Open has been mounting this week following news Open managing director Jon Florsheim has taken on a senior role at Sky Television.
