webTitle: Shock jocks tamed as public tunes out

fields.headline: Shock jocks tamed as public tunes out
fields.standfirst: Radio regulators are cleaning up the American airwaves, reports Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: Radio regulators are cleaning up the American airwaves, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
"This idiot should choke on his own vomit," is one listener's suggestion about a guest on Howard Stern's syndicated morning radio show.

Howard himself is full of scorn for the guest, someone called Frank who claims to be the reincarnation of Jimi Hendrix, mocking him for the "crap" he's talking.

A cab driver calls in with his own views of Howard: "I want to kick your ass, you know-nothing, crazy guy."

Howard Stern, America's best-known shock jock, is used to pushing his radio talk show to the limits. But now someone may indeed be about to kick his ass - metaphorically at least.

New guidelines are being issued in an attempt to clean up the American airwaves, which have become increasingly raunchy and explicit.

"Understandably the public is outraged by the increasingly coarse content aired on radio and television at all hours of the day, including times when children are most likely to be watching or listening," the federal communications commissioner, Susan Ness, told Variety this week.

"The flood of letters and email we receive reflects a high degree of anger. Despite an onslaught of on-air smut, the commission necessarily walks a delicate line when addressing content issues and must be careful not to tread on the First Amendment."

But new guidelines will be issued nonetheless. In the future, presenters must not go in for explicit or graphic conversation or deliberately titillate their listeners between 6am and 10pm, when children are most likely to be tuned in.

Misbehaving stations will face fines or could even be taken off the air for breaking the rules.

But yesterday morning Howard was pulling no punches as he engaged in his standard verbal badinage with callers. "Oh, for God's sake! Stop acting like a 12-year-old," he tells one listener to his syndicated show.

And he is followed on the 97.1 FM Talk station in LA by a trio of presenters including a woman who talks about how much better she looks in the nude if it's cold.

However, just as the Feds are starting to take action comes a sign that listeners are getting weary of the self-consciously shocking jocks and are taking action themselves. One of the big radio success stories of recent weeks is that of comedian Steve Harvey who has become a presenter at KKBT-FM, the LA station called the Beat.

Harvey was one of the stars of Spike Lee's documentary film, The Original Kings of Comedy, which was by no means tame. But he eschews the normal shock-jock style in favour of a less obvious routine.

In six months he has taken the station's morning show from 19th in the ratings to fourth - an astonishing achievement in radio - and his fans say that one of the reasons they tune is is because Harvey avoids all the now predictable "dangerous" stuff that shock-jocks use.

But is Howard Stern likely to change his ways? That would be a real shock.

fields.headline: Wednesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours have lost a multi-million pound court case against their former accountant
fields.trailText: "L'enfer du Nord: Paris - Roubaix / Tour de Rumour, Tour de Rumour / La Cote d'Azur et Saint Tropez / Tour de Rumour, Tour de Rumour / Les Alpes et les Pyrennees / Tour de Rumour, Tour de Rumour / Derniere etape Champs-Elysees / Tour de Rumour, Tour de Rumour"
fields.body:
The Spanish press are suggesting that Barcelona striker Patrick Kluivert has signed a pre-agreement to join Chelsea this summer. The Dutch marksman is reported to be asking the Catalan giants for £4m next season, but Barcelona are only prepared to offer him a paltry £3m.

The interest has put Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's Stamford Bridge future in doubt. He could be heading to Barcelona in a swap in a deal with Kluivert. But Real Madrid are also reported to be interested and may bid £20m to bring the Chelsea striker back to the Primera Division, where he was top scorer for Atletico Madrid last season.

Aston Villa keeper David James is reported to be a £5m target for Barcelona. The Sun says that James is on a shortlist of three to become Jose Reina's deputy. Meanwhile, the Mirror claim that James has been taking Spanish lessons, although the former Liverpool keeper says that he is only learning the language so he can converse with Juan Pablo Angel. James was keen to dismiss the rumours, saying: "I'm happy here and I can see the club going places."

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson insists that although his club will not playing in Europe next season, the Magpies still have all the pulling power of the big boys. "We're not afraid of going out and buying anyone," he told the Star. "If the Barcelona skipper Josep Guardiola was willing to leave Spain and we could afford him, I think he'd be prepared to join Newcastle."

Meanwhile, Robson insists that Newcastle favourite Kieron Dyer is going nowhere, despite reported interest from Leeds, say Teamtalk. Dyer also attracted the attention of Liverpool and Manchester United before injury ruined his season, with Newcastle rumoured to be hoping to cash in on up to £20m for the former England international - a massive mark-up on the £6m they paid Ipswich for his services in July 1999. But Robson insisted: "We have no intention of selling Dyer. We want to build the Newcastle team of the future around him and the chairman is in complete agreement."

Southampton caretaker manager Stuart Gray is ready to offer Saints reject and Fulham success story Luis Boa Morte another chance to prove himself at the Dell. Boa Morte has signed 19 goals for Fulham this season where he has been on loan, and Craven Cottage boss Jean Tigana is keen to make the move permanent. But Southampton still hold his registration and Gray said: "He's the sort of player we could perhaps do with having around."

Meanwhile, Southampton veteran Francis Benali is due for a return to the club, says the Star, because Nottingham Forest cannot afford to make his loan move permanent. The 32-year-old defender said: "It looks like I'll be heading back to the Dell because Forest don't seem to be in a position to sort something out."

The Daily Star report that Middlesbrough's swoop for Slovakia striker Szilard Nemeth has hit problems, even before the ink has dried on the striker's £7.5m deal. His £30,000 a week contract is in doubt because he fails to meet the criteria for a work permit. Nemeth, 23, has not been a regular in the Slovakia senior team for two years as required.

webTitle: Brando "flat-out comic" in Scary Movie sequel

fields.headline: Brando "flat-out comic" in Scary Movie sequel
fields.trailText: The legendary star is to make a cameo appearance in Scary Movie 2 for a reported fee of $1m
fields.body:
The freewheeling career of the mighty Marlon Brando looks set to take a further twist this week with the news that the revered method actor is set to cameo in Dimension Films' Scary Movie 2, the sequel to last year's spoof horror hit. The 77-year-old star will play the role of a priest who performs "supernatural exorcisms" and will pocket a reported $1m (£696,000) for the pleasure.

Dimension co-chairman Bob Weinstein could hardly contain his excitement as he broke the scoop: "In an unprecedented move, Dimension Films has landed movie icon Marlon Brando in a wild, comedic turn." Weinstein added that Brando was persuaded after discovering "a kinship with his brand of comedy" during a meeting with Scary Movie creator Keenen Ivory Wayans. But could it be that Dimension are getting a little ahead of themselves? Spokesmen for the actor have yet to officially confirm the reports.

According to Weinstein, the Scary Movie 2 cameo will mark Brando's "first flat-out comic role". But the Oscar-winning star of On the Waterfront and The Godfather has clearly been doing some homework. Eyewitness accounts from the set of his latest film The Score described the acting heavyweight wandering on-set stripped naked from the waist down and startling co-star Robert De Niro with a remote-control whoopie cushion (see earlier story). Can a live Marlon Brando stand-up show be that far behind?

 More about Marlon Brando.

fields.headline: Elton John loses court case
fields.trailText: Sir Elton John today lost a multimillion pound high court case over tour costs he claims he should not have paid.
fields.body:
Sir Elton John today lost a multimillion pound high court case over tour costs he claims he should not have paid.

Mr Justice Ferris ruled against the singer in a 138-page judgment, following a hearing which lasted 43 days over three months and ended on February 1, when he reserved his decision. The singer now faces a legal costs bill of around £8m.

53-year-old Sir Elton was suing Andrew Haydon, former managing director of John Reid Enterprises (JREL) - for many years the singer's management company, and City accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, which looked after his business interests.

He alleged that Mr Haydon, 45, was negligent in allowing JREL to charge him for overseas tour expenses, including booking agents, accountants and producers.

Sir Elton contended that the "several millions" which he paid out in touring expenses should have been borne by JREL under a management agreement

PricewaterhouseCoopers was accused by Sir Elton of negligence in managing his affairs. Both defendants vigorously contested the allegations made against them.

Sir Elton was not present as he is currently on tour in America.

webTitle: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Lack of holiday affinity

The good news is that the office of fair trading (OFT) has announced that it is prepared to start legal action against four major tour operators to force them to disclose details of their cancellation charges. (Currently travellers who change their holiday plans are charged the full price of their package regardless of whether the firm manages to sell it on.)

Sadly, the OFT's wrath comes too late to help Molly Bordill, a widowed pensioner from Stockport. She was telephoned unexpectedly by a company called Affinity Holidays which offered her a 70% discount on a trip to Florida. Alas, when asked for her credit card details she relayed them (oh readers, when will you learn!) before being bombarded with possible holiday packages.

Thrice, she says, she made clear that she had changed her mind and did not want the deal. Each time she was transferred to another salesman who renewed the hard sell and ignored her protests. As soon as the call was finished she rang her credit card company to express her concerns. Lo and behold, she discovered that in the intervening minutes her account had been debited to the tune of £340, a sum she insists was never mentioned on the phone. Two letters to Affinity have gone unanswered.

 Affinity Holidays turns out to be based in Florida and calls to its customer services 0800 number connect to the US. Readers with long memories might think that all this sounds vaguely familiar. Exactly a year ago we reported on the plight of three householders cold-called by a Florida-based holiday firm, Bahamas and Florida Direct. They were told they could not receive a brochure about the packages described to them unless they paid there and then for a holiday. Refunds were promised if the brochure did not appeal, but these proved hard to come by. Trading standards has confirmed that it received dozens of complaints about the company.

Could Affinity be our old friends under a new guise? "We used to be Florida Direct," says the American who answers the 0800 line, "but the UK firm of the same name who managed our reservations were unable to handle all the bookings, so things went wrong and we changed our name." Funny that. Last year Hounslow trading standards told us that the problems lay with the American firm, not its British associate.

Meanwhile, we called MasterCard at Natwest to find out why Bordill was not offered a dispute form under the Consumer Credit Act since she had explained that the transaction was against her wishes. NatWest argues that it has no liability because American telesales firms are not subject to British law and are therefore not obliged to offer seven-day cooling off periods. Nonetheless, it has decided that it will refund Bordill as a goodwill gesture and mentions that it has received 10 complaints about Affinity.

Now here is an odd thing: when NatWest calls Affinity in an attempt to recoup its goodwill gesture it is told there is no chance of a refund, but when Consumer rings Affinity the same afternoon we are told that Bordill's package has been cancelled - coincidentally around the same time that we first faxed the firm. "We make it a rule to record all our telesales conversations and in this case the recording went wrong so we've no proof of what transpired," says a spokeswoman. "A refund will be sent within 30 days."

Dial P for poor service

How to fill your blank diary in four easy steps. Ring Dial-a-Phone and take up their offer of a free camera with every mobile phone sold. Give your address. Correct address when repeated wrongly due to misheard postcode. Pay extra for a Saturday delivery. Wait in. Try for three days to phone Dial-a-Phone to find out what happened to delivery.

Discover package was sent to that wrong address. Take day off work for new delivery. Take call confirming correct address. Peace of mind was once an elusive thing but now, of course, you can purchase it, for a hefty down payment. MJ Locke's 95-year-old mother did so when she acquired a washing machine and took out an extended warranty with Merloni. One day the machine failed to empty itself and Merloni sent round an engineer who got it working again. Seven months later Merloni wrote explaining that no fault had been found and that she would be invoiced for the visit. Locke protested in writing but the only reply came three months later in the form of a bill for £57.

The same day Mrs Locke receives a phone call and a basket of flowers. So insurers have a gooey streak after all, but pity the ordinary Joe left to battle it out with corporate giants.

fields.bodyText: Lack of holiday affinity The good news is that the office of fair trading (OFT) has announced that it is prepared to start legal action against four major tour operators to force them to disclose details of their cancellation charges. Alas, when asked for her credit card details she relayed them (oh readers, when will you learn!) before being bombarded with possible holiday packages. Thrice, she says, she made clear that she had changed her mind and did not want the deal. Each time she was transferred to another salesman who renewed the hard sell and ignored her protests. fields.headline: Channel 5 thwarted in bid to shift news
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Channel 5's bid to move its main news out of peaktime has been blocked by the Independent Television Commission, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5's attempt to move its main news bulletin out of peaktime has been blocked by the Independent Television Commission.

The regulator has ruled against the broadcaster's request to bring 5 News forward by half-an-hour to 5.30pm.

Channel 5 wanted to move the bulletin to accommodate Home and Away, which it planned to screen at 6pm when it launches in July.

The broadcaster snatched the long-running soap from ITV last year and is banking on the show to help lift its ratings.

However, the ITC has agreed to allow Channel 5 to run a 60-minute news and chat show, 5 News and Talk, from 5.30pm during the run-up to the general election.

"We have some sympathy with the arguments that Channel 5 put forward in favour of moving its news out of peaktime," an ITC spokeswoman said.

"But the commission was unwilling to see the requirement for Channel 5 to provide 20 minutes of news and 10 minutes of current affairs in peaktime being reduced."

Channel 5 had proposed to replace its existing commitment with 15 minutes of peaktime news in the form of hourly updates.

Related story
Mar 8: C5 stretches ITC rules with news move

webTitle: Morgan Freeman rallies against the flag

fields.headline: Morgan Freeman rallies against the flag
fields.trailText: Hollywood star and Mississippi resident Morgan Freeman has thrown his weight behind a campaign to abandon the pro-slavery Confederate emblem from the state's official flag.
fields.body:
Hollywood star and Mississippi resident Morgan Freeman has thrown his weight behind a campaign to abandon the Confederate emblem from the state's official flag. Mississippi is the only American state that still uses the pro-slavery Confederate symbol, 136 years after slavery was abolished.

A referendum next Tuesday will decide whether the flag is scrapped for good. But its opponents are facing defeat after a recent poll found that 66% of Mississippi voters wanted to keep the Confederate emblem. This week Freeman, who rarely gets embroiled in political issues, became actively involved in the campaign for its removal.

"I see the emblem as a legacy because everywhere you see skinheads and hate groups gathered, what are they waving? That silly thing," the Nurse Betty star told The Arizona Republic. "We feel like we have to mount an aggressive campaign to get voters out to vote. Otherwise people will just sort of sit and wait and see what happens."

If the vote backs the old flag, Mississippi could face an economic boycott from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and other black American groups. The problem is that the overwhelming proportion of Mississippi's white voters who support the Confederate flag are backed by a surprising three out of ten black voters.

 More about the Mississippi flag issue

webTitle: Guardian columnist sounded out for top job at Spectator

fields.headline: Guardian columnist sounded out for top job at Spectator
fields.trailText: The Spectator magazine has sounded out the controversial editor of Radio 4's Today programme as a potential successor to Boris Johnson. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The Spectator magazine, bastion of the reactionary right, has sounded out the controversial editor of Radio 4's Today programme as a potential successor to Boris Johnson.

Rod Liddle, who is also a Guardian columnist, was approached by the Spectator's publisher recently and asked if he would be interested in the job. Mr Johnson, the current Spectator editor, is standing for the safe Tory seat of Henley at the election.

Mr Liddle would be seen as a surprise choice - but his reputation as a maverick and his interest in European issues make him attractive.

He has had a bumpy stint at Today, where he has made many enemies within the BBC. He has, however, established the programme as a platform for edgy journalism, in much the same way as the Spectator has become a voice of opposition in print.

There are a number of other prominent names in the frame: the frontrunner within the Telegraph group, which owns the magazine, is columnist Matthew D'Ancona; while fellow Telegraph writer Alice Thomson is also a possibility.

As editor of Today, Mr Liddle must be seen to be scrupulously impartial, but he has a background on the left of the political spectrum. Associates say, however, that Mr Liddle's politics have moved significantly: he is certainly not a new Labour man, and is said to believe that the distinctions between right and left have blurred to the point where the labels are almost meaningless.

Nevertheless, more traditional rightwing media figures such as Stephen Glover and Simon Heffer, who write for the Daily Mail, would be much safer bets for the Spectator post. They are regular contributors to the magazine.

It has been suggested that at least 15 senior journalists and commentators on national newspapers have put themselves forward as candidates to Conrad Black, the Telegraph group proprietor. Mr D'Ancona, Mr Glover and Mr Heffer are all associates of Mr Black and his chief executive, Dan Colson.

But Mr Liddle is known to Kimberly Fortier, the Spectator's highly regarded publisher, who flagged up the idea to him recently.

Like the Spectator incumbent, Mr Liddle is a colourful figure - he used to play in a rock band, and named his son after Wat Tyler, leader of the Peasants' Revolt.

webTitle: Four the love of the game

fields.headline: Four the love of the game
fields.standfirst: With the Serie A title seemingly in Roma's pocket, it's not just English football that's getting its kicks from the race for a Champions League spot. James Richardson looks at the runners and riders
fields.trailText: With the Serie A title seemingly in Roma's pocket, it's not just English football that's getting its kicks from the race for a Champions League spot.
fields.body:
It wasn't long ago that coming second was for losers. Not these days though, thanks to the Russell Grant-like expansion of the lucrative Champions League.

With Italian clubs granted four places in the Champions And Anyone Else Who Knows Them League (the new name still not confirmed at time of writing), a place anywhere near the top of the league here is a hot ticket. (Thus not since Marc Almond played the biscuit game has coming fourth been so eagerly sought after.)

So, with nine matches to go, and with the top three spots sewn up in Serie A, which Italian sides are hoping to go fourth and multiply?

Right now the standings are a little thrown out by a game rained off on Saturday night, but there's a cluster of eager clubs crowding round. And what a disparate bunch they are: right now it's Parma that's making like a football columnist. They're holding fourth, and behind them lie Atalanta, the two Milanese sides and Bologna.

Frankly, it's Parma's to lose. Backed by the immense resources of Dairy giants Parmalat, the only thing this club has lacked in recent years is consistency - now, under their third coach this season Renzo 'the Red' Ulivieri, they finally have that too. The only thing that might trip them up in these last two months is their widening gyre of transfer rumours - half their first team is lined up with cushy deals in the big cities, and the other half is scrambling to catch up. More on that shortly.

Should they stumble, next in line are Atalanta - and how strange is that? Last season Atalanta were in Serie B, and despite having kept much the same squad from the second division, they still haven't been out of the top five all season. Their fairy-tale run was supposed to end a long while back, but with nine games left it's still only goal difference that's keeping them behind the big cheeses at Parma. That said, finishing 4th looks one miracle to many for this under-resourced club.

Of the other three teams within striking distance, Inter are the most dangerous. Bologna will settle for a Uefa Cup place. Milan after their glut of injuries have rallied of late, but they look way too knackered to go overtaking anyone. Their neighbours though have plenty of strength left - fresh from bowing out of all possible cups indecently early, and with a positively bulging roster.

Just as well: star forward Christian Vieri has already made it clear that he'll only stay on if Inter make the Champions League - as he so succinctly explains, "I'm not interested in playing in the Uefa Cup".

Naturally, whichever team does make it will have a bundle more lolly to chuck around toddler style on the transfer markets this summer. Thus while we've got our crystal ball out, what comings and goings can we look forward to?

First off, some expect an end to the crazy numbers of the post Bosman transfer boom, thanks to the EC's new transfer rules. Juve's Luciano Moggi, the man who brought Maradona to Napoli, predicts prices falling by up to 40%.

That will only be after this summers' spree however, which meantime should be a doody, as Italy's big clubs try and keep pace with loadsamoney Spanish pair of Real Madrid and Barcelona. Some early deals are already sorted: Roma have Bari's spotty Totti doppelganger Antonio Cassano. Lazio have two Udinese internationals: Fiore and Giannichedda.

The same two clubs are also involved in the widespread interest for three Parma players: Buffon, Cannavaro and Thuram. It was probably unfair for Parma to be hogging all three of them anyway, so; Cannavaro's off to Lazio, Buffon to Roma, with Thuram taking his pick between Juve, Milan, Lazio or that Spanish duo.

All three deals will be worth £20 million plus. Elsewhere, Juve are vainly trying to convince Patrick Vieira that Italy's not such a bad place after all, and Mark Viduka - this years' Robbie Keane? - has been touted around, so far with a similar lack of success.

At Milan, club management are circulating some remarkable bids in an attempt to buy back some credibility. After all the highlight of their last campaign was signing Fernando 'redundant' Redondo from Real Madrid, who turned up busted and hasn't played since. This time rumours see them swooping intrepidly for both Michael Owen and David Beckham - to keep each other company presumably.

Other targets are Fiorentina's Manuel Rui Costa, and while they're at it, Rivaldo from Barcelona. This last deal is one of the likeliest - it's not the first time his name's been connected with the Rossoneri, and at 29, Barca are eyeing an ever-decreasing profit if they don't sell. Rivaldo, known in Spain as 'Mr 10%' for his cut of any transfer fee, is doing his best to hurry a move along.

The biggest surprise of the summer though will be if Massimo Moratti of Inter can live up to his new-found budget philosophy. Last week, the man who has spent around £200 million on Inter announced: "I've learned my lesson: I've discovered the most expensive players don't always bring the best results." Who'd have thought it?

In this new spirit, Moratti has contented himself with a few Turkish acquisitions and the odd bit of poaching among Serie A's less glamorous names (Milan's Thomas Helveg, and Marco Materazzi ex of Everton and now with Perugia). Come May though, look for Inter to explode in a landslide of Lira with at least six top class acquisitions, four of whom will be strictly 'in the hole' fantasisti, incapable of playing with each other. Whether they make the Champions League or not, that's one new leaf that cannot last.

webTitle: Day 51: foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 51: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 51: An NFU official hits back at ministers who have blamed farmers for spreading foot and mouth.
fields.body:
Daily Telegraph
A National Farmers' Union official hits back at government ministers who have blamed farmers for spreading foot and mouth, branding them "incompetent", on page six.

The Independent
Reports on its front page that tens of thousands of animals may be needlessly slaughtered because of illegal stock movements, according to the government.

The Guardian
Leads its front page with news that the government expects there to be 25% fewer farms by 2005 following a round of closures and mergers in the wake of the foot and mouth crisis.

The Times
Has a front page lead saying the army has accused some farmers of deliberately infecting their livestock with foot and mouth to cash in on the emergency.

webTitle: Motorola expected to shut plant as Marconi swings the axe

fields.headline: Motorola expected to shut plant as Marconi swings the axe
fields.trailText: The US-driven downturn in Britain's electronics sector gathered pace yesterday amid fears that Motorola will today announce the closure of its Bathgate plant near Edinburgh with the loss of 3,200 jobs.
fields.body:
The US-driven downturn in Britain's electronics sector gathered pace yesterday amid fears that Motorola will today announce the closure of its Bathgate plant near Edinburgh with the loss of 3,200 jobs.

Meanwhile Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, confirmed it would axe 1,500 jobs in Britain and a similar number abroad, but said it would meet profit forecasts despite the slowdown.

Scottish executive officials said the future of Motorola's Bathgate factory "appeared to be bleak".

Motorola has already set in train plans to cut 22,000 jobs worldwide, including 700 in Swindon, partly because of slack demand for mobile phones.

Shares in Marconi rose as investors breathed a sigh of relief that it would make operating profits of around £800m for the year ending March 31. They closed at 341p, up 31p.

Restructuring is expected to cost Marconi £400m but chief executive George Simpson said: "In a volatile sector, Marconi continues to deliver good top-line growth."

The 1,500 job losses in Britain are likely to most affect plants in Liverpool and Coventry. Wherever possible, redundancies are to be made on a voluntary basis.

Marconi stressed a commitment to proceed with plans to establish new, hi-tech plants on greenfield sites at Ansty, near Coventry, Nottingham and Northampton. Last May it received a £25m regional assistance grant for Ansty, where 2,200 jobs could be created.

The MSF union reacted angrily to the job losses and complained about a lack of consultation. Union officials are meeting local shop stewards today, and industrial action has not been ruled out.

"Marconi seems hellbent on rewarding their staff with the sack despite the profits they have made. Our members learned of Marconi's plans in Sunday newspapers; this is no way to reward loyal staff," said Glyn Thomas of the MSF.

But John Mayo, deputy chief executive, said his company had sent out repeated offers to union officials to attend meetings which had not been taken up. Marconi is expected to cut a third of the jobs at its Edge Lane plant in Liverpool, located on the boundary of the Kensington "new deal" area that has received £62.4m of public money.

Electronics group Siemens is to cut 2,000 jobs at its mobile telecoms division in Germany - 25% of the workforce.

webTitle: 'Heads will roll' if Bayern win, warns Keane

fields.headline: 'Heads will roll' if Bayern win, warns Keane
fields.trailText: Roy Keane has warned his Manchester United team-mates that "heads will roll" if they fail to beat Bayern Munich in the second leg of their Champions League quarter-final next week.
fields.body:
Roy Keane has warned his Manchester United team-mates that "heads will roll" if they fail to beat Bayern Munich in the second leg of their Champions League quarter-final next week.

Speaking to Match magazine, Keane admitted: "If we do go out to Munich, heads will roll. There's no doubt about that, no doubt at all.

"When I say heads will roll, I mean players' futures, mine included. Hopefully we'll remember that when we're standing in Munich's stadium. Every player should be looking at themselves and wondering, and I'm one of them.

"There have been other players at United who had big reputations and they were sold nonetheless, so we should all be worried. That's not just a reaction to the Bayern defeat, it's something I've been thinking for a while."

The Republic of Ireland international has also accused United of standing still while other sides in Europe have progressed - and says the club should think about spending £50m to turn things round.

"You can continue the same for a while but eventually you have to say enough's enough," he said. "We've not done it in Europe for a couple of years, which is two years too long. And we've no divine right to win the trophy, there are eight teams left all thinking they deserve to win the trophy as well.

"They've all put in the effort like we have but if you haven't got the quality maybe it's time for the club to say we need to spend 20, 30, 40, 50 million," he added.

"Maybe last year you could have said we were unlucky against Madrid, they were outstanding on the night, whatever, but we've been suffering this year. If the lad at Dynamo Kiev had scored that goal we'd have been out at the first stage, so the signs have been there that we haven't been firing on all cylinders."

But Keane has insisted that United are "more than capable" of getting a result in Munich next week.

"We only have to look back at the semi-final against Juventus a couple of years ago when we managed to score three goals at their place," he said.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst: He is an expert on advertising in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the past 10 years. Every Wednesday morning, Stefano Hatfield, now based in New York heading Ad Age Global, will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue. This week, he asks whether size does matter in adland
fields.trailText: April 11: Stefano Hatfield asks whether size matters in America's adland.
fields.body:
Difficult as it was for Madison Avenue and the rest of Spin City to tear itself away from the absolutely fascinating Sophie Rhys-Jones saga across the pond, another self-referential media story actually made bigger news over here - the annual Fortune 500.

The stark news for our high-profile advertising agency groups after all these years of endless acquiring and merging and other consolidating was that the number of them that made it into the magazine's hallowed list of the world's biggest companies for 2000 was zero.

That's right, not one made the Global Top 500, and only Omnicom (at 292) and the Interpublic (IPG) Group (at 317) made it into the US domestic list. True North, soon to be swallowed up by IPG, and Grey were numbers 849 and 977 respectively. Sir Martin Sorrell's WPP is not a US group despite its agencies being America-based, and, regardless, is not large enough to make it into the Global Top 500 anyway.

Just how small advertising agency groups really are, despite the extraordinary amount of relative noise they make, can be gauged by a quick glance at places 499 and 500 in the global list - Somerfield and the Limited.

Both these retailers had revenues of just over $9.7bn in 2000, which contrasted with Omnicom's $6.1bn, and IPG's $5.6bn. WPP's Young & Rubicam acquisition puts it slightly ahead of Omnicom, and IPG's True North buy would give it revenues of $7.2bn on 2000's figures. That's still some $2.5bn shy of Somerfield and the Limited.

Does it matter? After all, advertising is a people business, we keep being told. The question I'm asked more than any other by people who work within the industry and neutral observers, is why do agencies need to keep getting bigger? Why do they need to acquire each other? Surely, the personal relationships on the ground in whatever local market are more important? Well, yes, and no.

Of course, that local relationship is important particularly in the cause of creating excellent and relevant advertising campaigns, which, should we forget, is the point of the exercise. However, these relationships are increasingly powerless to withstand the inexorable march of the global consolidation of accounts into single networks. To take one example of many, last week saw St Luke's in London lose the HSBC business to the Lowe Lintas network through no fault of its own other than it was not global.

To establish such global networks takes huge investment, primarily in people, but also real estate and systems. There is now the need to build integrated direct marketing and public relations networks too, as well as build a powerful standalone global media buying force. Then came the internet, and advertising agency groups were forced to dig deep to offer services they were not sure would ever generate huge returns. That takes the kind of funding that is only available to public companies. And, even if you are quite large - Bcom3, Young & Rubicam - it is not large enough to compete with the likes of IPG.

Although, many worker bees in advertising try to ignore it, the fact that their agency is part of a public company entirely changes the rules by which they work. New business is often not of a scale enough to impress Wall Street or the City, so growth must come from constant acquisition. And even then, the big agency groups are not home and dry.

It does matter to be in the Fortune 500, or the S & P 500, or the FTSE 500 and the like. Advertising agency stocks are relatively lightly traded by volume - at least outside the big three! The State of Wisconsin's pension fund manager would be taking a large enough relative gamble by plumping for an agency stock, being part of a grouping that he or she could at least explain to the rest of their board imparts a certain confidence.

So although to their staff and certain clients, the big agency groups may appear monolithic, their CEOs who regularly play in the big league know that they are relative minnows. Whether this is a good or bad thing entirely depends on your perspective.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

fields.headline: M&S in brand rethink
fields.trailText: 10am: Marks & Spencer is to undergo a wholesale review of its brand and advertising, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is to undergo a wholesale review of its brand and advertising in the face of a massive sales collapse.

The beleaguered retailer is restructuring its marketing department, axing the position of head of advertising held by Matthew Chambers and recruiting two new senior marketing roles.

M&S has created two new marketing roles - head of external marketing and head of marketing planning and brand management.

Mr Chambers will not be considered for the new head of external marketing role, said an M&S spokeswoman, and is in discussions with the company about his future.

More roles are expected to be culled as the restructure moves from the senior level down through the rest of the marketing department.

The company is searching for a new of head of external marketing, a role that covers advertising, sponsorship and all marketing to consumers.

The head of marketing planning and brand management will be responsible of marketing planning and strategy.

Both positions report to M&S marketing director Alan McWalter. Recruitment is expected to take up to three months.

"When the new head of external marketing gets here they will review everything in their area, which includes advertising and sponsorship," said the spokeswoman.

Mr Chambers was responsible for the appointment of advertising agency Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R and Walker Media last year.

Rainey Kelly's campaign of a nude, size 16 model proved controversial when religious groups ripped the posters down from hoardings in protest.

fields.headline: Pass the babies
fields.standfirst: A freemarket in adoption is simply wrong
fields.trailText: Still only nine months old, the internet twins have already had four sets of parents and are due two more sets now they are being returned to the US. Yet the high court decision on Monday was the right and proper course.
fields.body:
The nightmare is not yet over. Still only nine months old, the internet twins have already had four sets of parents and are due two more sets now they are being returned to the US. Yet the high court decision on Monday was the right and proper course. Indeed, since the Arkansas court - which granted the original quickie adoption order to the far from suitable English adopters, Alan and Judith Kilshaw - had subsequently annulled it, there was no other course the English court could have taken. The two babies have American citizenship. The law being the law - and the multiple parties already involved in this tug-of-love case - it took five days of legal argument plus many weeks of preparation to reach this decision.

Rarely has the need for regulation of adoption been so publicly underlined than by the trauma suffered by the twins in the unregulated American free market. Twice sold to the highest bidder, then chased across the US by competing adoptive families, and finally subjected to unending television appearances once having reached Britain with the Kilshaws, the babies were rightly taken into care by Flintshire social services. At least the national furore over their treatment forced ministers' hands. The reform of UK regulation of overseas adoptions has been accelerated with a statutory order passed two weeks ago; and ministers are committed to ensuring that the domestic adoption reform bill, currently before the Commons but unlikely to be enacted before the election, will be re-introduced early in the next parliament.

There is one small act which should now be done for the twins. The current plan is to send them back to temporary foster parents in the US until the American courts have resolved the competing claims. Why not keep them here until a final US decision is reached? At least that way the babies would be saved from yet another short-term placement. They have already been shuffled too much.

webTitle: A bunch of lilies does not seem like a problem. But in Ulster nothing is that simple

fields.headline: A bunch of lilies does not seem like a problem. But in Ulster nothing is that simple
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The marble-lined great hall of the Stormont assembly, built in the 1930s as a symbol of Northern Ireland's place at the heart of the British empire, is an austere place at the best of times.
fields.body:
The marble-lined great hall of the Stormont assembly, built in the 1930s as a symbol of Northern Ireland's place at the heart of the British empire, is an austere place at the best of times.

So when plans were drawn up to display Easter lilies in the hall this weekend, there were hopes that Stormont's imposing surroundings would for once be brightened up.

Well-intentioned members of the Stormont commission, who run the assembly building, reckoned without the Rev Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists. The lilies would have to go, Dr Paisley's supporters thundered, because the flowers are a symbol of the republican movement and will be used at Easter to commemorate dead IRA terrorists.

The assembly was hastily recalled from its holiday recess yesterday for an emergency debate on the Easter lilies. The Paisleyite motion was passed, after winning the support of members of David Trimble's Ulster Unionist party, but was thrown out because it failed to win cross community support.

Jim Wells, a DUP member of the assembly who forced the emergency debate, was infuriated: "For the first time in the history of the United Kingdom a government building will be used to display symbols which honour IRA terrorists."

Nationalists and the non-sectarian Alliance party complained that the Northern Ireland assembly had been made to look ridiculous after it was recalled to discuss such a triv ial matter. "What sort of lunacy has descended on this assembly that we have to be urgently reconvened over a bowl of lilies?" asked the Social and Democratic Labour party's member Alban Maginness.

The idea of allowing two displays of Easter lilies to be placed at Stormont was originally proposed as a compromise by the Alliance party member Eileen Bell, who sits on the assembly commission. She hoped that allowing lilies into Stormont would go some way to satisfying Sinn Fein - which wanted a full scale republican floral display - without upsetting Unionists.

Sinn Fein, whose members will commemorate the IRA's dead on Easter Sunday by pinning paper lilies to their lapels, had wanted the floral displays to be placed next to a notice marking the work of the national graves association which tends IRA graves.

Lilies became a republican symbol after the 1916 Easter Rising in Dublin when 15 republicans were executed by British forces.

Ms Bell said: "We hoped that our compromise to allow floral displays of lilies, without the references to graves, would be a first step to addressing the issue of symbols. How wrong we were."

Ms Bell had assumed that her compromise would be uncontroversial because lilies will be on display in churches throughout Ireland this weekend, including some Protestant churches. David Ervine, the former loyalist paramilitary who now sits in the assembly for the Progressive Unionist Party, ridiculed the DUP for recalling the assembly over "a bunch of flowers when parliament wasn't recalled last summer when people were dying on our streets".

But Mr Ervine, who was sentenced to 11 years in prison in 1974 after being stopped with a bomb in his car, horrified Sinn Fein members when he expressed regret that he had not killed more republicans. "I have no particular desire to appreciate or venerate the re publican dead other than perhaps myself and some of my colleagues might have liked to have added to the ranks of the republican dead," he said.

Unionists will now insist that Orange lilies should be displayed at Stormont on July 12 when Orangemen mark the anniversary of the Battle of Boyne in 1690.

At least there is one sign of hope. In the optimistic climate of the Good Friday agreement assembly members adopted a neutral logo - the six flowers of the flax plant to signify the six counties of Northern Ireland.

webTitle: Mayor wins court date for tube battle

fields.headline: Mayor wins court date for tube battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's legal battle against the government's £13bn plan to run the London Underground as a private-public partnership will be fought out in the courts on June 12.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's legal battle against the government's £13bn plan to run the London Underground as a private-public partnership will be fought out in the courts on June 12.

London's mayor was yesterday given permission for a high court judicial review of the government's plans which are set to become an issue in the lead up to the election. London Underground did not oppose the granting of a four day hearing.

Mr Livingstone and Bob Kiley, his transport commissioner, will argue that lives will be put at risk becaue tube maintenance and management will be separated under the PPP. The legal action follows the breakdown of talks between Mr Kiley and John Prescott, deputy prime minister, to settle the future funding and control of the tube.

The mayor's transport authority, Transport for London, is seeking court orders prohibiting London Underground from entering PPP arrangements for "provision, construction, renewal or maintenance of the tube", or "any other arrangements inconsistent with the mayor's transport strategy".

Its counsel, Richard Gordon QC, said that the important and urgent case raised significant issues over Mr Livingstone's transport strategy functions.

Mr Justice Sullivan said he was satisfied that the mayor's statutory powers were "novel, complex and untested in the courts", and that the issue was "of vital importance to Londoners generally".

He said the issue should be resolved as soon as possible so that Mr Livingstone knew whether to take the PPP into account when formulating his final transport strategy.

The government yesterday released details of its plans for a 30 year lease to the private sector, in which it plans to invest £2bn of the total £13bn cost.

fields.headline: Corridor capers
fields.standfirst: Reform of Whitehall is necessary
fields.trailText: The civil service is in no fit state to deliver the service promises labour has made - the time has come to look at reform in Whitehall
fields.body:
The case for an authoritative, external look at the civil service has been strong for at least 15 years - ever since its then head, Sir Robert Armstrong, produced his notorious maxim to the effect that permanent officials are there to do their ministers' bidding and no more. Margaret Thatcher's political extinction calmed fears about "politicisation" in Whitehall but left many questions pending. Armstrong's memorandum on civil servants' duties raised the central one. Officials have to be more than yes-people. If the public cannot rely on them to say no when power is being abused and blow the whistle, our scheme of executive government becomes even more lopsided than it already is. But if civil servants are to have such a constitutional role it must be written down clearly and their accountability established.

In recent years Giles Radice on the former Commons Treasury and civil service committee and now Tony Wright at the head of the public administration committee have made a start at doing just that. The latest report from Mr Wright's committee says the time has come to round out a wider plan for reform. Look, it says, at the ferment - over Whitehall's departmental geography, the impact of even milk-and-water freedom of information, over pay and conditions and ethos in the public service at large, the residual role of elected local authorities and the expansion of delegated government. Beneath the surface, there is rumbling discontent at the qualities and formation of top officials, their gender and backgrounds.

Once, a "royal" commission might have been convened. But another Tony, the prime minister, has shown scant interest in how government works. He let Armstrong's successor but one, Sir Richard Wilson, proceed with an internal reform which, it is now clear, has been anything but. Perhaps, belatedly, No 10 realises that machinery does matter. A civil service that entered the 1980s still clinging to an ethos shaped in the 1940s was left battered by Thatcher's handbag and now wanders the corridors bemused. It is in no fit state to deliver the service promises Labour has made - and on which its political fate depends. In a better-ordered political world an able MP such as Tony Wright would be a Cabinet Office minister. As it is, he should be asked to continue his committee's excellent work and make positive recommendations for Whitehall reform.

fields.headline: New dawn breaks for Capricorn Corley
fields.standfirst: Three years after quitting ITV, Paul Corley's new  role at GMTV makes him a big player again. Since status matters to the ambitious Goat, he must be relieved his time on the borders is over
fields.trailText: April 11: GMTV's Paul Corley is back where any Capricorn belongs - at the top of the mountain, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
With his dramatic return to mainstream television as managing director of GMTV, Paul Corley is back where any decent Capricorn belongs - at the top of the mountain, surveying the terrain beneath him.

Three years after quitting ITV, and after a long stint at Border TV that ended last summer, Corley's new executive role makes him a big player again.

Since status matters so much to the ambitious Goat, Corley must be relieved his time on the borders is over.

Capricorn is instinctively conventional and conservative - a city suit and gentleman's club sign - and Corley's horoscope (December 23 1950) has all the pragmatism, management skills and sense of fair play. He's a decent bloke to do business with.

The sign lacks risk-taking fire and Corley probably baulks at individualists and outsider ideas. But this makes him one of the grown-ups, a father-figure who gets things done and can be relied on in the real world, with minimum of fuss.

Corley has a cute Gemini Moon, so his sharp thinking makes him more streetwise and versatile than most Capricorns, and this Capricorn-Gemini combination is as good as it gets for media management.

He may not turn people on through panache and charisma but his safe pair of hands should not be underestimated.

Corley's successful comeback looks like a combination of lucky Jupiter, good karma and good friends. His astrological links with GMTV are exceptional.

This company is an Aquarian (January 29 1991) but it also has strong Capricorn in its horoscope and shares with Corley the identical degree in Capricorn of Mercury, planet of communication. It is ideal for strategic thinking about the company's long-term future.

There is, however, a more ambivalent pattern connecting the horoscopes to do with Pluto, the transformative planet that symbolises the cycle of "death and rebirth".

This overshadowed his departure from centre stage between September 97 to 99 and good-morning GMTV represents a return from the Shades of Hades/Pluto.

Ironically, just as his new dawn breaks, GMTV's horoscope for next year is heading to the twilight zone with the very same Sun-Pluto contacts.

It may be about to undergo a lacklustre phase in mid-2002 and some may think, rather unfairly, that the boss has brought it with him.

Hopefully, Capricorn Corley will turn out to be the rock-solid anchor that GMTV needs as it goes through its own cycle of regeneration and change.

fields.headline: The demon privatisers
fields.trailText: One of the enduring myths about modern British politics is that New Labour has no ideology. Tony Blair and his entourage are still routinely portrayed as people without convictions, hollow political mannequins, clutching at every opinion poll straw in the wind and prepared to ditch policies at the slightest hint of disapproval from a battery of focus groups. Nothing has demonstrated more clearly how absurd this caricature is than the government's unswerving commitment to the privatisation of public services, a policy that has been driven through with heroic disregard for the views of the general public, let alone its own supporters.
fields.body:
One of the enduring myths about modern British politics is that New Labour has no ideology. Tony Blair and his entourage are still routinely portrayed as people without convictions, hollow political mannequins, clutching at every opinion poll straw in the wind and prepared to ditch policies at the slightest hint of disapproval from a battery of focus groups. Nothing has demonstrated more clearly how absurd this caricature is than the government's unswerving commitment to the privatisation of public services, a policy that has been driven through with heroic disregard for the views of the general public, let alone its own supporters.

If the prime minister and Gordon Brown were genuinely slaves of public opinion, they would long since have turned their backs on the bacchanalia of sell-offs and contracting-out presided over by the Tories. As last month's ICM poll for the Guardian confirmed, most people want public services run by the government and local authorities, not in "partnership" with private companies.

Even more are opposed to the partial sale of air traffic control and the profligate and potentially catastrophic part-privatisation of the tube the chancellor seems determined to foist on Londoners. Huge majorities support the renationalisation of the railways and private prisons and 40% even want to return BT to public ownership, though the case for taking back control of the telecoms behemoth has hardly surfaced in mainstream debate for a decade.

This mood in favour of public provision does not quite represent the sea-change sometimes suggested, since there was never majority support for privatisation under Thatcher and Major. In any case, new Labour is pressing ahead regardless with the private colonisation of public services, opening up parts of the public sector for business that even the Conservatives could not reach - and prepared to expend substantial political capital in the process.

The sale of air traffic control cost the government one of its biggest backbench revolts, while its dog's breakfast scheme for the tube is currently being forced through against a spectacularly broad alliance of trade unions, London business, Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, London Labour MPs and the mayor, not to mention the mandate of the capital's electorate.

There is little doubt that putting Railtrack out of its private misery would be a wildly popular manifesto pledge. But ministers insist they are having none of it, as Lord Macdonald wrings his hands at the government's lack of control of the railway, suggesting passengers take to the roads instead in protest at Virgin's fourfold fares increase.

M eanwhile, under a string of euphemistic sobriquets - public-private partnerships, private finance initiatives, best value, education action zones - the government is preparing to bring profit-seeking corporations into the heart of public health, education and other services that have so far escaped the full force of new Labour's marketing zeal. Enthusiasts insist that users are unconcerned about who provides services. But the evidence is piling up that where private companies make cost savings, they mostly do so at the expense of the pay, conditions and jobs of public service workers, while private finance deals fail to transfer risk to the private consortia as claimed, squeeze other services and end up costing taxpayers substantially more in the long run. What is needed is a historic reform of treasury rules to allow publicly owned bodies to borrow on their own account, removing a crucial pressure to use more expen sive privately raised finance. But there is currently no prospect of the chancellor agreeing to any such loosening of central control.

Almost unbelievably, in the country that gave the world BSE, the government is now backing a Brussels proposal to privatise meat inspection and hand over the job to the abattoir owners themselves. Just as alarmingly, the iniquitous health and social care bill is up for its final debate in the Lords next week. With barely a murmur of public discussion, the bill would open the way for the wholesale provision of NHS clinical services, as well as employment of doctors and nurses, by private corporations. It would also create a mechanism for health service bodies to charge for personal care for the first time.

But come the general election, public opposition will be largely unrepresented and there will be no major party standing in England committed to halting and reversing the slow-motion disaster of creeping privatisation. So far, resistance - such as the middle England revolt in Worcester over a particularly damaging PFI hospital scheme and the continuing Unison strikes by Dudley health workers against transfer to the private sector - has been patchy.

That will have to change if new Labour, whether led by Blair or Brown, is to be weaned off its addiction to neo-liberal public service models imported from the US. Along with their weakness for corporate power, it is now clear that that the decisive factor in the government's drive to privatise is ideological.

webTitle: Peter Mandelson on Tory election hopes

fields.headline: You must learn from us, William
fields.standfirst:
Labour's resigned cabinet minister now turns Spectator columnist

Special report: Election 2001
fields.trailText: After suffering their mighty defeat, William Hague's team decided that they wanted a party looking forwards, not stuck in the past, and so they went for copycat tactics. They had a false conception of what the Labour party had done, concluding that we won by changing our image alone, deciding to do the same and making the jump - without agreeing where they were jumping to.
fields.body:
After suffering their mighty defeat, William Hague's team decided that they wanted a party looking forwards, not stuck in the past, and so they went for copycat tactics. They had a false conception of what the Labour party had done, concluding that we won by changing our image alone, deciding to do the same and making the jump - without agreeing where they were jumping to.

Of course, we have not made it easy for them to forge a new identity. We have confused the picture by moving on to ground they considered their preserve - in economics, welfare and defence. But just because New Labour has captured clothes it should always have worn does not mean that the Tories have to run around stark naked. There is life after Thatcher; they have not searched hard enough for it.

This brings us to the second reason for William's difficulties: his failure to come to terms with the Tory right. They are standing in his way and he is not taking them on. There are strong parallels between what happened to Labour in the early 1980s and what is happening to the Tories today.

The Labour left believed that the party lost power because the case for socialism hadn't been argued strongly enough. The Tory right believe that the Conservatives have lost power because of the Major leadership's betrayal of Thatcherism.

To the Labour left, the betrayal that hurt most was acceding to IMF cuts in 1976. To the Tory right, the betrayal that still rankles is the removal of Margaret Thatcher in 1990. William is simply unable to respond to this. Instead, he appearsembarrassed by the Tory past.

Again, there is a parallel here with the two attempts to forge New Labour. Neil Kinnock, a leftwinger able to face down the left, began the task of retrieving Labour and its true values from the party's immediate past. But, 10 years on, it took Tony Blair fully to spell out the alternative.

The Tories have failed to understand what we had to go through and how long it took to create New Labour: the new constitution; the introduction of one member, one vote; changing the relationship with the unions; the break with discredited policies; and the manifesto that was thrashed out and voted on by the whole membership.

All this involved a lot of thought and hard argument. It meant taking people on and making enemies on the way, as some of us know only too well. The Tory leadership want the gain without the pain; they want the advantage of a new electoral appeal without forging a new party to underpin it.

What should Central Office do if, as most expect, the election takes place in June? In sum, make the best of a bad job. Run a good, lively, well-disciplined campaign. Don't upstage the policy content of the manifesto by an outpouring of xenophobic gush that will achieve headlines but not extra votes. Don't make William look unstatesmanlike. Remember, when he was made to look youthful, he simply came across as juvenile. Above all, have something intelligent to say. Do not get down in the gutter (you only become dirty that way). Then, after the election, start the project again - and this time do it thoroughly.

The project - making the Conservative party electable - has to be built on the foundations of Tory values. These are not synonymous with Thatcherism. Nor should they be expressed through a return to the old one-nation Tory politics of the 1950s. This would be the equivalent of Labour finding solutions in a return to old-style 1960s social democracy.

Instead, the party has to look at the world as it is, not as it was - rather as Ted Heath did in 1969, when he invented policies for Selsdon Man, a pre-Blair combination of economic realism and sensible welfare. The Tories need to undertake a thorough analysis of what has happened to the real world since Thatcher, and what modern Conservatism has to offer to the lives of the general population - their jobs, the struggle to balance work and family life, access to high-quality public services, an active and affordable welfare state, a safe environment and a modern system of government.

But, if you tuned into the debates raging inside the Tory party at the moment, you would hear little of these issues. Instead, you would get an earful of authoritarian rhetoric countered by a blast of libertarian hyperbole. Tories are kidding themselves if they think that this debate is where millions of votes are going to be picked up from their fellow citizens.

Although I earnestly want this century to be given to progressive politics, with the Conservatives kept out of office by the centre left for a long time to come, I also believe that British democracy requires an effective opposition. This is not what the Tories are providing at the moment. Uncertain of their direction, they are driving along in a semi-roadworthy condition with the handbrake on. Whatever his qualities as a leader, in these circumstances it is not William that needs changing, but the vehicle.

fields.headline: MPs prepare to play as politics is postponed
fields.trailText: Battle buses would be rolling if Tony Blair's nerve had held. Mr Blair, William Hague and that chubby redhead would be mobbed by supporters three times a day and fail to answer the questions asked by TV interviewers.
fields.body:
Battle buses would be rolling if Tony Blair's nerve had held. Mr Blair, William Hague and that chubby redhead would be mobbed by supporters three times a day and fail to answer the questions asked by TV interviewers.

MPs would be out of Westminster's bars and in Britain's shopping precincts, delivering rehearsed replies to whatever questions were posed by bewildered customers outside Sainsbury's.

E-Day minus 23 and the suspense would be unbearable as pundits predicted the result on May 3. Would Mr Blair win by 100 seats, or by 200? Instead, ministers and MPs yesterday went through the motions in the extended fag-end of the parliament, desperate to get away for the Easter holiday before resuming the phoney war.

Football has a pools panel made up of the good and the great to forecast results when bad weather stops play, so is it time to institute a polls panel when politics is postponed?

Pending the wait until June 7, David Butler would be our Geoff Hurst and one of the Dimbleby's (both would be too expensive) might agree to take the place of Roger Hunt. Peter Snow and his swingometer must be as safe a pair of hands as Gordon Banks, while we'd find some academics to substitute for the FA suits.

Since Labour are in government, Mr Blair's seats should be home wins. Given that there are fewer away wins in football, they would be the Tories. A Lib Dem victory could be a score draw (almost certainly guaranteeing a jackpot), with the SNP awarded nil-nils.

Andrew Roth would make a fine James Alexander-Gordon to read out the May 3 results: "Enfield Southgate, away win; Hull East, home win; Ross, Skye & Inverness West, score draw..."

Alas we were subjected yesterday to an hour-long session of health questions. Health ministers had little to say, Labour backbenchers little to ask and Tory MPs little purpose as they contemplated sitting to the left of the speaker's chair for another four years after Mr Blair recovers his nerve.

David Tredinnick (Bosworth, away win) appeared to suggest that homeopathy be used to treat animals infected by the foot and mouth virus. And shameless Ann Winterton (Congleton, away win) bravely praised the work of husband Nicholas (Macclesfield, away win).

A wag (ground unknown, home win) yelled "Buy one, get one free" ,which brings us to health secretary Alan Milburn (Darlington, home win). In his early years as a left-winger Mr Milburn spent many happy hours in a bookshop in Newcastle upon Tyne called Days of Hope. Perhaps he really was reading Das Kapital, for yesterday he displayed a grasp of economics undetected when he was a Treasury minister.

"Trickle down economics have failed," he declared. "They haven't benefited the poorest in the poorest communities." Wow! Emboldened, Mr Milburn extended his NHS brief to link research into phobias with foreign affairs, to insist the former "could be helpful to the Tories, given the prevalence of Europhobia, xenophobia and homophobia on the benches opposite."

Tom Levitt (High Peak, home win) was 47 yesterday and received greetings from health minister John Hutton (Barrow and Furness, home win). "Can I start", Mr Hutton said, "by wishing my friend many happy returns. I hope he will have a happy return in the not too distant future as well."

Mr Levitt had the good grace to blush. High Peak - another home win?

fields.headline: The problem is the monarchy - not the royals
fields.trailText: Never mind the quality of the News of the World's journalism, feel the literary width of its headline: "Sophie's Choice". Who would have thought that Murdoch's Sunday rag had such knowledge of modern American fiction?
fields.body:
Never mind the quality of the News of the World's journalism, feel the literary width of its headline: "Sophie's Choice". Who would have thought that Murdoch's Sunday rag had such knowledge of modern American fiction? Perhaps a future instalment of the Wessex saga will be titled "A Confederacy of Dunces".

A prime dunce is the man chosen by the News of the Screws to advise Sophie on her choice. He is "one of Britain's most distinguished constitutional experts ... Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage - the bible of the nation's nobility". As I have pointed out before, no qualification is required to become a leading "constitutional expert" - though a gobstopping moniker helps, which is why Lord St John of Fawsley does so well at the game.

Brooks-Baker has been pontificating expertly all week. "It was completely irresponsible of her [Sophie] to be so sloppy and negligent," he informed the Scotsman. "I think one of the problems she faces is that she was not trained for this job." Just like Brookie, one might add. Interviewed on CNN last Wednesday, he was introduced thus by Larry King: "Harold Brooks-Baker in London, you published Burke's Peerage, what do you think?" With deplorable sloppiness, Brooks-Baker neglected to point out that he has never published an edition of Burke's Peerage, and doesn't even own the rights to it.

He is in fact an American businessman who sells volumes such as the Burke's Peerage Book of Brooks-Bakers, which are no more than computerised print-outs listing people who happen to share a surname. And, of course, he supplements this income by holding forth to the gullible. At the time of Sophie Rhys-Jones's wedding he told the world's media that the Queen would "almost certainly" give Prince Edward a dukedom as his wedding present, the likeliest title being the Duke of Cambridge.

Infuriated beyond endurance by his posturing, the Queen's press officer stated publicly that "he is speaking with no knowledge or authority".

Which probably makes him the ideal person to hold forth on royal shenanigans: who better than a clown to discuss a joke? In the words of Liz Smith, the New York gossip columnist, his fellow-panellist on Larry King Live: "Well, I just can't take it seriously. I mean, these people have all had the same troubles since the Battle of Hastings or whatever it was." Or, as Kim Howells MP told the Daily Telegraph, British royals have always been "a bit bonkers".

Historically undeniable, I'd say. But the Telegraph was apoplectic, expressing the hope that 10,000 swords would leap from their scabbards "to avenge this insult to the Queen". The Daily Mail accused republicans in the cabinet of taking cruel pleasure in the Windsors' misfortunes. "New Labour has no time for the royal family," it thundered. "There is a measure of grudging respect for the Queen, but ... the minor royals, such as Edward and Sophie are regarded with open contempt."

Physician, heal thyself. This is the same Daily Mail which began the year by attacking the "rude and unkind" Princess Royal, and then issued a magisterial rebuke to Zara Phillips for brawling with her boyfriend ("such conduct falls a long way short of the standards set by the Queen").

On the day after her second stroke, it denounced Princess Margaret as "a bitter, unhappy, selfish, old woman" who had "dissipated her indulged life". When Prince Andrew took a holiday in Thailand, the Mail accused him of "blundering out from Sarah's shadow into a mid-life crisis". His subsequent appointment as roving ambassador for British Trade International was greeted with the headline: "Boorish jokes, topless beauties and the question: Is this man really the right person to represent British business?"

Nor can ministerial contempt for Prince Edward match that of the Daily Mail, which recently savaged this "dimwitted, pompous stuffed shirt who thinks the world owes him a living and the rest of us owe him deference".

In a flag-waving editorial last Saturday, the Mail maintained that the royal family "still commands immense loyalty and affection". Really? Lynda Lee-Potter, the conscience of the Mail, wrote in January that "the old adulation which many felt has been eroded. Even ardent royalists may soon begin to feel that their idols are unworthy of either respect or affection." Her hunch was confirmed two weeks ago, when an opinion poll commissioned for the Queen was leaked to ... the Daily Mail. "A devastating secret report compiled for the monarch by pollsters Mori spells out the low regard in which her family is held," it reported. "Fewer than one in four people thinks they are hard working and only one in 10 thinks they are good value for money."

Just so. But the hyperbole of rightwing tabloids seems to be as infectious as foot and mouth. A front-page story in the Independent on Sunday warns that "the controversy over the private business of the minor royals is now threatening to spill over into a full-blown constitutional crisis for Tony Blair ... With the monarchy still commanding majority support from the public, it would be disastrous to fight an election on the issue."

What fantastic nonsense. Like all previous Labour prime ministers, Tony Blair has no intention of fighting an election on the issue - or even mentioning it. As the playwright David Hare remarked a few years ago: "We know in our hearts that the monarchy is a historical absurdity. But because we lack the courage to abolish it (as indeed we lack the courage for any radical undertaking), instead we are taking out our anger at our own bad faith by torturing the individuals involved."

Until politicians are bold enough to start questioning the need for a head of state and the purpose of the royal prerogative, the terms of "debate" will continue to be set by the cretins of Wapping. Sophie's choice, as defined by the News of the World, is whether or not she should be addressed as Her Royal Highness. Does anyone, other than Harold Brooks-Baker and Sir Herbert Gussett, care two hoots?

Another rail fiasco looms

A letter from Professor Lewis Lesley to the New Statesman catches my eye. "At Liverpool John Moores University, we have shown that it is safe, practical and economic to install high-speed railways along the centre of motorways using existing service stations for park and ride. These 'motorway railways' could carry HGVs piggyback on freight trains."

In the 1970s a pressure group called the Railway Conversion League campaigned for rail lines to be covered with tarmac. It turns out that Professor Lesley came up with the opposite idea four years ago. Elevated "motorway railways" above the central reservations of the M1 and M6 would involve minimal environmental disruption, since no fields or back gardens would have to be dug up. By cutting the journey time between London and Birmingham to 35 minutes, and the London-Manchester trip to 1 hour 20 minutes, they would would tempt drivers to use trains, thus easing traffic congestion.

Immediately after the 1997 election, John Prescott promised to give "serious consideration" to this ingenious scheme. Since then, however, he seems to have forgotten about it. Instead he is pressing ahead with a high-speed Channel tunnel link from Folkestone to London, even though most Eurostar travellers are perfectly happy with the existing service.

The project, financed by one of his beloved private-public partnerships, will cut through swathes of the Kent countryside and cost taxpayers £2bn. A report by the national audit office two weeks ago concluded that "the link represents poor value for money in terms of estimated economic benefits": Prescott's claim that it would give a £1bn boost to the economy was based on "debatable financial assumptions" and wildly optimistic forecasts of passenger numbers.

Does this sound familiar? Before Tony Blair finds himself lumbered with a second-term fiasco, someone should whisper two words in his ear: Millennium Dome.
