webTitle: Comment: Daily Mail rattled by Wessex affair

fields.headline: Their time's running out
fields.standfirst:
Now even the Daily Mail is rattled by the implications of the Wessex affair, writes Jonathan Freedland

Special report: The future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Now even the Daily Mail is rattled by the implications of the Wessex affair.
fields.body:
They are playing their most desperate card. Whenever royalists fear that they're losing the argument, they always reach for the weapon of last resort. It used to be a two-word salvo: President Thatcher. Or, depending on the audience, President Hattersley. Or President Kinnock.

Yesterday the Daily Mail's front page updated the manoeuvre, by asking "Would you want this lot to replace the monarchy?" alongside a photomontage of Queen Cherie Blair, King Keith Vaz, Queen Margaret Jay and King Charles Falconer - all decked out in digitally doctored crowns and ermine. Radio 5 Live played a similar game, polling its listeners on a possible president: Jamie Oliver came in first, ahead of Mo Mowlam, Anne Robinson and Richard Branson. The Naked Chef promised longer pub opening hours and better food, with hospitals and schools all dishing out pukka tucker.

It's all jolly good fun but the Mail's move, in particular, betrays an unexpected sense of panic in the monarchist camp. The President Beckham gambit is for use only in emergency, when the royalist fight is almost lost: it's designed to ridicule the republican case, divert attention from the absurdity of heredity and shame Britons into thinking that they could only ever make stupid democratic choices. The aim is to infantilise the British public, to reduce us to children who couldn't possibly be trusted with a vote: after all, we'd only waste it. The suffragettes had to endure the same condescension a century ago.

But we should not be downcast by this latest assault; we should be cheered by it. For who would have foreseen that a fairly mild story of royal tittle-tattle would unleash the intense debate of the last week? A few off-colour remarks from Sophie, the "Countess of Wessex", and within 48 hours the debate had spiralled down to fundamentals. As the Sun put it last Wednesday, "Is it time to ditch the monarchy?"

Contrast that with the recent bumpy rides for the palace. When Charles and Diana broke up in 1992, the revelations drove commentators into two rival camps - but they were Spencer v Windsor rather than republican v monarchist. The questions then were whether Charles could ever marry Camilla, whether she could become queen, whether the succession should skip to William. Only a fringe few debated the institution itself.

Even the Firm's darkest hour - the aftermath of Diana's death in 1997 - saw the critics hesitate. When the Windsors refused to speak about, react to or even pay tribute to the dead princess, the public cry was not for abolition but for modernisation. Again, only a dedicated minority suggested the monarchy had to be scrapped, not saved.

Yet this time, and with so much weaker a provocation, the response has been sharper and more radical. Where ministers kept silent in September 1997, they have been speaking out now - with no reprimand from the royals' one-time friend in No 10. The restraint of 1992 and 1997 seems to have eroded.

The public are equally unbound. Tune in to any of the countless phone-ins generated by Sophiegate and two impressions quickly take root. First, those who still insist that monarchy and constitutional reform are dry topics of interest only to Charter 88 chatterers, are wrong: this is a switch-on subject that excites instant and enormous public debate. Second, arguments that were once the lonely preserve of conviction republicans have leaked into the national mainstream. For every old royalist canard, there's now a punter ready to phone in and defeat it. Britons are losing their fear, the old deference falling away as fast as the royal mystique. Now they feel free to attack the monarchy in a language that would once have barred them from the airwaves.

No wonder the royalist camp is rattled. They hang by a frail thread when a nothing story like Sophiegate can unravel their cause so quickly. But how should republicans seize this moment? What should we do next?

The first instinct is to demand nothing less than immediate abolition - on logical as well as emotional grounds. For it's clear that any of the current modernisation proposals are bound to fail, just as they always do. The "lord chamberlain", Richard Luce, can try to draw up guidelines for royal working practices, just as MPs can demand a register of royal interests. But neither will succeed because both are trying to square a circle, squeezing an ancient, feudal idea - royalty - into a modern, democratic world. The two just do not mix, for royalty rests on medieval concepts of bloodline and heredity while modernity seeks to reward merit and offer equal opportunity. Modern royalty is as silly an idea as a plastic crown or a Perspex sceptre. It is a contradiction.

M oreover, for purists, modernisation means accepting a principle they regard as plain wrong. Committed republicans object to the very idea of selecting Britain's head of state not on merit or democratic will but by the accident of birth. Slimming down the number of HRHs does nothing to tackle the fundamental wrongness of that practice. Indeed, "reform" may even give heredity a new lease of life by covering it with the deceptive patina of legitimacy. Republican instinct opposes it.

And yet perhaps we ought to learn the lessons of recent success. Making moderate, reasonable demands for change does seem to work. The purist would have dismissed calls to make the royals pay tax as a distraction from the main cause. Yet it established a precedent, making clear that the Windsors were not beyond the reach of politics or parliament. Equally, the Guardian's campaign to scrap the 1701 Act of Settlement - which bars non-Protestants from the succession - struck many hardcore republicans as missing the point: since hereditary succession is bad, who cares which aristocrats are included and which are shut out? Yet raising that issue wrongfooted monarchists, forcing them to admit that the foundations of their institution are archaic. How could they let a non-Protestant on the throne when the monarch doubles as head of the Church of England? Before long, the Guardian's simple plea had royalty's defenders tangled up in knots.

So perhaps republicans need to adopt a twin strategy. We should continue to make the larger case for democracy, even as we support the current calls for a streamlined, transparent royal family. As the recent past has proved, by moving one step at a time we can build a consensus, piece by piece. And each advance steadily whittles away at the very foundations of the monarchy. It is not overnight revolution, but death by a thousand cuts.

For now, we should back Labour MP Tony Wright's call for a commission to probe this central constitutional question. Republicans can argue their case there and, once we've won one reform, we can demand another. Eventually we might establish the consensus needed for the final push - due in the next two or three decades, as Britain finally prepares for the departure of its current, remarkable head of state.

By then republicans should have won over their fellow Britons so that, when we finally bid farewell to the Queen with a full state funeral, the nation unites - to bury this fairytale institution once and for all.

Modern royalty is as silly an idea as a plastic crown or a Perspex sceptre. It is a contradiction. M oreover, for purists, modernisation means accepting a principle they regard as plain wrong. Committed republicans object to the very idea of selecting Britain's head of state not on merit or democratic will but by the accident of birth. Slimming down the number of HRHs does nothing to tackle the fundamental wrongness of that practice. Indeed, "reform" may even give heredity a new lease of life by covering it with the deceptive patina of legitimacy. Republican instinct opposes it. And yet perhaps we ought to learn the lessons of recent success. Making moderate, reasonable demands for change does seem to work. The purist would have dismissed calls to make the royals pay tax as a distraction from the main cause. Yet it established a precedent, making clear that the Windsors were not beyond the reach of politics or parliament. Equally, the Guardian's campaign to scrap the 1701 Act of Settlement - which bars non-Protestants from the succession - struck many hardcore republicans as missing the point: since hereditary succession is bad, who cares which aristocrats are included and which are shut out? Yet raising that issue wrongfooted monarchists, forcing them to admit that the foundations of their institution are archaic. How could they let a non-Protestant on the throne when the monarch doubles as head of the Church of England? Before long, the Guardian's simple plea had royalty's defenders tangled up in knots. So perhaps republicans need to adopt a twin strategy. We should continue to make the larger case for democracy, even as we support the current calls for a streamlined, transparent royal family. As the recent past has proved, by moving one step at a time we can build a consensus, piece by piece. And each advance steadily whittles away at the very foundations of the monarchy. It is not overnight revolution, but death by a thousand cuts. For now, we should back Labour MP Tony Wright's call for a commission to probe this central constitutional question. Republicans can argue their case there and, once we've won one reform, we can demand another. Eventually we might establish the consensus needed for the final push - due in the next two or three decades, as Britain finally prepares for the departure of its current, remarkable head of state. By then republicans should have won over their fellow Britons so that, when we finally bid farewell to the Queen with a full state funeral, the nation unites - to bury this fairytale institution once and for all. webTitle: Don't play around, ministers tell the prince

fields.headline: Don't play around, ministers tell the prince
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Duke of York is to be warned by ministers to toe the line in his new role as a roving ambassador for British industry in an attempt to minimise the risk of another royal public relations fiasco.
fields.body:
The Duke of York is to be warned by ministers to toe the line in his new role as a roving ambassador for British industry in an attempt to minimise the risk of another royal public relations fiasco.

Senior Foreign Office sources have told the Guardian that Prince Andrew will be kept on a tight rein to ensure he has no opportunity to let his personal interests interfere with his official duties as the figurehead of the export industry.

"There is no way that we will let British trade policy be determined by the location of the world's best golf courses," one ministerial source said last night.

The prince's appointment has been a source of considerable disquiet at Buckingham Palace and in Whitehall since it was announced last November. But it is the fallout from the Countess of Wessex's comments to a fake sheikh that has underlined the potential for disaster.

Yesterday, 65 MPs signed a motion calling on the royal family to set up a register of royal interests, setting out their business affairs for pub lic inspection. The MPs "applauded" the palace's decision to consider issuing guidance to royals engaged in business, but they said it should consult the Commons before finalising the details.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, gave the strongest cabinet signal yet that the royal family must come clean about its business dealings - implicitly backing a register.

"The necessity of all of us, be we MPs or indeed, members of the royal family, to operate at all times with the highest degree of probity, is something that we all need to bear in mind," he told the BBC.

Gordon Prentice, the Labour MP who drafted the Commons motion, said: "MPs have to provide this information to the register of members' interests to make sure we make decisions in the public interest rather than our private pecuniary interest. If the royals are up to their elbows in the commercial world it is right that there should be the same transparency."

The development came as the chairman of the Commons public administration committee indicated that he is considering launching a wider examination of the crown and its prerogatives. Tony Wright, Labour MP for Cannock, will discuss the proposal with senior colleagues on both sides of the house. "Parliament has to find a way of moving the debate forward," he said.

The focus of political unease is now turning to Prince Andrew, who is due to retire from the Royal Navy this month after 22 years of service. Most observers had expected him to keep a low profile after formally leaving the navy in July, using the time to indulge his passion for golf.

Instead, he will become a special representative of British Trade International, the government's umbrella body promoting exports and inward investment. The role, which is likely to focus mainly on Middle Eastern countries, is unpaid, but all travel expenses are covered.

Even before the "Sophie tapes" affair, the prince's appointment was being viewed with "heavy trepidation" in diplomatic circles, amid serious concern that his jet-setting lifestyle was a recipe for controversy which could humiliate the royal family and damage the international reputation of the government and British business.

The prince, 41, is taking over the position from his cousin, the Duke of Kent, who has represented British industry overseas for almost 25 years. During that time, he has been on more than 100 foreign visits which, crucially, have attracted little controversy.

Sources said Prince Andrew would be left in no uncertain terms that he would be expected to be "much closer to the Duke of Kent model than the Sophie model" in keeping his opinions to himself.

Yesterday, the Guardian revealed that the palace's imminent review of minor royals' business interests will examine Prince Andrew's new role to ensure that strict rules are in place by the time he takes up the position to prevent a rerun of the Countess of Wessex controversy.

Concerns about the prince first surfaced in January after he was photographed sunbathing on a luxury yacht off the coast of Thailand with a group of topless women. A spokeswoman for the prince insisted last night that he would be taking his new role seriously.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 A contender emerges for Press Officer of the Year. Geoff Baker writes from "The Paul McCartney Press Office" in response to an item of mine elsewhere about Paul telling Liam Neeson that killing animals is the same "as what Hitler did to the f****** Jews". Whether through poor basic comprehension or deliberate misunderstanding, Geoff mistakes the remark that Paul was being crassly flippant for an accusation of anti-semitism. Moreover, he implies it was crystal clear from the original quote that what Paul meant to say was "like f****** Hitler killing the Jews", or the alternate reading "Hitler f****** killing the Jews." It's nice to receive a lecture on accuracy from a man whose Daily Star career is remembered for his exclusive about Princess Margaret joining the cast of Crossroads, while students of public relations everywhere will be impressed by his emollient closing line. "I think you should apologise," concludes Geoff. "You f****** twat." Nice work.

 Meanwhile, a bizarre but diverting sheaf of papers reaches the Diary. It looks like a proposal for Teresa Gorman's autobiography - "presented by Judith Chilcote Agency" it reads on the front page - and this impression is reinforced by a howler on the very first page with which my sane and rational Paul Johnson would be pleased (Teresa lists Ted Heath's dates as PM as 1969-1974). As for the first line - "You don't have to be mad to get into politics, but it helps" - somehow this confirms the authorship beyond question. More of this rich treat very soon.

 "Call me paranoid" is Crazy Janet Daley's opening to a Telegraph rant suggesting the whole Sophie Wessex thing is a New Labour diversionary plot. Alright, Janet, you're paranoid. No, honestly, you are. Now pipe down.

 Surveillance (1): former Mail on Sunday editor Jonathan Holborow discussing the Sunday Mirror disaster on Newsnight. Although Jonty was on cracking form, admirers were baffled by the absence of long-term companion Oswald, the white cotton hankie he presses to his mouth at times of stress. "I recorded the interview and freeze framed it," says one disappointed fan, "and I couldn't detect so much as a faint bulge in his top pocket. Where is Oswald?" We don't know where the garment is, in truth, but by God we're going to find out.

 A shortage of characters continues to plague Tory prospects. A week ago, all MPs and candidates received the pager message: "in order to maintain constant contact with you between now and June 7, please inform Gavin Barwell on 7984 **** if you have any plans to take a sh...". Startled recipients assumed this to be a misrouted command from New Labour, but in fact Mr Barwell had simply run out of characters, and minutes later an addendum arrived. "ort break," it read.

 Richard Taylor of pharo.com sends a press release. I haven't managed to get beyond the headline, "Does Rhodri Morgan hold key to Hess death?", and I doubt I ever will, but good of him to take the trouble.

 Surveillance (2): immigration minister Barbara Roche on Nicky Campbell's Radio 5 phone in, tacitly taking credit for a plan to kick out an awful lot more sad and desperate people this year than last (in fact, as we mentioned recently, the new figures are classic New Labour false accounting). As for your own ancestors, Babs, who fled here from Russia to make a better life for themselves and for descendants like you, it isn't for me to ask whether these "economic migrants" are corkscrewing their way towards the earth's core.

 Many of us were saddened to arrive for work yesterday without being met by an SWP picket line protesting about Jeremy Hardy's departure from this page. Could something possibly be organised, please, for later this week?

webTitle: Gun sale to Jamaican police criticised

fields.headline: Gun sale to Jamaican police criticised
fields.standfirst: Amnesty deplores export by UK firm to force with 'highest kill rate'
fields.trailText: Amnesty International yesterday criticised the government for allowing the export of 500 handguns to the Jamaican police, which, it says, has the "appalling record" of the highest rate of police killings per capita in the world.
fields.body:
Amnesty International yesterday criticised the government for allowing the export of 500 handguns to the Jamaican police, which, it says, has the "appalling record" of the highest rate of police killings per capita in the world.

In a new report about human rights abuses on the island, Amnesty says that 140 people died at the hands of the police last year, with more than 1,400 killed in the past 10 years.

The report draws attention to a letter from the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, last month, justifying the sale of the guns just two days after seven young men were gunned down by the police in disputed circumstances.

The export of guns, from the Devon company, Dince Hill, was delayed for over a year because of concerns about the number of fatal shootings. However, it was given the go-ahead after a visit to Jamaica by Ms Mowlam in her capacity as co-ordinator of the government's international anti-drugs policy.

She was assured that the police were being given human rights training to capture suspects without killing them. In her letter of March 16 to the Labour MP Tony Benn, who had raised the subject on behalf of the pressure group Caribbean Justice, Ms Mowlam said that the government had to be "satisfied that there is no clear risk that the equipment will be used for internal repression or external aggression".

She added that it was important that the Jamaican government now passed investigations of police shootings to a civilian authority.

On March 14, 60 police officers from the crime management unit surrounded a house in the town of Braeton. The Amnesty report says that according to police, the officers were met by a hail of bullets; they returned fire and the seven were killed.

But the report adds: "Local residents told a different story. According to their testimonies, the police captured five of the young men, beat them up in the front yard of the house, and then executed them one at a time."

Amnesty said that a pathologist, Peter Leth, on behalf of Amnesty's Danish medical network, acted as an expert observer at the autopsies. He reported that six of the seven had been shot in the head, some repeatedly, as well as receiving other bullet wounds in some cases. Four had been shot from behind. Dr Leth concluded it was highly unlikely that this pattern of wounds could have occurred by shooting from outside.

While recognising that the Jamaican police had a dangerous job coping with crime by heavily armed gangs, Amnesty said it was "gravely concerned that the authorities in Jamaica are failing to prevent serious and systematic human rights violations at the hands of the police and security forces. The decision to license the supply of handguns to these officers is wholly inappropriate."

The report was presented to the Jamaican police commissioner, Francis Forbes, on Monday by Amnesty's secretary general, Pierre Sane, in what was reported to be a heated meeting in Kingston.

According to the Jamaica Observer newspaper, Mr Forbes said Amnesty was encouraging witnesses in Braeton not to cooperate with the police.

webTitle: Prescott orders rail fares review after Virgin's 10% increase

fields.headline: Prescott orders rail fares review after Virgin's 10% increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott last night ordered an urgent review of rail fare regulation following the furore in the industry at the decision of Virgin Trains to increase fares by almost 10% from May 21.
fields.body:
John Prescott last night ordered an urgent review of rail fare regulation following the furore in the industry at the decision of Virgin Trains to increase fares by almost 10% from May 21.

The deputy prime minister said that some "grey areas" existed on fares and agreed with the example that a standard second class return fare from Manchester to London of £150 looked "excessive". Under Virgin's plan the fare will rise to £164.

Mr Prescott said that he was asking the strategic rail authority to examine the issue and to report back as soon as possible. "It may be possible for us to do something but we must await the outcome of a meeting which the SRA has with the shareholders of Virgin Trains later this week," he said.

When given details of two Lancashire businesswomen who were told by their company that it was cheaper to hire a car to travel to London for a meeting rather than spend £300 on two tickets, Mr Prescott replied: "That does seem expensive."

Fares on long distance journeys beyond a 50-mile radius round London are generally uncontrolled. Most of the big train operators try to keep fares tied to inflation, but Virgin has been a notable exception. Great North Eastern Railway is raising its fares by 3.3%, largely because of the aftermath of the Hatfield rail crash.

In spite of Mr Prescott's intervention, there is likely to be very little that the SRA can do. It exercises control over commuter fares, mainly in the London area, which have been kept below inflation over recent years.

But unregulated fares are a different matter. When the train companies negotiated their original contracts with the rail franchise director, currently Mike Grant, they did so on the understanding that the market would decide what the fares would be.

But this loose arrangement has not worked because some long distance fares have risen well above the rate of inflation in recent years, and by more than 50% in some cases. The SRA is expected to take a tough stand with Virgin and its partner, Stagecoach, when it meets them tomorrow. One way out would be for the government to increase its subsidy to the company, but ministers appear to have already ruled out this option.

The train drivers' union, Aslef, yesterday criticised the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, over remarks which were seen as encouraging people to switch to the roads in protest at Virgin's proposed price increase.

webTitle: Plans for EU force are confused, MPs warn

fields.headline: Plans for EU force are confused, MPs warn
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Plans for a European rapid reaction force are confused, at the mercy of "differing interpretations", and suffer from a "lack of democratic accountability", a cross-party committee of MPs warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans for a European rapid reaction force are confused, at the mercy of "differing interpretations", and suffer from a "lack of democratic accountability", a cross-party committee of MPs warned yesterday.

In a report likely to fuel the debate about the plans, the Commons foreign affairs committee noted that while the Nice treaty stated that the EU's common foreign and security policy must be "compatible" with Nato, the status of the proposed force was dealt with in a separate annexe agreed by EU leaders.

The treaty says moves towards a common EU defence policy "shall respect the obligations of certain member states which see their common defence realised in Nato".

The annexe says the aim is to give the EU "an autonomous capacity to take decisions and action in the security and defence field".

It adds: "In developing this autonomous capacity to take decisions and, where Nato as a whole is not engaged, to launch and conduct EU-led military operations in response to international crises, the EU will be able to carry out the full range of... humanitarian and rescue tasks, peacekeeping tasks and tasks of combat forces in crisis management, including peacemaking".

The Labour-dominated committee said in its report: "It remains to be seen just how soon differing interpretations of the report's conclusions can be reconciled, and what the statement that the EU-led military operations will take place only 'where Nato as a whole is not engaged' will mean in practice."

The US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, has expressed concern about the proposed European force, prompted in part by French insistence that the EU should have an independent military planning structure.

Whitehall insisted that while EU political and military leaders will want to draw up their own strategic plans, operational plans will be drawn up with Nato or national capitals.

The MPs said Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, told them "how much we depend on Nato, how important it is for our defence policy... and we cannot do it without them".

This, the committee said, raised the question whether Turkey, a member of Nato but not of the EU, would be able to block operations by vetoing use of Nato assets.

 Production of a new missile originally due to have been fitted to RAF and navy bombers in 1998 has been delayed indefinitely, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.

BAe Dynamics and the French company Matra had failed to meet MoD specifications for the advanced short-range air-to-air missile, Lady Symons, the defence procurement minister, told the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell.

webTitle: Optimistic staff blame rebuilding programme for poor cleanliness

fields.headline: Optimistic staff blame rebuilding programme for poor cleanliness
fields.trailText: The neutrally painted walls and shiny clean floors of Broadgreen hospital's wards belie its status as one of the dirtiest hospitals in Britain.
fields.body:
The neutrally painted walls and shiny clean floors of Broadgreen hospital's wards belie its status as one of the dirtiest hospitals in Britain.

Yesterday both staff and patients at the hospital in Liverpool appeared to be slightly baffled by the Department of Health's decision to name it for having unacceptable hygiene standards. Broadgreen, which faced the threat of closure for many years, is in the middle of a rebuilding and demolition programme which has effectively turned it into a building site.

It is one of 10 NHS hospitals across the country which have been given an autumn deadline to improve.

Tony Sutton, a 28-year-old day patient on ward 27, said: "This place is much better than the Royal Liverpool hospital in the city centre, which is a real pit in comparison. I think this is a good, clean hospital and there is nothing wrong with it. The ward is light and cheery and the staff make you feel really comfortable. I can't see what the problem is."

When he arrived on the ward yesterday, Rodney Harrison, 34, said he thought it was really clean and he was surprised by how old the building was, as it appeared to be quite modern.

Alison Jager, a staff nurse on the surgical day ward, said it was unfair that the problems with building work had been reflected in the criticisms of the hospital. "The work is being done to improve the long term future of the hospital. I feel quite offended personally that we have been included because of this. The staff who work here are quite happy and confident about the cleanliness of the wards."

Pearce Butler, chief executive of the Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS Trust, said it was obviously disappointed by the inspectors' report, but he said it was clear if you looked around the hospital what effect the rebuilding programme has had.

"We have effectively been working on a building site which has no doubt created real problems," he said.

As if to emphasise his point, the constant din of a hydraulic breaking machine smashing up huge chunks of concrete echoed in the background. He said: "It has been an unusual and difficult year for the hospital and we are confident that we will be able to hit the autumn deadline."

He said he believed that staff morale was high, as they could now look forward to the future as money was being spent on refurbishing the hospital and rebuilding. "The people of Liverpool understand and welcome the work being done," he added.

In the past year, £6.5m has been spent on the infrastructure - replacing car parks and roads circling the hospital and drains, pipes and electrical cables. A further £15m has been earmarked for a new building for surgery. Mr Butler said the investment was being made to secure the long term future of the hospital, which had been in doubt.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said a lot of the problems at Broadgreen related to the infrastructure of the hospital, rather than the specific cleanliness of wards and hygiene. It needed more artwork and car parks required renovation. In addition, furniture needed upgrading and landscaping was also highlighted as an area of concern.

Broadgreen hospital will now be given between £250,000 and £750,000 to lift standards and experts will be sent in over the next few months to help it improve.

webTitle: Ten dirty hospitals get support to clean up

fields.headline: Ten dirty hospitals get support to clean up
fields.standfirst: Milburn announces extra cash and professional teams to help get the worst offenders up to scratch as 40 institutions fail the hygiene test, writes Sarah Boseley
fields.trailText: Milburn announces extra cash and professional teams to help get the worst offenders up to scratch as 40 institutions fail the hygiene test, writes Sarah Boseley.
fields.body:
Ten hospitals in England were yesterday named and shamed as facing the biggest struggle to meet cleanliness targets by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who is sending in professional support teams and delegating extra funds to clean up the poorest performers.

The Department of Health claimed yesterday that standards had risen spectacularly in the last six months: the number of unacceptably dirty hospitals has dropped from 253 to 40.

The drive to clean up hospitals was announced in the government's NHS plan last July, partly in response to patient complaints but also in an effort to reduce the number of infections in hospital, which affect 100,000 people a year, kill 5,000 and cost the NHS about £1bn to treat.

Hospitals have been designated red, yellow or green under a new traffic light scheme for performance measurement. Of the 40 labelled red, 10 are considered to be performing badly enough to require extra money and support teams to help them sort out their cleaning.

One named and shamed hospital trust, the United Bristol Healthcare Trust, which runs the Bristol royal infirmary, complained yesterday that it was dealing with antiquated buildings.

"Parts of the BRI date from 1732, one of the very few 18th century hospital buildings in the UK still used for patient care," it said in a statement which spoke of the "considerable challenge" the trust faced in bringing standards up to the 21st century.

Mr Milburn, visiting the Royal Free hospital in north London which has moved up from a red rating to green, took a tough stance. "Despite this marked improvement, there is to be no let up in our drive to raise standards of hospital cleanliness," he said. "The fundamentals of care are too important to be left to chance."

But Mike Stone of the Patients' Association said he hoped there was not an electioneering element to the cleanliness drive. "It is good that the government is doing something about cleanliness in hospitals, something we have been concerned about for years," he said.

"However, there is still a lot to do and the fact that there are still some 40 that are on a red light is worrying. I just hope this isn't a one-off initiative in the run-up to the general election. Cleanliness in hospitals needs to be at the top of the agenda."

Naming the 10 hospitals, the Department of Health said they were not necessarily the dirtiest in England, but the ones facing the hardest struggle to improve.

They are: Broadgreen hospital, Liverpool; Bristol royal infirmary; Russells Hall hospital, Dudley, West Midlands; Wordsley hospital, Dudley; Corbett hospital, Dudley; Guest hospital, Dudley; Mount Vernon hospital, Northwood, Middlesex; Watford hospital, Watford, Herts; Essex county hospital, Colchester, Essex; Pembury hospital, Tunbridge Wells, Kent.

Each will get between £250,000 and £750,000 to help the clean-up effort. The government has already put in £30m for cleaning, painting and refurbishing everything from wards to visitors' toilets.

A further £30m will, the government hopes, be enough to bring the rest of the hospitals up to scratch and implement new national hospital cleaning standards published yesterday.

Mr Milburn's other secret weapon in the clean-up is the recently announced return of hospital matrons, who will have the "authority to keep the wards clean", said Mr Milburn.

Competitive tendering for hospital cleaning contracts has also been scrapped, because low prices have resulted in lower standards.

The public service union Unison yesterday said it was calling for sustained investment in cleaning and for cleaning staff to be part of the NHS.

Unison representatives will meet the Department of Health on April 24 to push for a set of principles on the cleaner wards initiative.

The union's secretary for health, Paul Marks, said: "The destructive impact of contracting out is still evident by the fact that many of the services named are run by private contractors."

webTitle: Seven held in Ulster mob murder inquiry

fields.headline: Seven held in Ulster mob murder inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland police ombudsman yesterday ordered the arrest of seven people, including an RUC officer, in connection with the murder of Robert Hamill, a Catholic who was kicked to death by a loyalist mob four years ago.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland police ombudsman yesterday gave a powerful demonstration of her new powers by ordering the arrest of seven people, including an RUC officer, in connection with the murder of Robert Hamill, a Catholic who was kicked to death by a loyalist mob four years ago.

The move delighted campaigners who have been demanding a public inquiry into the death of the father of three in April, 1997, and also showed that the ombudsman, Nuala O'Loan, is prepared to use her resources to investigate the most contentious unsolved cases. It was the first time Mrs O'Loan had issued such a directive since being appointed Northern Ireland's first police ombudsman in November last year.

Two women and five men, one an RUC reservist, were seized early yesterday in the Portadown area of Co Armagh, over "matters arising from the murder" of Mr Hamill. They were still being questioned last night. It is understood none of them had been arrested before over the death.

Six men were charged with murdering Mr Hamill following the attack, but the case against five of them collapsed when two key witnesses withdrew their evidence.

A sixth man, Marc Hobson, of Deerpark, Portadown, was later acquitted of the murder by Lord Justice McCollum, sitting without a jury, who said it was impossible to be satisfied of his guilt. He jailed Hobson for four years for causing an affray.

Mr Hamill died in the Royal Victoria hospital in Belfast on May 8, l997, 12 days after being attacked in the centre of Portadown. He had been on a life support machine and never regained consciousness. His third child was born after his death. Witnesses described how up to 30 people beat and kicked Mr Hamill and three friends as they returned from a night out. One onlooker said the crowd chanted: "Die, Fenian, die." Mr Hamill's family have claimed that four armed RUC officers sat in a Land Rover a few yards away and failed to intervene.

Three weeks after her appointment as ombudsman, Mrs O'Loan took over supervision of the investigation into complaints about the police handling of the Hamill inquiry.

Mrs O'Loan said yesterday: "I have previously given a commitment to Mr Hamill's family, and to the public, that I will dedicate the necessary resources to ensure that all avenues are investigated in this case and we get to the truth. This morning's arrests are part of that process."

The Hamill family said it hoped yesterday's operation was a turning point. "Whilst there is already a compelling case for a public inquiry, we hope these recent developments will finally persuade the British government to commit itself to an independent public judicial inquiry," a statement said.

Mrs O'Loan received 950 complaints against the RUC in 11 weeks following her appointment. They have come from Protestants and Catholics throughout the province, and range from issues such as rudeness to serious physical assault.

She has 33 investigators, recruited from 500 applicants worldwide, including lawyers, customs and excise officials and former police. She has promised her investigations will be politically impartial and fully independent from police and government interference. She is already involved in aspects of the inquiries into the murder of the human rights lawyer Rosemary Nelson, blown up by a loyalist car bomb in 1999.

webTitle: Alastair Campbell: The royals are so thick

fields.headline: The royals are so thick
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister's official spokesman disapproves of the monarchy. Below we publish some of his opinions, written when he was a tabloid columnist

Special report: The future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, disapproves of the monarchy. We publish some of his opinions, written when he was a tabloid columnist.
fields.body:
 May I share with you my earliest memory of a political row? It was with my mother, about the Queen - classic Freudian stuff, shrinks would say. I was eight, and refusing to watch the Queen's Christmas Day broadcast.

Though I'm sure I didn't articulate it in this way at the time, I have never gone for the notion that the royal family represents all that is right in this country. They represent to me much that is wrong in this country, notably its class system, obsession with titles, dressing up and patronage and the arrogance of unelected power.

I feel no more or less strongly about the royals now than I did then, while many others have grown to share my views, including my Mum, who thinks the Queen and the Queen Mum were co-conspirators in Prince Charles's adultery.

But now I read that class was not, as I had always thought, a product of a hierarchical colonial system, the monarchy, the church, the landowning classes, the hereditary principle and private education, allied to an apparent desire for subservience. Instead it was an invention of Karl Marx.

Prince Edward would not normally be allowed house room in a column which likes to deal with serious subjects, and Majesty magazine would not normally be allowed across the Campbell threshold. But some statements are so mind-blowing they cannot be ignored.

I quote from the said prince in the said magazine: "In this country we're always looking down, always looking in, trying to belittle ourselves. All this constant thing about class, for instance, which is the worst thing in the world Marx ever invented."

Invented!! Can you believe he said that?

My closest friend, who died not long ago, is buried near Marx's grave in Highgate cemetery, so I see the gaggle of admirers laying roses at the foot of his tombstone regularly. I have never been tempted to leave flowers there myself. Great theories, shame about the practice. Marx did many things. But inventing class was not one of them. He produced theories aimed at creating a classless society, a desire we are led to believe is shared by Honest John [ Major ].

The royal family's existence is a constant reminder of the hollowness of Major's rhetoric, and idiotic statements by its leading members a constant boost to the republican cause. They're fine opening hospitals. It's when they open their mouths they get into trouble.

Which is probably why I've never watched the Queen's Christmas broadcasts.

Extracted from Today, February 24 1994

 Of course one doesn't wish to be offensive to one's future king, does one?

But the day I need lessons on how to raise or educate children from someone who cannot hold his marriage together, does not see his own kids from day to day, delegates their upbringing to nannies and private school spankers, went to a spanking academy himself, needed the power of patronage to get into university, apparently wants to send his own sons to Eton, the spanking academy, whose advisers all come from similar establishments and are similarly ill-suited to speak about the real world, and who courts his mistress with lavatorial suggestions, is some way off.

... His "Back to Basics" offering was one piece of garbage too far.

May 9 1994

 Prince Philip upsets the Hungarians with a little joke about their "pot bellies". Now, to show that insensitive and stupid comments are not generational, Lord Linley reveals himself to be as crass as Uncle Phil.

Presumably he thought that as he was a royal, rather than a silly little boy, Heathrow security men would realise he was joking when he said he had a gun and a grenade in his bag, and nod him on with a chuckle, a tug of the forelock and a doff of the cap.

Instead, they surrounded him, searched him and - apart from failing to get him arrested and banged up - treated him like a normal human being.

There are many reasons for the decline in royal esteem. One is that so many of the royals are thick.

May 10 1993

fields.headline: Extent of farm crisis revealed
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government plans a major reduction in the number of farms and farmers as part of a recovery package for British agriculture in the wake of the foot and mouth outbreak, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The government plans a major reduction in the number of farms and farmers as part of a recovery package for British agriculture in the wake of the foot and mouth outbreak, the Guardian has learned.

Ministers expect that by 2005 as many as 25% of farms - almost all small ones - will have closed or merged, with 50,000 people forced to leave the industry.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) is soon due to publish three major reports analysing the long-term structural crisis in British farming. The reports, central to the government's strategy for agriculture published last year, are likely to argue that large scale farms tend to be more productive, and are more likely to compete successfully in an increasingly liberalised trade in world food.

Some Blairites would like to see the subsidy regime reformed to reward good farming practices, but admit the room for manoeuvre is restricted by EU regimes.

In an attempt to speed up the process of reform in the wake of the crisis, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, is expected to propose an early retirement scheme for those on uneconomic farms. He is also examining incentives to boost the small number of farmers taking out insurance against epidemics, and fresh help to persuade farmers to diversify, including a relaxation of planning regulations.

Maff figures show that many uneconomic farms make more money from offering bed and breakfast, than from farming.

Mr Brown is already studying reports from the three Maff task forces on hill farms, the dairy industry and the cost of inputs to farming, such as energy and capital.

The hill farms task force, chaired by David Arnold Forster, chief executive of English Nature, calls for subsidies to increase early retirement and diversify the financially crippled sector. Despite subsi dies of £33,000 a year, the average income of hill farmers is only £9,000 a year.

Mr Brown wants to create an industry that more effectively generates farmer income, rather than simply supporting sheep numbers.

Subsidies based on sheep numbers, poorly policed by Maff, were a cause of the large sheep movements which rapidly spread the epidemic. One senior official described the current unregulated sheep regime as being like the Wild West.

Mr Brown has broadly hinted at a large scale early retirement scheme. He told MPs on Monday: "The big decision for farmers who have received a compensation payment is whether to restock the farmholding - or pause and think very carefully what the future holds for them."

A serious discussion had to occur, he said, about the future support arrangement for the sheep regime. In 1999, nearly 25% of hill farmers were older than 60.

Any recovery plan would come on top of the £500m in various compensation payments to farmers whose animals have been slaughtered. Before the foot and mouth outbreak, Maff's working papers on the economic outlook for agriculture already predicted that profitability would only return if there was a further shift towards larger enterprises.

Maff predicts that the number of farm workers could fall by 3.5% a year. As a result, the number of farmers could fall below 300,000 by 2006, a drop of 100,000 since 1994.

The fall in the number of farms, on top of existing trends, could be 15-20%, although some may be merged into larger businesses.

The ministry's figures reveal a tale of unproductive cattle and sheep farms. In 1999, 75% of the sheep and cattle holdings were responsible for 98% of output. The largest 10% of holdings are responsible for 35% of output. Most smallholdings - 17% in 1999 - are in Cumbria, which is worst hit by foot and mouth.

However, there is likely to be a fierce Whitehall battle over whether Maff and the interests of agribusiness should be allowed to dominate any recovery plan. On March 3, Mr Brown announced a full-scale inquiry into the foot and mouth crisis, including the implications of increased world travel, the globalisation of trade and the effect of modern farming on disease control.

Maff believes it set a clear direction for future policy in its Strategy for Farming document last spring. Since then, however, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, has caused consternation by urging a wider inquiry, amounting to a royal commission, on the future of farming. Downing Street favours a brief external inquiry looking at the underlying issues.

webTitle: Optimistic staff blame rebuilding programme for poor cleanliness

fields.headline: Optimistic staff blame rebuilding programme for poor cleanliness
fields.trailText: The neutrally painted walls and shiny clean floors of Broadgreen hospital's wards belie its status as one of the dirtiest hospitals in Britain.
fields.body:
The neutrally painted walls and shiny clean floors of Broadgreen hospital's wards belie its status as one of the dirtiest hospitals in Britain.

Yesterday both staff and patients at the hospital in Liverpool appeared to be slightly baffled by the Department of Health's decision to name it for having unacceptable hygiene standards. Broadgreen, which faced the threat of closure for many years, is in the middle of a rebuilding and demolition programme which has effectively turned it into a building site.

It is one of 10 NHS hospitals across the country which have been given an autumn deadline to improve.

Tony Sutton, a 28-year-old day patient on ward 27, said: "This place is much better than the Royal Liverpool hospital in the city centre, which is a real pit in comparison. I think this is a good, clean hospital and there is nothing wrong with it. The ward is light and cheery and the staff make you feel really comfortable. I can't see what the problem is."

When he arrived on the ward yesterday, Rodney Harrison, 34, said he thought it was really clean and he was surprised by how old the building was, as it appeared to be quite modern.

Alison Jager, a staff nurse on the surgical day ward, said it was unfair that the problems with building work had been reflected in the criticisms of the hospital. "The work is being done to improve the long term future of the hospital. I feel quite offended personally that we have been included because of this. The staff who work here are quite happy and confident about the cleanliness of the wards."

Pearce Butler, chief executive of the Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS Trust, said it was obviously disappointed by the inspectors' report, but he said it was clear if you looked around the hospital what effect the rebuilding programme has had.

"We have effectively been working on a building site which has no doubt created real problems," he said.

As if to emphasise his point, the constant din of a hydraulic breaking machine smashing up huge chunks of concrete echoed in the background. He said: "It has been an unusual and difficult year for the hospital and we are confident that we will be able to hit the autumn deadline."

He said he believed that staff morale was high, as they could now look forward to the future as money was being spent on refurbishing the hospital and rebuilding. "The people of Liverpool understand and welcome the work being done," he added.

In the past year, £6.5m has been spent on the infrastructure - replacing car parks and roads circling the hospital and drains, pipes and electrical cables. A further £15m has been earmarked for a new building for surgery. Mr Butler said the investment was being made to secure the long term future of the hospital, which had been in doubt.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said a lot of the problems at Broadgreen related to the infrastructure of the hospital, rather than the specific cleanliness of wards and hygiene. It needed more artwork and car parks required renovation. In addition, furniture needed upgrading and landscaping was also highlighted as an area of concern.

Broadgreen hospital will now be given between £250,000 and £750,000 to lift standards and experts will be sent in over the next few months to help it improve.

webTitle: Alistair Beaton's satirical play on Labour

fields.headline: The PM, the wonk and the wardrobe
fields.standfirst: When real life has spin doctors hiding in prime ministers' wardrobes, how can fiction top it? Alistair Beaton on how he made a drama out of a farce Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: When real life has spin doctors hiding in prime ministers' wardrobes, how can fiction top it? Alistair Beaton on how he made a drama out of a farce.
fields.body:
It was October 1994. Blackpool. In a suite of the Imperial Hotel a drama was unfolding that would define the future of New Labour. But was it a comedy or a tragedy? It certainly had elements of both. Tony Blair, with a small but devoted band of special advisers, had decided in secret that if he was serious about coming to power, he needed to dump clause four, the party's historic commitment to public ownership. To avoid leaks (and the tedium of democratic debate) members of the shadow cabinet were being informed of this dramatic change at the last possible moment.

Not consulted, just informed. One by one they trooped obediently into Blair's rooms in Blackpool to be told that in a few hours' time the leader would tell his party conference that clause four had to go. This was a bit like the disciples being told by Jesus that he'd had second thoughts about the sermon on the mount. Stunned members of the shadow cabinet (only John Prescott had been told in advance) reeled out of Blair's rooms wondering what had hit them. To avoid embarrassment, the policy wonks and spin doctors who had engineered the coup had been told to stay out of the way.

Unfortunately, one of them, the focus-group expert Philip Gould, got his timing wrong and had to hide in a wardrobe. Hiding in wardrobes is, of course, the stuff of farce.

On that particular day, I knew nothing of the goings-on at the Imperial Hotel. I was down at the conference centre, preparing to listen to Blair's conference speech before filing my nightly conference report for Radio 4. As in the previous few years, I had been asked by The World Tonight to attend all the party conferences that autumn, and each evening provide a satirical report on all that was most ridiculous, laughable or just plain mendacious about each day's events.

So that's how I found myself in the Winter Gardens that day, not far from the troubling figures of Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell, as Blair electrified conference with his most radical "modernising" measure to date. I found it difficult to decide which of the three men I wanted to observe most closely.

Was it Blair, up there on the platform, with his false blokeyness, his flights of verbless rhetoric, his toe-curling attempts at being funny, and his rehearsed spontaneity? Was it Campbell, an intensely physical presence: brooding, thoughtful, yet always combative and primed for action? Or was it Mandelson, sinister, tight, controlled, unmoving, like a lizard basking on a rock, waiting for an unsuspecting lefty to pass within range of his tongue? And which of the three was really running the show?

Much later, when I learned of the farcical comings and goings in the Imperial Hotel, I began to think about a comedy that could distil the synthetic drama of a party conference into the genuine drama of a stage play. With the spin doctors and the policy wonks as my protagonists, I was able to side-step the problem of asking actors to impersonate well-known politicians.
Going for the wonks had the added advantage of allowing me to harness the perception that power increasingly rests in the hands of unelected advisers. There remained the problem of the absurd. When real-life politics includes senior advisers hiding in prime ministers' wardrobes, where is the space for comic exaggeration?

When working as a script editor on various radio and television programmes, I would often ask the writer to change something that I felt was lacking in truth, because without truth, there is no good comedy. With astonishing frequency the response was: "Oh, but that really happened to me." I believed them. But what they had failed to do was make that reality as credible as fictional reality.

To seduce the audience into believing, the writer has to create a remorseless logic of truth, which has everything to do with what is happening on the stage. This may or may not be more grotesque than what is happening in the real world, but it must be internally consistent; then it becomes possible to create all kinds of satirical grotesques that the audience will accept. This is the process that made our rehearsals as arduous as they were compelling.

Is Feelgood a satire? Well, I suppose it is, but satire always sounds didactic to me. It conjures up images of earnest lefties pretending not to be bored as they sit watching turgid plays about the state of the nation. And yet Feelgood certainly contains as much anger as many apparently more "serious" plays. I voted Labour in May 1997, and felt an overwhelming sense of relief to see Britain liberated from the bunch of second-raters who had been running it for so long. Despite the overwhelming attractions of William Hague, I shall again vote Labour in the next election. But I cannot deny that I feel cheated. This is not a left/right issue. I don't have a great deal of sympathy for the dreary hymns of old Labour socialism. But quite simply, New Labour became so good at coming to power, it didn't know what to do once it got there.

The worm at the heart of New Labour's rose is the idea of consensus politics. The stubborn refusal to take on vested interests. The pathetic, puppy-like reliance on focus groups. The reduction of politics to a form of marketing, where your researchers tell you what policy the punters would like to buy and so you set about manufacturing the product to fit. It is no way to bring about change. It is, essentially, a reactive and thus a reactionary process.

And once the Conservatives have dumped William Hague and got themselves a grown-up leader, this is the path that they too will follow. This is the way of the future. Feelgood may be a satire on New Labour, but in the end I fear it's also a play about the whole of modern politics.
fields.bodyText: It was October 1994. Blackpool. In a suite of the Imperial Hotel a drama was unfolding that would define the future of New Labour. But was it a comedy or a tragedy? It certainly had elements of both. Tony Blair, with a small but devoted band of special advisers, had decided in secret that if he was serious about coming to power, he needed to dump clause four, the party's historic commitment to public ownership. To avoid leaks (and the tedium of democratic debate) members of the shadow cabinet were being informed of this dramatic change at the last possible moment. Not consulted, just informed. One by one they trooped obediently into Blair's rooms in Blackpool to be told that in a few hours' time the leader would tell his party conference that clause four had to go. This was a bit like the disciples being told by Jesus that he'd had second thoughts about the sermon on the mount. Stunned members of the shadow cabinet (only John Prescott had been told in advance) reeled out of Blair's rooms wondering what had hit them. To avoid embarrassment, the policy wonks and spin doctors who had engineered the coup had been told to stay out of the way. Unfortunately, one of them, the focus-group expert Philip Gould, got his timing wrong and had to hide in a wardrobe. Hiding in wardrobes is, of course, the stuff of farce. On that particular day, I knew nothing of the goings-on at the Imperial Hotel. I was down at the conference centre, preparing to listen to Blair's conference speech before filing my nightly conference report for Radio 4. As in the previous few years, I had been asked by The World Tonight to attend all the party conferences that autumn, and each evening provide a satirical report on all that was most ridiculous, laughable or just plain mendacious about each day's events. So that's how I found myself in the Winter Gardens that day, not far from the troubling figures of Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell, as Blair electrified conference with his most radical "modernising" measure to date. I found it difficult to decide which of the three men I wanted to observe most closely. Was it Blair, up there on the platform, with his false blokeyness, his flights of verbless rhetoric, his toe-curling attempts at being funny, and his rehearsed spontaneity? Was it Campbell, an intensely physical presence: brooding, thoughtful, yet always combative and primed for action? Or was it Mandelson, sinister, tight, controlled, unmoving, like a lizard basking on a rock, waiting for an unsuspecting lefty to pass within range of his tongue? And which of the three was really running the show? Much later, when I learned of the farcical comings and goings in the Imperial Hotel, I began to think about a comedy that could distil the synthetic drama of a party conference into the genuine drama of a stage play. With the spin doctors and the policy wonks as my protagonists, I was able to side-step the problem of asking actors to impersonate well-known politicians. Going for the wonks had the added advantage of allowing me to harness the perception that power increasingly rests in the hands of unelected advisers. There remained the problem of the absurd. When real-life politics includes senior advisers hiding in prime ministers' wardrobes, where is the space for comic exaggeration? When working as a script editor on various radio and television programmes, I would often ask the writer to change something that I felt was lacking in truth, because without truth, there is no good comedy. With astonishing frequency the response was: "Oh, but that really happened to me." I believed them. But what they had failed to do was make that reality as credible as fictional reality. To seduce the audience into believing, the writer has to create a remorseless logic of truth, which has everything to do with what is happening on the stage. This may or may not be more grotesque than what is happening in the real world, but it must be internally consistent; then it becomes possible to create all kinds of satirical grotesques that the audience will accept. This is the process that made our rehearsals as arduous as they were compelling. Is Feelgood a satire? Well, I suppose it is, but satire always sounds didactic to me. It conjures up images of earnest lefties pretending not to be bored as they sit watching turgid plays about the state of the nation. And yet Feelgood certainly contains as much anger as many apparently more "serious" plays. I voted Labour in May 1997, and felt an overwhelming sense of relief to see Britain liberated from the bunch of second-raters who had been running it for so long. Despite the overwhelming attractions of William Hague, I shall again vote Labour in the next election. But I cannot deny that I feel cheated. This is not a left/right issue. I don't have a great deal of sympathy for the dreary hymns of old Labour socialism. But quite simply, New Labour became so good at coming to power, it didn't know what to do once it got there. The worm at the heart of New Labour's rose is the idea of consensus politics. The stubborn refusal to take on vested interests. The pathetic, puppy-like reliance on focus groups. The reduction of politics to a form of marketing, where your researchers tell you what policy the punters would like to buy and so you set about manufacturing the product to fit. It is no way to bring about change. It is, essentially, a reactive and thus a reactionary process. And once the Conservatives have dumped William Hague and got themselves a grown-up leader, this is the path that they too will follow. This is the way of the future. Feelgood may be a satire on New Labour, but in the end I fear it's also a play about the whole of modern politics.

fields.headline: A little local difficulty
fields.standfirst: Greater centralisation is neccessary if we want to avoid a postcode lottery for public services. But, asks Tony Travers, is it a price we are prepared to pay?
fields.trailText: Greater centralisation is neccessary if we want to avoid a postcode lottery for public services. But is it a price we are prepared to pay?
fields.body:
Failures - real or perceived - in Britain's health service, schools, railways and, most recently, in the regulation of agriculture have led to demands for improved public provision and standards that more nearly equate to those enjoyed in other European countries. Overseas commentators cast baleful eyes over our waiting lists, derailments and pyres.

But spending is only part of the story. The distribution of services from area to area has become a matter of high politics. Regardless of whether the quality of services is up to scratch, we have seen successive governments struggle to ensure that there is a fair allocation of hospitals, universities and, now, publicly funded scientific research facilities around the country.

Throughout the 20th century governments refined the complex methods used to assist local authorities where property values were low, preventing them wielding the rates to pay for their spending. From 1945 new grants were paid to support schools and social services. In the 1970s, a resources allocation working party generated a formula that implied a major redistribution of health resources away from London to the rest of the country. The Thatcher and Major governments - perhaps without realising what they were doing - further refined the measurement of local government spending needs.

All this effort to pay grants to support councils and health authorities with high needs and/or low resources was largely to achieve a single objective: territorial equity. Today's public service agreements (PSAs) and the increased targeting of public resources through such schemes as Sure Start, designed to improve the lot of the disadvantaged, attest to the Blair government's desire to bring everywhere up to common standards of educational achievement, public health and even freedom from crime. The PSAs seek, by a given date, to secure minimum levels of achievement by all local authorities. Once again, the assumption is that wherever people live, they have a right to expect a minimum (or average) public service outcome.

The electorate's expectation that public service levels should be broadly similar throughout the country has led to frantic efforts to find distribution formulae and targeting methods that are "fair". The results of one such redistribution, for education, are shown in the chart. Poorer areas such as Manchester and Tower Hamlets get bigger needs assessments (and spending levels) for their schools than their richer counterparts Stockport and Richmond-upon-Thames. But don't the children deserve equal treatment? Few politicians of any party would be willing to defend the proposition that service levels should vary from one authority to another simply because the people who live there have different income or need levels.

Behind all this lies a profound question: do we need more centralisation in order to secure equal access to public services? It cannot be avoided any longer. Ministers feel they are under pressure to ensure that standards in schools, libraries, playing fields and transport are as equal as possible in every council, constituency and region. There must be no postcode lottery for operations, prescription drugs or, indeed, anything else.

But if we want this level of equal access to public services (whether or not it is actually achieved) is there any way of delivering it other than massive central intervention? In a new paper for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation* we have set out how, in the past, supporters of local government asserted that more local control and the freedom to determine taxation should be the main driver of the reform of council finance. Yet if local authorities were given such freedom, it would inevitably result in widening differences in local service provision and tax levels.

Ask yourself these questions. First, would it be acceptable for a child who lives on one side of a street to have access to a nursery school, while another on the opposite side (in a different council area) did not? In other words, should the accident of location dictate whether or not a three-year-old goes to a decent school or not? Is it acceptable if the City of Westminster council could have far higher service levels at the same time as setting far lower tax levels than any other council in the country (which is approximately the case)? The corollary of this is that Liverpool has far higher tax levels and considerably lower spending.

Unless the public accepts that it is reasonable for the three-year-old to go without a nursery place and for Westminster to be rich and low-taxed, it is hard to see how central meddling and control can be avoided. For a number of reasons, the British have come to expect far greater efforts to achieve territorial equity than virtually any other advanced country.

Studies show that measures taken by the centre to secure "equalisation" in local authority services are complex and sophisticated. Similar central formulae are used to allocate money for health, what is now called learning and skills (until recently further education and the training and enterprise councils), universities and now the regional development agencies. Within council areas themselves formulae are used to allocated money school by school.

As the government ponders the future of public provision - its own future - it needs to think seriously about whether it wants to have local variation between essential services. Other countries manage to get by with rather less top-down central control. On the other hand, expectations in those countries do not extend to all-embracing demands for precise territorial equity.

As the public expenditure machine pushes the new money announced last July into hospitals, schools and transport, perhaps we should stop to wonder whether our extreme centralisation is a price we really want to pay for our aspirations of fairness.

*A new account? Choices in Local Government Finance, by Gerry Stoker and Tony Travers, Joseph Rowntree Foundation, to be published April 27

webTitle: Ten dirty hospitals get support to clean up

fields.headline: Ten dirty hospitals get support to clean up
fields.trailText: Ten hospitals in England were yesterday named and shamed as facing the biggest struggle to meet cleanliness targets by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who is sending in professional support teams and delegating extra funds to clean up the poorest performers.
fields.body:
Ten hospitals in England were yesterday named and shamed as facing the biggest struggle to meet cleanliness targets by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who is sending in professional support teams and delegating extra funds to clean up the poorest performers.

The Department of Health claimed yesterday that standards had risen spectacularly in the last six months: the number of unacceptably dirty hospitals has dropped from 253 to 40.

The drive to clean up hospitals was announced in the government's NHS plan last July, partly in response to patient complaints but also in an effort to reduce the number of infections in hospital, which affect 100,000 people a year, kill 5,000 and cost the NHS about £1bn to treat.

Hospitals have been designated red, yellow or green under a new traffic light scheme for performance measurement. Of the 40 labelled red, 10 are considered to be performing badly enough to require extra money and support teams to help them sort out their cleaning.

One named and shamed hospital trust, the United Bristol Healthcare Trust, which runs the Bristol royal infirmary, complained yesterday that it was dealing with antiquated buildings.

"Parts of the BRI date from 1732, one of the very few 18th century hospital buildings in the UK still used for patient care," it said in a statement which spoke of the "considerable challenge" the trust faced in bringing standards up to the 21st century.

Mr Milburn, visiting the Royal Free hospital in north London which has moved up from a red rating to green, took a tough stance. "Despite this marked improvement, there is to be no let up in our drive to raise standards of hospital cleanliness," he said. "The fundamentals of care are too important to be left to chance."

But Mike Stone of the Patients' Association said he hoped there was not an electioneering element to the cleanliness drive. "It is good that the government is doing something about cleanliness in hospitals, something we have been concerned about for years," he said.

"However, there is still a lot to do and the fact that there are still some 40 that are on a red light is worrying. I just hope this isn't a one-off initiative in the run-up to the general election. Cleanliness in hospitals needs to be at the top of the agenda."

Naming the 10 hospitals, the Department of Health said they were not necessarily the dirtiest in England, but the ones facing the hardest struggle to improve.

They are: Broadgreen hospital, Liverpool; Bristol royal infirmary; Russells Hall hospital, Dudley, West Midlands; Wordsley hospital, Dudley; Corbett hospital, Dudley; Guest hospital, Dudley; Mount Vernon hospital, Northwood, Middlesex; Watford hospital, Watford, Herts; Essex county hospital, Colchester, Essex; Pembury hospital, Tunbridge Wells, Kent.

Each will get between £250,000 and £750,000 to help the clean-up effort. The government has already put in £30m for cleaning, painting and refurbishing everything from wards to visitors' toilets.

A further £30m will, the government hopes, be enough to bring the rest of the hospitals up to scratch and implement new national hospital cleaning standards published yesterday.

Mr Milburn's other secret weapon in the clean-up is the recently announced return of hospital matrons, who will have the "authority to keep the wards clean", said Mr Milburn.

Competitive tendering for hospital cleaning contracts has also been scrapped, because low prices have resulted in lower standards.

The public service union Unison yesterday said it was calling for sustained investment in cleaning and for cleaning staff to be part of the NHS.

Unison representatives will meet the Department of Health on April 24 to push for a set of principles on the cleaner wards initiative.

The union's secretary for health, Paul Marks, said: "The destructive impact of contracting out is still evident by the fact that many of the services named are run by private contractors."

fields.headline: RTL to rebrand Pearson TV
fields.trailText: Pearson Television is about to disappear as owner RTL has appointed consultants to begin working on a new identity for the production company. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Pearson Television, which makes some of the best-know programmes in broadcasting, is about to disappear. RTL, the pan-European commercial TV and radio group which now owns the business, has appointed consultants to begin working on a new identity for the production company.

Pearson, the media group which owns the Financial Times, injected the production business into RTL when it was formed last year through a merger with CLT-UFA. Insiders said the decision to rebrand the TV division was in part driven by the acceptance that Pearson is unlikely to be a long-term investor in RTL.

Pearson TV is behind some of the most popular programmes on the small screen, including Baywatch, The Bill, Neighbours and The Price is Right - still popular in the US.

RTL has promised to make more shares available by September to increase liquidity and allow the company to take a berth in the FTSE 100. There is currently a free float of just 11%. The threshold for inclusion in the Footsie is 15%.

Insiders say it is unlikely that Pearson will be a seller in the short term because of the present state of the markets which has depressed RTL's share price. German business press has instead suggested that WAZ, a local publishing company, may be willing to dispose of its stake. WAZ has a 7% stake in RTL but the voting rights rest with Bertelsmann which has a 60% share.

Didier Bellens recently admitted that Pearson TV had suffered from a lack of investment in the years prior to its inclusion in RTL. At the MIP TV conference in Cannes he said: "What was lacking in Pearson TV was investment in new ideas, new formats and new pilots. We knew that. When we bought it, it was known throughout the market. You can live for a while on the big brands, The Bill, Neighbours, The Price is Right. But in every business you need to invest in R&D. When we closed the deal in July last year, we immediately announced we would double investment in 2000 and again in 2001."

Two of its newest formats are Greed, a game show presented in this country by Jerry Springer, and Pop Idol, the follow up to Popstars.

An insider said the company had ruled out simply renaming Pearson TV as RTL because it needed to retain some independence from the broadcast channels owned by the group. Although Mr Bellens is keen to develop synergies through distribution of programming among its 22 TV channels, he has stressed the need to continue selling programming to other broadcasters.
