webTitle: Pensioner held on obscene mail to TV stars

fields.headline: Pensioner held on obscene mail to TV stars
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Police investigating obscene letters sent to famous women, including broadcasters and actors, yesterday arrested a man in his 70s. By David Ward.
fields.body:
Police investigating obscene letters sent to famous women, including broadcasters and actors, yesterday arrested a man in his 70s.

Metropolitan police detectives raided a house in Wigan, Greater Manchester, and detained the man on suspicion of causing a public nuisance.

He was questioned at a police station in Manchester and was released on bail last night until June 12 pending further inquiries.

Women who received letters included Joan Bakewell, Today presenter Sue MacGregor, former Avengers star Diana Rigg, former Pan's People dancer Dee Dee Wilde and Nyree Dawn Porter, who found fame in the BBC's 1967 adaption of The Forsyte Saga.

Anne Heseltine, the wife of former deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine, was another victim.

Yesterday's arrest was based on information provided by two viewers after an appeal last month on BBC's Crime watch UK. Both viewers are thought to have named the same man.

After the programme, other actors contacted police to say they had received similar letters. Extracts were shown to indicate the writer's distinctive writing style.

The writer, always presumed to be a man, is thought to have sent letters to more than 60 women during the last 20 years. Many were at the peak of their fame in the 1970s and 80s.

The letters, all in longhand, were posted in airmail envelopes bearing Bolton, Lancashire or Manchester postmarks. They were sent to the homes of the women or to their agents and described sexual fantasies in explict detail.

Police linked the letters in December when Moira Lister complained about a note she received while appearing in a play in London. She revealed that she had been "dogged for years" by the writer.

On Crimewatch, Ms Dawn Porter commented: "It is he who is the victim, not us. He needs help." Ms Bakewell said: "This just has to come to an end. We've been harassed and patient long enough. It is time he realises how much he is upsetting people."

Mrs Heseltine revealed later that she had received two letters. She said they contained "lots of rather obscene pictures which were very small and fuzzy".

She described writers of such letters as "rather pathetic people, by and large. I don't think they are harmful to anyone but themselves".

webTitle: Evans and Piper are tabloid dream match

fields.headline: Evans and Piper are tabloid dream match
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The millionaire DJ Chris Evans is to marry pop singer Billie Piper, according to the tabloids yesterday. By Esther Addley.
fields.body:
By tabloid standards, stranger things have happened. But even seasoned celebrity watchers were yesterday wondering at a match which seemed just too perfectly made in showbiz heaven to be true.

The millionaire DJ and habitual self-publicist Chris Evans is to marry his girlfriend of less than four months, the pop singer Billie Piper, according to the tabloids yesterday.

The Mirror said the couple, together since December, are planning an August wedding at his £6m mansion in Surrey. The newspaper quoted "an insider" who claimed to have information that Piper, 18, had proposed to Evans on his 35th birthday earlier this month.

It is the latest twist in a relationship that, though short, has been public and frequently bizarre. Just three days after they became an item, Evans, the former chief of Virgin Radio and worth an estimated £80m, bought his new girlfriend a £105,000 Ferrari filled with red roses, even though the teenager had not passed her driving test.

Ritchie Neville, the singer from boy band 5ive, to whom Piper had previously been engaged, could only - publicly - bemoan his lot.

Adding to the drama, the singer was involved in a court case last month, in which a woman aged 32 was given an 18-month suspended prison sentence for threatening to decapitate her after she allegedly gave the woman a "sly" look during filming for a TV show.

Observers who have raised an eyebrow at the 17 year age gap in the pairing have also been a little cynical over the DJ's highly publicised fling with the former Spice Girl, Geri Halliwell. The nation's two most famous redheads embarked on a tabloid blitz in November 1999 after they claimed to have fallen in love, he briefing the Mirror in detail, she the Sun. But only a week later the romance was over, with cynics saying the announcements had coincided with the release of a single by Halliwell, which went straight to number one. The pair also shared the same PR company, Freud Communications.

Piper has also been accused of capitalising on her relationship with Evans. She has been dogged by rumours that her record company, Innocent, was close to dropping her after her latest album failed to succeed like her early singles.

Evans's influence on the teenager has not been universally welcomed: the singer's PR company, Vital, dropped her in February, reportedly as a result of his influence. And two weeks ago Piper's manager, Nicki Chapman, one of the judges on the TV programme Popstars, cancelled her three year contract.

Record companies rarely object to tabloid coverage, but when their stars become less pliable, especially when guided by seasoned media operators, their enthusiasm can cool.

Both stars' agents refused to comment yesterday. But it may be worth bearing in mind that Evans's birthday, when Piper supposedly proposed, is also April Fool's Day.

fields.headline: Finding time to care
fields.standfirst: In the wake of recent horrific reports of cruelty to long-term patients,  David Brindle looks at a new move to heal wounds within the mental health sector
fields.trailText: In the wake of recent horrific reports of cruelty to long-term patients, David Brindle looks at a new move to heal wounds within the mental health sector
fields.body:
Nursing staff swearing at patients, manhandling them, feeding them on the toilet and punishing them by locking them out in a verandah area without adequate clothing or blankets. An image of care in a bygone era? No, these were practices in the recent past at the former Garlands hospital in Carlisle.

Exposure of what went on in the hospital's Kielder House unit, as first revealed by whistle-blowers and then, last November, censured by the government's new commission for health improvement, came as a salutary reminder of the all too often woeful standards of care of long-term mental health patients. With the focus so much on care in the community in the past 20 years, the welfare of those left in hospital has been neglected.

"Those" in this context does not mean just the patients - the most difficult and often most unrewarding to nurse. It also means the staff - the carers who, for whatever reason, have not followed the majority of patients into the community and who have continued to work in under-resourced and often shabby hospital settings.

"You end up with a group of staff who are perhaps not the most vigorous but who, to put it bluntly, have probably not been well-served by the organisation," says Roger Paxton, head of psychological therapies and research at St George's Hospital in Morpeth, Northumberland. "All the support for staff has been directed at those in the community. So you have a relatively neglected staff group looking after a relatively neglected client group."

St George's, not so far from Garlands as the crow flies, but a million miles in terms of practice, is taking steps to make good this neglect. In a necessarily slow but steady programme, it is providing intensive training and support for staff who work with its 64 continuing care in-patients, some of whom have been there decades. And the results are already apparent.

Known as Baits (behaviour analysis and intervention training and support), the programme aims to improve understanding of people whose serious mental health problems manifest in challenging behaviour, including disruption, violence and extreme withdrawal. It was developed originally for use in learning disability services, where some staff were found to take an extreme view of those they were supposedly caring for.

"They saw these people as actually evil," says John Iceton, senior nurse therapist at St George's and one of the programme's founders. "They believed they were doing these things to staff personally, to get at them or hurt them. They really had no idea about challenging behaviour."

Translated into a mental health context, the programme runs for a minimum 17 weeks and involves taking an entire staff group, of all grades, off duty for (usually) whole day workshops once a week. It is, therefore, a substantial investment of time and resources and requires solid backing from managers.

The starting point is a one-to-one interview with each staff member, lasting perhaps three hours, during which they are encouraged to talk candidly about their feelings for their patients. And they do. "It's almost as if they want to off-load everything they have been carrying around for years," says Iceton. "They think they are not supposed to think anything bad about clients, but they do - they are human. Once you've got rid of those negative thoughts and feelings, people are in a better position to start thinking more constructively about what actually happens."

Over the weeks, the staff groups work on understanding first their own reactions to challenging behaviour, then the patients who display it. One premise is that such behaviour is functional, perhaps to attract attention or avoid tasks; a second is that it is interlinked with the staff's own behaviour. "Staff find that difficult at first," says Iceton.

At the end of the course, participants are prompted to think what they could do to enrich the lives of their patients. Typically, this is nothing ambitious but the kind of everyday activity the rest of us take for granted: going out to a pub, perhaps, or even just getting them to help with their own laundry. "It could be something quite simple, like going shopping," says Julia Rochester, nurse specialist working on Baits. "Some of them will not have been shopping for years."

The programme, which some 40 staff have been through so far, is being formally evaluated by the University of Newcastle upon Tyne. Researchers are assessing the increased knowledge and competencies of staff and the extent of application of Baits-inspired techniques. But judging simply by the enthusiasm of staff at St George's, now part of the new Newcastle, North Tyneside and Northumberland mental health trust, the approach is a clear success.

"I had worries," admits Paxton. "Particularly on one ward with a larger-than-life ward manager: I thought she would react badly. But I got it wrong; I misjudged the reaction. That's because it's not ordinary training at all. Right from the start, you are listening to the staff.

"Of course, it's fundamentally about delivering a decent service for people who are hugely needy and, frankly, neglected. But in order to deliver that, you have got to give something to the staff."

webTitle: What happens when a mentally ill patient turns aggressive?

fields.headline: Liberating experience for staff and patients
fields.trailText: So what happens when a St George's patient turns aggressive?
fields.body:
So what happens when a St George's patient turns aggressive? "What we wouldn't do is look at an incident in isolation," says Chris Rutherford, senior clinical nurse. "We'd maybe go back 48 hours to see what had happened, what had changed perhaps, to lead up to it. It's all about habit."

Rutherford believes that undergoing the Baits programme has changed her attitudes to patients - and to herself. "Before, you looked at it as the client's problem," she says. "But it's not always the other person. It's a positive way of thinking."

What particularly impresses lower-grade staff is that the programme is undertaken jointly by all members of a nursing team. Jackie Minnock, a nursing assistant, recalls: "It was across the board; it didn't matter what grade you were, everybody got the same training. We could have our views and values taken on board and I feel now that I can disagree with Chris, even though I'm an A-grade and she's an F."

Sharon Fenton, an E-grade staff nurse, describes the programme as a "liberating" experience. She believes that she is, as a result, confident to intervene if she witnesses a staff/patient confrontation or a potential loss of temper on either side.

"If you see a colleague having a difficulty, you would help them out - maybe take over the situation," Fenton says. "Afterwards, you would spend some time talking through what was happening. In the past, the person might have been left to get on with it."

Success is gauged in small ways: the highly dependent patient now making her own tea and coffee; the woman helped to overcome her fear of public transport.

"We first went with her on the bus, then moved to a seat in front of her, then got off at the stop before her," says Minnock. "It took a long time, but she is discharged and at home now."

Patience is essential. As Rutherford says: "It's slow, it's about breaking the chain."

webTitle: G2: The fall of Sunny Delight

fields.headline: The last straw
fields.standfirst: It was a dream recipe: take a new soft drink, add some great marketing and sit back and watch the profits soar. But then the backlash began. Parents read the ingredients, a girl in the US turned yellow and sales began to slide.  Felicity Lawrence  on how Sunny Delight lost its shine
fields.trailText:
It was a dream recipe: take a new soft drink, add some great marketing and sit back and watch the profits soar. But then the backlash began. Parents read the ingredients, a girl in the US turned yellow and sales began to slide. Felicity Lawrence on how Sunny Delight lost its shine.

Dec 19: Ribena goes to court over Tooth Kind claims

Nov 15: Rowland scoops Sunny Delight account
fields.body:
You get a strange reaction when you ring marketing people to tell them that things aren't going so well for Sunny Delight. They express a certain glee at its decline, schadenfreude even. What is it about Sunny D, as it is known to thousands of schoolchildren in the playground, that provokes so much resentment among professionals for whom manipulation is bread-and-butter stuff? And why should so many of these people insist on hiding behind anonymity?

The rise and fall of Sunny Delight is the story of how a brand became a lightning conductor for all the anxieties we have about the way we buy and sell things today. It is a tale of corporate power but also of consumer triumph; of a manufacturing giant having to come to terms with a new world in which the consumer is increasingly smart; and a tale with a moral: brands that overreach themselves will meet their Nemesis.

Sunny Delight burst upon Britain with its sunshine logo in April 1998. By August 1999, it was the country's third-largest-selling soft drink. It was the only new consumer product of the decade to jump straight into the UK's league table of top brands. Ranked 12th in Marketing magazine's Biggest Brands Survey of 1999, with annual sales of £160m, it came close to challenging established soft drinks such as Pepsi, which had sales of £190m. The Grocer magazine named it a top product.

Yet only three years later it appears to be in deep trouble. Figures from AC Nielson's independent retail audit show that sales are down 36% by value and 28% by volume (moving annual totals to February 2001), even though the brand's owner, Procter and Gamble, has been reducing the product's price steadily to sustain the volume of sales. "That is a frightening situation. I'd say they have known they've been in trouble for a long time with this," says Andrew Seth, former chief executive of Lever Brothers and now chairman of The Added Value marketing consultancy. And yet the picture had looked so sunny.

In a statement P&G said that in a market as competitive, dynamic and diverse as the soft drinks one it expected to see a levelling off of Sunny Delight sales following the initial phenomenal success, and pointed out that Sunny Delight is still one of the top 10 brands.

It was a textbook launch. Although Sunny Delight had been available in the US since 1964, it was sold there as a downmarket drink competing for space alongside squashes and long-life drinks on ordinary shelves. The approach in the UK was to be different. P&G, one of the world's most powerful grocery manufacturers, had acquired it at the end of the 80s and in 1996 began a long and thorough process of test marketing it for the UK in Carlisle.

Robert Moberly, a leading brand consultant, remembers its arrival. "I hadn't even seen the ads but it appeared overnight as a phenomenon. It had an instore presence on a scale I have never seen before. I was very surprised, but when I found out it was P&G my surprise lessened. Suddenly my eight-year-old was screaming for it. When I tasted it, it was disgusting. It reminded me of all those orange drinks after the war. I hadn't tasted that ersatz flavour for years. Then I looked at the ingredients."

Here was the rub. Sunny Delight is 5% citrus juice, and a lot of sugar and water, with vegetable oil, thickeners, added vitamins and flavourings, colourings and other additives that make it look like fresh orange juice. "It was put together with incredible care and skill, aimed at the immature tastebuds of young children. They managed to get a taste the kids adore and a message that gives mums the permission to buy it. It was an entirely manufactured brand which I felt should not succeed," Moberly recalls.

The ingredients were cheap but the price was set at a premium. P&G invested in a new filling plant costing about £12m, according to industry estimates, so that the drink could be packaged in the sort of frosted plastic bottles that fresh orange juice is usually sold in. The stroke of genius, by general marketing consent, was to sell Sunny D in chiller cabinets, next to the fresh fruit juices, simultaneously reinforcing the impression that it shared their healthy qualities and opening up new space for a juice drink. "That was a major coup," says Mick Williamson, head of the drinks unit at The Research Business International. "It meant they weren't fighting against other brands and putting it in the chill cabinet suggested it was better for you."

P&G is one of the handful of companies that has the muscle to dictate where products are sold in supermarkets and to force blanket distribution on the retail trade. (This power is also one of the reasons why so few people want to comment openly - you never know when you are going to want to work for them.)

The big chains obliged, impressed no doubt by the prospect of higher than usual profit margins, and a heavyweight promotion. A £9.2m advertising campaign, with the slogan "The great stuff kids go for", featured children in energetic outdoor pursuits and showed Sunny D in a fridge next to less apparently healthy drinks such as cola.

All this was backed up by a huge direct marketing campaign to get people to sample Sunny Delight. P&G declined to discuss with us the details of these promotions, but one of the key factors was undoubtedly its ability to identify young families who could be leafleted with special offers.

P&G's brands include Pampers and it is thought to have built up a powerful database from offers over the years which tells the company who we are and how old our children are. It is also reported to have worked with retailers' data from loyalty cards to identify young, lower-income families. Teenagers were targeted with sponsorship of basketball and balls bearing the drink's logo.

This combined onslaught led to instant success. But the backlash came equally fast.

The health watchdog the food commission condemned Sunny Delight as a con, accusing P&G of putting it in chill cabinets to mislead. Newspapers, the BBC's Watchdog programme and Radio 4 all carried attacks on the brand and dubbed it "The unreal thing". P&G argued that the drink had to be chilled to maintain its integrity and vitamins. "We had to go out to buy refrigerated lorries, refrigerated storage, the whole lot, we wouldn't have done that as a marketing ploy," says Sally Woodage, P&G's external relations manager. The brand in the US might be "ambient" rather than chilled and have added vitamins, "but it is not exactly the same product".

Then came the comic twist in the drama. In December 1999, a paediatrician, Dr Duncan Cameron, reported a new and alarming condition in the medical journals: Sunny Delight syndrome. A girl of five had turned bright yellow and orange after drinking 1.5 litres of the stuff a day. She was overdosing on betacarotene, the additive that gives the sugar-and-water drink its orange colour, and the pigment was being deposited in her hands and face. While the condition was not dangerous, the doctor warned that booming sales could lead to many other children turning "a faint yellowy colour".

By a marketing man's nightmare of coincidence, the TV ads for the brand at the time showed two white snowmen raiding the fridge for Sunny Delight and turning bright orange. To add to the embarrassment, a leading consultant dermatologist, Professor John Hawk, said too much betacarotene could cause tummy upsets and farting. As if to confirm its status as spawn of the devil, P&G was forced to join that happy band of cigarette manufacturers who put voluntary warnings on their products. Its bottles now carry the unprecedented message: "Like all soft drinks, Sunny Delight should be consumed in moderation."

P&G has launched a low-sugar version, Light Sunny Delight, to meet some of the criticisms, as well as other flavours, but these do not seem to have made much impact on the downward trend of the sales graph.

The mistake, according to rivals was to "overclaim". Andrew Marsden, marketing manager of Britvic soft drinks, says: "If you overclaim, then you subsequently have to face the results. Customers are not thick." Children, moreover, are very fickle.

Seth thinks the implications are broader. P&G is a successful business with more than a century and a half of history and many of the world's best brands. Food and drink have been identified by the company as a key sector if it is to meet its ambitious targets for growth. Sunny Delight was a stalking horse, according to Seth, but does not measure up to the company's usual high, "almost Calvinist" values.

A brand needs to have some genuine advantage over rivals and to inspire trust if it is to have legs. In an age when the link between producers and consumers is largely broken, where we buy not from a friendly local shopkeeper but from a faceless retailer, brands become our shorthand - they represent a substitute kind of trust. You can't check the label every time, so you buy the make you know. If it turns out to be not what you thought, you feel doubly betrayed.

Last month, P&G announced it would be hiving off Sunny D into a new joint venture company with Coca-Cola, which has suffered a similar slowdown in growth. It would not comment on its sales figures, nor on its current market share. "That depends on how you define market - I mean if you take non-dilutables on a Monday in Wigan ... We are very pleased with Sunny Delight given that we're in a very competitive market," says Woodage. "In hindsight we might have wanted to make it clearer that this is a different sort of drink, ie a non-carbonated fruit-flavoured beverage," she admits.

Is this a turning point, where manufacturers ignore the new, sophisticated consumer at their peril? "People have got smarter. They've never been stupid, but now they care more. They want authentic things," says Dick Powell, of the product designers Seymour Powell.

And the next big thing? Water, according to the market researchers Mintel.

"It meant they weren't fighting against other brands and putting it in the chill cabinet suggested it was better for you." P&G is one of the handful of companies that has the muscle to dictate where products are sold in supermarkets and to force blanket distribution on the retail trade. (This power is also one of the reasons why so few people want to comment openly - you never know when you are going to want to work for them.) The big chains obliged, impressed no doubt by the prospect of higher than usual profit margins, and a heavyweight promotion. A £9.2m advertising campaign, with the slogan "The great stuff kids go for", featured children in energetic outdoor pursuits and showed Sunny D in a fridge next to less apparently healthy drinks such as cola. All this was backed up by a huge direct marketing campaign to get people to sample Sunny Delight. P&G declined to discuss with us the details of these promotions, but one of the key factors was undoubtedly its ability to identify young families who could be leafleted with special offers. P&G's brands include Pampers and it is thought to have built up a powerful database from offers over the years which tells the company who we are and how old our children are. It is also reported to have worked with retailers' data from loyalty cards to identify young, lower-income families. Teenagers were targeted with sponsorship of basketball and balls bearing the drink's logo. This combined onslaught led to instant success. But the backlash came equally fast. The health watchdog the food commission condemned Sunny Delight as a con, accusing P&G of putting it in chill cabinets to mislead. Newspapers, the BBC's Watchdog programme and Radio 4 all carried attacks on the brand and dubbed it "The unreal thing". P&G argued that the drink had to be chilled to maintain its integrity and vitamins. "We had to go out to buy refrigerated lorries, refrigerated storage, the whole lot, we wouldn't have done that as a marketing ploy," says Sally Woodage, P&G's external relations manager. The brand in the US might be "ambient" rather than chilled and have added vitamins, "but it is not exactly the same product". Then came the comic twist in the drama. In December 1999, a paediatrician, Dr Duncan Cameron, reported a new and alarming condition in the medical journals: Sunny Delight syndrome. A girl of five had turned bright yellow and orange after drinking 1.5 litres of the stuff a day. She was overdosing on betacarotene, the additive that gives the sugar-and-water drink its orange colour, and the pigment was being deposited in her hands and face. While the condition was not dangerous, the doctor warned that booming sales could lead to many other children turning "a faint yellowy colour". By a marketing man's nightmare of coincidence, the TV ads for the brand at the time showed two white snowmen raiding the fridge for Sunny Delight and turning bright orange. To add to the embarrassment, a leading consultant dermatologist, Professor John Hawk, said too much betacarotene could cause tummy upsets and farting. As if to confirm its status as spawn of the devil, P&G was forced to join that happy band of cigarette manufacturers who put voluntary warnings on their products. Its bottles now carry the unprecedented message: "Like all soft drinks, Sunny Delight should be consumed in moderation." P&G has launched a low-sugar version, Light Sunny Delight, to meet some of the criticisms, as well as other flavours, but these do not seem to have made much impact on the downward trend of the sales graph. The mistake, according to rivals was to "overclaim". Andrew Marsden, marketing manager of Britvic soft drinks, says: "If you overclaim, then you subsequently have to face the results. Customers are not thick." Children, moreover, are very fickle. Seth thinks the implications are broader. P&G is a successful business with more than a century and a half of history and many of the world's best brands. Food and drink have been identified by the company as a key sector if it is to meet its ambitious targets for growth. Sunny Delight was a stalking horse, according to Seth, but does not measure up to the company's usual high, "almost Calvinist" values. A brand needs to have some genuine advantage over rivals and to inspire trust if it is to have legs. In an age when the link between producers and consumers is largely broken, where we buy not from a friendly local shopkeeper but from a faceless retailer, brands become our shorthand - they represent a substitute kind of trust. You can't check the label every time, so you buy the make you know. If it turns out to be not what you thought, you feel doubly betrayed. Last month, P&G announced it would be hiving off Sunny D into a new joint venture company with Coca-Cola, which has suffered a similar slowdown in growth. It would not comment on its sales figures, nor on its current market share. "That depends on how you define market - I mean if you take non-dilutables on a Monday in Wigan ... We are very pleased with Sunny Delight given that we're in a very competitive market," says Woodage. "In hindsight we might have wanted to make it clearer that this is a different sort of drink, ie a non-carbonated fruit-flavoured beverage," she admits. Is this a turning point, where manufacturers ignore the new, sophisticated consumer at their peril? "People have got smarter. They've never been stupid, but now they care more. They want authentic things," says Dick Powell, of the product designers Seymour Powell. And the next big thing? Water, according to the market researchers Mintel. fields.headline: Daihatsu pulled over by advertising watchdog
fields.trailText: 8.30am: An advertising campaign for Daihatsu cars has been slammed for encouraging dangerous driving, writes Claire Cozens
fields.body:
An advertising campaign for Daihatsu cars has been slammed for encouraging dangerous driving.

The Advertising Standards Authority has criticised Daihatsu for a press advert headlined "Quick enough to see off a 1.6 litre VW Polo Gti", alongside a picture of the car in motion.

The advert stated that "the 100 bhp Sirion 1.3SL... will exhilarate you with 0-62 mph in 9.6 seconds".

The watchdog ruled that the advert encouraged anti-social driving and ordered the company to change its approach for all future campaigns.

Electrolux also got into hot water with the regulator over an advert for its vacuum cleaner.

The advert used the line, "I've got a big one, baby" alongside a claim that the cleaner had a "huge 2.8 litre dust bin, which holds more dirt than any other cleaner".

Rival manufacturer Dyson complained that two of its models had 4-litre bins. The company also challenged whether the claim "to make cleaning more hygienic and the home healthier" could be substantiated.

The ASA upheld the complaints and asked Electrolux to ensure the claims did not appear in any future advertising.

The watchdog also upheld complaints against Central Trains after the train company issued promotional leaflets saying its timetables were back to normal after a temporary suspension.

The watchdog upheld a complaint that normal service had not fully resumed.

fields.headline: Loaded features boss resigns
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Loaded features director Tammy Butt, the only female staff journalist on the lads' mag, has resigned, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A second senior member of staff has resigned from lads' mag Loaded today as anger mounts among staff over editor Keith Kendrick's new "vision" for the magazine.

Features director Tammy Butt, the only female staff journalist on the title, is believed to have no job to go to.

Ms Butt, a former editor of More, was lured from Emap's Heat last year to join Loaded.

She confirmed that she will leave Loaded after working out her notice, but was not prepared to discuss the reasons for her departure.

The resignation follows a row between Mr Kendrick and journalists on the lads' mag, after Mr Kendrick, who has just joined from Chat magazine, put forward a series of proposals.

Journalists were angered by Mr Kendrick's vision, believing it watered down the magazine's original vision in a drive to make it similar to its higher-circulation rivals FHM and Maxim.

The "vision", included the suggestion that Loaded should carry a column called "Badge of Honour", with role models including a man who gets mugged while trying to pick up a prostitute and a man who tested a new camcorder by videoing himself masturbating.

Last week managing editor John Aldred left the magazine. He was also believed to be unhappy with Mr Kendrick's plans for the title.

Meanwhile, Loaded has announced the appointment of former Ministry of Sound editor Scott Manson as deputy editor.

Mr Manson, who joined Ministry in 1998, left the magazine last month.

webTitle: Reuters picks over stricken US rival

fields.headline: Reuters picks over stricken US rival
fields.trailText: News and financial information group Reuters yesterday said it was considering a bid for parts of its stricken rival, Bridge Information Systems.
fields.body:
News and financial information group Reuters yesterday said it was considering a bid for parts of its stricken rival, Bridge Information Systems.

A statement coming out of the US early yesterday morning appeared to contradict earlier comments from chief executive Tom Glocer, who had denied any interest in acquiring Bridge.

In a recent interview he boasted of winning new business because of the financial troubles of Bridge, which is now under chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US.

Two months ago, Mr Glocer told analysts: "Most of the companies that have now [become] a part of Bridge - ADP, Telerate and Knight-Ridder - were very well shopped on the market before. We had the chance, and did in fact look at them. You can certainly read something into the fact that we passed on each of them last time around and my personal opinion, without any offence to Bridge, is that none of those properties has improved in attractiveness in the era under joint management."

Bridge's "evolving situation" has made it a possible bid target, and Reuters will now be able to pick off assets instead of having to bid for the whole company. A spokesman refused to speculate on which parts of the business the company is interested in, but a deal could help to shore up Reuters' position in the US.

Last month, Bridge reached an agreement to sell some of its assets to SunGard Data Systems, a financial software company, for $165m (£115m) in cash. SunGard's offer is for Bridge Trading, an electronic transactions system, eBridge, an internet hosting service, EJV Bond Data and BridgeNews LiveWire, a company news service. The bid remains conditional on no higher offers being made. Other assets still up for grabs include financial data business Telerate, Bridge's main news service for its overseas operations.

Bids for parts of the company must be filed today with a bankruptcy court in St Louis. One of Bridge's creditors, Highland Capital, filed an involuntary bankruptcy petition against it in February. Bridge's debt has spiralled to more than £500m since it bought Telerate in 1998.

Launched in 1974, Bridge was bought by a New York-based private investment fund - Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe - in 1995. WCAS rapidly expanded the company through acquisitions including Telerate, then named Dow Jones Markets, and Knight-Ridder Financial, which gave it a ready-made network of news bureaux.

Bridge News includes a network of 600 journalists in 100 countries who write for developed and emerging markets.

fields.headline: ONdigital partners curb spending
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications and Granada, the shareholders in ONdigital, are understood to have bowed to pressure from investors to curb their ongoing investment in the pay-TV platform.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications and Granada, the shareholders in ONdigital, are understood to have bowed to pressure from investors to curb their ongoing investment in the pay-TV platform.

ONdigital, which will announce its next set of subscriber numbers in two weeks, is expected to announce a shift in focus away from the aggressive pursuit of market share to the retention of existing customers and raising revenues.

Analysts have been increasingly uncomfortable with the outlay in ONdigital, which has climbed with the launch of free set-top boxes and add-on services, including internet over the TV, ONnet.

An industry source said: "We have got the brand up now and want to carefully control the amount of cash going into ONdigital and to keep hold of customers. Analysts have been concerned about the £1.2bn peak funding figure being put out and are asking: where does it really stop?"

When Granada and Carlton unveiled the platform in May 1998, they said it would need just £300m funding.

The source said both companies feel it is a waste of money to keep subsidising set-top boxes.

The shareholders are banking on the wider adoption of digital sets, which dispense with set-top boxes and replace them with a smart card slotted into the back.

The decision is part of the strategic review of ONdigital that has been conducted since Granada and Carlton bought United News & Media out of ITV.

fields.headline: Two-year probation order for Eminem
fields.trailText: Rap star Eminem thanked a Michigan judge for his compassion yesterday after receiving two years probation for carrying a concealed weapon. The star admitted the charge.
fields.body:
Rap star Eminem thanked a Michigan judge for his compassion yesterday after receiving two years probation for carrying a concealed weapon. The star admitted the charge.

"The judge treated me fair, like any other human being," Eminem said after the hearing in Mount Clemens.

As part of the probation, Judge Antonio Viviano ordered the Grammy-winner to undergo counselling and drug testing, and not carry any weapons. He was also fined $2,500 (£1,700).

The judge said that although all crimes involving weapons are serious, in this case the gun was not loaded and there was no danger to human life.

Eminem was charged after a June 4 fracas outside a nightclub in Detroit. Police say Eminem struck a man he says he saw kissing his estranged wife, Kim Mathers. The two have a five-year-old daughter.

Eminem also faces charges in a nearby county that he illegally possessed and brandished a weapon hours before his arrest during a confrontation with another rapper.

Eminem's lawyer, Wally Piszczatowski, said the rapper was worried about the effect of the case on his daughter.

fields.headline: Blackhurst tipped to replace Street-Porter
fields.trailText:
1pm: The ex-deputy editor of the Express is the favourite for the top job at the Independent on Sunday, writes Jessica Hodgson.
12pm: Street-Porter quits Independent on Sunday
fields.body:
Chris Blackhurst, who left his job as deputy editor of the Express along with editor Rosie Boycott earlier this year, is the favourite to replace Janet Street-Porter as new editor of the Independent on Sunday.

Mr Blackhurst, who is working on the Independent as a political investigative journalist, was deputy editor of the Independent on Sunday under former editor Boycott.

Other names in the frame are believed to include the Independent's executive editor Tristan Davies, deputy editor for the Independent on Sunday Mike Williams and Independent deputy editor Ian Birrell.

Staff at the paper are believed to be taking bets on the above candidates.

A statement to staff at the paper today confirmed that Ms Street-Porter, who has edited the newspaper since 1999, would stand down after the general election.

Simon Kelner, editor-in-chief of the Independent and the Independent on Sunday, would not be drawn on her replacement.

However, he refused to rule out any of the suggested internal favourites and added that external candidates were being considered.

He denied Ms Street-Porter had been asked to resign.

"Janet intimated to me when she took this job on that she didn't want to do it until she took her pension," he said.

"Shortly after Christmas, she intimated that, come the spring, the time would be right for her to look around for something else."

Asked whether Ms Street-Porter had proved former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie right when he claimed she couldn't edit a bus ticket, Mr Kelner said: "She's proved them all wrong."

Related story

webTitle: Helping young offenders stay out of custody

fields.headline: Facing facts
fields.standfirst: Kate Hilpern on a dramatic approach to help young offenders stay out of custody
fields.trailText: Kate Hilpern on a dramatic approach to help young offenders stay out of custody
fields.body:
Like many young offenders, 16-year-old Nathan loathes depending on a "front". He says: "It's what landed me in here. I feel I have to be the 'tough' guy or the 'cool' guy to survive, and the next thing I know I'm inside for stealing cars. Even in here [Feltham young offenders' institution, Middlesex], nobody says what they really mean. It's a frightening place, so you just pretend you're a certain kind of person that you believe will keep you the safest. That makes you do it all the more when you get out, and so the cycle goes on."

What does make Nathan stand out from other young offenders, however, is his willingness to admit it and even to change it. It is, he says, the result of an innovative drama course that the Geese Theatre Company - a touring company based at the Midlands Arts Centre in Birmingham - has extended to young offenders to help them examine their behaviour and develop more constructive ways of handling challenging situations.

It works like this. Masks, representing a variety of "fronts", are worn by the actors, who then play out a scene according to the rationale of that behaviour. The mask for Cool ("Listen, you're all making a lot of fuss about nothing - if you want the TV, just steal it") is an ominous, green face with dark glasses; Target ("I don't feel in control of this situation - it's everyone else's fault I'm doing this") has an archery target on the forehead. At various points in the performance, the audience of young offenders calls out for the character to lift the mask and explain what he is really feeling - and how he might find ways to act on that feeling, rather than according to the front. The actor then tests out the consequences of that option.

"It's not about truth, but more about what is being withheld - highlighting hidden vulnerabilities and concealed thoughts and feelings," says Sally Brookes, the theatre company's programmes director. "That's why we use 'fragment' masks because they display only a fragment of behaviour. Few people are The Joker, The Mouth, The Victim or any other front all the time."

Through workshops, lasting one day, and "residencies", which last several, the mobile company focuses on the young offenders' motivation and ability to change. Brookes says: "We recognise that wider social and economic factors have a major influence on crime - particularly when it comes to young offenders - but we work from the premise that he can nonetheless make active choices and has a responsibility for his actions."

She admits that many of the 14 to 18-year-olds are sceptical about the idea of drama. "They feel it's childish and silly," she says. "But it's overcome fairly quickly - not only because there is a clear logic to what we're doing, but because they get to explore behaviour patterns one step removed through the medium of an actor. That means they themselves don't end up feeling judged or interrogated."

Also popular among under-18s is the fact that there are no scripts, and no feeling of intimidation that can be associated with being asked to read aloud. There are simply events, scenarios, settings and masks. And humour is particularly important in working with this age group, Brookes says, because most have had negative experiences with adults in a learning environment. "Our emphasis is on making the work both enjoyable and useful," she says.

Geese believes that each workshop must be tailor-made to the needs of a particular group. One, for instance, may focus intensively on aggression, while another may explore a range of knee-jerk reactions and their ramifications. One may focus on behaviours outside prison, while another may include the experience of prison itself.

Lou Heywood, the company's touring director, says: "The objectives must be clear. One session we recently ran was for young offenders who had been in the institution less than a week. Many seemed confident, but you could tell that almost all of them were frightened, particularly if they didn't understand the system.

"The first part of the drama involved acting out a scene in which a lad went into his cell for the first time. Using the masks, we explored what he might be thinking. The aim was to let the group talk honestly about the kinds of feelings they might have, rather than letting them out through destructive behaviour."

Like all the trainers at Geese - which expanded from the US to Britain in 1987 - Heywood comes from a background of drama training, with a strong interest in issue-based theatre. In addition, all staff receive six-month training in teamwork, the criminal justice system, probation services and aspects of offending behaviour.

"Young offenders are a difficult group to measure in terms of the effects of the course," admits Brookes. "But the verbal feedback from prison workers and probation workers, as well as the young people themselves, is certainly positive enough for us to be booked up for months ahead."

"The first part of the drama involved acting out a scene in which a lad went into his cell for the first time. Using the masks, we explored what he might be thinking. The aim was to let the group talk honestly about the kinds of feelings they might have, rather than letting them out through destructive behaviour." Like all the trainers at Geese - which expanded from the US to Britain in 1987 - Heywood comes from a background of drama training, with a strong interest in issue-based theatre. "But the verbal feedback from prison workers and probation workers, as well as the young people themselves, is certainly positive enough for us to be booked up for months ahead."

fields.headline: Game of life
fields.trailText: One of the Geese Theatre Company's most widely used performances with young offenders is Lifting the Weight, an interactive game in which actors deal with a variety of realistic situations that they face during their first year after release from custody.
fields.body:
One of the Geese Theatre Company's most widely used performances with young offenders is Lifting the Weight, an interactive game in which actors deal with a variety of realistic situations that they face during their first year after release from custody.

There are five areas in which characters confront challenges: survival, free time, family, work and authority. Each area contains tokens - players must try to "win" them to stop themselves returning to custody - which focus on issues such as personal responsibility, self-control, resisting peer pressure, alcohol and drug abuse. Adding to the challenge is another actor, The Fool, who tries to persuade characters to take the offending option. As the characters confront difficult situations, they lift their masks and ask the audience what course of action they should follow. The likely outcome is acted out and there is a debate on whether the character deserves a token.

Geese programmes director Sally Brookes says: "To negotiate the game successfully, the characters in the play need to look honestly at their often dangerous behaviour and its consequences, for both themselves and others - and begin to identify alternative solutions.

"But, as young offenders well know, it's not about pat solutions or happy endings. There are always more tokens to work for."

fields.headline: Outside in
fields.standfirst: Involving people in looking after their elderly relatives is a healthy move for care homes, says  John Cunningham
fields.trailText: Imagine how very different life might be for elderly residents of a care home if it was run jointly by a group of relatives and staff, within a framework provided by the management. Or if designated visitors had a swipe card for the front door, allowing them to drop in at any time to check or chat as freely as when their relatives were still fit enough to manage in their own homes.
fields.body:
Imagine how very different life might be for elderly residents of a care home if it was run jointly by a group of relatives and staff, within a framework provided by the management. Or if designated visitors had a swipe card for the front door, allowing them to drop in at any time to check or chat as freely as when their relatives were still fit enough to manage in their own homes.

To managers and staff of many care homes, even to consider such initiatives might seem laughable; to implement them would involve high costs and higher risks. All too often, it seems, the overriding emphasis of residential care is on security and control. But some homes do little even to lighten the mix of communal living with activities and social events such as family teas, outings or special functions for Easter or Valentine's day.

The reality of some homes is such that many relatives find their guilt over placing mum or dad in them is aggravated by a soulless routine and staff who refuse to let visitors do small, but meaningful, tasks: brushing hair, for instance, or making a cup of tea with just the right amount of milk. Many complaints about such care regimes are mumbled, but never brought to the attention of senior staff. Now, however, the Relatives and Residents Association (RRA), a charity working to improve the quality of life in care homes, has compiled common grievances and come up with a guide to good practice, intended for those who run residential and nursing homes in private, voluntary and local authority sectors.

The guide, Involving Relatives and Friends, aims to achieve fuller and better partnership between residents, and their relatives, and the staff and managers of homes. That, too, was the aim of the RRA's founder, Dorothy White, who in 1997 won £3,500 under the then Guardian Jerwood Award for excellence among smaller charities. Before her death the following year, she asked that the prize money be used to further her work - so the charity has put it towards the cost of publishing the book.

Julia Burton-Jones, RRA's development worker who wrote the guide, recognises the difficulties of all parties: guilty relatives; residents with deteriorating memories; and staff faced with difficult demands. Although homes generally are now less paternalistic than they once were, she says that "professionals have been taught to 'take over', however well meant, and family and friends, albeit reluctantly, expect to let them." Families are wary of rocking the boat, believing their relatives will get far better treatment if everyone conforms to the expectations of the home.

Burton-Jones accepts that the regime in each home is different, so not all her suggestions will apply. The proposals, based on the experiences of RRA members, are practical.

Brochures are often the starting point for a traumatic family decision. As well as giving a sunny picture of facilities, they must spell out the rules, and the charges for extras, and make clear whether fees are for a room alone, or for the level of dependency of its occupant. It sounds straightforward, but few information packs are said to give sufficient detail. Contracts drawn up by care homes, moreover, are often vague about crucial issues such as the financial obligations of relatives when an elderly client dies.

But there is also a need for much more cheerful documentation. In the best run homes, key staff help new arrivals to put together a "life history book" - a sort of structured personal album, not only to remind residents of milestones in their lives, but also to aid staff in getting to know (and remember details about) those in their care.

Staff need to get to know the next of kin well, too. The guide recommends an induction programme to familiarise family members with the way a home functions - down to just who is responsible for laundry, which can be a frequent cause of friction.

Jewish Care is cited as a good example: the charity runs a course of six weekly sessions to enable friends and relatives of a resident to familiarise themselves with the home. Regular "relatives' forums" are held at other homes and these, too, are commended as a way of building an on-going partnership, so that families do not feel excluded by staff.

Generally, homes now encourage friends and families to call as often as possible to see their loved ones. The era of restricted opening times has gone, and the problem is now likely to be one of relatives feeling visiting to be a waste of time when a resident may be unable to recognise them. Even in these distressing circumstances, staff must be reassuring that visits are worthwhile: Burton-Jones writes that "there is comfort for residents in having a familiar person in the room, even when few words are spoken".

When residents are well enough to talk, there should be areas for private conversations. A commode in a bedroom can be an embarrassment to both parties - but one which care staff are sometimes insensitive to. On other occasions, such as illness, a son or daughter might want to spend a watchful night in a parent's room, and staff should be able to provide an extra bed.

Almost all the improvements the guide describes are drawn from good practice at one or more homes. Many score well on innovative social programmes: Staplehurst Manor, a Bupa nursing home near Tonbridge, Kent, is cited for its themed evenings, ranging from a Neapolitan night with a four-course Italian meal, to a Valentine's concert and buffet with free tickets for couples married 40 years or more. But Staplehurst is also praised for bringing in experts to stage a question time on dementia.

One of the most cheering possibilities is for the old to be kept in touch with children, as a reminder of continuity. This has been spectacularly achieved at Sevenoaks, Kent, where Westminster Healthcare has combined its nursing home with a Montessori nursery on the same site. There are other ways of sustaining links between young and old, though, and the RRA says that "making children feel welcome need not cost a great deal: blowing bubbles or playing with a balloon can be great fun".

As for more radical ideas, the notion of a swipe card visiting system has yet to be put into practice. But the home run by staff and relatives may not be far off. At Grove Court, a private home in Leeds, a relatives' group meets monthly and not only organises social events, but participates in staff training. The long-term aim is for a joint group of relatives and staff to take over the running of the establishment.

As Brian Daniel, Grove Court's proprietor, says: "It has to be the reasonable right of a relative that they should have a stake in influencing the quality of life of those so dear to them."

fields.headline: Point to point
fields.standfirst: Profile  Victor Adebowale, leaving homelessness to tackle addiction
fields.trailText: Profile Victor Adebowale, leaving homelessness to tackle addiction
fields.body:
Victor Adebowale, chief executive of homelessness charity Centrepoint, has surprised many working in the field by announcing his departure to drug, alcohol and mental health charity Turning Point. He will take up the £85,000-a-year chief executive post in September.

Adebowale has been strongly identified with the housing cause. Neil Churchill, deputy chief executive of rival charity Crisis, says: "Victor is the public face of homelessness - a very charismatic figure who will be a great loss to the sector."

Adebowale, 38, has spent most of his career in the housing field, rising to become a key adviser to government and an outspoken champion of young people's rights. He was last year awarded a CBE for his services to the government's New Deal taskforce and for his work with unemployed and homeless people.

During his five years at Centrepoint, the government has established the rough sleepers' unit with the aim of reducing by two-thirds the number of people sleeping on the streets. The role of homelessness tsar has been created and a homes bill is completing its passage through parliament. There was speculation that Adebowale would be appointed tsar, but it eventually went to Louise Casey.

After establishing such a leading role, Adebowale's move to Turning Point - a charity with a lower profile - is puzzling some people. "When I first heard about the move, it sounded like a sideways step," says James Tickell, deputy chief executive of the National Housing Federation. However, it is perhaps testament to Adebowale's leadership of Centrepoint that a charity with a staff of 200 and £10m annual income has greater public recognition than does an older one with 1,300 staff and a turnover of £20m. As Tickell says: "Victor has made Centrepoint punch way beyond its weight."

Turning Point runs drug and alcohol recovery services across the country, including rehabilitation and counselling. It recently appointed a high-profile chair in Lionel Joyce, formerly a leading NHS manager, but it still lacks prominence. Victoria Stark, chief executive of Look Ahead Housing and Care, says: "Victor will be a big bonus to Turning Point in raising its low profile. He has a strong personality and a good media presence."

Stark adds: "It has been great to have someone at such a senior level in housing from the black and ethnic minority community." Adebowale is one of the few black chief executives in the voluntary sector - and he has often pointed out this lack of diversity to a sea of white faces at charity conferences.

Eric Appleby, director of Alcohol Concern, says: "Victor keeps issues in the limelight, but he isn't just a front person; he combines this with managing an organisation and providing good services. Turning Point will benefit enormously from his contribution." However, Churchill thinks Adebowale will "have his work cut out" pulling together a coherent response to the impact of drugs and alcohol on society. "It is a huge agenda," he says.

So Adebowale's in-tray will be stacked high by the time he arrives in his new post. However, the subject matter is not entirely new to him. Before joining Centrepoint in 1995, he had a brief spell as director of the Alcohol Recovery Project.

He began his career as a volunteer for Newham Community Housing Cooperative, in east London, but soon gained employment as an estates officer for Newham council. He then moved to the Patchwork Community Housing Association, helping to provide special needs housing. His first senior role was regional director of Ujima Housing Association, Britain's largest black-led housing association.

Adebowale will leave his latest post having recently introduced a new management structure and a five-year plan, giving Centrepoint a stronger training and employment remit. Income has also doubled during his time as chief executive.

Although he is widely seen to be close to New Labour, he is not afraid of spats. Last November, he warned the government it was in danger of missing the point with its New Deal for young people by not targeting the most disadvantaged. He also hit out at its campaign to stop people giving to beggars, saying that "giving should be the choice of every individual." He insisted that a long-term strategy was needed in consultation with drugs and health agencies, homelessness services and people on the street - perhaps a foretaste of his future career plans.

fields.headline: Dangerous liaisons
fields.standfirst: Asking personal questions puts health visitors at risk
fields.trailText: Asking personal questions puts health visitors at risk
fields.body:
An external evaluation of a needs assessment tool used by health visitors in north London has raised profound doubts about the practicality and usefulness of a single means of gauging families' problems.

The evaluation, the first of its kind, has also expressed concern for the safety of health visitors required to ask blunt personal questions. Clients told researchers that when a health visitor had interviewed them, they "felt like hitting her" and "felt like putting her lights out".

The tool, developed by Parkside NHS trust, is one of many attempts to provide some format or guidance for health visitors in assessing and prioritising families' needs. It was constructed through a series of focus groups, and by a working party of health visitors, before being introduced across the trust in 1999.

Results of the evaluation, conducted over a full year by a team from the Florence Nightingale school of nursing and midwifery at King's College, London, have so alarmed local MP Barry Gardiner that he is calling on the trust's chief executive to consider his position.

"I am pretty seething about this," says Gardiner, who raised some health visitors' concerns about the tool before it was put into practice. "The [evaluation] report shows that the warning signals that staff were giving were absolutely and totally justified.

"I don't blame the trust for having tried to standardise its practice in this systematic way. What I do blame them for is the way they responded when there were clear signals being delivered by their own staff and by a local MP."

The tool involves asking families a series of questions about their health, environment and social situation. These include reactions to statements including: "You or your partner feel that you have a dependency for drugs or alcohol"; "There is an adult in the house with violent tendencies"; "You or your partner have serious financial difficulties".

Parents are also asked: "How loving do you feel towards your baby/child?" and "How confident do you feel being a parent?"

The evaluation team, led by Sarah Cowley, professor of community practice and development, found that most health visitors were reading out the questions like a checklist rather than blending them into conversation. "The transcript of one recorded interaction revealed that 122 questions were asked in one and a half hours," the team's report notes.

Most hostility to the tool was shown by families with higher levels of need. "The sense of 'being judged' came across strongly," says the team. Commonly, health visitors sought to distance themselves from the procedure by attributing it to a higher authority within the trust.

In addition to its other concerns, the team questions whether data elicited for clinical purposes may legitimately be used for workload planning purposes without the client's knowledge or consent. It concludes that it is "very unlikely" that a single tool could ever be developed by managers to determine "what they are paying for" as well as identifying all family needs, while aiming at the same time to empower clients.

Gardiner, Labour member for Brent North, has written to Richard Higgins, Parkside's chief executive, claiming that the trust's failure to act on initial anxieties about the tool was "wholly reprehensible". He has asked Higgins to consider "whether, in the light of such failure, you can continue to lead the trust effectively and with the full confidence of both public and staff".

Parkside has announced that it will be re-examining the tool. Judith Barlow, the trust's health visiting leader, says: "The trust is working with health visitors to adapt the framework to suit practice. To many, this is a positive initiative that gives all clients the opportunity to discuss factors affecting the whole family's health."

fields.headline: Micro wave of optimism
fields.standfirst: Community activists vital for neighbourhood renewal
fields.trailText: Community activists vital for neighbourhood renewal
fields.body:
The government's drive for neighbourhood renewal is in danger of missing or misunderstanding one of the most powerful drivers of community development - the individuals and micro organisations that vastly outnumber official charities.

This is the conclusion of new research that identifies a vast, but hidden, layer of community activity - dubbed "micro social enterprises" (MSEs). The ungainly term is applied to low-level community activity, usually carried on out of sight of established government and voluntary sector bodies.

Keith Leech is one such micro social entrepreneur. He likes folk music and beer. And in one of those "if only" pub conversations, he dreamed up the idea of an annual May Day festival in his adopted home town of Hastings.

Unlike most such pub ideas, Leech did not think better of it the next morning. He struggled for years to put on the Jack in the Green event, which he describes modestly as "an excuse to get dressed up, make a noise and drink beer".

After 15 years it has become a national attraction, enticing folk music lovers from all over the country. And while the time invested by Leech and others remains unpaid, the council does chip in with a modest grant to cover costs.

Researchers reckon that there are as many as 1m similar tiny organisations. They argue that they are vital to community health and the government's drive for neighbourhood renewal, but are either ignored or misunderstood.

"They are either invisible or irritating to most funders and policymakers," says Alex MacGillivray, one of the authors of the research study, Low Flying Heroes.

The title derives from the idea that these community activists operate mostly under the official radar that monitors community development. This drives the report's recommendations that, in taking account of these organisations, officialdom also needs to allow for their size, nature and diversity.

The study criticises what it describes as the "ladder mentality" in the community development establishment, which sees a desirable progression from micro organisation to official, service-delivery charity. "Many policymakers and funders have a single vision - sometimes tunnel vision - of how every group should be constituted, how it should operate and where it should be heading," says MacGillivray.

He points out that most MSEs operate informally - "a blend of Dad's Army and Arthur Daley". They frequently have no constitution, committee, growth plan or any of the other accoutrements of establishment bodies. And they often do not want money - or at least not the sizeable chunks which funders mostly want to hand out.

fields.bodyText: The government's drive for neighbourhood renewal is in danger of missing or misunderstanding one of the most powerful drivers of community development - the individuals and micro organisations that vastly outnumber official charities. This is the conclusion of new research that identifies a vast, but hidden, layer of community activity - dubbed "micro social enterprises" (MSEs). The ungainly term is applied to low-level community activity, usually carried on out of sight of established government and voluntary sector bodies. Keith Leech is one such micro social entrepreneur. He likes folk music and beer. And in one of those "if only" pub conversations, he dreamed up the idea of an annual May Day festival in his adopted home town of Hastings. Unlike most such pub ideas, Leech did not think better of it the next morning. He struggled for years to put on the Jack in the Green event, which he describes modestly as "an excuse to get dressed up, make a noise and drink beer". After 15 years it has become a national attraction, enticing folk music lovers from all over the country. And while the time invested by Leech and others remains unpaid, the council does chip in with a modest grant to cover costs. Researchers reckon that there are as many as 1m similar tiny organisations. They argue that they are vital to community health and the government's drive for neighbourhood renewal, but are either ignored or misunderstood. "They are either invisible or irritating to most funders and policymakers," says Alex MacGillivray, one of the authors of the research study, Low Flying Heroes. fields.headline: A friend in need
fields.standfirst: Problems that homeless people face don't disappear when they get a home.  Saba Salman on a new support scheme
fields.trailText: Problems that homeless people face don't disappear when they get a home. Saba Salman on a new support scheme
fields.body:
Paul Strong used to be a rough sleeper. "When you've had the life you know taken from you," he says, "it can be hard to start afresh - even with professional help."

Strong lost his local authority flat after falling into rent arrears, slept rough for several months and lived in hostels before finding a new, permanent home in Brixton, south London, earlier this year. Now he is to take part in a pilot project, run by homelessness charity Crisis, which will pair people like him - former street homeless people who have recently found permanent accommodation - with volunteer "befrienders" to help them keep hold of their new homes and integrate with their new communities.

A report published by Crisis last year suggested that one in four ex-rough sleepers was unable to sustain a tenancy once off the street. Problems identified included loneliness, lack of choice about accommodation and little opportunity to mix with those who are securely housed. Being a rough sleeper means being part of a community - and breaking away from that camaraderie can be a daunting prospect. Soon a new flat may be abandoned for the hostel or the street.

Under the pilot befriending scheme, 23 volunteers are being matched with clients of tenancy sustainment teams from homelessness agencies across London. Funded by the government's rough sleepers' unit, the project will be officially launched in June and by this time next year should have set up more than 300 befriending partnerships. If successful, it could go national. Befrienders with the Crisis scheme will commit about two hours a week for six months. Although they will not provide professional advice, neither is the role the same as a friendship - it is a service. Unpaid, independent and impartial, volunteers can empathise with homeless people in a way that professional workers cannot. A Crisis spokeswoman says: "We're looking for people who are non-judgmental and compassionate, reliable and conscientious and able to communicate with people from diverse backgrounds.

"Many of the volunteers see it as an opportunity for personal development and to broaden their horizons. They learn a great deal from meeting other volunteers, who come from all walks of life, and homeless people themselves."

Strong, 50, will be one of the first recipients of the new scheme. He was evicted from his flat by Hammersmith and Fulham council, west London, after building up rent arrears of £3,000. He had lived there for 15 years, but fell behind with the rent after his wife fell ill and he stayed off work to look after her. Unable to get compassionate leave, he took time off anyway and, as a result, lost his job as a security guard.

"First we lived at my mum's flat, on the same estate, but after a year she had to go into a home and my brother took over the tenancy," Strong says. "There wasn't room for us, and because we were in arrears, we weren't eligible for another council flat. We had no money, no home, and I didn't know where to turn.

"That's when we went on the road and slept rough for five months. We lived on Shepherd's Bush Green and used the soup and clothing runs provided by local agencies. It was a terrible time. But we had no choice. We couldn't get another tenancy with the council and had no idea about how the system worked.

"Eventually, a local outreach worker got us into a hostel for about five weeks in west London, then another in Holborn and then another. Finally, our application for permanent housing came through and we were offered this flat in Brixton. I don't know this area at all, and I would rather be somewhere I know, but I want to make a go of things. I want to get to know my new patch, find new friends. I love playing snooker, but it's hard when you don't know anyone."

Blake Ludwig, 41, works in IT in the City. He is one of the first Crisis befrienders and is paired with Paul. He first volunteered with Crisis to help with clothing runs in and around the City and has also worked in the charity's network of winter shelters.

"I wanted to be more involved on the frontline, and when I heard about the befriending project I was immediately drawn to it," says Ludwig. "At first, I thought I would visit the client at home, fix his thermostat, do odd jobs, but Crisis explained it was a companionship role. A contractual friendship.

"I'll take my client, who I've been told very little about, into his community. Just hang out, get to know him, and help him to make new friends so he feels more settled. Ex-homeless do have support from social workers, but that is purely practical. The Crisis project will allow someone who's not in the system to help. Perhaps they will trust us more.

"I want to be involved because I think we all need to look beyond our own experiences and selves and to give something back to society."

fields.headline: Kick starting community spirit
fields.trailText: Football is increasingly seen as a means of channelling the energy of disaffected young people. The Football Foundation, a charity launched in July last year, aims to promote social inclusion and help counter drug abuse and racism by using soccer as a focal point for developing community spirit. Funded by the government, the Football Association and the FA Premier League, the charity has an annual budget of £60m and is committed to revitalising youth organisations by providing pitches and changing facilities.
fields.body:
Football is increasingly seen as a means of channelling the energy of disaffected young people. The Football Foundation, a charity launched in July last year, aims to promote social inclusion and help counter drug abuse and racism by using soccer as a focal point for developing community spirit. Funded by the government, the Football Association and the FA Premier League, the charity has an annual budget of £60m and is committed to revitalising youth organisations by providing pitches and changing facilities.

Professional football clubs also see the game as a way of bringing together local communities and encouraging healthier lifestyles. Millwall have run a project in south London since 1985, funded by the local authority, and are targeting estates with high crime rates in Lewisham and Southwark. Players from the club travel with goals and bibs to organise the games in local neighbourhoods. About 60 children - boys and girls - turn up each evening to play.

The Football Foundation last week gave £15,000 to Millwall to enable the club to buy mobile floodlights so that games and coaching can be played all year round.
