fields.headline: Reclaim the streets
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot  meets an ex-Hell's Angel who took on local toughs - and won back a park
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot meets an ex-Hell's Angel who took on local toughs - and won back a park
fields.body:
Dusk in Edgwick Park, Coventry, and the boys are coming out to play. Young teenagers for the most part, they will soon be hurtling around an all-weather, floodlit football pitch. But for the time being, they are standing around in huddles, hands in pockets, shoulders hunched against a chilly breeze. Some are talking to community policeman Eddie Massey, who confides later: "Five years ago, this lot would have blanked me or run away and called me names."

Others are gathered by a small electric buggy. They are chatting to Stuart Parker, 53, who was born with a mild form of spina bifida that has progressively worsened with age. "I'm going to report you to that copper for speeding in this thing," jokes a young lad. "You were going at eight miles an hour." Parker pulls on his cigarette and grins amiably. The irony is that he was once a Hell's Angel who bombed around Bristol on a 750cc Norton.

These kids wouldn't know that. All they know is that Parker and his wife, Elaine, 54, have put themselves out on their behalf. Over the past five years, they have built up partnerships - with the city council, the police, business sponsors, youth workers and others - which have reclaimed this park from drug dealers and alcoholics. Apart from anything else, it now boasts the sort of facilities for football and basketball that many youngsters can only dream of.

The Parkers are unlikely soccer enthusiasts. Elaine admits that she knew little about the game and Stuart was always a "rugby man". He was a front-row forward in his younger days, when he didn't have to rely on wheelchairs and electric buggies to get about. But, like his wife, he has come to appreciate the wide appeal of the round-ball game and the value of organised matches for channelling excess energy, harnessing aggression and providing a meaningful platform for hitherto hidden skills.

It all started one afternoon in 1996, when a ball came flying through the Parkers' bathroom window. They have a small, ground-floor council flat which backs on to the park and fronts on to a terrace street in Foleshill, the most economically deprived and multi-racial area of Coventry.

Faced with smashed glass and a broken extractor fan, some of us might feel a little frayed at the edges on hearing the time-honoured street cry: "Can we have our ball back, mister?" But even in his Hell's Angel days, Stuart was involved in youth work. "The best way to talk to these kids is on their level," he says. "Don't lecture them and patronise them. Listen to their opinions."

So he pushed his wheelchair across the street and introduced himself to 10 morose-looking 14 and 15-year-olds. "They were a bit suspicious at first," Elaine recalls. "But one of them knew us and he acted as a go-between." Gradually, the Parkers wheedled out of the youths the reasons why they chose to play football in the street rather than in the park. The answers amounted to too many threatening drug-dealers, too many bullying gangs, too many "winos".

The following evening, Stuart outlined his strategy to the Foleshill crime action group. He wanted to set up a five-a-side league, properly organised by qualified coaches. Letters were written and phone calls made. Cautiously encouraging responses were elicited. Coventry's leisure services department made available what was, at the time, a rather run-down "multi-sports" area. A Home Office initiative, community action against crime, put in £1,200 initially in 1996 and has almost matched it every year since, to buy equipment and pay the coaches a modest weekly fee. Directors of Jaguar, a prominent local employer, were invited along to watch a Thursday evening session and, as a result, more money was made available through the Business in the Community scheme.

Involving the police was considered vital, though initially it was fraught with problems. A match was arranged between some of the local youths and the Coventry constabulary. "But we publicised it too widely," Elaine concedes. "Half the drug barons in the city turned up. There was a lot of verbal abuse from the sidelines and bottles were thrown on to the pitch. We had to abandon the match. The police went away to put their uniforms on, came back and made eight arrests."

In the meantime, Stuart had been leaned over by one drug dealer who threatened to carve open his stomach. But former front-row forwards and Hell's Angels don't frighten easily - even those in wheelchairs. "My grandfather," he says, "always told me to fear no man but to respect every man - until he loses it."

Startled by Stuart's bloodcurdling response to his threats, the drug dealer was led away by one of his mates. They have been in retreat ever since after some rigorous policing. In fact, they have simply gone elsewhere to ply their trade. Crime in Edgwick Park officially fell by 38% over the following six months and has remained comparatively low.

"It's become a family park again," says Elaine, who has lived in Foleshill all her life.

The Parkers have capitalised on this revived interest by running summer schemes during the long school vacation. Not only football and basketball, but trips out to swimming pools, bowling alleys and cricket grounds. Last summer, almost 500 youngsters took part.

Heartened by the manifestation of community action in Edgwick Park, the local authority released £96,000 from the single regeneration budget to transform the multi-sports area into an all-weather pitch with a felt surface and a robust high fence around it. The floodlights stay on until 10 most evenings and the fence takes a hell of a pounding from flying footballs. Never more so than on Thursdays, when a seemingly endless sequence of five-a-side games flow from end to end under the guidance of Football Association coaches John Robinson and Lincoln Libird.

"There were some difficulties at first because some characters wanted to run the show their way," Robinson admits. "We had to make it fun and earn respect. Now the park's full of kids who just want to play football."

That's all Ben Williams ever wanted to do. He's 15 now but was only 10 when the scheme started. "I jumped at the chance to play," he says. "This park used to feel really dangerous. It was full of people who were either drunk or on drugs. We don't see them now."

It would be wrong to give the impression that Edgwick Park has become some kind of idyllic sylvan glade. There is still dog shit and shards of broken glass on some of the paths. And there is still some hideous racist graffiti on the shelter. But out on the all-weather pitch, there are 25 youngsters - Asian, Afro-Caribbean, mixed-race and white, plus a few asylum seekers from Somalia, Albania and the Congo. They all want to play football. Together.

fields.headline: Contract flaw
fields.standfirst: Council rebuked for inflexibility
fields.trailText: Council rebuked for inflexibility
fields.body:
Essex county council has been censured by the local government ombudsman for failing to maintain a home care service for a 90-year-old man after the service contractor pulled out because it could not recruit staff.

The authority refused to break its policy by paying mileage costs to another care agency that said it might step in and provide the service. The man subsequently went into residential care and died in hospital shortly after.

In a ruling, which will be studied closely by all councils struggling to maintain home care provision in the face of recruitment problems, the ombudsman, Jerry White, says that when a service failure occurs "the council might well have to seize any realistic opportunity to make the service good".

Finding Essex guilty of maladministration causing injustice, of "fettering its discretion", White observes that it appears the man's home care was "entirely sacrificed to maintain the purity of the council's contractual arrangements".

The man is described as having suffered Parkinson's disease, arthritis and curvature of the spine. His wife, who was 92, was his main carer but she herself suffered angina and breathing problems and was registered blind. He had been assessed in 1995 as needing home care morning and evening - arrangements confirmed by reassessment in 1998. The council's own care staff provided the morning help and an agency was responsible for the evening putting-to-bed service, seven days a week.

In February 1999, the agency gave a month's notice that it could no longer provide the service at weekends. The council contacted all its contractor agencies to see if they could take over, but only one said it might and only then if mileage costs were paid. Under Essex's policy, contractors received a flat-rate fee with no mileage allowance.

With effect from March 26, the council said the man would have to go into a care home at weekends at a cost to the authority of £100 on each occasion, plus transport. He never returned home from his first weekend away and died in hospital on April 21. His wife had also been admitted to hospital and died on May 16.

The ombudsman, acting on a complaint by the couple's son, found that Essex did have a procedure for considering extra funding for care in individual cases. But the authority said enacting this would have been "damaging to stable contracting arrangements".

White concludes that the council's treatment of the couple "fell far short" of acceptable standards. He is recommending Essex pay the son £500. The authority is yet to consider this formally. But Michael Leadbetter, county social services director, says his department has already looked at lessons that can be learned, particularly in respect of recruiting home carers. "This has been a sad situation which we regret," he says.

webTitle: Helping women with learning difficulties cope with abuse

fields.headline: Unique place of safety
fields.standfirst: An east London refuge is helping women with learning difficulties cope with abuse
fields.trailText: An east London refuge is helping women with learning difficulties cope with abuse, writes Jenny Knight
fields.body:
"My dad is a bad man. He shouldn't have done what he did. I want to see my mum and I can't because of him, and she can't come here because it's secret." Suddenly, Jasmine changes the subject. Whirling round, she turns up the radio and starts to dance. "I love music, particularly Indian music. I like cleaning. Look at my toys."

Jasmine, a young Asian woman, lives in Beverley Lewis House, Britain's only refuge for women with learning disabilities who have been abused. Most of the residents also have emotional, psychological or behavioural difficulties.

The centre is named after a black, deaf-blind woman with learning disabilities who was found dead in 1989, age 23, wrapped in newspapers and weighing less than five stone. Her name was chosen as a reminder of how easily people like her can fall through the safety nets provided by health and social services.

The refuge, on an east London housing estate, was set up in 1995 after women with learning disabilities complained that there was no safe place for them. Backed by supporters, they formed an organisation called Powerhouse and secured funding for the project from the housing corporation.

Research shows that women with learning disabilities are particularly vulnerable to sexual abuse. At mainstream women's refuges, most residents are fleeing immediate danger. At Beverley Lewis House (BLH), however, the abuse suffered by many is deep in the past and may have continued for years. Because they may have difficulty expressing themselves, and may not be believed, the abuse may emerge only through depression or self-harm.

Hilary McPherson, services manager of East Thames Care, part of the East Thames Housing Group which manages the refuge, says: "The residents gain information on sex and relationships and how to keep themselves safe. Some may have had very limited social experi ences. Society has devalued these people and, combined with abuse, this means that their self-image and sense of self-worth can be negatively affected."

Some women may have learned to win love and attention by being provocative or sexually available. Refuge staff aim to pass on assertiveness skills about how to say no and how to build self-worth. In common with mainstream refuges, staff may have no formal qualifications in social work or psychology. But all have experience with people with learning disabilities and an understanding of the effects of abuse. They also call on a local community health team for professional support.

Like other places offering residential care for people with learning disabilities, BLH is expensive - charges range from £46,000 to £52,000 a year. The women share two-bedroom flats and are supported to do their own shopping and cooking.

Annie has been in the refuge for four months. She wants to return to the seaside town where her family lives, but can she look after herself? "I don't like London," she says. "I miss my friends. My ex-partner used to beat me up. Men are always beating women up when they don't deserve it. When I go home, if I see him, I will walk on the opposite side of the road."

Annie sounds very positive, yet she avoids eye contact. She finds new, everyday experiences hard to deal with. She still remembers with alarm getting lost on a train journey.

Michelle McCarthy, lecturer in learning disability at the Tizard centre at Kent University, has evaluated the refuge and found a tension between the need to keep the women safe and their desire to see friends and family. Many residents told her it was unfair to deny them all visitors, and most felt bored.

In all, about 40 women have stayed at BLH, which can take 12 women at a time. All have to be funded, usually by social services from their home area. Because of the high cost, many referrals are only of women whose previous placements have broken down - often because of their behaviour.

Sandra Baum, a local consultant clinical psychologist, says: "We need more of these refuges across the country. Men with learning disabilities are also abused and yet there is no safe place for them. Often, because of the extent of the abuse, people with learning disabilities cannot be cured in two years, but they can learn to trust, learn about boundaries and reduce their destructive behaviour."

 Names of residents have been changed.

fields.headline: Radical chic
fields.trailText: The original settlements offered people in need a range of assistance, dispensed from a purpose-built house in the heart of their neighbourhoods. Childcare, health, literacy, learning and crafts were covered, and advice was often available on legal problems and welfare rights.
fields.body:
The original settlements offered people in need a range of assistance, dispensed from a purpose-built house in the heart of their neighbourhoods. Childcare, health, literacy, learning and crafts were covered, and advice was often available on legal problems and welfare rights.

This interest in rights led directly to the formation of the Citizens Advice Bureaux network. The Workers' Educational Association was also a product, indirectly, of the settlement movement's heady mix of altruism and Christianity. "Sentimental philanthropy!" snorted his father when the newly-graduated William Beveridge announced he was opting for settlement work, rather than the law or academia as his career.

But settlement life was not all high-minded. There were dances on Saturday nights, summer picnics in the woods, and communal meals were as often cooked by young undergrads as by mature mums.

Most big cities had settlement houses. The flagship was probably Toynbee Hall - one of many in London's east end - where Beveridge shaped his ideas on the welfare state during a stint as sub-warden in the 1900s. In the 1960s, it played a crucial role in the rehabilitation of disgraced Conservative war minister John Profumo, who worked there after resigning. Today, at 86, he remains president of Toynbee's trustees.

fields.headline: Will Blair stand and deliver?
fields.trailText: Unpublicised and thus unreported, the one publication capable of resolving some of the forthcoming bitter election disputes over who spent what on whom was released last week. Public expenditure is always high on any election agenda. Should we spend more or less on public services? This election all three major parties want more expenditure, but this will not end the disputes.
fields.body:
Unpublicised and thus unreported, the one publication capable of resolving some of the forthcoming bitter election disputes over who spent what on whom was released last week. Public expenditure is always high on any election agenda. Should we spend more or less on public services? This election all three major parties want more expenditure, but this will not end the disputes.

There have been two defining spending events in our recent history. The first was Margaret Thatcher's first white paper published in her first year as prime minister in 1979. Its opening statement read: "Public expenditure is at the heart of Britain's present economic difficulties."

It was that white paper which led to 18 years of Tory squeeze. Of course, not all services and not at all times. The recession in the early 1990s, which they helped create, pushed up the cost of social security (via unemployment) from 10% of GDP in 1990 to 13.3% in 1993. But 1979 set the climate.

The second defining event was last November, when Tony Blair acknowledged the unacceptably low level of public spending in Britain over the last 20 years: "Who can seriously doubt that Britain has been chronically under-invested in for over 20 years? We have the fourth biggest economy in the world. Yet we do not have the fourth best public services."

Public expenditure had already begun to rise by then, thanks to Gordon Brown's overlapping three-year spending programmes that followed two tough years of Labour squeeze. But it was on November 22 that Labour clearly signalled it would go into this election restoring public spending as a public virtue - and the Tories recognised they too would have to support a more limited but real rise in spending.

So what emerges from the 140 pages of figures in Public Expenditure: Statistical Analyses 2001-02 from HM Treasury? Hold on to three facts. Public spending as a proportion of national income at the end of the fourth year of a Blair government is the lowest for 27 years, averaging 38.7%, compared to Major's 41.4%, Thatcher's 43%, Wilson/Callaghan's 45.4%, Heath's 41.4% and Wilson's 39.9%. To be fair, the Blair figure involves far less on debt charges and unemployment than earlier administrations.

Second, belatedly, health spending has taken off. This year's 5.7% of GDP is the highest on record - after three years below Tory levels. Three further years of rises planned at twice the historic rate will mean a 33% rise in real resources over five years.

Third, education still lags. Even the latest figure, 4.8%, was exceeded by the Tories in five out of their last six years. More is promised, but even more is needed if the status of teaching is to be restored.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.body:
Taking the Michael

The government could be heading for the crash barriers in Hastings, where anti-bypass fever is building - to the consternation of local Labour MP Michael Foster, who reckons the road has "total local support". An anti-bypass candidate is now being considered for the marginal seat, and Transport 2000 and Friends of the Earth have initiated proceedings for a judicial review; building these roads would, they say, contravene environmental and human rights legislation. Foster should have a word with David Rendell MP, who tried to defend the Newbury bypass and rose to giddy heights of absurdity.

Copped out

The government has come up with 160 sectors of British industry which could be affected by the foot and mouth epidemic. They should add the nuclear industry. The Dutch government has stopped a shipment of used nuclear fuel to Sellafield. Because of the demands put on the Dutch police by foot and mouth, not enough could be spared to escort the consignment.

My Lordzzzzz

A teensy bit of history was made last week when the Green party initiated its first debate in parliament. Lord Beaumont of Whitley, the green peer, proposed that Railtrack should be renationalised. The glorious moment was witnessed by a handful of Labour lords who had mostly forgotten this was their policy five years ago, one peer who was asleep, and two Green party members relegated to the balcony due to their inappropriate attire.

Testing time...

The 25 new farmscale GM test sites throw up some interesting facts: 1. The same farm that Greenpeace raided so publicly in 1999 will be used again to test maize; 2. Nine trials are in foot and mouth infected areas and three are very close to condemned farms; 3. The same group which organised successful opposition to the infamous Watlington trial in 1999 is planning to see off a site at Hinton Waldrist in west Oxfordshire; 4. Two trials are sited right along the route of a proposed bypass. This could all end in tears, Mr Meacher.

... the world over

Monsanto is nursing a bit of a bloody nose in Thailand. Following intense pressure by local farmers and non-governmental groups, the government has now stopped all GM field trials, having already banned all commercial growing of GM crops on its territory.

fields.headline: For peat's sake
fields.standfirst: This weekend our TVs will be bombarded with adverts for compost. Innocent, right? Wrong, say protesters, who claim important areas of conservation are at risk. Pete Bowler on the battle for our boglands
fields.trailText: This weekend our TVs will be bombarded with adverts for compost. Innocent, right? Wrong, say protesters, who claim important areas of conservation are at risk. Pete Bowler on the battle for our boglands
fields.body:
Over the Easter holiday weekend, a battle will take place to win the hearts and minds of Britain's gardeners. The giant, American-owned Scotts Company will spend £2m on TV advertising for a new peat-based, multi-purpose compost. Meanwhile, 50 local Friends of the Earth groups will be lobbying customers at selected DIY and garden centres across the country, urging a boycott of Scotts' Miracle-Gro brand.

This marketing battle will take place against a background of consumer support for a ban on the use of peat, and moves to give the last remaining 6% of raised peat bogs in the UK sufficient protection to enable peat mining to be stopped. The bogs are important habitat for rare plants and birds, such as the UK's largest carniverous plant the great sundew, and the short-eared owl. One site alone supports over 3,500 species.

In a survey published this month, 74% of BBC Gardeners' World magazine readers supported a ban on peat. Over 70% of respondents were happy with the quality of peat-free composts, 78% said they would use them again and 41% were prepared to pay a premium for them.

Last August, English Nature proposed five sites for new or extended designations as special areas of conservation (Sacs) under the European Union Habitats Directive. Scotts operate on three of the sites, at Thorne and Hatfield moors, in South Yorkshire, and Wedholme Flow, in Cumbria. Of the other areas, Bolton Fell Moss is owned by Sinclair Horticulture and Solway Moss by Richardson's Moss Peat Co. Both are in Cumbria. They are among 230 proposed Sacs which would, after consultation, be submitted to Brussels and treated as fully protected sites.

The proposals were additional to earlier Sac designations, following criticism from Brussels in September 1999, that not only was government not putting forward enough sites for the ultimate in EU conservation protection, but also there was a particular shortage of peatland sites.

Although 200 of the sites have been forwarded to Brussels, all five of the peatland sites remain in limbo. Campaigners say that a barrage of questions and delaying tactics have been employed by the two biggest companies to stave off an end to damaging peat mining.

The companies deny this. Nick Kirkbride, managing director of the Scotts Company, says: "We have simply asked English Nature: 'Do these sites qualify?' We feel that there are a number of reasons why they may not. For example, the EU interpretation manual says sites are unlikely to qualify if they consist largely of bare peat. On that basis, our sites do not meet the criteria. We are also questioning whether the sites are capable of restoration to the required habitat type."

Chris Turner, technical manager for Sinclair Holdings, has a similar view. "We have asked English Nature for clarification of the Sac site selection process and criteria", he says.

Both companies acknowledge that Sac designation would require local minerals planning authorities to review existing planning consents. They would determine whether peat extraction is damaging the sites' potential to be restored to the designated habitat type. If this was found to be the case, it would lead to planning permission being revoked, with compensation payable.

The companies' response has been met with disdain by conservationists. Olly Watts, peatland policy officer of the RSPB, says: "The UK's two largest peat extraction companies are treating national and international designations with disdain."

A paragraph in this year's interim report to shareholders by William Sinclair Holdings illustrates the problem. It states: "The position on Sacs, which was referred to in detail in the 2000 report and accounts, remains virtually unchanged. The board is determined to win its case and continue its peat operations in Cumbria. The previous deadline for the submission of our case against the imposition of the Sac has been waived by the authorities as they endeavour to provide answers to our queries, which they are duty bound to do prior to our submission."

Other interested parties were asked to submit their comments on the Sac proposals by October 11 last year, with the Department of the Environment (DETR) hoping to submit the full list of sites to Brussels by the end of that month. Both Scotts and William Sinclair Holding have yet to submit their comments, but both say they are within days of doing so.

Craig Bennett, wildlife campaigner for Friends of the Earth, claims that Scotts has used delaying tactics elsewhere and is filibustering. "In 1990, the US government filed a suit against the Scotts Company, seeking a permanent injunction against peat extraction at a site in New Jersey. The company's lawyers have held the suit in 'administrative suspension' ever since and, over 10 years later, the case is still not resolved."

In the UK, things may be less elastic. The DETR has to send its complete list of candidate Sacs to Brussels by September. However, Helen Kirk, who lives close by Scotts operations at Hatfield moor in South Yorkshire, believes that even this will be too late.

"What Scotts have done is bought themselves an extra season of peat extraction," she claims. "They are mining peat as fast as they can, and stockpiling it. In places, the remaining peat is very woody, very poor quality. The chances of restoring the site to raised mire peat bogs are being reduced each day."

Nick Kirkbride, of Scotts, insists that the rate of extraction is not being speeded up. He says: "We bring peat on to the Hatfield factory site from local moors and imports from abroad. There is very little variation in the overall volume of peat we process each year."

Watts believes the answer is prompt action by English Nature and the DETR. "They must confirm the proposed Sacs quickly," he says. "Then local authorities can get on with their job, review the planning permissions, revoke them, and end damaging peat mining for good."

 Pete Bowler is a Guardian country diarist.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: new ideas give the countryside hope

fields.headline: Scrubs up a treat
fields.standfirst: When Rachel Carson published Silent Spring in 1962, she conjured up an image of spring bereft of birds caused by insidious, unchecked pollution and the profligate use of pesticides by agriculture. Such a simple yet terrifying idea inspired a generation and contributed to the rise of the modern environmental movement. In Britain this spring, a silence is is descending on agriculture itself. For a countryside which owes its character to farming, this silence is also terrifying.

fields.body:
When Rachel Carson published Silent Spring in 1962, she conjured up an image of spring bereft of birds caused by insidious, unchecked pollution and the profligate use of pesticides by agriculture. Such a simple yet terrifying idea inspired a generation and contributed to the rise of the modern environmental movement. In Britain this spring, a silence is is descending on agriculture itself. For a countryside which owes its character to farming, this silence is also terrifying.

Out of the silence will emerge a debate about what shape the future countryside will take. It will be motivated by competing interests and cultural, political and economic agendas. Despite the feelings of despair surrounding the present countryside crisis, there are many options.

One real possibility is that agriculture may regroup to become even more intensive, sacrificing the small farmers on uneconomic land. National Farmers' Union leaders in London will almost certainly pressurise the government to return to the same system as before foot and mouth. The supermarkets may press to be rid of livestock auctions so they can deal directly with farmers. However much environment minister Michael Meacher may want a return to small abattoirs, this may not happen.

However, new forms of agriculture may emerge which are subsidised to produce environmental benefit rather than food production. By design or default, large areas of Britain may be left to the processes of wild nature.

It could be argued that the present countryside crisis is the opposite of Silent Spring: as agriculture suffers, wildlife flourishes. It may also be argued that the decline in agriculture should be treated in the same way as mining, steel working and ship building. Many areas that lost their heavy industry have gained improved environments. Others haven't. Agriculture could go either way. However, political forces in the countryside, together with the cultural significance of our farmed landscapes, mean that significant change will be resisted.

If the sheep and cattle are gone and the grip of agriculture which shaped out landscapes is wrested by one crisis too many, the wild will slowly reclaim the countryside. Seed and root, leaf and wing will push out from woods, stream banks and hedges, and the forest in waiting will make its return journey from obscure corners in the land. In many parts of the country, particularly the uplands, wild nature is gathering for an opportunity denied for generations. But such an opportunity is met by a fear of nature being out of control.

In recent years much thinking, research and discussion among conservation bodies has circled around the idea of reforming agriculture, by getting rid of sheep. For a long time, conservationists have been campaigning against overgrazing to restore the ecology of the uplands, so well described by Chris Baines in these pages last week. Slowly, official attitudes are beginning to swing behind this fewer-sheep-is-better campaign. At the moment, any debate about this is tricky because of the terrible hardship being faced by many farmers.

The National Trust is worried that, in the Lake District for example, it is not just the uniquely adapted breed of Herdwick sheep which are endangered, but the uniquely adapted breed of hill farmers too. David Riddle, assistant director of estates for the National Trust, says: "Lower levels of grazing in the short term may not cause damage in the Lake District and will have ecological benefit. Losing sheep and the farmers may not be a disaster for wildlife habitats but it would be a cultural, social and economic disaster, and have a fundamental change on the landscape. The National Trust recognises that the value of landscape, the wildlife, and public access depends on farmers. As a society we have to decide what are the products we want from the countryside and there will be a readjusting about what we expect from it."

It is possible to be sympathetic towards farmers and their families and still appreciate that nature is creating an opportunity for change far greater than any reform of the Common Agricultural Policy.

Mark Avery, director of conservation for the RSPB, says: "In the short term we must have great sympathy with farmers. However, the prime minister's speech on March 6 pointed to a silver lining in the crisis, and this is a rethink on food and farming. While there is no pleasure to be taken in present difficulties, it is possible to think of a new start with new energy and to involve people in affected areas such as the Lake District, Wales and Devon in finding different ways of moving forward."

In the Lake District, recent reports on the foot and mouth crisis have focused on the threat from scrub which, left unchecked by grazing sheep, would spread to ruin the beauty of the landscape and scare away the tourists.

Scrub is often used as a derisory term but it really describes young or emerging woodland. According to environmental consultant Peter Taylor: "There has been much scaremongering about the fear of scrub making the countryside look neglected. But we can think of it instead as a rewilding of the uplands with a positive message about new trees, species reintroductions and sustaining communities through the kind of sylvo-pastoralism practised in parts of the continent."

A kind of sylvo-pastoralism, grazing using woodland pasture instead of open fields or grassy moorland, has been practised in Britain for centuries, but only tiny fragments of it remain because of farming intensification. By using small suckler herds of cattle, ponies and deer instead of sheep, large areas of new woodland in the uplands could be ecologically enriched and reinvigorated. This sort of farming requires more space for animals to range and that too may be a consequence of foot and mouth.

There are environmentalists who would dearly love to see an end to farming in upland areas of Britain and a return to wilderness exclusive of any human intervention. There are also those who favour a recolonisation of wilder areas by people seeking a lifestyle closer to nature's rhythms and further away from modern urban life. There are many who want to preserve the cultural landscape character of places like the Lake District, with its wide-open spaces maintained by sheep grazing, and find the prospect of new woodland an anathema.

The story of Silent Spring not only helped to start the environmental movement, it also coincided with the intensification of agriculture. We may have come full circle in that environmental concerns will reshape agriculture and in so doing, reshape the countryside. But promoting the value and potential of scrub will require courage.

fields.headline: Front... to back
fields.body:
Stolen moments A burglar ignored valuables at a flat in Hove, East Sussex, and stole only roses, wine and candles. Worcestershire Evening Mail, 23.3.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Hard lesson A student at Southampton University had his £1,300 mountain bike stolen while he was attending a lecture on criminology. Birmingham Evening Mail, 28.3.01 (Simon Briggs, Bearwood)

Slow getaway A man who robbed a building society in Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands, was caught because a heart condition prevented him from running away. Sutton Coldfield News, 23.3.01 (Paul Blackham, Sutton Coldfield)

Wafer-thin evidence The disappearance of the entire supply of communion hosts from a church in Spexhall, Suffolk, is being blamed on a squirrel. East Anglian Daily Times, 31.3.01 (J Newman, Ipswich)

Pie and a pint? Children at a school in Barford St Martin, Wiltshire, are to be supplied dinners by a local pub because the council can't guarantee providing hot meals. Sunday Independent, 1.4.01 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Ghost busted A paranormal investigator believes air currents may be responsible for spine-chilling sensations in a gallery at Hampton Court reputed to be haunted by Henry VIII's fifth wife, Catherine Howard. Oldham Chronicle, 30.3.01 (D Connor, Oldham)

Yow orrite? Foreign nurses at hospitals in Walsall, West Midlands, are being given lessons in Black Country dialect so that they can understand what patients are saying. Midlands Metro, 30.3.01 (Karen Barnes, Stratford-upon-Avon)

Nagging doubt A pub sign showing a wizened old woman at the Nag's Head in Thame, Oxfordshire, is to be replaced by a traditional one of a horse's head after town councillors complained that it was ageist and sexist. Oxford Times, 30.3.01 (Joel Brookfield, Oxford)

Slippery customers Two African giant land snails were found in a bedroom at a Leeds hotel after being left behind by a guest. Metro, 28.3.01 (Wendy Yates, West Norwood)

Sneak preview Portsmouth council is to use CCTV cameras to catch people who put out their rubbish too early. Portsmouth News, 22.3.01 (L Napier, Winchester)

Home alarm A fire crew carrying out safety checks at homes in Brighouse, West Yorkshire, received an emergency call to return to their station, where a mechanical digger had cut through a gas main. Huddersfield Daily Examiner, 27.3.01 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Lunchtime blow-out A bomb alert that caused Bedford's central library to be cleared was called off when the suspect package turned out to be a lunchbox containing a cheese sandwich and a packet of Wotsits snacks. Bedfordshire Times and Citizen, 16.3.01 (Janet Walker, Kempston)

Daffy idea Sixteen children were treated in hospital at Bexhill, East Sussex, after eating daffodils as part of a dare. Sunday Independent, 1.4.01 (Carol Pink, Bigbury on Sea)

Unwedded bliss An unmarried couple who have lived together for less than a year and rarely see each other because they are both lorry drivers won a 'Mr and Mrs' competition run by the village cricket club in King's Sutton, Northamptonshire. Banbury Guardian, 8.3.01 (John Forster, Daventry)

webTitle: Jackson: I'll say sorry for US to China

fields.headline: Jackson: I'll say sorry for US to China
fields.standfirst:
Rev Jesse Jackson ready to difuse standoff between the US and China

Special reports
China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: No international hostage drama involving Americans is complete without a role for the Rev Jesse Jackson and yesterday the former presidential candidate thrust himself into the midst of the 10-day standoff between China and the US by offering to "break the impasse" and try to bring the 24 crew members home.
fields.body:
No international hostage drama involving Americans is complete without a role for the Rev Jesse Jackson and yesterday the former presidential candidate thrust himself into the midst of the 10-day standoff between China and the US by offering to "break the impasse" and try to bring the 24 crew members home.

As negotiations continued between Washington and Beijing over the terms on which the crew of the grounded US spy plane on Hainan island would be allowed to leave, Mr Jackson announced that he had applied for a visa to visit China and that he was ready to help "save face" for both governments by making the apology for the April 1 incident that the Bush administration still refuses to offer.

"If we were to apologise, we lose nothing, politically, diplomatically, militarily, economically. We have nothing to lose and our soldiers to regain," Mr Jackson said yesterday.

"The difference between apology, regrets and 'I'm sorry' is not a great enough distinction to leave the American soldiers there," Mr Jackson said. "The Chinese, culturally, they want to hear the word apology. Culturally, we will not apologise, even for slavery. We are hung up on that word."

Mr Jackson's move came as a Gallup poll indicated that Americans were much more willing to apologise to China than to believe that the US air crew was at fault. Only 13% of Americans believe the US was responsible for last week's mid-air collision, but 41% think their government should make an apology to China. Overall, 68% think the US was not responsible and 54% say the US should not apologise.

The Bush administration appeared not to dismiss Mr Jackson's initiative out of hand. "We certainly appreciate the interest of Mr Jackson and other Americans about the welfare of the air crew and their desire to help out, if that becomes appropriate at some time," the state department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said. "But we are clearly using the diplomatic channels at this point."

Mr Jackson spoke yesterday to the secretary of state, Colin Powell, about his plans. A call to the White House national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, went unreturned. But with little sign of a diplomatic breakthrough on the cards, Mr Jackson may become a more significant factor than his many detractors would like.

"Diplomacy sometimes takes a little longer than some people would like," President Bush said. "We are working hard to resolve the situation.

He said a decision by the Chinese to allow the detained US crew to communicate with their families by email was "an important piece of news".

The White House continued to stress that the administration was prepared to be patient in the search for a solution, but some newspapers reported yesterday that Mr Bush's advisers had concluded that they had no choice. Officials believe that retaliatory acts would not speed the crew's release, and could damage wider US interests in Asia, the New York Times reported.

With frustrations mounting among Mr Bush's Republican supporters, the Chinese ambassador to the US, Yang Jiechi, has written to members of Congress warning them not to try to derail Beijing's bid for the 2008 Olympic Games.

Any attempt to block Beijing's bid would "constitute a gross interference in the internal affairs and inherent rights of the IOC", the letter states, and would "run counter to the spirit" of the Olympic charter.

fields.headline: Woman prison officer taken hostage
fields.trailText: A woman prison officer was last night taken hostage in a cell by a male prisoner.
fields.body:
A woman prison officer was last night taken hostage in a cell by a male prisoner.

Police were called to Wakefield prison, West Yorkshire, after a member of staff was barricaded in a cell by a prisoner at 7.30pm, the prison service confirmed.

"We have one prisoner who has taken one member of staff hostage. The situation is contained, things are quite calm and there is no compromise to public safety," a spokeswoman said.

"At this stage we do not know anything about any demands. There is no evidence of the prisoner having any weapons or having harmed the member of staff," she added.

It was at Wakefield prison that killer and kidnapper Michael Sams imprisoned Julia Flack, the wife of the Archdeacon of Pontefract, John Flack, in 1995.

Sams, who was given four life sentences for murder, including the killing of Leeds teenager Julie Dart, and kidnapping Stephanie Slater, an estate agent, in 1993, was believed to have been trying to draw attention to his grievances as an inmate.

He had eight years added to his four life sentences in 1997 for the false imprisonment of Mrs Flack, a probation officer, whom he tried to throttle with a key chain.

The prison service recently announced that Wakefield would house a £500,000 special unit to hold some of the most dangerous men in Britain's prisons.

Wakefield prison was designated a dispersal prison in 1966 and is now a "lifer main centre" with the focus on serious sex offenders.

It accepts all suitable prisoners from within its catchment area.

The prison service would not say how many women officers work at the unit, but some 15% of uniformed officers throughout the service are female.

The decision to open the "exceptional risk regime" was made after "serious flaws" were discovered in a three-year-old experimental control unit at Woodhill prison, near Milton Keynes.

An academic evaluation published in January of the segregation unit in Woodhill's D wing, which held up to 48 of the most dangerous and disruptive inmates, concluded that it was seriously flawed.

The chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, condemned the regime's isolation of inmates for long periods as a risk to their mental health, and questioned its legality.

The Wakefield unit, expected to open in the autumn, will allow prisoners televisions and computers in their cells, and they will be able to receive visits and telephone calls and have exercise daily.

It is set to hold such men as Charles Bronson, the armed robber and hostage taker, and Robert Maudsley, nicknamed Hannibal the Cannibal for the way he murdered three fellow inmates.

webTitle: Painter wins Britain's richest art prize

fields.headline: Painter wins Britain's richest art prize
fields.standfirst: Special report: Beck's Futures 2001
fields.trailText: An artist who made his name painting "beautiful blonde girls on park benches" last night won Britain's richest art prize, the Beck's Futures Award.
fields.body:
An artist who made his name painting "beautiful blonde girls on park benches" last night won Britain's richest art prize, the Beck's Futures Award.

For Tim Stoner, 30, who aims to make his own life more like the happy, smiley world of his pictures, the win was a double delight, since he was presented with the £24,000 prize by the supermodel and photographer Helena Christensen.

The rest of the £65,000 prize money was spread among the other 10 shortlisted "emerging artists" whose work is now on show at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London.

Martijn Van Nieuwenhuyzen, who chaired the panel of judges, said Stoner's silhouettes of faceless women dancing and happy bathers were the kind of pictures "that should be painted today - of a utopia gone wrong. His paintings depict a seemingly worryless world... a vision of consumerist paradise. But it doesn't take long before the dark undertones of his idealised world... become apparent".

Stoner, whose work has already been bought by such influential collectors as Charles Saatchi, is now studying painting at the British School in Rome. He says that although his paintings have been compared to illustrations from "some kind of rightwing, lifestyle catalogue", his view is that his painting is just "social history".

His style evolved after a visit to a Goya exhibition in Marbella four years ago. He began to "paint incredibly beautiful blonde girls on park benches, trying to explore the motif of desire and the leisure against a pictorial position which emphasises some kind of horror, misplacement and anxiety".

The choice of the 11 shortlisted artists was thought tame by some critics but may reflect the "unsensationalist stance" now being taken by many after the hullabaloo of Brit Art. There are five painters among the winners.

Meanwhile the Japanese filmmaker, Meiro Koziumi, won the £2,000 Beck's Futures Student Film and Video Award.

The Beck's Futures 2 exhibition is sponsored by the Guardian, and stays at the ICA until May 20, then goes on tour.

Stoner, whose work has already been bought by such influential collectors as Charles Saatchi, is now studying painting at the British School in Rome. He says that although his paintings have been compared to illustrations from "some kind of rightwing, lifestyle catalogue", his view is that his painting is just "social history". His style evolved after a visit to a Goya exhibition in Marbella four years ago. He began to "paint incredibly beautiful blonde girls on park benches, trying to explore the motif of desire and the leisure against a pictorial position which emphasises some kind of horror, misplacement and anxiety". The choice of the 11 shortlisted artists was thought tame by some critics but may reflect the "unsensationalist stance" now being taken by many after the hullabaloo of Brit Art. There are five painters among the winners. Meanwhile the Japanese filmmaker, Meiro Koziumi, won the £2,000 Beck's Futures Student Film and Video Award. The Beck's Futures 2 exhibition is sponsored by the Guardian, and stays at the ICA until May 20, then goes on tour.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: Delivered from crisis to emptiness

fields.headline: Delivered from crisis to emptiness
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The pleasant young man with the rifle arrived shortly after breakfast yesterday, and it was all over by lunchtime, not that anyone had much appetite.
fields.body:
The pleasant young man with the rifle arrived shortly after breakfast yesterday, and it was all over by lunchtime, not that anyone had much appetite. The vet was close behind him. She pronounced the herd disease-free but, on the other hand, dead.

And so, in a couple of hours on a cool spring morning, the Dukes Farm herd of 80 pedigree Limousin cattle were slaughtered, having been built up over the past 17 years by Ken and Ruth Watkins. Theirs was one of nine - nine! - farms wiped out over the past two days in the Herefordshire parish of Craswall, not because they had foot and mouth but because they all bordered Forest Farm, which did.

These animals don't even turn up in the statistics on the news, the ones supposedly showing that the disease is slowing down. "It's as though we're being buried in an unmarked grave," said Ruth.

Craswall is a huge, beautiful, chilly place, nestling on the edge of the Black Mountains, just before England becomes Wales. It is about the size of Manhattan, but with barely 100 families, nearly all of whom had cattle and/or sheep. On Monday the army, the police and the men in overalls moved in.

They had all gone by yesterday afternoon. In the corners of fields were those neat piles farmers love. Until you got close, it was hard to tell what was what. Some were just piles of straw; some were logs; some were piles of fodder beet, now redundant. Most comprised sheep, legs upwards, sometimes with their lambs alongside in a ghastly tableau. There was no sound, except muted birdsong and a barking dog.

The Watkinses bred Limousins thoughtfully, carefully and with a quiet passion. I know because they are friends and neighbours. On special occasions, we might have roast beef from their herd, which helped us understand the difference between what you buy in supermarkets - and food.

They got the news on Friday, after which slaughter was scheduled within two days. Maff time being what it is, that meant four days. It was an odd time for the family, their moods veering between optimism and depression, emotion and hard-headedness. Three weeks ago Ken had sat at our table and talked about how slaughter might be a good thing: it would force the decision he had contemplated but resisted for years. He is a craftsman in oak and does not need the aggravation all stock-farming has delivered lately.

This echoes a widespread feeling among farmers. Those who get culled get paid; those still in the game get nothing but have to keep paying for feed. (As one put it to me: "We can't buy. We can't sell. We can't shift 'em. We can't move on. We can't give up. We're stuck.") This makes it impossible to believe that at least some of the 1,200 cases have not been deliberately self-inflicted.

But economic theory sometimes gets overtaken by emotion. A small breeding herd is not normally just destined for the slaughterhouse. They have names; they have personalities. Each year's calves have names beginning with the same letter, like a car registration plate. The 2001 crop were all supposed to be S, yet until yesterday Ken was still feeding cows called Drusilla and Gazette. And he was very proud of his bull, Waindale Onthemove - nothing much to look at, especially after a hard winter's shagging - but a successful 132-stone patriarch.

Yet the Watkinses supported the cull, as did the other Craswall farmers. There were two meetings over the weekend, attended by almost all those affected, and at neither was there serious opposition to the policy. The anger is directed at the implementation, and the perceived incompetence of the bureaucracy, even after two months of crisis. Maff is turning into a generic: "You've made a right maff of that."

In Herefordshire, the problems are doubled because a few miles away - across a border wandering sheep refuse to respect - the cull is controlled by the Welsh assembly. There is no evidence of contact between the sets of officials.

Ken witnessed an example of the system's madness yesterday, after his herd were shot. The vet saw four unidentified sheep in the area to be culled. Under the rules, they had to go. But the rules also forced her to ring Maff in Worcester for permission. She did not even have a special number, but had to wait on the notorious helpline like everyone else.

Anger was not, however, the predominant mood. As the slaughterman worked, Ken and Ruth sat inside with their elder son, Michael, listening to Mozart, which did not entirely drown out the shots. The younger children had been sent away so when the shooting stopped, the farm was quiet. "There's a huge sense of relief," said Ken. "I was afraid the cattle would be clutching the wall in terror, but they assured me they never get out of a state of bemusement."

The next few days will be difficult. But he's looking beyond that. "It's going to feel very strange not to spend every morning and evening of my life feeding and looking after cattle. At the moment I don't know what it means but I feel it's going to be a liberation. I don't intend to farm again."

Michael, who at 17 has been rock-like while his parents' mood has shifted over the past few days, is more than ever convinced that he wants a less fraught career. It is Ruth who seems least certain: "You can't have 70,000 square miles of theme park. My great-grandfather kept a milking herd in the heart of London. I don't think I can let it die."

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Foot and mouth is now on our diarist's doorstep and the strain is taking its toll on everyone

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth is now on our diarist's doorstep and the strain is taking its toll on everyone.
fields.body:
Peter completely lost the plot yesterday morning. Every little thing that could have gone wrong did. The cows were mixed up in the big shed, and a couple of ewes had either abandoned their live lambs or delivered dead ones during the wet night. So, following the strain of the last few days, Peter let rip with the ripest of farmyard language and everyone ducked for cover.

Since I wrote last Friday's entry the countryside in our near neighbourhood has changed - probably for ever. In two localities - Hallington and Capheaton - we have had further confirmed cases of foot and mouth, and this time Maff has reacted swiftly. The confirmed cases were taken out promptly. Between Saturday and yesterday the livestock from the adjacent farms have been taken. Our friends and colleagues have gone through a hellish time.

The sight of army Land Rovers and huge container wagons has become almost commonplace. Every time we see or hear reports of wagons queuing at the quarry entrance (just over a mile from our house) or parked in the large layby beside one of our boundary fields, we wonder who will be the next to succumb to the disease or feature on the latest "contiguous" list. The strain is really taking its toll on us all. On Monday I was totally exhausted and I've been told (many times) that I've completely lost my sense of humour.

The two hamlets at Hallington and Great Bavington have also been seriously affected. For two days Great Bavington has been almost cut off, the roads shut while the grisly work at nearby farms was carried out. If you find yourself on the wrong side of the tape then you're stuck, and once again there is no information to help any of us to plan, or make allowances, for such a contingency.

A friend of mine, Nicola Bell, told me about a vet she met who was deeply upset about the fate of the young lambs and calves so recently born, and then dispatched by lethal injection, so long before their time. This is what really gets to us all around here. We are now fairly well through the lambing of the Mule flock and the Scottish Blackface sheep are due today; but all the lambs we have worked so hard for might end up in a big hole. I know we rear them to sell to the butcher but, as any livestock farmer will tell you, that is a different proposition altogether.

We talk to our nearest neighbours constantly and the phone has become a lifeline - we almost cling together like shipwrecked sailors swimming desperately for the lifeboat. We're all extremely conscious that if one of us drowns, the rest go down as well. But the pressure is spoiling even long-standing friendships: disagreements, sometimes fuelled by ill-founded rumours, are boiling over, and huge rifts are opening up in the rural community.

The pressure on us was turned up even more on Sunday morning, when a neighbour phoned to say they'd found a sick cow. The farmer thought she had a post-partum infection, probably caused by a section of the placenta retained in the womb. The farmer's vet couldn't visit, but suggested, from a description of the symptoms that included a hanging-out tongue, that she might be getting a touch of milk fever, but told our friends to call Maff. Although we were terrified, we decided to say nothing - we did not want to cause any extra panic among our family and staff.

Never has a day seemed so long, or the phone, when it rang, sounded so loud. At tea time on Sunday we received another call. Maff had not been in touch but the cow seemed brighter. The antibiotics and dose of calcium seem to be helping. By Tuesday she was, thankfully, back to normal and more importantly, no other animals nearby looked sick.

The phone bill arrived yesterday. I had to hide it from Peter until I had recovered from the shock - it was 50% higher than normal, but then I've hardly used the car in the last seven weeks.

More cases are appearing in Northumberland, and in various areas, although they are mainly contiguous to earlier ones. One confirmed case on Monday was next to the Hadrian's Wall farm that succumbed nearly three weeks ago. This new case occurred on a farm which had until now escaped the contiguous cull. The livestock were killed the next day. The neighbour, Willie Woodman, who has been on tenterhooks for so long, knows he will not escape this time.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will next appear on Friday.

fields.headline: Police check 'illegal' livestock movements
fields.standfirst:
Farmers' leaders angered by allegations of compensation fraud

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farm union leaders were last night on the defensive as police forces moved in to investigate hundreds of suspected illegal movements of cattle carried out since the foot and mouth epidemic started
fields.body:
Farm union leaders were last night on the defensive as police forces moved in to investigate hundreds of suspected illegal movements of cattle carried out since the foot and mouth epidemic started

Accusations were levelled that infected carcasses were being moved around the country to spread the epidemic and that farmers were fraudulently claiming money for nonexistent livestock.

As the number of daily outbreaks climbed to 41, the highest total for more than a week, bringing the overall total to 1,205, West Mercia police said they were launching an inquiry into illegal movements of animals.

It follows increasing concern by the Ministry of Agriculture that the disease is still not under control in some places and that it is being spread into new areas by the transport of animals. Yesterday 10 new cases were confirmed in Gloucestershire.

An official report commissioned by Tony Blair disclosed that trading standard officers had investigated 309 cases of alleged illegal livestock movements since the outbreak began and that many more were in the pipeline. Many of these are thought to have been in Powys where 62 allegations are being investigated. One farmer is reported to be close to being prosecuted and could face a fine of up to £5,000 if found guilty.

Many are being investigated as a result of anonymous tip-offs by members of the public. "We have people calling us who notice that a field which was previously empty one day has animals in it the next," said a council spokesman.

Police have also begun investigating allegations of fraudulent claims for compensation during the foot and mouth crisis. These were highlighted at the start of the epidemic and centre on the practice of a few farmers who "bed and breakfast" livestock, or lend them out to neighbouring farmers in order to claim EU subsidies.

Maff yesterday would neither confirm nor deny reports that it had asked police to look into a possible incident of a farmer deliberately infecting his livestock to get compensation. But a retired Derbyshire sheep farmer suggested this week that the practice was common in the 1967 epidemic.

He said: "There were gangs doing it. It would not surprise me at all if it was going on today".

But Antony Gibson, the NFU's south west regional director, said there was "no justification" for blame being put on the victims of the epidemic. Acccusing ministers of trying to take the heat off themselves, he said: "They have been mak ing these insinuations almost from the start, suggesting it was farmers who were responsible for spreading the disease, rather than recognising their own incompetence for not bringing it under control.

Meanwhile, Maff was accused of suppressing some statistics on the numbers of animals affected by foot and mouth after rising embarrassment over the failure to reach slaughter targets.

Although, over three weeks, there has been gradually increasing censorship, a daily total of animals to be killed and already slaughtered has always been given. But this stopped yesterday.

webTitle: Is it the end of the Lake District?

fields.headline: 'If they go, it is the end of Lakeland'
fields.standfirst:
A Harry Griffin, lifelong resident of the Lake District, despairs at the possible foot and mouth cull of the region's famous Herdwick sheep

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A Harry Griffin, lifelong resident of the Lake District, despairs at the possible foot and mouth cull of the region's famous Herdwick sheep.
fields.body:
If the scourge of foot and mouth spreads through the Lake District fell country, it will be the biggest disaster to hit the area during the 90 years of my lifetime - no, for even longer. Unless it is quickly checked, the disease will not only ruin the scenery of a million postcards, but shatter a long-established way of country life, wreck the tourist industry and destroy the area as we know it today.

This is because the fell farmers and their sheep - particularly the hardy, indigenous Herdwicks - are really the architects of the scenery. If the sheep are slaughtered and the fells cleared, it will change everything. Rough scrubland and coarse grasses will quickly take over the landscape. Moss, bogs and marshes will proliferate. Gorse and juniper will spread. The close-cropped upland pastures will disappear. The old stone walls will crumble. The whole landscape will harshen and deteriorate. The Lake District will disappear.

The disease reached the Lake District fell country for the first time the other day - at the lonely farm of Black Hall in the upper reaches of the Duddon valley. Two or three miles to the southwest, across the unfenced fells, are some of the Herdwick farms that Beatrix Potter bought from the proceeds of her little books. She had many, many thousands of them.

The first Herdwick sheep probably came with Norse settlers in the 10th century, although they may have already been part of the flocks of the Cistercian monks of Furness Abbey, who first farmed the Lakeland dales. Either way, they have been indigenous to the area for 1,000 years: stolid, patient animals with sad, but rather noble, white faces, the "little grey sheep" of a hundred books and poems.

Unlike lowland sheep or cattle, contained in their fields, Herdwicks roam the fells, seeking the sweetest grass. With their rather tough, oily wool, they live up in the mountains in all weathers - apart from lambing, dipping and shearing times, when they are briefly brought down to the "inbye" fields adjoining the farmstead. There are no fences on the high land and sheep pass freely from one farmer's grazing acres to the next farmer's sheep run. (Stray sheep are exchanged at the annual shepherds' meets, the farmers immediately identifying their own by the "smit" marks made by dye on the fleece of the sheep, and the "lug" marks on their ears.)

But the most remarkable feature of the Herdwicks is their homing instinct. On the fell they are "heafed" to their own part of the mountain. That is to say, they and their families always graze that area, and if taken away for lambing, return there instinctively. This homing instinct, once destroyed through mass slaughter, may never be restored.

They would be sorely missed at the dinner table, too. Their mutton, when slowly cooked in a Lakeland farmhouse oven and topped with a rich, golden crust, is superb; and Herdwick mutton is said to have been on the menu at Buckingham Palace on several ceremonial occasions.

There are other mountain sheep on the Lakeland fells, notably Swaledales and Rough-Fells, but the hardy Herdwick is the sheep most likely to be seen in and around the Duddon valley, the Coniston fells, the Buttermere fells and, through Borrowdale or Wasdale, up to the highest land in England, the Scafells. More than the old drystone walls that quarter the fells, the packhorse bridges or the whitewashed farmsteads, the little grey Herdwick sheep typify the Lakeland.

If they and their shepherds go, that is the end of the Lakeland where I have climbed, walked, skied and skated for nearly 80 years; of the Lakeland I have written about nearly all my life.

When I try to picture the Lakeland without the Herdwicks and the farmers, my thoughts go back to Grisedale - The Valley That Died, as it was called in a television film and a book about it. This is not one of the two Lakeland Grisedales but the Grisedale in the Yorkshire dales, above Garsdale.

This lovely, lonely, upland valley was a favourite corner of mine, the homeland of a happy farming community of perhaps a dozen families until economic conditions drove all but one of them away. They left behind a graveyard of ruined farmhouses, with the roofs fallen in and bedsteads, cookers and armchairs abandoned; a child's toy here, a broken bicycle there.

But it was the state of the valley that most hit me when I returned - soured pastures, overgrown paths, once-green meadows now full of swamps and rushes, field walls falling down and dereliction everywhere. In recent years the dale has recovered a little and the Forestry Commission has moved in, but the Grisedale of years ago - sparkling streams and new lambs leaping in the meadows - has gone for ever. Will the Lake District suffer the same sad fate?

 A Harry Griffin has been writing a country diary for the Guardian from the Lake District for 50 years.

fields.headline: Cumbria reopens 100 paths
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: One hundred footpaths in Cumbria closed by foot and mouth will be open by Easter - although three which were to have opened near Keswick will now remain closed because of a new outbreak of the disease.
fields.body:
One hundred footpaths in Cumbria closed by foot and mouth will be open by Easter - although three which were to have opened near Keswick will now remain closed because of a new outbreak of the disease.

The decision was announced by the county's foot and mouth taskforce which has negotiated the openings to appeal to visitors eager to walk in the Lake District and beyond dur ing the Easter break. "All the routes have been carefully considered on a risk assessment basis using guidelines agreed in the county between the taskforce and Maff," a spokesman said.

Routes open include a newly fenced path to Shepherd's Crag in Borrowdale, a popular spot for climbers, and shore walks by Ullswater. The car park at Gowbarrow will also reopen.

A route will be available down the western side of Thirlmere and the Lodore landing stage on Derwentwater will come back into use, enabling visitors to take cruises and to walk around the lake.

Many routes are in areas on the west coast and on the fringes of the national park. Other paths are to be investigated.

"With new cases still being confirmed in the county, the utmost care is taken [over] each path or site to ensure it meets risk assessment criteria," the spokesman added.

fields.trailText: The nightmare is not yet over. Still only nine months old, the internet twins have already had four sets of parents and are due two more sets now they are being returned to the US.
fields.body:
The nightmare is not yet over. Still only nine months old, the internet twins have already had four sets of parents and are due two more sets now they are being returned to the US. Yet the high court decision on Monday was the right and proper course. Indeed, since the Arkansas court - which granted the original quickie adoption order to the far from suitable English adopters, Alan and Judith Kilshaw - had subsequently annulled it, there was no other course the English court could have taken. The two babies have American citizenship. The law being the law - and the multiple parties already involved in this tug-of-love case - it took five days of legal argument plus many weeks of preparation to reach this decision.

Rarely has the need for regulation of adoption been so publicly underlined than by the trauma suffered by the twins in the unregulated American free market. Twice sold to the highest bidder, then chased across the US by competing adoptive families, and finally subjected to unending television appearances once having reached Britain with the Kilshaws, the babies were rightly taken into care by Flintshire social services. At least the national furore over their treatment forced ministers' hands. The reform of UK regulation of overseas adoptions has been accelerated with a statutory order passed two weeks ago; and ministers are committed to ensuring that the domestic adoption reform bill, currently before the Commons but unlikely to be enacted before the election, will be re-introduced early in the next parliament.

There is one small act which should now be done for the twins. The current plan is to send them back to temporary foster parents in the US until the American courts have resolved the competing claims. Why not keep them here until a final US decision is reached? At least that way the babies would be saved from yet another short-term placement. They have already been shuffled too much.

webTitle: Zimbabweans' hopes of land fade into dust

fields.headline: Zimbabweans' hopes of land fade into dust
fields.standfirst:
A year ago veterans seized this white farm. Now the workers are starving

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The workers on Calgary farm mostly sided with the war veterans when they invaded the white-owned holding exactly a year ago this week.
fields.body:
The workers on Calgary farm mostly sided with the war veterans when they invaded the white-owned holding exactly a year ago this week.

The veterans' leader - an army corporal called Stanley Mapfumo - promised the farm hands higher wages and said the lush 1,400-hectare (3,500-acre) farm just north of Harare would be divided among those who worked it.

Above all, he pledged, they would be equal in this new enterprise. No more farmers to answer to.

Today, Cpl Mapfumo is settled into one of the large, comfortable houses abandoned by the white owners from where he directs the workers still crammed into "the compound". But there is hardly enough cash to pay the farm hands, so now they only work a few days each month. And they are still waiting for their personal slice of Calgary.

To many of them, it is increasingly difficult to tell the difference between Cpl Mapfumo and what went before. Except now they are hungrier and more fearful of the future.

"We regret the war veterans coming very, very much," said one of the farm hands who cannot be identified for his own safety. "We thought there would be better things to come but now we are beginning to realise. There's so much uncertainty - no crops, the bosses are leaving. What's our future like? I think it is bleak."

When the small batch of war veterans descended on Calgary last year, they told its owner, David Wheeler, that the land was stolen from their ancestors and they wanted him to hand over half the farm.

Mr Wheeler's father bought the property in 1922 from a Shropshire-born farmer who had seized the land from its black residents 16 years earlier.

Cpl Mapfumo led the charge to redress history. He is a driver at a local army barracks and old enough to be a genuine veteran of the liberation war of the 1970s. The moment he stepped on to Mr Wheeler's land he became the "base commander".

He upped his demands by telling the farmer to hand over the entire place or the war veterans would be back to take it by force.

Mr Wheeler was defiant. He said he would not move or even talk to them. But he took the threats seriously when two days later another farmer, David Stevens, was murdered by war veterans.

Within 24 hours Mr Wheeler fled with his wife and three children to South Africa and then to France. By the time they were settled in a village near Toulouse, several hundred war veterans were ensconced at Calgary.

The farm's 120 workers were divided. Some were suspicious of the war veterans but most liked what they heard.

While Mr Wheeler paid his workers the legal minimum wage of 64 Zimbabwe dollars (85p) a day, the war veterans promised them 70 dollars a day and their own land. More than half the workers immediately went over. Their first job was to clear a few acres and plant sugar (kidney) beans.

But at the end of the first month there was no money for pay. Cpl Mapfumo said the workers would have to wait until the beans were harvested and sold. And one other thing, they would have to wait for their personal share of Calgary.

Hopeful

The workers were still not their own masters, but on the whole, many thought it better than working for a white farmer.

"The war veterans told us this was going to be our farm and everyone would share. There is a lot of land here so we knew there was plenty for everyone," said a farm hand. "We were very hopeful, even when the war veterans did not have money to pay us. We thought they will go and get it from the government."

Mr Wheeler returned to Zimbabwe in August without his family, and tensions on Calgary rose sharply.

He got into a running battle with the war veterans and won a high court order expelling Cpl Mapfumo and his men from Calgary but the police refused to enforce it. Mr Wheeler cut off the veterans' electricity supply. They reconnected it and beat up his mechanic whom they wrongly blamed for severing the power.

The war veterans threatened the farmer's maid, denigrating her as "Wheeler's wife" because she was staying alone with him in the house, and they rolled his 80-year-old retired housekeeper in the mud.

By the end of January, the war veterans had had enough of Mr Wheeler. Cpl Mapfumo stormed into his house with a gang.

"Do you think you are a bull?" he shouted at the white landowner, and started pounding him with his fists. The other veterans leapt in, kicking and punching. Mr Wheeler was hospitalised with a deep head wound and a broken rib.

After Cpl Mapfumo led his men to the police station, where they accused the farmer of assaulting them, Mr Wheeler moved out of Calgary.

By now the farm was deteriorating fast. No new crops were planted, other than the sugar beans, and the fields were overgrown and untended, one small contribution to a looming food crisis in Zimbabwe.

The workers were increasingly hungry and disillusioned with the war veterans. But still Cpl Mapfumo found new followers, principally from farm hands sacked because there was no more work for them.

"The workers are having a big problem," said one employee. "Some of them are starving in the compound."

Suffering

The workers' families back in their home villages were also suffering. They were used to receiving small remittances from the workers' pitiful wages, but those have dried up.

Most of Cpl Mapfumo's own contingent of veterans has drifted away, leaving just a handful living on the farm fulltime who stare back blankly at questions. Neither is Cpl Mapfumo keen to discuss the situation. At his army base, he sends word that anyone found trespassing on "his land" will be beaten.

Calgary is not the only property where the farm occupations are quietly collapsing. The war veterans have abandoned Mr Stevens's farm altogether. His widow says they are afraid of her murdered husband's ghost.

Still, many of the workers cling to the final hope of getting a share of Calgary.

"The idea of wanting land was always there. It is very important to many poor Zimbabweans. During this war veterans' campaign we thought we would have our own land but we haven't got it," said another farm hand.

"Now some of the workers are wondering if the farm is not being saved for someone else, someone important in the government. Otherwise why don't they just give us the land?"

Mr Wheeler has drawn comfort from the crisis on his farm.

"They have proved they don't know what they are doing. They will have to give us the land back or the country is finished," he said.

But it is not that straightforward. Well over 100,000 Zimbabweans have signed up to receive a parcel of the two-thirds of white-owned land earmarked for redistribution.

The government has yet to let them loose on the farms, but the presidential election looms - it must be held within a year - and it may suit President Robert Mugabe to entice voters and disrupt the opposition with a new and much larger round of land occupations.

Some of the workers on Calgary are sceptical that they will benefit. The only winners there are Cpl Mapfumo and his followers living comfortably on the hill.

"They will all cling to the houses," said a farm hand. "That is what they wanted all along. They were never interested in the land."
