fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a panel headed Winky Dink to Sky Sports, page 3, Online, April 5, about the development of interactive TV, we wrongly said that in 1993 Oracle changed its name to Teletext.
fields.body:
 In a panel headed Winky Dink to Sky Sports, page 3, Online, April 5, about the development of interactive TV, we wrongly said that in 1993 Oracle changed its name to Teletext. In fact, the two were separate companies. Oracle had to bid for its franchise in the same way as the ITV companies did, and was outbid by Teletext Ltd, who took over on January 1 1993.

 The summary of the response to our survey of MPs, page 8, G2, yesterday, did not add up. The detailed figures fell one short of the total of 231 MPs who responded. That was because the number of Labour responses should have been given as 152 and not 151.

 A correction yesterday to a sports report on page 30, March 28, was itself wrong. Graeme Hick actually has the worst average, at 31.32, of any specialist batsman in Test history with more than 3,000 Test runs. Bev (not Bec) Congdon (32.22) and Graeme Wood (31.83) were originally named as possessing a lower average than Hick. They actually possess a higher one.

 In our review of Muse at Manchester Academy, page 16, April 9, we said their new song was called, Plug Me In. It is actually called Plug In Baby.

 The still used to illustrate our feature about the Beatles film A Hard Day's Night, pages 10 and 11, Friday Review, April 6, did not come from A Hard Day's Night as captioned. It came from Help!

 Professor Maxwell McGlashan who appeared in the Birthdays column, page 23, March 31 (for Sunday, April 1), died on July 18, 1997. Apologies to his family.

 It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Tesco piles it high
fields.standfirst:
But farmers are angry over its £1bn profit

What's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Stores could be sometimes forgiven for feeling that they are damned if they do and damned if they don't.
fields.body:
Stores could be sometimes forgiven for feeling that they are damned if they do and damned if they don't. Earlier this week Marks & Spencer was in disgrace because of falling profits. Yesterday Tesco was in trouble because its profits were rising. The group - which has long since ousted Sainsbury's as the consumers' supermarket of choice - notched up its first £1bn in profit last year and immediately sparked a controversy. The National Consumer Protection Council said it was high time Tesco cut its prices and gave customers more benefits from the company's profits. The National Farmers Union said it would be difficult for many of its members to understand how Tesco could make £1bn when they were devastated by the foot and mouth crisis. This is a far cry from the time when M&S made over £1bn. The group was given national hero status at the time. But that, as they say, belongs to history.

Tesco argues, quite plausibly, that it has grown bigger by taking market share from other supermarkets. Terry Leahy, chief executive, claims that prices are down 11% in real terms over five years and that profits after tax are just 3p in the £ - hardly profiteering. But that won't quell the controversy because of the long running row over supermarket groups using their market power to squeeze unacceptably low prices from Britain's farmers. This argument had been simmering long before foot and mouth gave it an added dimension. Farmers have been complaining that they have been forced to sell lambs to supermarkets at less than cost or at an unacceptably low profit so shops can keep prices down out of the sweat of the farming community. Last month Tony Blair joined in the debate when he said supermarkets had "pretty much got an armlock" on farmers - even though a recent inquiry by the competition commission had found the supermarkets not guilty of profiteering.

That was true. But it is also true that the imbalance in bargaining power between a handful of giant supermarket groups and the small farmers may have led to an oligopolistic situation in which shop prices are lower than they really ought to be simply because a small number of buyers can squeeze prices down to uneconomic levels. Farmers are particularly vulnerable when there is a surplus of the products they produce. The logic of this - not easy to achieve in real life - is that supermarkets ought to raise prices as long as the extra income goes to the producer rather than to the customer. Consumers for their part are complicit in this process because they buy cheaper bulk-bought meat from supermarkets rather than getting the (more expensive) personal touch from their local butcher. Ironically, meat prices have started to rise again but only because foot and mouth has sent the price of imported meat soaring by 20% in the past month, so overseas farmers will get the benefit.

It is possible that the destruction of livestock brought about by the foot and mouth outbreak will so reduce the supply of UK meat that higher prices will result. But that will depend on whether customers switch back to home production. Either way, there is something wrong with the balance of power between supermarkets and British farmers. Consumers can't have it both ways - sympathising with farmers while continuing to shop until they drop in supermarkets. It is all very well for the National Consumer Protection Council to call on customers to shop elsewhere for cheaper food. But buying even cheaper food isn't going to help the farmers. What they want is a level playing field.

webTitle: Rivals flounder as Debenhams profits leap 9%

fields.headline: Rivals flounder as Debenhams profits leap 9%
fields.trailText: Debenhams, the high-street department chain, was yesterday celebrating a 9% leap in profits, apparently unaffected by the woes that have hit a number of other large retailers.
fields.body:
Debenhams, the high-street department chain, was yesterday celebrating a 9% leap in profits, apparently unaffected by the woes that have hit a number of other large retailers.

The company revealed that it had outperformed the FTSE all-share index by 58% in the past year, and the UK general retail index by 36%. While other high-street retailers - including Gap and Marks and Spencer - have been stuck in the doldrums, Debenhams posted pretax profits for the six months to February 24 of £80.8m - up from £73.8m -Sales were up 11.9% at £867.4m; like-for-like sales rose by 6.9%.

Yesterday shares in Debenhams rose by 22.25p on the back of the results, closing at 440p.

"We are seeing a strong performance in the current season across clothing and non-clothing," said chief executive Belinda Earl.

"Our new stores are outperforming and we have a serious momentum behind our brands. "The high street is generally looking much more confident. Our prices are stable - this time last year there was still price deflation."

Key to the retailer's success has been drawing in cus tomers who have drifted away from other established high- street names. Debenhams now claims to control 13.1% of the UK department store market.

It has attracted custom through strong designer label offerings and the introduction of initiatives such as lockers for weighed-down shoppers and family-friendly services.

"We believe that our strategy will continue to enable us to build market share," said chairman Peter Jarvis. He added that the company would continue to pursue a rolling programme of investment which has been driving profitable growth.

Debenhams now operates 96 stores in the UK, with over 7m sq ft of shop floor, and eight stores due to open in the next three years.

"We believe that we could trade profitably in over 150 markets in the UK giving us huge potential to expand in the future," Ms Earl said.

"We are in negotiation for a number of possible sites and actively looking for new sites in markets where we are not represented."

Credit Suisse First Boston, broker to Debenhams, yesterday raised its pretax profits forecast for the retail group from £140m to £143m for the year to August, and from £150m to £155m for the following year.

webTitle: Square Mile slowdown hits St Ives

fields.headline: Square Mile slowdown hits St Ives
fields.trailText: St Ives, the printing group, yesterday said the paucity of corporate activity in the City had contributed to a 4% decline in profits in the first half of the year to £30.7m.
fields.body:
St Ives, the printing group, yesterday said the paucity of corporate activity in the City had contributed to a 4% decline in profits in the first half of the year to £30.7m.

Shares in the company fell by 12% to 357p as chairman Miles Emley warned that the level of City activity was unlikely to return in time to lift full-year profits.

The publication of documents for takeovers, flotations or demutualisations account for 15% of St Ives' revenues.

Mr Emley said it was difficult to predict when City work would return. "There are as many views as there are people to express them. But it will come back. Those clever people in the City will find some way of making money."

St Ives attempted to calm investors' nerves by suggesting that its broad range of business would help it weather the slowdown in work coming from the Square Mile.

St Ives prints books, including the Harry Potter series and magazines such as the Economist, as well as direct mail brochures and mail-order catalogues.

The success of the Harry Potter novels helped maintain UK market share of the book-printing business at more than 20% in a sector described as "resilient" by St Ives.

But it admitted that the fall in dot.com advertising had dented some magazine printing contracts in the US. St Ives is also facing a market that is increasing in capacity. A number of rivals invested in new machinery on a speculative basis when the dot.com market was booming.

Around 100 jobs have already been axed at St Ives to reduce costs, largely in the UK financial printing division.

Mr Emley expressed surprise at the share price fall, noting that the City should have noticed that corporate business was drying up.

"I would have thought this would have already been in the price," he said.

The share price has almost halved since its peak of 635p at the start of last year.

Revenues fell by 2.4% to £233m while the dividend was lifted by 5% to 5p.

fields.headline: Red, white and blue claims the day
fields.standfirst: Tesco breaks the £1bn barrier
fields.trailText: With little in the way of boasting or swagger, Tesco yesterday announced profits of more than £1bn.
fields.body:
With little in the way of boasting or swagger, Tesco yesterday announced profits of more than £1bn.

In the middle of the foot and mouth crisis the company that sells 25% of our food quietly published results which - to borrow a phrase from competitor Sainsbury's duff advertising campaign of 1999 - were really something to shout about.

After a two-year competition commission investigation into whether the supermarkets make excessive profits and an off the cuff remark from the prime minister earlier this year about the supermarkets having their suppliers in "an armlock", it would not have been surprising to see the beleagured farmers' groups wading into battle against the grocer once again.

But even the National Farmers Union was on side with the UK's biggest grocer and urged its members to work with, rather than against, such a successful organisation.

Tesco's strategy - in a nutshell - is to plaster the world with its red, white and blue colours. It is expanding across central Europe and Asia.

Its operations in Hungary and Thailand, the countries leading its international ambitions, have just moved into profit.

It is testing the water in Taiwan, making plans for Malaysia and considering putting a toe in the water in China and Japan.

It is also talking to bombed-out US online grocers about shipping its already profitable UK dot.com home delivery service across the Atlantic.

Meanwhile at home, it is planning more non-food sales, with a target of £5bn turnover by the end of next year.

Yesterday chief executive Terry Leahy snuck out a little warning that the shops in Poland - 10 so far, another five on the way - might be hit by recent interest rate rises and that his South Korean venture - seven stores so far, another 17 planned - had already been affected by the economic downturn there.

But these new regions are not expected to make a real impact until 2002.

Until then, the UK still looks good, with plenty of expansion in the pipeline to deliver the double-digit earnings growth Tesco promises. The group is driving sales, but holding its margins despite food price deflation of 2%; and although its rivals are improving, they are not moving fast enough to eat into Tesco's market share yet.

There is, however, one worry - that Tesco might follow M&S and believe it has become part of the establishment now it is raking in a billion a year.

The warning signs would include odd moves such as appointing a former spy chief to its board, as M&S did with Dame Stella Rimington.

But until then, Tesco is a class act. Its main European rival, Carrefour, trades at an unjustified premium. The share price may have recoiled a little yesterday, but it remains a core holding.

Off digital

At a conference on Monday, ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble could be heard haranguing government, the BBC and ITV for not doing enough to encourage the take-up of digital TV. BBC Choice, Knowledge and ITV2 have not done much, he noted, to drive sales.

The government, which hopes to switch off the analogue signal in 2006-2010, had missed a huge opportunity, he said. Since culture secretary Chris Smith made his announcement on the switch-off, 6m TV sets have been sold in Britain, of which only 150,000 are digital. Public information campaigns are needed, he said. But it is starting to become apparent that the attribution of blame is preparing the ground for some difficult truths.

In a Guardian interview in January, Mr Prebble said he remained confident that the company would reach the 2m subscriber mark by the end of next year.

At that point it would reach break-even, he said. In a Financial Times interview little over a week ago, that date was fudged. Although not directly attributed to Mr Prebble, it had shifted back to 2003-4.

Now, it emerges, Carlton and Granada, ONdigital's two main shareholders, are getting cold feet about the cash they are willing to plough into the pay-TV platform.

In happier times, investors were comfortable with the ever-growing investment in ONdigital. With the collapse in advertising seen at ITV, they are starting to fidget. The argument from the shareholders appears to be that ONdigital has reached a size where it does not still need significant investment to maintain its momentum. The focus will be on increasing revenues instead of winning new market share.

With just 1m customers compared with BSkyB's 5m and an offer that is weaker in almost every respect, that argument carries little weight. With churn levels said to be at 25%, this is the time to bite down and invest, not retrench. Mr Prebble's shareholders are putting him in a very uncomfortable position.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • Doing business abroad can be a difficult affair, what with having to deal with language barriers and different social mores. A textbook example is the experience of a UK information technology company called Torex. The company's Torex Health arm last year bought Laufenberg, a German developer of specialist hospital software. When the new owners examined the software produced by the acquisition, they noticed that there was an important function missing compared to the similar UK product. Where, they asked their German colleagues, was the software for managing hospital waiting lists? The Germans looked puzzled, and translators were brought in to explain. Still the Germans were puzzled, explaining that as German hospitals didn't have waiting lists, there wasn't any need.
fields.body:
 Doing business abroad can be a difficult affair, what with having to deal with language barriers and different social mores. A textbook example is the experience of a UK information technology company called Torex. The company's Torex Health arm last year bought Laufenberg, a German developer of specialist hospital software. When the new owners examined the software produced by the acquisition, they noticed that there was an important function missing compared to the similar UK product. Where, they asked their German colleagues, was the software for managing hospital waiting lists? The Germans looked puzzled, and translators were brought in to explain. Still the Germans were puzzled, explaining that as German hospitals didn't have waiting lists, there wasn't any need.

 The foot and mouth disease is sweeping the nation, but perhaps mad cow disease has started infecting Bupa, the private health insurer. The company this week posted a "foot and mouth disease fact sheet" to its clients, including those in such rural idylls as central London. The sole item of note is the unfortunate name of an unrelated human condition called hand, foot and mouth: the Coxsackie virus.

 Tough times for Marconi, which has seen its share price do a lead turkey impression (a 70% fall in the last six months) and yesterday confirmed it would be cutting 3,000 jobs. The strain seems to be getting to its deputy chief executive, John "Hold The" Mayo. When the Guardian asked some pointed questions during a press conference, Mayo replied: "I'm a bear with a very small brain." An odd admission, to be sure. He then berated journalists for their "typically British response" to the gloomy job cuts news (1,500 in the UK alone), and tried to puff jobs that Marconi were creating - even after it was pointed out that the bulk of them had already been announced by the government when it gave £25m of aid to Marconi last year.

 As promised, the winners of our prestigious competition to help Merrill Lynch equity analysts overcome a crippling "psychological barrier" in downgrading stock recommendations to their clients. The runner-up prize - a proud achievement that carries no physical reward - goes to Tony Hall of Liverpool, for his suggestion that the brutal term "sell" should be replaced with "buy-buy" (as in bye-bye). But the champers goes to Bill Currie of HSBC, who suggests a term that implies a rapid change in fortune, and something to be gotten rid of as soon as practical: "Vaz."

Email
richard.adams@ theguardian.com

fields.headline: The show can't go on
fields.standfirst: The government's £25m handout was meant to put theatre back on its feet. It's not working out that way, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: The government's £25m handout was meant to put theatre back on its feet. It's not working out that way, says Lyn Gardner.
fields.body:
A few weeks ago the corks were popping and the champagne flowing as British theatre greeted the news of how a £25m injection of new government funding would be distributed among theatres and companies.

BAC, the south London venue, received a 236% increase in funding. Among those celebrating were Steve Hoggett, Scott Graham and Vicki Coles of the physical theatre company Frantic Assembly. But they didn't know whether to laugh or cry.

The trio were thrilled that BAC, their base, had been recognised for its work in encouraging experimental new work. But they were devastated that their own company appeared to have been passed over by the Arts Council's theatre review.

If there is any company in Britain that seems to fulfil the Arts Council's desire to support a talented new generation of artists, it is Frantic Assembly. Yet they went away empty-handed from what was billed as the biggest bonanza in British theatre. "It was the worst day of our lives," says Coles. "We didn't just feel disappointed. We felt completely isolated, as if we weren't part of British theatre. We felt further down the scale than we've ever felt."

They are not alone. Charlotte Jones of the Independent Theatre Council, an organisation that represents many small and medium-sized companies, points out that only 80 out of the 500 companies represented by the ITC benefited from the allocation of funding through the theatre review.

Many of these companies feel betrayed and upset, and many are wary of talking about what has happened for fear of sounding like whingers. Some are also concerned that speaking out will jeopardise their chances of future funding.

Others, such as Frantic and Nick Sweeting, the producer of a number of small companies including Improbable and Told By an Idiot, are rather braver. Like Frantic, Told by an Idiot was passed over in the theatre review; Improbable, which is already attracting international attention, was offered only a £50,000 national touring contract starting in 2002/3. Sweeting is still looking for clarification from the Arts Council as to what strings, if any, are attached to this money.

But all is not completely lost for companies that, after years of being told that they would be the next to get on the funding ladder, have come away from the review feeling poorer than ever. While most of the £25m has gone to the regional repertory theatres, £2m has been held back. This money will be distributed between the regional arts boards. The intention is that a limited number of companies will be invited to apply for these funds, which will be awarded as fixed-term contracts coming on tap in 2003/4.

Unfortunately, nobody thought to tell the companies about the £2m. The arts boards are now hurriedly putting in place mechanisms by which this can be distributed.

Nicola Thorold, director of drama at the Arts Council, says that we should be celebrating the fact that this money, together with that already distributed, means that independent companies will be benefiting to the tune of over £4.5m. Charlotte Jones thinks it is great too, but points out that "all of the Arts Council strategy could have been met by the small-scale companies and for very much less than £25m".

Jones has her own agenda, which places less emphasis on the role of the regional reps. But she speaks for many companies when she says how dissatisfied they are at the lack of consultation about the way the money was allocated. "The actual recipients were not involved in the strategic process. The amounts given seem arbitrary," she says.

Astonishingly, Jones says she knows companies that have been given more money than they may actually have wanted, or even know what to do with. "If they had been asked what they needed, they might have requested less. But they were never given that responsibility."

Even more worryingly, many independent companies feel that in the excitement of having secured the £25m, the Arts Council has failed to deliver the shake-up in the funding system that The Next Step, the Arts Council's response to last year's Boyden report into the state of British theatre, appeared to promise. To put it bluntly, there is more money for the same old people while many young, innovative companies still find themselves going hungry.

"This was supposed to be a watershed but companies never got a chance to bid against the dinosaurs," says Sweeting. Frantic Assembly agree: "The money may be new, but the system that allocates it hasn't changed and the beneficaries are the same old names." And, according to Jones, "The Next Stage promised that there would be losers. Our sector was expecting to see some reps close, but actually there haven't been many losers. Lots of people have been left on the outside again."

Thorold answers these criticisms by pointing out that "we do have an appraisal process and the Arts Council is committed to looking at the best use of fixed-term agreements. As funds come to an end we will review them." But this is of little comfort to those who now find themselves with little or nothing. In fact, some feel their situation is worse than it was before, as funding is now tied up for the foreseeable future. As Scott Graham of Frantic puts it: "This opportunity for change will never happen again to us or the Arts Council. We feel completely rejected."

It would be a huge irony if what had been welcomed as the start of a golden age for British theatre should result in some companies leaving the country or throwing in the towel. Improbable, Frantic Assembly and Told by an Idiot are seriously considering their futures.

 Frantic Assembly's latest show, Underworld, is at the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6, from April 23. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

fields.headline: Nepalese babies survive 103-hour operation
fields.standfirst: Astonishment in medical world as marathon separation of twins triples previous duration record
fields.trailText: A team of bleary-eyed surgeons in Singapore yesterday completed a marathon 103-hour operation to separate a pair of conjoined twin sisters who were born sharing a brain cavity.
fields.byline: John Aglionby, south-east Asia correspondent, and  Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
A team of bleary-eyed surgeons in Singapore yesterday completed a marathon 103-hour operation to separate a pair of conjoined twin sisters who were born sharing a brain cavity.

Doctors said they were "cautiously optimistic" that Ganga and Jamuna Shrestha, from Nepal, would recover but admitted it was too early to say how much permanent brain damage they might have suffered.

The girls were last night recovering - in separate rooms for the first time in their 11-month-long lives - in Singapore General Hospital's intensive care unit after more than four days on the surgeons' table.

Keith Goh, the neurosurgeon who was instrumental in bringing the twins to Singapore and who led the surgical team, said: "Happily we had no adverse events during the entire five days, so we are cautiously optimistic."

However, he tempered the euphoria yesterday afternoon by adding: "How they will survive only time will tell."

Lee Seng Teik, the leading plastic surgeon in the team of 16 doctors who worked round the clock after the girls were placed under anaesthetic at 9am on Friday, doubted that everything would go smoothly in the future.

"We expect there to be problems that we will encounter as we go along, in the medium and long term," he said.

There was some astonishment in medical circles at the length of the operation, which the Singapore surgeons said was due to the need for painstaking care in separating hundreds of tiny blood vessels which the babies' brains shared.

Neurologists had to try to identify where each tangled vessel belonged before it was irrevocably cut.

Other operations for craniopagus - as a join at the skull and brain is called - have lasted no more than 30 hours. The longest operation undertaken by the team of surgeons at Great Ormond Street hospital in London - one of the most experienced in the world at separating conjoined twins, although they have not separated fused brains - lasted just 18 hours.

The risks are increased the longer the operation lasts.

The girls, who come from Khalanga, a mountain village in Nepal, and are named after sacred rivers in India, are expected to stay in intensive care for at least two weeks, and in hospital for three months. They are still under sedation and will undergo a controlled wake-up process during the next few days.

Separation occurred at about 9am (3am in Britain) yesterday, 88 hours after the actual surgery began. It took 52 hours longer than the doctors had predicted last week.

Dr Goh said the mother, Sandhya Shrestha, her husband KC Bushan, and her father, Arjun Dev Shrestha, burst into tears when told the news.

Dr Teik's team then began covering Jamuna's gaping brain. They first covered her head with the synthetic material Goretex to replace part of the dura, a fibrous tissue layer covering the brain.

They then mixed bone material with polymer sheets to act as a base for new cells to grow. These cells are expected to become solid bone within a year.

The mixture was then covered with skin taken primarily from Jamuna's back. She was wheeled out of the operating theatre at 11.10am.

Ganga, whose head was "not [looking] as nice", according to Dr Teik, spent another five hours in surgery as the plastic surgeons completed a similar process, taking the grafted skin from her thighs.

The girls were moved from a supine to a prone position and back several times during the prolonged operation.

Claire Ang, one of the anaesthetists, said the team went through a whole gamut of emotions.

"It varied from hysterical to euphoric and involved light-headedness, frustration and mood swings - from being very emotional to not caring at all and just wanting to sleep," she said.

Most of the doctors cat-napped for a couple of hours each day but said they could not sleep properly because they were constantly thinking about the unfolding drama on the operating table.

Dr Goh said their after care would continue for years.

"Their brains are shaped like a tower," he said, using plastic models to demonstrate how the two brains were separated. "They can't go through society with a head shaped like this."

Ganga, who has a cleft palate, was much feistier and always hungry, while Jamuna was more shy.

The girls' parents and grandfather, who had broken their vigil at the hospital only to pray at a local Hindu temple and to take an occasional shower, declined to speak publicly yesterday.

But one of their uncles, Abhaya Shrestha, said from Khalanga that the whole family was delighted.

"We had only 50% hope that they would survive," Mr Shresta said. "Now this is a miracle and we just can't describe how happy we all are to hear the news."

The operation to disentangle two babies' brains was only made possible by advanced computer technology devised in Singapore, writes Sarah Boseley, health editor, but it had never been used in the country before.

Two years ago he used the imaging program to rehearse the operation on the Banda twins from Zambia, which he and his team carried out in South Africa.

Dr Carson was an adviser to the Singapore surgeons in the lengthy preparation before the separation of Ganga and Jamuna.

The imaging software combines a series of scans of the babies' brains to build a 3-D virtual model. The Singapore surgeons spent six months studying the brains and rehearsing. Wearing 3-D glasses, they manipulated the image by moving their hands, without buttons, keyboard or mouse.

"We made three scans of those poor babies, and then we let the surgeons see it and plan," researcher Luis Serra said."Ben Carson looked at the data, familiarised himself, then he and [neurosurgeon] Keith Goh talked about it."

But computers could not have fully prepared the surgeons for the complexity of their task.

fields.headline: Insects and rugs and rock'n'roll
fields.standfirst: The Barbican's new show of Iranian art is full of surprises - from giant cockroaches to a Middle Eastern Tracey Emin.  Samantha Ellis  reports
fields.trailText: The Barbican's new show of Iranian art is full of surprises - from giant cockroaches to a Middle Eastern Tracey Emin. Samantha Ellis reports.
fields.body:
Bita Fayyazi has made 2,000 ceramic cockroaches - and still they come. "They breed," the Iranian artist says, smiling. They are three times the size of any cockroach I've ever seen but creepily realistic. And Fayyazi is more than fond of them: "I'm obsessed with the creatures. I'm fascinated by them."

Before the roaches it was dogs. Inspired by seeing animals run over, she sculpted 125 dead dogs for a project called Roadkill. "I lived with the dogs, I cried over them ..." Eventually she decided to dump them, then couldn't bear to. "I thought, why should I get rid of them? They are part of my life. So I found an empty field, I dug a hole and I buried them." She filmed the burial and is now planning to make more dogs to exhibit, this time lifesize, with the film as backdrop.

All Fayyazi's work is obsessive and very personal. "The roaches are changing because I am changing," she says. "They started out like caricatures but now they are becoming more real." And when she is confronted with a real cockroach she doesn't kill it. "You know what's happened in our house?" she muses. "I don't see many roaches any more. Maybe they just became considerate towards us, like we are towards them. That's what I like to think."

Fayyazi is in London for an exhibition of Iranian contemporary art at the Barbican, a show that should bridge the gap between the Persian carpets at the V&A and shows from artists in exile such as Shirazeh Houshiary and Shirin Neshat. What is most surprising about the exhibition - at least for non-Iranians - is the prominent role played by women.

Life has clearly become easier since the ayatollahs came to power and blacklisted artists, shut galleries and outlawed the depiction of female nudity. Since Mohammad Khatami became president in 1997, the ban on female singers performing in public has been relaxed; last year Googoosh, the "queen of Persian pop", got her passport back. Unveiled Lives, the film festival accompanying this exhibition, reminds us of the fine films made recently by women directors, including two shorts by Neshat, as well as a new film by Marzieh Meshkini, whose husband, Mohsen Makhmalbaf, is one of Iran's top film-makers, and whose daughter Samira Makhmalbaf made the claustrophobic allegory The Apple when she was only 17.

But many women artists are still questioning the restrictions imposed on them. Shadi Ghadirian, at 27 the youngest artist in the show, re-creates pre-revolution Qajar-period studio portraits, posing her friends in traditional costume, sometimes veiled, sometimes with the veils lifted (a sign of protest in Qajar times), holding a ghetto blaster or a can of Pepsi. The anachronisms highlight just how strange it is that women are legally required to wear the veil today.

Incongruity also drives the work of Ghazel, a 34-year-old video artist taking part in the exhibition. She writes, directs and stars in her Me films, a series of funny, piquant vignettes in which she sunbathes, boxes and even waterskis - all while wearing her unwieldy black chador. She says she has had all the artistic freedom she wanted, but adds: "I never asked any permission. I don't know what would have happened if I had." And while she describes the veil as "the reality of life in Iran", she won't be drawn on whether she wore a chador before it became mandatory.

Perhaps this obliqueness is a function of a culture of veiling: in a country where all women are veiled, it's no surprise to find work that is hidden, codified, obscured. And while Neshat's work is deeply critical of Islam, Ghazel seems to work within its traditions, however much she may question them. "It's all about me and my paradoxes," she says. "I live my parallel life with my camera." She went to an international school, speaking English at school and Farsi at home, and "always felt like an outsider". Now she divides her time between France and Iran.

Her sense of cultural dislocation comes through most strongly in the scenes shot outside Iran. One, an ice-skating film, is a refracted reconstruction of a true story: "I won a cup and no one came to take pictures of me." In the film she takes her own pictures. It's reminiscent of Tracey Emin's Turner Prize-nominated film about a disco-dancing contest in Margate, where boys yelled "slag" at her; in the film she goes back and dances how she wants to. There's some of that wish-fulfilment in Ghazel's film too, but it's a moment of sadness, years after the sullied victory.

Perhaps most poignant are the films in which Ghazel tackles the big issues. Inevitably, revolution and war inspires many Iranian artists - not least soldier-turned-fruitseller Khosrow Hassanzadeh, whose paintings of white linen bodybags are the most haunting works in the show - but Ghazel's mode is humour. In her film People Had To Find Amazing Ways To Sneak Out (Of Our Country), she rolls herself up in a Persian carpet, then rolls off screen.

It could be a magic carpet, or the carpet Cleopatra arrived in for her secret assignation with Antony, but people did actually escape Iran hidden in carpets, so the joke is tinged with sadness. "It's the Iranian sense of humour," Ghazel says. "If a bomb goes off today, tomorrow there will be 10 jokes about it."

 Iranian Contemporary Art is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), from tomorrow until June 3. Unveiled Lives runs from May-10.

fields.headline: Dutch pass euthanasia bill
fields.standfirst: Senators end nearly 30 years of debate despite protests by Christian groups
fields.trailText: The Netherlands became the first country to legalise euthanasia last night in a move expected to encourage several other European countries to follow suit.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in The Hague,  Andrew Osborn and Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
The Netherlands became the first country to legalise euthanasia last night in a move expected to encourage several other European countries to follow suit.

As protesters gathered outside the wood-panelled chamber of the Dutch upper house of parliament, the country's 75 senators approved the bill to allow doctors to end the lives of terminally ill patients in certain highly prescribed circumstances. With one senator absent, the upper house voted by 46 to 28 to introduce the law, a result that both opponents and supporters of mercy killing had agreed was a foregone conclusion.

Parties in favour of euthanasia control 46 of the senate's 75 seats, over 90%of the Dutch population supports the bill, and the practice has been taking place informally for decades anyway.

But that did not stop opponents of the new legislation protesting against the move yesterday in a vain attempt to persuade the senators to cause an upset by blocking the bill. Christian activists sang hymns in the senate courtyard while at least 5,000 people, many of them schoolchildren, staged a silent march from the railway station to the town's picturesque Plein Square.

They listened with rapt attention as religious leaders and Calvinist politicians condemned euthanasia in Old Testament terms.

Two protesters in black Balaclavas and white laboratory coats clutched oversized syringes supporting a banner proclaiming that "euthanasia will always be murder".

One of the men, Oskar, said he was a Catholic historian and argued that the Dutch government had used a barrage of propaganda to "brainwash" the population into supporting euthanasia. He told the Guardian: "It was a propaganda war and they won. It was like Goebbels and the Nazis and that's how they brainwashed the population..

"Thou shalt not kill is an essential commandment for every society. There are so many old people in this country and they want to get rid of them. I worry about it a lot."

Pro-euthanasia activists, who have been campaigning since 1973 for legislation, were in buoyant mood last night, but they remained adamant that the debate had been a long and a fair one.

Dr Rob Jonquiere, director of the country's main pro-euthanasia lobby, said: "We've been discussing this issue for the past 25 years. It was an open debate and it is good that it took such a long time. .

"I think my life is my life. Dying is the only security I have in my life and the major ity of the Dutch population agree with me."

Only 8%of the population is fiercely opposed to euthanasia. "This is not about asking a doctor to commit a crime but about asking for help."

Once the formalities are completed - a process expected to take two weeks - doctors will be able to perform euthanasia without fear of prosecution. In the past doctors have found themselves hauled before the courts for performing the practicedespite having the full consent of the dying patient.

Under the law, euthanasia will administered only to patients who are in continuous, unbearable and incurable suffering. A second opinion will be required, the patient must be judged to be of sound mind, and their request to die must be made voluntarily, independently and persistently.

The decision to decriminalise the practice in the Netherlands could prompt many other countries to adopt similar legislation.

Deborah Annetts, of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society in Britain, said: "It is of major significance to other countries. A psychological barrier has been broken."

In Belgium a draft law is under consideration and Britain, France, Australia and Italy all have strong euthanasia movements.

The Netherlands showed the rest of Europe the way when it came to tolerating soft drugs and the commercialisation of sex and it has now taken the lead on mercy killing. But a small committed section of the Dutch population will always feel betrayed by the liberal instincts of fellow countrymen.

Senator Kars Veling, from the small Christian Union party, said last night: "I am ashamed of this as a Dutchman. I think it is a terrible mistake."
How the world legislates
Belgium A law legalising euthanasia is expected to be approved later this year.

Sweden "Suicide assistance" is a non-punishable offence. A doctor can, in extreme cases, unplug life support machines.

Denmark Terminally ill patients can decide if and when they should abandon vital treatment.

France Euthanasia is illegal but the law does not regard a doctor's considered decision to refuse life-saving medication as murder.

Britain Euthanasia is a criminal offence carrying a mandatory life prison sentence. The BMA has always opposed euthanasia, but a minority of doctors would like the law changed.

Germany Euthanasia is a highly sensitive issue. The administration of a deadly drug is regarded as murder.

America Euthanasia is outlawed, although Oregon allows medically assisted suicide where a doctor gives a patient lethal drugs but does not administer them.

Australia Northern Territory passed a law allowing euthanasia in 1996 but it was later repealed by the federal government.

China The government authorises hospitals to practise euthanasia in the terminal phase of an illness if patients formally request it.

fields.headline: Mississippi rallies to the flag
fields.trailText: A hundred and thirty six years after the civil war, just one of America's 50 states flies the emblem of the pro-slavery Confederacy on its flag. And if the opinion polls are right, Mississippi will keep it that way in Tuesday's referendum.
fields.body:
A hundred and thirty six years after the civil war, just one of America's 50 states flies the emblem of the pro-slavery Confederacy on its flag. And if the opinion polls are right, Mississippi will keep it that way in Tuesday's referendum.

An Associated Press poll found that 66% of voters in the southern state are against plans to change the flag and give Mississippi a new image.

Only 22% say they want to remove the South's civil war-era battle banner from the Mississippi flag and replace it with a ring of 20 stars, which signify Mississippi's history as the 20th state in the union.

Facing defeat, reformers have turned to Mississippi's black American voters, who make up more than a third of the state's electorate. To help mobilise black voters, campaigners have enlisted the Hollywood star Morgan Freeman, who lives in Mississippi.

Freeman rarely gets involved in political campaigns, but he is making an exception over what he says is a moral issue.

"I see the emblem as a legacy, because everywhere you see skinheads and hate groups gathered, what are they waving? They are waving that silly thing," Freeman told the newspaper Arizona Republic. "We feel like we have to mount an aggressive campaign to get voters out to vote. Otherwise people will just sort of sit and wait and see what happens."

Mississippi has become the last citadel of the Confederate flag after South Carolina and Georgia took steps recently to sideline the emblem .

South Carolina's legislature voted last year to remove the Confederate flag from the flagpole on top of the state capitol building where it had flown for nearly 70 years. In a compromise move, the flag now flies less prominently next to a civil war memorial in the grounds of the state house.

Georgia made a similar move at the start of this year, when the governor and legislators crafted a secret compromise to reduce the previously prominent Confederate emblem in the state flag to a much smaller and less dominant position in a newdesign.

Mississippi decided to leave the issue to the state's voters. But the outcome could prove a major political miscalculation by Governor Ronnie Musgrove, who desperately wants the flag to be changed.

"It's a great opportunity for our people to make a tremendous statement about who we are and how important the future is to our state," he says. "I want to remove every obstacle I can when it comes to attracting good jobs to our state, and this is a way to do it."

Under Mr Musgrove, Mississippi has fought hard to try to turn round its racist image. The governor, a Democrat who won office by the narrowest of margins in 1999, has led an aggressive campaign to promote Mississippi as a more glamourous and more urban state.

The south of Mississippi is undergoing a major economic transformation, fuelled by tourism, casinos, shipbuilding and, most recently, Nissan's decision to build a $1bn (£690m) car plant in the state. The extreme north of the state is booming, too, settled by a fast-growing population of Memphis commuters.

"You don't go to the top 10 overnight," Mr Musgrove said, adding that Mississippi is starting to show the signs of a much improved quality of life.

If the vote backs the old flag, Mississippi could face an economic boycott by the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People and other black American groups. A similar boycott in South Carolina was decisive in pushing the state to make concessions.

Business opinion has rallied behind change. The Mississippi Economic Council, the Mississippi Tourism Association, and local bankers and manufacturers groups have all weighed in behind the new flag.

The problem is that an overwhelming majority of the 61% of Mississippians who are white - and even a significant minority of blacks - seem committed to the old flag. Four out of five whites oppose change, along with nearly three out of 10 blacks.

Polls show that most opponents of change say the old flag is a symbol of civil war-era Southern heritage and pride.

In fact the Confederate emblem was not incorporated into the state flag until 1894, during a time of white backlash when states in the Deep South passed a series of racial segregation and discrimination laws that were not removed until the 1960s.

webTitle: S Africa to use blood substitute from cows

fields.headline: S Africa to use blood substitute from cows
fields.trailText: A fluid made from the blood of American cows will soon be running through the veins and arteries of patients in South Africa after the country became the first to sanction the use of non-human haemoglobin in blood transfusions.
fields.body:
A fluid made from the blood of American cows will soon be running through the veins and arteries of patients in South Africa after the country became the first to sanction the use of non-human haemoglobin in blood transfusions.

The fluid, christened Hemopure by its US makers, falls short of being artificial blood. But for a short time it can be infused into patients and pumped by the heart as a stand-in for blood's most vital function, carrying oxygen around the body.

South Africa faces a critical shortage of blood for transfusions because of the high level of HIV infection among its population, 25% of which is thought to be HIV positive.

Hemopure's makers, Biopure of Cambridge, Massachusetts, claim that the product is so intensively screened and processed - it goes through 22 stages of purification - that it cannot pass on viruses or the rogue proteins thought to be responsible for new variant CJD, the human form of BSE.

It can be given to humans of any blood type.

Donor blood has to be refrigerated and can only be stored forsix weeks, while Hemopure can be stored for two years at room temperature.

There is a risk of side effects, including stomach pain, weakness, hypertension, jaundice and nausea, but Biopure says normal blood transfusions also have the samerisks.

Hemopure has not yet been licensed in Europe or the US, where regulators await the results of clinical trials. Biopure spokesman Douglas Sales said yesterday that the South Africans had been satisfied with those trials' preliminary data.

It is not known how much the fluid will cost, although the firm said it would charge developing countries less than they would affluent countries.

Michael Thomas, the clinical director of Britain's Blood Care Foundation, said that despite Biopure's reassurances there were likely to be concerns in this country about the CJD risk, the danger of an immune reaction to cow molecules, and the potential side effects of artificial blood substitutes.

But he added that bovine haemoglobin worked better than its pure human equivalent when it came to moving oxygen around the body.

And artificial blood substitutes, he said, are likely to be adopted worldwide eventually.

webTitle: Hunger strike in Turkish jails claims 4 lives

fields.headline: Hunger strike in Turkish jails claims 4 lives
fields.trailText: The Turkish prison system was approaching another crisis last night after a leading doctors' organisation warned that it appeared inevitable that more inmates would die soon from hunger strikes.
fields.body:
The Turkish prison system was approaching another crisis last night after a leading doctors' organisation warned that it appeared inevitable that more inmates would die soon from hunger strikes.

"We are expecting news of further deaths at any moment," the Ankara Medical Association said. "There is no time to waste."

The government had called on the hunger strikers to end their protest, but three people have starved to death since Saturday - two inmates and a young woman protesting in solidarity with her imprisoned brother.

Another inmate died last month.

The hunger strikers are members of extreme leftwing groups which want to overthrow the state. Their mass protest began last October over plans to transfer prisoners from dormitory wards into new jails with smaller cells.

In an effort to break the hunger strike, Turkish security forces stormed 20 jails in December and transferred about 1,000 inmates to the new prisons. Thirty prisoners and two soldiers were killed in four days of clashes, but the enforced transfers did not end the "death fasts".

The latest victim was Gulsuman Donmez, whose brother is on hunger strike in prison. Donmez died in a house in Istanbul on Monday night after an intermittent hunger strike which lasted 147 days. Several other inmates' relatives are reported to be in a critical condition.

It is not known how many prisoners are still refusing food, or whether they are taking vitamins or any other supplements which could prolong their lives. According to official figures, about 300 inmates are taking part in the protest, but local human rights groups believe the number could be twice as high.

More than 120 people have been taken to hospital with symptoms of advanced malnutrition, including memory loss, partial paralysis, vomiting, diarrhoea, badly blurred vision and deafness.

Last week the international pressure group Human Rights Watch called on the Turkish government to take steps to bring the hunger strike to an end. It condemned the new "F-Type prisons", which it says contravene international standards.

"The isolation regime in F-type prisons is physically and psychologically damaging to prisoners and should never have been instituted in the first place," the group's spokeswoman, Holly Cartner, said.

Four F-type prisons - with cells which hold up to three people - are now in operation. Inmates are only allowed out of their cells once a week if a close family member visits.

The hunger strikers want the system to be abandoned.

The ministry of justice, however, says it is not responsible for the protest, and that there is no question of giving in to the inmates' demands.

The government insists that it had a duty to regain control of the prison system. In the old dormitory wards inmates used to run their own affairs, and indoctrinate new recruits.

With Turkey immersed in an economic crisis, the hunger strike has received little attention. But observers warn that the death toll could rise dramatically if no action is taken.

fields.headline: $16,000 tip puts recovery on menu
fields.trailText: Although the restaurant does not even rate among Manhattan's finest eateries, the couple who had arrived in the chauffeur-driven Mercedes-Benz still made short work of rattling up a bill for $9,000.
fields.body:
Although the restaurant does not even rate among Manhattan's finest eateries, the couple who had arrived in the chauffeur-driven Mercedes-Benz still made short work of rattling up a bill for $9,000.

A little steep perhaps for a drinks-assisted meal comprising simply chicken, cheese, grilled vegetables, tomatoes, aubergine and dessert.

But it was the entry of $16,101 (£11,100) in the gratuity box on the credit card slip that made it a particularly special evening at the Upper East Side eatery. And with that the much-anticipated recession was over before it had really started, at least according to Nello Balan, the owner of the restaurant on Madison Avenue, in the richest neighbourhood in the United States.

"I think things will turn around and the economy will come back again," he said after his slow trade had been transformed by the stroke of a pen held by an unnamed vice-president at a London-based brokerage house.

The tip from the 37-year-old Wall Street trader was for the matre d'htel, Lenny Lorando, whose previous biggest gratuity had been a mere $1,000.

Mr Lorando, 31, said of his windfall: "I feel very fortunate. We try to do the best and make everybody happy, and we get excited when they're pleased. But I must say, I was struck."

The rule of thumb in New York restaurants is to pay double the tax of 8.25%. Anything less is likely to elicit a sneer and a few well-chosen words from the waiter. It is not uncommon for diners to leave 25%.

The trader's $25,000 night out included a 1995 bottle of ChteauMargaux ($1,200), a 1988 Lafite Rothschild ($750), and drinks for everyone in the restaurant ($1,200). Everyone, on the night in question, included the movie star Jamie Lee Curtis. Mr Lorando said that he would keep $10,000 of the tip and divide the remaining $6,101 among the 10 colleagues on duty. "They all want to take the week off but I have to come back to work," he said.

Zagat's, the revered guide book to New York restaurants, awards Nello's 18 out of 30 for food, 16 for decor and 15 for service. This puts it in the good to very good category, just below very good to excellent, and quite a way beneath the grouping for eateries judged as near extraordinary to perfection.

"Double-park your Ferrari," says the guide. "Do the kiss-kiss darling thing - join the Euro-chic Eastsiders enjoying good northern Italian fare and primo people-watching; critics zap too much attitude, too little service and too big bills."

Zagat's idea of too big is their warning that diners can expect to pay $54 a head.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Doctor dies in Israeli assault
fields.body:
Doctor dies in Israeli assault

Israeli anti-tank missiles pounded targets in the Gaza strip yesterday, killing a Palestinian military doctor and injuring 18 others.

The army said it targeted the Palestinian naval headquarters, a military police post and a national security border post in response to mortar attacks on Jewish settlements.
AFP, Beit Lahiya

Berlusconi joins with extremists

Silvio Berlusconi's centre-right coalition has forged a pact with an extreme-right party in Sicily for the Italian general election on May 13.

The Fiamma Tricolore party is the rump of a former fascist movement.
Reuters, Rome

Car bomb rocks Croat minister

A moderate Bosnian Croat government minister, Mladen Ivankovic, blamed Croat nationalists yesterday for a car bomb attack which damaged his home.

The blast followed attacks on international and local officials as they tried last week to take over the Hercegovacka bank in Mostar, believed to be the financial lifeline of separatists.
Reuters, Mostar

Eminem is put on probation

American rap star Eminem was sentenced by a judge in Michigan to two years' probation yesterday after pleading guilty to carrying a concealed weapon. The Grammy winner was also ordered to undergo counselling and submit to drug testing.
AP, Mount Clemens

UK cooperates over Abacha

Nigerian officials said yesterday that Britain had supplied information that would allow the freezing of accounts in London of the family and associates of the late dictator Sani Abacha.

Nigeria has been concerned about British delay in freezing the accounts, which are believed to hold more than £300m, ever since a formal request was made last June.
David Pallister

Israeli changes name to Mr .com

A hi-tech worker from Tel Aviv claims to be the first man in the world to rename himself ".com".

Tomer Krrissi, 25, now known as Tomer.com, said: "The internet changed my life." The interior ministry initially said a name could not include punctuation, but lawyers for Mr .com forced a rethink.
AP
Jerusalem

webTitle: Tim Parks on his beloved Hellas Verona

fields.headline: Boys from the dike
fields.standfirst: Our man in the stands hates to say it, but Hellas Verona are heading for relegation - while their 'clean-faced' rivals look like winning promotion
fields.trailText: Tim Parks, our man in the stands hates to say it, but Hellas Verona are heading for relegation - while their 'clean-faced' rivals look like winning promotion.
fields.body:
There is another team in Verona. I hoped to get through this season and this series of articles without ever mentioning them, without even thinking of them. I never used to think of them. But the time has come to confess the truth. The glorious Hellas Verona are in danger of being overtaken, of being replaced as the town's big team.

The menace is called Chievo (pronounced Kyevo) or in the local dialect Ceo (pronounced Cheo). I hope that's clear. Chievo is a small and irretrievably nondescript suburb of 3,000 souls, "cats and dogs included", on the east side of Verona where the river Adige is dammed and divided before being allowed to cross the city. Their football club is often called la banda della diga, the boys from the dike. It hardly sounds like Champions League stuff, does it? But the amazing fact is that while Hellas look set to plunge into Serie B, tiny Chievo are on the brink of promotion to A.

Towards the end of each game at Hellas's Bentegodi stadium, a corner of the collective eye anxiously checks the big screen opposite the curva sud. A huge shout of relief goes up when Napoli crash at Bologna, a pained sigh when Brescia equalise in Florence. These teams are Hellas's direct rivals in the relegation race.

But the real groan is always reserved for our own Cinderella. Unbelievably they have done it again, the fourth away win in a row. People shake their heads. It can't be happening. With two-thirds of the season gone, Chievo are five points clear at the top of Serie B, ahead of teams of the mythical likes of Torino, Sampdoria and Genoa. Assuming they make it, they would be the first parochial club to be promoted to Serie A. And if Hellas stay up as well, Verona would become the first small town to have two teams among the 18 privileged players of il più bel campionato del mondo.

"The cupola will never let that happen," writes someone on the Hellas chat line. Cupola - dome - is the word for the collective leadership of occult power. It's mafia vocabulary. "The truth is, they want us down and Chievo up," somebody responds grimly. " Chievo vaffanculo! Only Hellas in my heart. Everything else ... an international conspiracy!"

How has this state of affairs come about? And why would anyone pull strings to substitute Hellas with Chievo? Occasionally I go down to the stadium to check out what Chievo are up to. Ever since they made it into Serie C1 in 1986, they have been allowed to share the Bentegodi with Hellas. But how strange to see the terraces almost empty! I remember one game last year with only a few hundred people dotted here and there, mainly pensioners with a chunk of parmesan and a bottle of wine in their knapsacks for a half-time picnic, their radios jammed to their ears to pick up the news of the big game that really mattered to them: Inter and Juventus. "Hey Gianni," someone shouts at a Chievo player falling over the ball. They call the players by their first names. "Hey Gianni, I could do better than that!"

" Chievo = vittorie e silenzio, " a Hellas fan mocks on the chat-line. Victories and silence. He signs himself: Il bandito. When a Chievo fan responds irate, he comes back: "Incredible, I didn't know Chievo had fans!"

But the Chievo management has played its cards astutely. They must have appreciated years ago that the gate is fast becoming an irrelevant part of an Italian club's income. All the teams in Serie B get the same big cash handout from TV via the football league. This is the money that counts. But unlike other clubs, Chievo haven't succumbed to TV's appetite for celebrity. In this sense it is an advantage not having vociferous fans clamouring for big names. While the dressing rooms of most Italian clubs are beginning to resemble airport lounges, Chievo have kept the same core team on medium low salaries for years. And finally it's paying off. They are playing good football. They're winning. All of a sudden, people are actually watching them. Five or six thousand. Far more than the population of Chievo.

"Everybody's Chievando " - Chieving - comes another ironic voice over the net. Chiave means key, chiavare, to fuck. "The mayor is Chievando, the football league are Chievando, traitors all over the world, Chievando! And they all SIT DOWN! In the mythical curva at our Bentegodi, can you believe it! They sit down, to Chievare!"

When Hellas play, no one in the central sections of the curva sud sits down. Like everything else in Italy in this election year, the Chievo phenomenon is taking on political overtones. Hence the suspicion of conspiracy. The "correct" press love Chievo. There is no racism. The team has two black players. The public doesn't even shout vaffanculo at the visiting fans and seems somewhat offended when the lads from Genoa or Turin shout fuck off at them.

"The decent side of Verona!" announce the headlines, "A lesson for Hellas". Somehow, Sunday after Sunday, as we lose and they win, it is being insinuated that Chievo are getting the points because they are nice, good people. While we are yesterday's Nazis. Now the local leftwing publisher and lobbyist Giorgio Bertani has got in on the act, starting a Chievo supporters club. "Our statute stipulates that we are a non-political group supporting ideals of non-violence, and showing friendship and respect towards all cultures and colours!"

How wearisome this rhetoric is. As if football were merely about watching 11 men kick the ball around on the field. I almost have more time for the person who wrote on the chat-line: "Hellas, you're dead. You and all your racist supporters. Ignorant pigs. Roast in hell!" There's political correctness for you.

"Only Hellas in my heart," comes the reply. "Everything else ... politics and polenta." It's the bandito again. But things are looking bad for Hellas Verona. We stand on the terraces of San Siro watching the boys go down to Inter. They put up a good show, but what can you do when the referee's against you. "Every game, 10 against 12," someone mutters. For the nth time this season we've had a player sent off. And the replays will show we were right, there was no penalty, Vieri dived. But how can that possibly help?

Years ago, when people worried about relegation, I used to think that they were really concerned about having to watch poorer football, missing out on seeing the big teams. And of course that's part of it. But now I realise that what they're really scared of is that their community will dissolve and disappear.

We're not just going down into B, someone's coming up to take our place, someone with a clean face, someone the world wants to see rather than us. The casual fans, who have no sense of pathos, will desert. Who will get on the bus and travel through the night to watch Hellas play miserable Crotone in the deepest south, when they could stay at home and see Chievo take on Juventus?

Game over, we watch the big screen. The letters run across, right to left. Chievo 0 ... Has the tide turned? Ravenna ... 0. "Well, they've only drawn." "But all the closest rivals have lost!" It's a nightmare. It's really happening. The police gather and block the exits with their riot shields. Could this be the last time we'll come to San Siro? The boys raise their ancient cry: " Hellas, solo contro tutti." Alone against the world. What pathos, what delirium.

fields.bodyText: There is another team in Verona. I hoped to get through this season and this series of articles without ever mentioning them, without even thinking of them. I never used to think of them. But the time has come to confess the truth. The glorious Hellas Verona are in danger of being overtaken, of being replaced as the town's big team. The menace is called Chievo (pronounced Kyevo) or in the local dialect Ceo (pronounced Cheo). I hope that's clear. Chievo is a small and irretrievably nondescript suburb of 3,000 souls, "cats and dogs included", on the east side of Verona where the river Adige is dammed and divided before being allowed to cross the city. Their football club is often called la banda della diga, the boys from the dike. It hardly sounds like Champions League stuff, does it? But the amazing fact is that while Hellas look set to plunge into Serie B, tiny Chievo are on the brink of promotion to A. Towards the end of each game at Hellas's Bentegodi stadium, a corner of the collective eye anxiously checks the big screen opposite the curva sud. A huge shout of relief goes up when Napoli crash at Bologna, a pained sigh when Brescia equalise in Florence. These teams are Hellas's direct rivals in the relegation race. But the real groan is always reserved for our own Cinderella. Unbelievably they have done it again, the fourth away win in a row. People shake their heads. It can't be happening. With two-thirds of the season gone, Chievo are five points clear at the top of Serie B, ahead of teams of the mythical likes of Torino, Sampdoria and Genoa. Assuming they make it, they would be the first parochial club to be promoted to Serie A. And if Hellas stay up as well, Verona would become the first small town to have two teams among the 18 privileged players of il più bel campionato del mondo. "The cupola will never let that happen," writes someone on the Hellas chat line. Cupola - dome - is the word for the collective leadership of occult power. It's mafia vocabulary. "The truth is, they want us down and Chievo up," somebody responds grimly. " Chievo vaffanculo! Only Hellas in my heart. Everything else ... an international conspiracy!" How has this state of affairs come about? And why would anyone pull strings to substitute Hellas with Chievo? Occasionally I go down to the stadium to check out what Chievo are up to. Ever since they made it into Serie C1 in 1986, they have been allowed to share the Bentegodi with Hellas. But how strange to see the terraces almost empty! I remember one game last year with only a few hundred people dotted here and there, mainly pensioners with a chunk of parmesan and a bottle of wine in their knapsacks for a half-time picnic, their radios jammed to their ears to pick up the news of the big game that really mattered to them: Inter and Juventus. "Hey Gianni," someone shouts at a Chievo player falling over the ball. They call the players by their first names. "Hey Gianni, I could do better than that!" " Chievo = vittorie e silenzio, " a Hellas fan mocks on the chat-line. Victories and silence. He signs himself: Il bandito. When a Chievo fan responds irate, he comes back: "Incredible, I didn't know Chievo had fans!" But the Chievo management has played its cards astutely. They must have appreciated years ago that the gate is fast becoming an irrelevant part of an Italian club's income. All the teams in Serie B get the same big cash handout from TV via the football league. This is the money that counts. But unlike other clubs, Chievo haven't succumbed to TV's appetite for celebrity. In this sense it is an advantage not having vociferous fans clamouring for big names. While the dressing rooms of most Italian clubs are beginning to resemble airport lounges, Chievo have kept the same core team on medium low salaries for years. And finally it's paying off. They are playing good football. They're winning. All of a sudden, people are actually watching them. Five or six thousand. Far more than the population of Chievo. "Everybody's Chievando " - Chieving - comes another ironic voice over the net. Chiave means key, chiavare, to fuck. "The mayor is Chievando, the football league are Chievando, traitors all over the world, Chievando! And they all SIT DOWN! In the mythical curva at our Bentegodi, can you believe it! They sit down, to Chievare!" When Hellas play, no one in the central sections of the curva sud sits down. Like everything else in Italy in this election year, the Chievo phenomenon is taking on political overtones. Hence the suspicion of conspiracy. The "correct" press love Chievo. There is no racism. The team has two black players. The public doesn't even shout vaffanculo at the visiting fans and seems somewhat offended when the lads from Genoa or Turin shout fuck off at them. "The decent side of Verona!" announce the headlines, "A lesson for Hellas". Somehow, Sunday after Sunday, as we lose and they win, it is being insinuated that Chievo are getting the points because they are nice, good people. While we are yesterday's Nazis. Now the local leftwing publisher and lobbyist Giorgio Bertani has got in on the act, starting a Chievo supporters club. "Our statute stipulates that we are a non-political group supporting ideals of non-violence, and showing friendship and respect towards all cultures and colours!" How wearisome this rhetoric is. As if football were merely about watching 11 men kick the ball around on the field. I almost have more time for the person who wrote on the chat-line: "Hellas, you're dead. You and all your racist supporters. Ignorant pigs. Roast in hell!" There's political correctness for you. "Only Hellas in my heart," comes the reply. "Everything else ... politics and polenta." It's the bandito again. But things are looking bad for Hellas Verona. We stand on the terraces of San Siro watching the boys go down to Inter. They put up a good show, but what can you do when the referee's against you. "Every game, 10 against 12," someone mutters. For the nth time this season we've had a player sent off. And the replays will show we were right, there was no penalty, Vieri dived. But how can that possibly help? Years ago, when people worried about relegation, I used to think that they were really concerned about having to watch poorer football, missing out on seeing the big teams. And of course that's part of it. But now I realise that what they're really scared of is that their community will dissolve and disappear. We're not just going down into B, someone's coming up to take our place, someone with a clean face, someone the world wants to see rather than us. The casual fans, who have no sense of pathos, will desert. Who will get on the bus and travel through the night to watch Hellas play miserable Crotone in the deepest south, when they could stay at home and see Chievo take on Juventus? webTitle: Is Jemima Khan the new Diana?

fields.headline: Is Jemima Khan the new Diana?
fields.standfirst: If you flicked through the Sunday newspapers you'd have spotted the winsome Jemima Khan saving bears in one paper - and bemoaning the fate of Afghan refugees in another. Clever girl, says  Vicki Woods. Sophie could learn a thing or two from Pakistan's designer do-gooder
fields.trailText: If you flicked through the Sunday newspapers you'd have spotted the winsome Jemima Khan saving bears in one paper - and bemoaning the fate of Afghan refugees in another. Clever girl, says Vicki Woods. Sophie could learn a thing or two from Pakistan's designer do-gooder.
fields.body:
For a (former) head of a public relations outfit, that Sophie Wessex is pretty stupid, isn't she? She wanted to work - fine, we don't mind royalty working; better they should graft for their living like the rest of us instead of lying around on yachts all day reading Hello!. But - PR? What a cackhanded option. What was she thinking of - galumphing about in a business suit and chatting up clients, when she could have been wafting around in flowing robes as a Little Friend to all the World?

Mother Teresa and Princess Diana have been dead for nearly four years now - and where is their replacement for the wretched of the earth? For the halt and the lame? For the stricken and afflicted? Charity, charity, charity, Sophie! It's the primrose path to sainthood - secular or spiritual. There was such a gap in the market - why didn't you see it?

Too late now, missy. Jemima Khan's nipped in and filled it. Three pages in the Mail on Sunday: Jemima in Islamabad, desperately trying to rescue baby bear cubs from being baited with dogs in the ring. Three pages in the Sunday Telegraph: Jemima Khan on the Afghan border, singlehandedly providing 80,000 Jalozai refugees with tents and latrines. And even filing the copy herself afterwards. ("Look, even the foreigner cries for us!")

All this and a lifetime's devotion to cancer patients as well, at her hubby's cancer hospital in Lahore. The girl's a marvel. She's a Goldsmith heiress, for heaven's sake. And fabulously good-looking. Automatic upgrades, Tatler covers, dinner at the Ivy, super-A-list invites. We thought she'd lie around on divans all day being pampered like a houri after she married sexy old Imran, didn't we? Wrong, wrong. Jemima's a global friend to the friendless and her heart is bigger than an Oxfam truck.

So beyond fabulous for large-scale disaster wear, that salwar kameez, isn't it? Better than your actual Albanian nun's outfit. Clever Jemima! Women on the edge of a third world breakdown have hard wardrobe choices. Refugee camps, battle zones, bear-baiting pits on the outskirts of Islamabad - these are all very tricky photo-ops. You look ludicrously out-of-place in a power jacket and heels (Madeleine Albright, Clare Short) and barking mad, frankly, in the Woman Warrior option (Margaret Thatcher, Falklands tank, borrowed fatigues).

But the salwar kameez is perfect. The innate non-sexual modesty of the neck-to-ankle coverage says: "Forget I'm a woman, I'm only here to work," while the iconic femininity of that trailing veiling breathes, "But I'm gorgeous." Divine! It's got all the resonance of a nurse's uniform. I mean your Farewell to Arms/first world war nurses in capes and long pinnies, obviously, not those tetchy women from ER in polyester coveralls.

Even her little feet are fashionable: in tiny, sexy little strappy sandals, as worn in the schmutter capitals of the world (New York, Paris, London, Milan and - now - Islamabad). Who can forget Jemima strolling around Imran's cancer hospital in Lahore, deep in conversation with our royal Lady of the Sorrows? Both women tall, slender and fabulously photogenic; both dressed in salwar kameez with their silken dapattas floating around their glorious hair. Jemima's jim-jams (she designs them herself - is there no end to this girl's talents?) are on the restrained Calvin/Armani/Helmut Lang side of the fashion spectrum (white, cream, tan, vanilla, beige).

Jemima was very lucky with her choice of Muslim. If she'd married a Kuwaiti, she'd have had to battle with that horse's-bit contraption I keep seeing in Harvey Nicks. Not a great look. But the dappata - a 5ft-long,3ft-wide, loose veil made of translucent silk - is a very happy Pakistani compromise between Muslim modesty and sexy femininity.

It's forever sliding off, and you have to keep fiddling with it, like a Victorian deb with a fan. Watch Benazir Bhutto facing off tricky questions about governmental chicanery from some aggressive bloke. Fiddle-fiddle, waft-waft, drape-drape. The voice comes out as truculent and defensive as a Maff spokesman's on Newsnight, but the body-language says: "Ooh, kiss me once, kiss me twice, treat me nice."

And speaking of Benazir - Imran Khan's longtime enemy - what's happened to his own political aspirations? He once hoped to lead his nation himself, as he famously led it on the cricket field, but failed. Last time Pakistan had free elections (before the current military-dictatorship arrangement) Jemima accompanied him on the stump, practising her newly-acquired Hindi, as he took on both Benazir and Nawaz Sharif in a two-pronged attempt to find a woolly-headed Third Way. When the results came in, he told Jemima it was "a wipeout". How fabulous Immie!, she cried, and he had to tell her a wipeout meant NO seats, not all the seats.

Not to worry, Jemima. Politics, public relations - these are grubby places for a queen of all our hearts. Saving bears, rescuing refugees, curing cancer - that's how you'll win your place in heaven. There are few options open in public life for a woman of style, substance and staggering beauty - and the greatest of these is charity, charity, charity. Makes fabulous pictures, too.
