fields.headline: No 1856
fields.standfirst: Jedi
fields.trailText: Jedi.
fields.body:
Would this have something to do with science fiction? "The Force is what gives a Jedi his power. It's an energy field created by all living things. It surrounds us and penetrates us. It binds the galaxy together."

Excuse me? "Don't underestimate the Force!"

No of course not. But do you mind telling me what this is about? "A Jedi's strength flows from the Force. But beware of the dark side!"

Not Mandelson? "If once you start down the dark path, forever it will dominate your destiny."

Oh do shut up. There's a new Star Wars film, right? Wrong actually. Jedi is no longer just cinematic fiction, it's a new religion.

Are you sure? Well, it isn't one yet, but it may become one.

Go on. There's an email going around encouraging people to fill in their religion as Jedi on the census which will soon be dropping through your letter box.

Why? "Do it because you love Star Wars. If not then just do it to annoy people." That's what it says on the email.

Who's behind it? No one knows, but they reckon that if 10,000 people put Jedi down, then the government will have to recognise it as a legal religion.

Where did it all start? In New Zealand apparently. Then it spread to Australia which has its census this summer. Unfortunately the Australian Bureau of Statistics has warned anyone putting Jedi in their census return in the summer will be fined $500.

Sounds like religious persecution to me. Is the census on May 4? No. Why?

Because then the "Do say" bit could be: May the fourth be with you. It isn't though, but I've got another one.

Go on then. Do say: May the farce be with you.

Very good. Thank you.

fields.headline: Under the rainbow
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge.
fields.body:
April came with showers, many of them so tightly strung together that it has rained solidly ever since. However, one of these days was a classic. After a short, sweet shower, I came back down the steep lane and ran straight into a rainbow.

From above, the arch seemed like the outer surface of a dome, with mostly blue and green bands of light. Once inside it, trees on the hill to the north were dark silhouettes against the coloured arc and the light underneath was golden. The dome of light covered a diameter of about a quarter of a mile across a wooded plateau. Even after passing through it, the rainbow could still be seen for 5 minutes before fading away as the dark clouds above drifted off.

The evening light after the rain was crystal-clear, and even the far hills, lost in the murk for weeks, were now etched sharply against the sky. Looking out to the west, I thought I could see floodwater, but it was smoke. On flat land in the Severn Valley towards Shrewsbury, a white plume spread northwards from a long narrow fire: a beast burning. Apparently some animals may have come from Welshpool market, so they and every other sheep or pig they came into contact with had been slaughtered and were now on fire. This is getting bloody sick. The footpaths are closed and healthy animals are being burned.

Then the most magnificent sunset began to form. Washes of silver-blue and gold light shot with scarlet spread across the sky with weird, indigo, eyebrow-shaped clouds. Shots rang out sickeningly. The Edge acts as a huge natural amphitheatre and it is impossible to pinpoint where the shots were coming from, but they sounded like rifle fire.

webTitle: Fergie pulls in millions and haunts royal family

fields.headline: Fergie pulls in millions and haunts royal family
fields.standfirst:
Heavyweight references to former status are beyond palace control

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The World Trade Centre in lower Manhattan could barely be further removed from the home counties, but Sarah Ferguson is very much at ease signing copies of her books there. Her chatty, open style dovetails neatly too with the demands of American television.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison in New York and Stephen Bates
fields.body:
The World Trade Centre in lower Manhattan could barely be further removed from the home counties, but Sarah Ferguson is very much at ease signing copies of her books there. Her chatty, open style dovetails neatly too with the demands of American television: interviews on the flagship ABC or CBS network morning shows; standing in occasionally as a guest presenter on CNN's Larry King Live; delivering the odd dispatch as a special correspondent for NBC's Today programme; or fronting advertisements for Weight Watchers, Wedgwood china or Charles Schwab, the stockbroking firm based in California.

All this is viewed with a certain sharp intake of breath from Buckingham Palace, where she has been almost persona non grata since her divorce from Prince Andrew in 1996.

Whatever she does to earn money - and the evidence is that she has been rather more successful than most others - she is no longer a member of the royal family and so her activities will not come under the review being carried out by the lord chamberlain at the palace.

"She is a separate, independent, ordinary person," an official said yesterday. The Duke of Edinburgh, her former father-in-law, is said to march out of the room when she appears, though she does occasionally take her daughters to tea with Granny Number One.

There is no question that Ms Ferguson has traded on her royal links, particularly in America, to pay off the £4m debts that she ran up. The Americans have ceaselessly played up her former status and public sympathy there for the way she is perceived to have been treated.

Every time she remarks on her treatment - spending every Christmas at a house on the Sandringham estate while her daughters are invited up to the big house to see the family - the royals fume but can do nothing. She has comprehensively beaten the code of silence.

Last year, British tax inspectors were called in to check on her finances in Britain with a team of three poring over her £100,000 a year wages bill for four staff.

But there is nothing that the royal family can do to curb her activities in the US, which now include lobbying in Washington, two weeks ago attempting to win support for federal insurance cover to include weight loss initiatives and on behalf of the American Heart Association.

Her appearance in Washington con-firmed her position on the concerned celebrity circuit. Around the same time, the revolving doors of Capitol Hill were absorbing and disgorging the grizzled David Crosby, of Crosby, Stills and Nash, there to speak up for campaign finance reform; David Hyde Pierce, of Frasier (more funds for Alzheimer's disease research); Don Henley, of the Eagles, and Alanis Morissette (online entertainment hearings); and Backstreet Boy Kevin Richardson (colorectal cancer awareness).

And she had some success. "I thought she was remarkably trim for a spokeswoman for Weight Watchers," said Democrat senator Bob Toricelli, once the beau of Bianca Jagger. "Either she didn't need the product or it works very well."

Another senator said he had signed up with Weight Watchers. He was only joking but the 41-year-old duchess said: "They have all opened their doors and they are really interested in the epidemic of obesity in this country."

At one appearance promoting her fourth book for Weight Watchers - Reinventing Yourself with the Duchess of York; Inspiring Stories and Strategies for Changing Your Weight and Your Life - a woman shouted: "Thanks for being so real."

Weight Watchers pays her more than $1.7m (£1.2m) a year to be a spokeswoman and example of how 50lb can be shed by following the rules. She receives another $750,000 (£519,000) from Wedgwood, for whom she has had a hand in some designs. Her latest piece of advocacy is the Schwab advertisement, which is shown only in the US and might be construed as a little cheeky on British television - for which she is apparently paid £400,000 over two years.

In this advertisement, she is talking to a putative bride for a prince about the importance of understanding how money works. "Of course," she tells the little girl, "if it doesn't work out you'll need to understand the difference between a p/e ratio and a dividend yield, a growth versus a value strategy."

The duchess, who went to work with Weight Watchers four years ago, concedes that she is not quite on top of that one herself. In any case, she says, the advertisement is not just a commercial exercise: "It's deeper than that. It's saying 'when all else fails, don't give up'."

Doubtless, she is helped by her credo: "Be true to yourself." But what helped more was the support of two men: Sir Tony O'Reilly, owner of the Independent newspaper, and Howard Rubenstein, the New York public relations man whose speciality is remodelling profiles for troubled celebrities. "He's like my uncle, my samurai uncle," says the duchess.

Rupert Murdoch, Naomi Campbell, the developer Donald Trump, the much-married Revlon magnate Ronald Perelman, the song-writer Denise Rich - former wife of the fugitive tax fraudster Marc Rich - and George Steinbrenner, owner of the Yankees baseball club, have all had their images refracted through the Rubenstein prism. Sir Tony is chairman of Waterford Wedgwood and was still chairman of Heinz, then owners of Weight Watchers, when the duchess was taken on. "I wanted to contemporise Weight Watchers," he says. "Weight Watchers was about steelworkers' wives from Ohio and, while I've got nothing against them, it's not the image you want. What better way to contemporise Weight Watchers than someone who is English and chic? Somebody who has come back and made a new life for herself."

The duchess has evidently taken to this new life. She talks of having lunch with "the guys". Tiger Woods's mother became his "mom" when she interviewed the golfer as guest host of Larry King Live and a report for NBC about an American patron of the arts in the Czech republic was introduced as being by "our" Sarah Ferguson.

On top of the cash there is an endorsement from an unlikely source for the creator of Budgie the Little Helicopter, which ran as a cartoon on cable TV in the US. Elaine Showalter, a Princeton professor and author of Inventing Herself: Claiming a Feminist Intellectual Heritage, says the duchess should be regarded as a feminist icon - though a link with Monica Lewinsky might be less than welcome.

"Both have had scandalous failed relationships with men in positions of power," says Prof Showalter. "Both have been spokeswomen for diet centres. It's empowering and inspiring to see this much-mocked duo speak up, strike back and convert mistakes into lessons instead of hiding away in shame or going into a nunnery."

fields.headline: The long goodbye
fields.trailText: Positive Women | Sperm Donor Dads
fields.body:
Telling the stories of Nicki, Sarah and Emma, Positive Women (BBC2) was an extraordinarily powerful piece of television. It was one of those documentaries - well-made, unsentimental, deeply moving - that makes you think, "Ooh, I'm proud to pay my licence fee."

As the three women told of how they contracted HIV, discovered their status, and learned to live with the virus and the responsibilities and difficulties it presents, Positive Women was exceptionally poignant, sometimes sombre but also oddly uplifting, demonstrating, as it did, the strength of the human spirit. Because of this, it was humbling too. The three women proved to be enormously courageous, not simply by virtue of their participation - no mean feat in this super-tolerant country of ours - but because they seem incredibly sorted and, well, alive really.

As horribly clichéd as it may be, that the three laughed so much (Emma had even bought herself a flat pack coffin which she was currently using as a window seat/record box) but weren't afraid to confess their fears to the camera made the documentary very powerful indeed. To see such genuine, heartfelt emotion so coolly displayed - by Nicki, Emma and Sarah as well as their nearest and dearest - is quite a rarity. As an audience, we were incredibly lucky to be privy to that, particularly as Positive Women had not a trace of syrupy mawkishness. Instead, here was a heartfelt, mature, not to mention teary, 50 minutes of TV.

When Russell the sperm donor remarked on the unsuitable-for-television nature of the reading material which aided him in making a deposit at the sperm bank, he was perhaps unaware that Sperm Donor Dads was being made for Channel 5. "You probably won't want to look at these", he said quickly of the (well-thumbed) porn mags provided by the clinic to hurry him on his way.

Now, had Sperm Donor Dads been a normal Channel 5 programme, at this point there probably would have been a jumpcut to some pole dancers or to a woman with unfeasibly large breasts in a candy-pink bikini, but lo, there were no poles nor breast-filled bikinis. To be fair, its tabloid - and slightly unsuitable - title aside, Sperm Donor Dads was mercifully unsensational.

To show its sensible credentials, it kicked off with some Hard Facts. There are some 50,000 people in the UK who were created through artificial insemination with anonymously donated sperm - and a further 1,500 are added to that number every day. Remarkably, up to 80 per cent of these people are unaware of their status. Actually, Sperm Donor Dads wasn't really about the dads at all, if sperm donors can even be counted as dads, which I don't think they can.

Indeed, Russell was the only sperm donor featured, and his contribution - an explanation of the mechanics of sperm donation with only the hint of a bashful smile ("Then you adjourn to masturbate...") - wasn't half as important as those of other interviewees. That said, it would have been interesting to know more about his motives.

Contributions from a psychologist and a no-nonsense clinician called Susan, who has handled more sperm than Annabel Chong, were similarly worthwhile, though it was the people who were the product of anonymous sperm donation that had the most engaging stories to tell.

Given that they had no right to their biological fathers' details, frustration and bitterness were understandable, though some dealt with their situation better than others. One seemed quite angry that the only thing she knew about her father was that "he was able to masturbate to order", while another - who as a youth had imagined his father to be Prince Philip or Dirk Bogarde - had regarded his circumstances as a challenge and taken up his own investigations.

If Sperm Donor Dads had any shortcomings, they were that there wasn't nearly enough background on those involved so we could understand these differing reactions. Nor was there enough discussion of how important knowing one's biological parents really is. The search for one's origins is one of humanity's archetypal stories - "from Oedipus to Star Wars" as an interviewee said - but family is surely something more than an accident of biology. Blood is not always thicker than water.

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: The spirit is willing but the flesh is tasty
fields.trailText: The spirit is willing but the flesh is tasty.
fields.body:
I stopped eating meat a few weeks ago. All those burning animals, and the crocodile tears. It was the hypocrisy, operating at every level of the food industry - and most crucially at my level, the level of the consumer - which did the trick. Oh, and the piteous baa-ing of baa-lambs. The older I get, the more piteous they become. I know, it's meant to be the other way around.

So, no more meat, probably. In all truth, I've been a vegetarian for 20 years, except at mealtimes. At mealtimes, the resolve always somehow slipped, the alternatives to meat being too awful to contemplate. They're still pretty awful, frankly.

And there are other, associated, problems.

At university, a friend of mine ate, in the end, nothing at all. Every item of food was rejected for some ethical reason. Slightly masochistic in his other lifestyle choices - member of the SWP, supporter of Port Vale - he took the ethical thing to its logical conclusion. Restricted to a diet of hideous, flatulent pulses, he would later discover that they'd been grown as a profitable sideline by Guatemalan death squads. Off the approved list they'd go. Along with the steamed legumes produced by female slave labour for huge agro-chemical concerns whose bosses all support Stoke City. My mate learned a useful lesson: no food is entirely "ethical", no matter how disgusting it tastes.

So, he ate nothing. I assume that, by now, he's very, very hungry indeed, or dead. Which would be a shame, because he was a nice chap.

An opinion poll for the Today programme showed that one third of vegetarians have become so very recently, which suggests to me that there are a lot of people out there experiencing the same desperate mid-life crisis of pious self-flagellation. There certainly seem to be a few more vegetarians working in this office than there were, say, five years ago. And I suspect that rather than it being a direct response to BSE or foot and mouth, it's a complex, cumulative process which has as much to do with politics and even fashion as either of those other diseases.

Meanwhile, I need a structured regime to get me through. The Jewish dietary laws, for example. I understand that these strict rules can be relaxed, in certain extenuating circumstances. This is an excellent, common sense principle which I will be following. A "threat to life" is usually what's meant by extenuating circumstances, but let's not split hairs. Down the Red Lion last Sunday lunchtime, the veggie section of the menu board was obscured by a tall man in a hat. So I was forced to choose the roast beef. I wasn't happy about it, but there you are. Sometimes the real world intrudes and one needs to adapt.

 Rod Liddle is the editor of Radio 4's Today programme.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Life is Beautiful | Leaving Las Vegas | La Haine
fields.body:
Films

Life Is Beautiful
(Roberto Benigni, 1997)
8pm, FilmFour

Can you make a joke of the Holocaust? Benigni thinks so, and his effort met with both critical ire and Oscars for best foreign language film, best actor and best music. He starts with a light pastoral romance as his Guido woos and weds the haughty Dora (Nicoletta Braschi); it then elides into the horror of the camps, always leavened, though, by Guido, who protects his son by presenting it all as a big, daft game. It's a noble, deeply humanistic film, even if the end result is slightly awkward.

Leaving Las Vegas
(Mike Figgis, 1995)
9pm, The Studio

Brit director Figgis paints a black portrait of Vegas, for all its neon glare. Oscar-winning Nicolas Cage is Ben, the sacked scriptwriter intent on drinking himself into oblivion: this is The Lost Weekend with a vengeance. And while Elizabeth Shue as the hooker sharing his final binge is at times dangerously close to being the tart with a heart, she avoids being wholly overshadowed by Cage's performance. A powerful, gruelling picture of self-destruction.

Mickey Blue Eyes
(Kelly Makin, 1999)
10pm, Sky Premier

Hugh Grant's posh English auctioneer gets married to the mob in this undemanding comedy: when he proposes to Gina (Jeanne Tripplehorn), he soon learns that her family are actually Family. He hires The Godfather videos, but called on to impersonate Chicago mobster Mickey Blue Eyes , he's a predictable disaster. It's never more than a gentle entertainment, though James Caan as Gina's mafioso dad, Frank Vitale, exudes charm - plus a little Corleone menace.

La Haine
(Mathieu Kassovitz, 1995)
11pm, The Studio

An angry picture of inner-city hatred, Kassovitz's second feature explodes on the screen with incendiary force. It sounds like a story straight out of LA, but is set in a poor section of Paris, where black boxer Hubert Kounde, Jewish skinhead Vincent Cassel and North African youth Said Taghmaoui weigh a stolen gun in their hands and work up to violent reprisal against the oppressive police. The air of menace and imminent violence is palpable.

The Rat Pack
(Rob Cohen, 1998)
11.55pm, Sky Premier

The booze, the broads, the mobsters, the president_ it's all wrapped up here in Cohen's account of Frank Sinatra and his famous band of cronies. No great dramatic tension, but it swings along with smooth impersonations by Ray Liotta as Sinatra, Joe Mantegna as Dean Martin and Don Cheadle as Sammy Davis Jr, the black, Jewish butt of their jokes. And yet Sinatra comes out pretty clean, the kid from Hoboken enthralled by JFK, standing up for Sammy against racism, and when all else fails, possessor of the voice of the century.

Sports

Live Football
7pm, Sky Sports 1

Fulham will almost certainly win the league, no matter what the outcome is tonight, but Blackburn still have plenty to fight for as they bid to secure the second promotion berth. But whatever Bolton, in third, do, this fixture will almost certainly be played in the Premiership next season.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Psychology Of Fame | The Reith Lectures 2001 | High Resolution
fields.body:
Dr Raj Persaud discovers in his new inquiry into The Psychology Of Fame (11.0am, Radio 4) that renown rarely comes unaided. As Professor Leo Brodie sardonically observes, history's first great hero didn't rely on deeds alone. Alexander the Great took a flock of historians, sculptors and artists to ensure that the world had a full and favourable account of his conquests. The problem for modern celebrities is that fame has been democratised. That, of course, means that the level of public esteem has diminished proportionately.

In the second of The Reith Lectures 2001 (8.0pm, Radio 4) Professor Tom Kirkwood tries to damp down some of the wilder speculation about the implications of decoding the human genome. It is highly unlikely, he explains, that any adults still have a single cell which holds the same DNA sequence as the fertilised egg from which they started. These inevitable changes in our DNA are the process we call ageing. No one is ever going to discover, still less to modify, a specific "ageing gene".

A few years ago a Russian cat was reported to have travelled 2,000 miles to find its way home. In High Resolution (9.0pm, Radio 4) Adam Hart-Davis investigates the extraordinary ability of animals to navigate accurately over huge distances. Bees and trout, among others, are equipped to sense the earth's magnetic field, while migratory birds often rely on the angle of the sun.

A few years ago a Russian cat was reported to have travelled 2,000 miles to find its way home. In High Resolution (9.0pm, Radio 4) Adam Hart-Davis investigates the extraordinary ability of animals to navigate accurately over huge distances. Bees and trout, among others, are equipped to sense the earth's magnetic field, while migratory birds often rely on the angle of the sun.

fields.headline: Milton Batiste
fields.standfirst: Jazz trumpeter with endless energy and charisma
fields.trailText: Jazz trumpeter with endless energy and charisma.
fields.body:
Known for his flamboyant style and high-note attack, the trumpeter Milton "Bat" Batiste, who has died aged 66, was a journeyman rhythm and blues musician before joining Harold Dejan's reformed Olympia Brass Band in 1963. The original New Orleans-based band had been formed in the 1880s, and Dejan organised the revived outfit in 1960.

Batiste gradually took over as the band's "manager, go- getter, cashier, hustler, and every damn thing else". Having learned the traditional repertoire, he became the Olympia's most prominent and extrovert soloist and its deputy leader. He usually played the trumpet one-handed, using the other to bang on a tambourine.

One of 12 children, Batiste was born and brought up in the creole section of Crescent City. Enthused by the brass bands that marched for community funerals, and by Louis Jordan's blues numbers heard on a nearby bar-room jukebox, Batiste began playing the trumpet at high school.

After forming a local band, Batiste joined the Shuffling Hungarians, the backing band of the eccentric blues pianist Professor Longhair (Henry Roeland Byrd). "I was," he recalled, "one of the original Hungarians." Longhair and his musicians, mostly non-readers, were confined to the city's seedier black clubs, while literate musicians played the better venues.

Batiste's trumpet work may have lacked finesse, but his charismatic bandstand manner brought him engagements with a great variety of acts on the African-American "chitlin circuit" - including Little Richard's backing band, although he decamped when asked by Richard to wear lipstick and rouge. Criss-crossing the south, he worked with R&B artists such as Eddie Bo, Clarence "Frogman" Henry, Smiley Lewis and Big Joe Turner, and recorded with Champion Jack Dupree.

Back in New Orleans and leading his own Town Toppers, Batiste joined the George Williams brass band for 12 hours of marching on a Mardi Gras parade. "I stayed in bed for two days - I had never done anything like that before," he said.

Then came the Olympia. With the emergence of New Orleans as an international tourist venue, the Olympia played the Newport, North Sea and Ascona jazz festivals, and added European, African and Chinese tours to their jazz funeral schedule. Their 1967 British visit included a recording on the steps of St Paul's Cathedral. Batiste was soon a well travelled man; he also toured as a soloist.

Batiste formed the Young Olympians, encouraging funk-oriented youngsters towards the parade format. He started Dubat Records to record new bands. He played regularly at Preservation Hall in a smaller, sit-down version of the Olympia, his lead work always hot, if erratic at times. Sidelined by diabetes and heart trouble a year ago, he is survived by his wife, Ruth, and two children.

 Milton "Bat" Batiste Jr, musician, born September 5 1934; died March 29 2001.

fields.headline: Graziella Sciutti
fields.standfirst: Engaging opera singer turned director
fields.trailText: Engaging opera singer turned director.
fields.body:
Graziella Sciutti, who has died at her home in Geneva at the age of 73, was one of the most delightful sopranos of the postwar era. She first made her name at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in the early 1950s, and enhanced it with her work at the Piccola Scala, Milan, and in Britain, at both Glyndebourne and Covent Garden. She also became a favourite at the Vienna State Opera, the Salzburg festival and the Metropolitan Opera, New York.

Her métier consisted of roles calling for a vivacious stage personality, which she had in abundance, and a gift for soubrette characterisations. Her voice, though never large, was unerringly projected into the furthermost point of a theatre, so that she used her small resources to create an effect far beyond their size.

Born in Turin, she studied in Rome at the Accademia di Santa Cecilia. While still a student, she sang the soprano part in Bach's St Matthew Passion under Karajan in Rome. Gabriel Dussurget, founder and for years leading light of the Aix Festival, spotted her talent and cast her in the one-woman opera, Menotti's The Telephone, quite a feat for a young, immature singer. That was in 1951, when she also undertook Carolina in Cimarosa's Il Matrimonio Segreto. In succeeding years at Aix, she won her Mozartian spurs singing Susanna, Despina and Zerlina, and in 1954 she created the title role in Sauget's Les Caprices de Marianne there.

In the same year, Glyndebourne had its first encounter with the young Italian, as a pert Rosina in Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia. She followed that with an enchanting Nannetta in Verdi's Falstaff and as Susanna in 1958, both classic Glyndebourne stagings, and as Despina in 1959. She returned in 1970 as a witty Fiorilla in Rossini's Il Turco in Italia, and made a final appearance as late as 1977 as a deeply affecting Elle in Poulenc's one-hander La Voix Humaine, harbinger of her second career, since she directed it herself.

Among the conductors with whom she particularly enjoyed working were Vittorio Gui and Carlo Maria Giulini. A period working in Rome on Figaro with Giulini and the director Luchino Visconti was one she remembered with special pleasure.

Another feature of the early part of her career was a period in Paris working with Sacha Guitry on his and Hahn's hybrid work Mozart, and in the same city at the same time she appeared as Polly in Weill's The Threepenny Opera.

In 1956, she first appeared at Covent Garden, as Oscar in Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera, another part well suited to her mercurial voice and presence. She returned as Nannetta, Susanna and Despina in succeeding years.

In Italy, she sang Carolina again, to inaugurate the Piccola Scala in Milan in 1955, and either there or in La Scala itself she sang a variety of roles including Countess Adele in Rossini's Le Comte Ory. Her American debut came as late as 1961, as Susanna in San Francisco, and she then took the same role at the Met. At the Vienna State Opera she sang many of her best roles, including Nannetta in a Visconti staging of Falstaff conducted by Leonard Bernstein. Her Mozart was sought after at Salzburg, where she made a final appearance as Norina in Donizetti's Don Pasquale, under Muti in 1972.

In 1982 she returned to London, now as a recitalist, and gave a programme at the Wigmore Hall that reminded her listeners that her range stretched well beyond the works she had sung on stage.

Sciutti's voice and art are preserved on a number of recordings. She appears as Carolina in a reading of Il Matrimonino Segreto (1956), committed to disc at La Scala under Nino Sonzogno; as an engagingly quick-witted Susanna in the famous Glyndebourne recording of Figaro conducted by Gui (1958); as Zerlina in Giulini's classic 1959 set of Don Giovanni; as Marzelline in Maazel's set of Fidelio (1964); and on a disc of French song.

During the 1980s and 90s, Sciutti began to produce opera. She directed Figaro and L'Elisir d'Amore for Canadian Opera, then worked for opera companies in Germany and the US and at the summer festival of the Teatro Massimo in Palermo, where she specialised in 18th-century opera buffa. She also taught singing and interpretation at the University of Geneva.

She also worked eagerly with students. She very much enjoyed producing Figaro at the school of Chicago's Lyric Opera, and in Britain she staged Puccini's Trittico at the Britten Theatre of the Royal College of Music (where she was a staff member for some years) in 1987, then Don Giovanni, at the Royal Academy of Music's Lyons Theatre in 1993, for the Royal Schools Faculty (combining the RAM's and RCM's opera schools). In these she ably passed on her own talents as regards the importance of welding words to music in a rhythmically vital manner.

In all she achieved, Sciutti was a profound enthusiast for the art she so much loved, and to which she devoted her life. She sought perfection both in her own performance and in those of others, whether they were professionals or students. Typically Italian in personality, she enjoyed her life to the full.

In 1955, she married an American singer, Robert Wahoske; they divorced in 1960. She leaves a daughter, Susanna, and a grandson.

 Graziella Sciutti, soprano, born April 17 1927; died April 9 2001.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: A 200 hour community service order was imposed at Birmingham crown court yesterday on former detective constable Joseph Naughton, 41, who ignored an attack by one of his friends on a curry house owner while off duty.
fields.body:
Ex-policeman sentenced
A 200 hour community service order was imposed at Birmingham crown court yesterday on former detective constable Joseph Naughton, 41, who ignored an attack by one of his friends on a curry house owner while off duty. He was found guilty in March of deliberately failing to stop the assault.

Briton still held in Malaysia
Graeme Parker, 32, from East Sussex, was still being held in Malaysia yesterday after being detained on Sunday near the country's military headquarters, the Foreign Office said. He is understood to have been caught with a camera and no passport, but it is not clear what he was doing.

Electrolux criticised
Vacuum cleaner manufacturer Electrolux was yesterday criticised by the Advertising Standards Authority for claiming its products "make cleaning more hygienic and the home healthier". Electrolux was told that it must alter the wording of its brochure.

Clinton's trip to Oxford
Bill Clinton will visit Oxford University next month to open the Rothermere American Institute, a centre for study of the US. He will stay at University College, where he was a Rhodes scholar in the 1960s.

Green light for Concorde tests
Concorde's return to service after last July's fatal crash moved a step closer yesterday when French authorities gave the go-ahead for test flights with one of the supersonic aircraft.

Attack followed NF march
An Asian man was attacked and beaten by a group of up to 10 whites just hours after a National Front march in Bermondsey, south-east London, last Saturday, it emerged yesterday. Seven men and a woman have been arrested in connection with the attack, which police are treating as racist. It is not known whether the suspects were at the NF demonstration.

Explorer's polar venture
An explorer will today take his first steps on a 450-mile trek in freezing temperatures. Dave Mill, 33, from Kenmore, Perthshire, hopes to become the first man to walk solo and unaided to the north pole from the Canadian side.

Aid for blind prisoners
Blind prisoners will now be able read their rights in braille while in police custody. The City of London police force has teamed up with the Royal National Institute for the Blind in a scheme to put special copies of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act into cells.

Rail passengers 'were misled'
Central Trains "misled" customers by handing out post-Hatfield leaflets claiming normal services had resumed when they were still disrupted, the Advertising Standards Authority said yesterday.

Bird species show decline
Only six out of the 25 species which naturalists are fighting to preserve are on the way to or meeting recovery targets set 10 years ago, a new survey shows. It was compiled by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, the British Trust for Ornithology, and the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust.

New student record likely
Another record breaking year for degree applications was predicted yesterday by the universities and colleges admissions service. By late March, 373,261 people had applied for full time courses, an increase of nearly 3,000 on the same time last year.

Boy, 8, falls into canal
Hope was yesterday fading for Wayne Greaves, eight, who fell into the Aire and Calder canal at Bull Holme lock near Castleford, when playing with friends. It is thought Wayne, who was visiting his grandmother, had been swinging from a rope under a bridge.

fields.headline: Shakoor Rana
fields.standfirst: Cricket umpire who rattled the England captain
fields.trailText: Cricket umpire who rattled the England captain.
fields.body:
Pakistan's controversial Test umpire Shakoor Rana, best remembered for his finger-wagging confrontation with the England captain Mike Gatting during the second Test at Faisalabad of the 1987 series between Pakistan and England, has died of a heart attack, aged 64, while entertaining friends to dinner at his home in Lahore.

A large gathering of his family and friends attended his funeral the following day. His fellow umpires, Pakistan Cricket Board officials, members of the media and hundreds of his cricketing colleagues and admirers were also present to bid him farewell.

Tall and robust, but jovial and authoritative, Shakoor was born in the city of Amritsar in eastern Punjab. He made his first-class debut for Punjab as a medium-pace bowler and right-handed batsman in 1957, and later played for Lahore, Khairpur and Pakistan Railways, for whom he worked as a sports officer until his retirement.

However, it was not his prowess as a cricketer that got him into the limelight, but his row with the England captain during the series in Pakistan, which nearly resulted in the tour being called off.

The incident occured at the end of the second day of the second Test at the Iqbal Stadium in Faisalabad, with only three balls to go to stumps, and Pakistan tottering at 106 for 5. Gatting, it seemed, had moved the fielder David Capel from behind the batsman, Salim Malik, taking strike against the off-spinner Eddie Hemmings.

Shakoor called a no ball from the square leg position and signalled to stop play, accusing the England captain of incommoding the batsman. Gatting and Shakoor subsequently accused each other of cheating and swearing.

Play had to be stopped, and Shakoor refused to start play on the third day unless Gatting apologised. The third day's play was lost, as Gatting also demanded an apology. The England team manager, Peter Lush, drove to Lahore to make an abortive attempt to sort the matter out with the Pakistan board secretary, Ijaz Butt. Finally, the then Test and County Cricket Board (TCCB) asked the England captain to write an apology. The tour was saved and the Test resumed on the fourth day. By that time, England had lost the opportunity to force a win. Pakistan then held the tourists to a draw at Karachi to win the Test series 1-0.

Many believed that Shakoor was influenced by the then Pakistan captain, Javed Miandad, to take a firm stand against Gatting because Pakistan were in danger of losing the Test. Shakoor always denied that.

When asked if he did swear at the England captain during the row, Shakoor had replied, "I do not know much about swearing in the English language. I was repeating every word which Gatting was saying to me. I did not call the England captain a cheat."

Last year, when England toured Pakistan for the first time since the row, Shakoor made a public statement inviting the England captain to be his guest. "All is forgotten. I never had any personal grudge against him," he said.

He was quoted as saying: "I came to England a few years ago to see my son Mansoor, who was playing in the Bradford league. I saw Gatting sitting in a car. I went over because I wanted to talk to him and shake his hand. But he said, 'Oh God, not you again' and drove off."

Earlier, in the 1984-85 Test at Karachi against New Zealand, Shakoor had a row with the Kiwi captain Jeremy Coney after the umpire ignored an appeal for a catch at the wicket against Javed Miandad, and Coney led his team off in a rage before being persuaded to accept Shakoor's decision.

Shakoor had cricket in the family. His younger brothers, Shafqat Rana and Azmat Rana, played in Tests for Pakistan and another brother, Sultan, besides being a first-class cricketer, became a selector for the junior Pakistan teams. Shakoor's sons Mansoor and Maqsood also played first-class cricket. Moammar Rana, his nephew, is now a matinée idol of the Pakistani screen.

In first-class cricket Shakoor took 12 wickets at an average of 36.41, scored 226 runs at an average of 12.58 and took 11 catches. Shakoor made his Test debut as an umpire against the West Indies in Lahore in 1974. He stood in 18 Tests and 22 one-day games. After the 1987 row with Gatting, he was not given another Test until 1991 and officiated in his last Test against New Zealand at Lahore in 1997.

He is survived by his wife and sons.

 Shakoor Rana, cricketer and umpire, born 1936; died April 9 2001.

webTitle: Attacker sentenced again after victim dies

fields.headline: Attacker sentenced again after victim dies
fields.trailText: A man who served a jail sentence for assaulting a pensioner was beginning a second penalty yesterday after making legal history when he was taken back to court on a manslaughter charge following his victim's death almost four years after the attack.
fields.body:
A man who served a jail sentence for assaulting a pensioner was beginning a second penalty yesterday after making legal history when he was taken back to court on a manslaughter charge following his victim's death almost four years after the attack.

Paul Wroe became the first person to be charged over the death of a victim more than three years after the original assault. The prosecution was made possible by the abolition five years ago of the ancient legal rule that a person could not be charged with murder or manslaughter if the victim died more than a year and a day after the assault.

At least four other defendants have been prosecuted for murder or manslaughter since the rule was abolished but Wroe was the first whose prosecution needed the attorney general's consent because the death happened more than three years after the assault.

He was originally jailed for two years for battering 67-year-old Thomas Wallwork, who was left needing constant care after a blood vessel ruptured in his brain.

Mr Wallwork survived for almost four years in a permanent vegetative state, but in March 2000 the high court ruled that life support could be withdrawn and he died a few days later.

The old law was abolished in June 1996 by a private mem ber's bill backed by the crown prosecution service, which became the Law Reform (Year and a Day Rule) Act.

The act followed a campaign by Pat Gibson, whose son Michael was attacked on a night out in Darlington in 1992 and spent 16 months in a coma before he died. His attacker was charged with grievous bodily harm and sentenced to only two years in jail.

Wroe, 33, from Oldham, Greater Manchester, admitted manslaughter when he appeared at Manchester crown court last month. On Monday, he was ordered to do community service by the recorder of Manchester, Sir Rhys Davies, when he appeared for sentencing.

Imposing an 80-hour community punishment order, the judge said the "cowardly and brutal" attack on Mr Wallwork had unfortunately triggered an undiagnosed medical condition which led to a brain haemorrhage.

He said the judge who had originally jailed Wroe for two years in June 1997 had approached the case "wholly correctly".

"This therefore puts this court in an unusual situation because you now fall to be re-sentenced for the same course of action but on a different charge," the judge said.

Wroe would probably have been jailed for longer than two years had he faced a man-slaughter charge in 1997, but the judge now had to consider whether the original sentence was "excessively inadequate".

He said: "There is argument for the imposition of a further custodial sentence, but against that there is the argument of double jeopardy, and it seems to me that it is not a matter of compulsion that this defendant should be returned to custody."

The attack in July 1996 on Mr Wallwork, who lived in Ashton-under-Lyne, resulted from a minor feud with Wroe, who lived nearby at the time.

Roderick Carus QC, defending, said Wroe had been thinking about being re-charged since 1997.

webTitle: Britons find maharajah's torpedoed treasure ship

fields.headline: Britons find maharajah's torpedoed treasure ship
fields.trailText: The maharajah is believed to have chosen the mail ship in the vain hope that it would be overlooked by the German navy. But before it could reach its first stop of Port Said in Egypt, where the maharajah was to join it, the steamboat was sunk in the Mediterranean.
fields.body:
Treasures lost by a maharajah when a steamboat was sunk by a German torpedo in the first world war may soon be brought to the surface after a British couple discovered the sunken vessel.

A two year search by Alexander and Moya Crawford has finally pinpointed the missing ship. On board is believed to be a collection of gemstones and gold and silver bullion. Jagarjit Singh, maharajah of Kapurthala, lost gemstones gathered on visits to Europe and the US when a German ship torpedoed a Royal Mail steam packet vessel in 1916.

The maharajah is believed to have chosen the mail ship in the vain hope that it would be overlooked by the German navy. But before it could reach its first stop of Port Said in Egypt, where the maharajah was to join it, the steamboat was sunk in the Mediterranean. It was carrying 350 people, but only 59 passengers and 99 crew survived, and the maharajah's jewels, worth an estimated £1m at the time, were lost. Now, 85 years later, the Crawfords, from Newport-on-Tay in Fife, have located the vessel 3,000m down.

The couple's company, Deep Water Recovery and Exploration, hopes to have raised the treasures by the end of the year. It plans to use hydraulic equipment to remove decks leading to the ship's strongroom, where the bullion and chests bearing the jewels are believed to have been kept.

The potential value and condition of the treasure remain unclear. Robert Prescott, director of the Scottish Institute of Maritime Studies, said it is unlikely that gold bullion would be threatened by oxidation, but gemstones, if unprotected, would have become badly tarnished.

webTitle: World's Cleopatra artefacts on show at British Museum

fields.headline: World's Cleopatra artefacts on show at British Museum
fields.trailText: Mark Antony called her "Egypt" but she was the last of the Greek rulers of the eastern Mediterranean. Writers called her beautiful but no one knows what she looked like.
fields.body:
Mark Antony called her "Egypt" but she was the last of the Greek rulers of the eastern Mediterranean. Writers called her beautiful but no one knows what she looked like. She had a son by Julius Caesar who was killed by the man who became Augustus, first emperor of Rome. She spoke nine languages to hold on to a glittering throne and when she lost it she preferred a snake's bite to the humiliation of captivity.

The Romans smashed her statues and part of her city subsided in a series of earthquakes into its own harbour and is only now being mapped again by scuba-diving archaeologists. She stepped into myth, into painting, into the dramas of Shaw and Shakespeare and Hollywood.

Now Cleopatra of Egypt, last of the Ptolemies, is appearing again, this time at the British Museum. A new exhibition assembles statues, mosaics, paintings and jewellery from Russia, the Louvre in Paris, and museums around the world.

The display includes seven previously unrecognised images of the queen and a granite bust of her son Caesarion, fished out of Alexandria's harbour. "Basically, everybody we asked who had a Cleopatra said yes, you can borrow it," said Peter Higgs, curator of Greek and Roman antiquities. "There are still one or two that are missing that we know only from photographs but we're hoping as soon as the exhibition opens these will pop out of the woodwork and there'll be Cleopatras all over the place."

The queen ruled Egypt from Alexandria, the city founded by Alexander the Great, and surrendered it with her suicide - probably by cobra bite - in 30BC, a year after the decisive battle of Actium, and after Mark Antony had fallen on his sword.She survived in a number of small statues and on the faces of many coins struck during her reign.

She presented herself as an austere figure - a clever move, according to Dr Higgs, because her Roman enemies were offended by a woman ruling in her own right. "You can see coins from all over the eastern Mediterranean," he said. "Every time you look at them, you will see that she looks slightly different. Various people have talked lately about whether she was beautiful or whether she was ugly.

"Beauty is a word that is very difficult to talk about, but what we know from one Roman writer, Plutarch, is that it wasn't her face that attracted people, it was her great charisma, personality, and intelligence. She was the first of the Greek Ptolemaic rulers to actually bother to learn the Egyptian language.

"This was a time of political struggle, so she would have needed to appeal to different people in different ways. A very clever person learns many languages, especially when dealing with so many rulers of different nationalities."

But the powerful figure who manipulated her image in different ways gave way long after death to the creature of romance. "We have no idea what her body was like, we only know her face from how she chose to present it," said Dr Higgs.

Cleopatra influenced Roman religion. The cult of Isis dates from the conquest of Egypt, and she became a cult, with people wanting to look like her. After the renaissance, many became obsessed with her - a figure of tragedy, a power dresser, a martyr, and, later, a queen of glamour. She became the heroine of 25 films: the exhibition also shows images of Cleo the Star, as played by Claudette Colbert, Vivien Leigh, Theda Bara. "We were not allowed to present any images of Elizabeth Taylor, 20th Century Fox refused to let us."

 Cleopatra of Egypt: from history to myth, British Museum, from April 12.

webTitle: Three police forces criticised over woman's death

fields.headline: Three police forces criticised over woman's death
fields.trailText: Twelve police officers from three forces have been disciplined over the death of a woman who starved to death in a car park at a Cornish beauty spot, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Twelve police officers from three forces have been disciplined over the death of a woman who starved to death in a car park at a Cornish beauty spot, it emerged yesterday.

The reprimands followed an investigation by the police complaints authority into police handling of the disappearance of Davina Rappai, a 33-year-old computer engineer from Rugby.

Ms Rappai lived in her car in a National Trust car park at Gorran Haven, near Mevagissey, Cornwall, for at least five weeks before she was found dead in August 1998. Her parents had reported her missing in March that year. An inquest into her death last year recorded a verdict of death from natural causes due to malnutrition and mental illness.

The inquest heard that police ignored five calls from people concerned for her welfare in the 10 days before she died. Officers had been called out on previous occasions and said she had refused help. An inspector, sergeant and constable from the Devon and Cornwall force admitted neglect of duty and were reprimanded yesterday at force headquarters in Exeter. Two sergeants had previously been admonished and two constables and a civilian worker informally disciplined.

In Warwickshire, three police constables and a sergeant have been informally reprimraned for failing to include Ms Rappai's vehicle on the police national computer, not coordinating information that she was in the West Country, and not telling Devon and Cornwall police she was missing.

A Metropolitan police constable was informally disciplined earlier in the year for his part in the investigation.

fields.headline: Artwork identified at playwright's home
fields.trailText: A theatre poster which has been hanging for at least 60 years in a corner of George Bernard Shaw's dingy study at his Ayot St Lawrence home has been identified as a lost work by Aubrey Beardsley, the most famous and infamous graphic artist of his day.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A theatre poster which has been hanging for at least 60 years in a corner of George Bernard Shaw's dingy study at his Ayot St Lawrence home has been identified as a lost work by Aubrey Beardsley, the most famous and infamous graphic artist of his day.

The artwork, an original pen and ink drawing, was used for a poster for the Avenue Theatre - now the Playhouse - where Shaw's Arms and the Man had its world premiere in 1894. It is probably worth up to £30,000, although the National Trust, which owns the Hertfordshire house, Shaw's Corner, will not sell.

"It is really a very exciting discovery," said Stephen Calloway, an expert on Beardsley's work, who identified it for the trust. "Good Beardsley drawings just don't turn up any longer, it's a rare thing."

Like most of Beardsley's work, it was regarded as utterly shocking. Annie Horniman, the philanthropist who backed the theatre, said that even the London cab horses shied when they saw it. Punch dubbed the poster "Shoulders and the Woman".

Mr Calloway said the poster, "one of the most controversial ever to appear in London", was on show at the height of the furore over the decadence of Beardsley's work and "obscenity" of his drawings in The Yellow Book and for Oscar Wilde's Salome.

Shaw was an epic hoarder. Curators said the poster, hung among cheaply framed images of people the author admired, including Gandhi, had not been out of its frame since long before Shaw's death in 1950. Once it was studied closely it became clear it was not a print.

The poster was commissioned from Beardsley by Florence Farr, an actor turned promoter of contemporary work, whom Shaw loved for many years.

Shaw's play, Arms and the Man, which remains one of his most popular, drew one of the author's most famous curtain addresses to the audience after it was booed by one diehard: "He and I are of exactly the same opinion, but what can we do against a whole house who are of the contrary opinion?"

The poster will be back on the study wall when Shaw's Corner reopens to the public tomorrow.

webTitle: DNA link in hunt for Caroline's killer

fields.headline: DNA link in hunt for Caroline's killer
fields.standfirst: Breakthrough as US police hold murder suspect
fields.trailText: The prime suspect in the case of the murdered schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson, has been found to have DNA that "closely" matches that found at the scene of the crime, French officials revealed last night.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall and Paul Webster in Paris
fields.body:
The prime suspect in the case of the murdered schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson, has been found to have DNA that "closely" matches that found at the scene of the crime, French officials revealed last night.

The news meant Caroline's family faced the prospect of the five year hunt for her killer finally ending within the next 48 hours.

The breakthrough came after Miami police realised a Spanish waiter being held in their jail on a separate offence, had been named as the man French police "particularly" wanted to question in connection with the murder.

Preliminary analysis of a DNA sample from Francisco Arce Montez, aged 51, has revealed many similarities to forensic evidence found at the hostel in Pleine-Fougères, Brittany, where Caroline, aged 13, was raped and murdered during a school trip.

A second comparison is expected to be completed in France to see if there is an incontrovertible link.

Last night, Henri Bertrand, the press attaché at the French consulate in Miami, said the second test - which will not require the suspect to be taken to France - was being conducted because of differences between the French and US methods of DNA testing. "The DNA samples are close but are not the same. There are many similarities but we need to make sure," he said.

Olivier Pascal, the genetics expert at Nantes, who is expected to make the second analysis, said the proof needed by the French authorities was on its way from the US and the result was expected imminently. "The actual analysis will be done swiftly and the result will be known, at the maximum, within 48 hours," he said.

Montez, a Spanish restaurant worker and illegal immigrant, was arrested by Miami Beach police on March 13 after allegedly breaking into a woman's apartment, hiding in her wardrobe, and trying to commit a lewd act while she slept. But the connection was only made between him and Caroline after a US immigration officer on holiday in Britain read an article in the Sunday Times 10 days ago which named Montez - the man French police "particularly" wanted to trace. The immigration officer subsequently checked federal files.

Yesterday, Caroline's father John, who has seen a raft of arrests during the inquiry and who last week called for an international DNA database to help track his daughter's killer, remained cautious. "Why build your hopes up to have them dashed?" he said, from his home in Bodmin, Cornwall, before hearing about the closeness of the match. "We just have to wait and see."

Caroline was raped and murdered in her bed, alongside four other girls, in an unlocked French youth hostel in rural Brittany, on July 18 1996. Last week, a Bodmin inquest heard that two of her roommates on the school activity week had "watched in a sleepy daze", as she struggled to fight off her attacker, thinking she was having a nightmare.

At first, French detectives took DNA from about 3,500 men. They still want to question 48 others known to have been working in the area at the time. But, last month, Francis Debons, the judge leading the murder investigation, singled out Montez as the man they "particularly" wanted to trace from their suspects list. "It's his modus operandi that interests us," said a gendamerie spokesman.

Yesterday, French police sources confirmed Montez, who was working in restaurants in the Pleine-Fougères area at the time of Caroline's murder, was believed to be responsible for sexually harassing girls at youth hostels in the Brittany and Normandy.

An itinerant worker, Montez, from Zorilla, in the Asturias, was believed to have fled to Britain but has been in Miami for at least the past 18 months, and has a trespass conviction there. His more recent alleged offences, for which he is expected to be charged when he appears in court tomorrow, include two counts of burglary, and "lewd and lascivious behaviour". He is at present in Dade county jail, where he has been refused bail since, as an illegal immigrant, he could flee to avoid deportation.

webTitle: Tesco lags behind in buying British, survey claims

fields.headline: Giant lags behind in buying British, survey claims
fields.trailText: Tesco imports more of its groceries than any other leading supermarket chain, despite boasting of the local food it buys, a survey shows.
fields.body:
Tesco imports more of its groceries than any other leading supermarket chain, despite boasting of the local food it buys, a survey shows.

Researchers who visited eight Tesco stores across Britain compared a shopping basket of goods with other chains and found that Tesco shipped in 24% of its produce.

Sainsbury imported 23% and Asda 22%, according to an unpublished survey conducted for the food policy charity Sustain, and obtained by the Guardian.

The survey found that 5% of Tesco's food was produced locally and 14% regionally, while the rest was unlabelled and assumed to be produced in the UK.

Vicki Hird, policy director of Sustain, stressed that the survey was based on a small sample but said the superstore appeared to have no clear policy for reducing the distances its food travelled.

"We would like to see really clear targets for local and regional sourcing of food. There should be labelling and promotion of locally produced food and education of the consumer on buying locally.

"It is possible to do - a northern chain of supermarkets called Booths sources 25% of its produce locally."

Tesco promotes local produce with union-flag rosettes bearing the name of the item's county of origin. Leaflets encourage shoppers to buy local goods.

A spokesman said it had launched an initiative to sell more local produce three years ago after customer research showed this was what the public wanted. "We don't have targets or quotas but we are always on the lookout for suitable products. We try to buy British wherever possible."

A typical Tesco supermarket stocks around 50,000 lines of produce. Around 2,100 of these will be locally produced lines, such as Cornish strawberries, the spokesman said.

The distance food is transported has increased greatly in the past 20 years as retailers search the world for bargains.

Christian Aid, which launched the Global Supermarket campaign five years ago to mobilise consumer pressure, said the supermarkets' financial muscle gave them enormous power over developing countries.

"Supermarkets do cause problems because they drive very hard bargains in the name of delivering us cheap food," a spokesman said. "Bananas are a good example. The drive to keep prices low has caused a race to the bottom. Banana companies recently took their business out of Costa Rica and put it into Ecuador. It was bad news for Costa Rica and bad news for Ecuador - they were only doing it because the economy of Ecuador was suffering."

Food producers in Britain and abroad have been left powerless by the expansion of the supermarkets, Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University, said.

"When you have four chains intervening between the consumers and the producers, they have got immense power," he said. "The supermarkets have become a global food baronial class and farmers have been kebbabed."

Helen Lo, marketing director for the National Farmers' Union, said: "Supermarkets have a lot of buying power. The UK retailing industry is one of the most competitive in the world. We can be part of that and reap the benefits or decide we're not going to supply them - in which case where else do you go?"

fields.headline: Baby Wilfred's organs
fields.trailText: I read with concern that Dr Sebastian Lucas, Professor of Pathology at Guy's and St Thomas's hospital thinks that "the public has... shot itself in the foot again" over the "hysteria over organ retention at Brisrol and Alderhay hospital" (April 6).
fields.body:
I read with concern that Dr Sebastian Lucas, Professor of Pathology at Guy's and St Thomas's hospital thinks that "the public has... shot itself in the foot again" over the "hysteria over organ retention at Brisrol and Alderhay hospital". His letter (April 6) suggests that the medical profession has learned nothing from the inquiry.

My apparently strong, healthy baby died in 1978 in Bristol. His body was taken for a coroner's inquest. The report was inconclusive but cot death was one of the possible causes of his death. At the time we would definitely have agreed to organ retention for research had we been asked. It would have been a comfort to us to know that Wilfred's death was not completely in vain.

There was a moment of horror for us when we next saw Wilfred's body at the undertakers. His chest appeared to have caved in grotesquely. The last time we had seen him he had been very peacefully himself. Now I am waiting in some distress to find out whether this was because organs had been taken from him.

I commend the courage of the Alder Hey parents in pursuing the truth despite their personal pain, and hope that a new climate of truth, respect and openess can help to rebuild trust in the profession. I am very concerned that Dr Lucas, who seems in other ways a sympathetic man, still doesn't seem able to get the point.
Pen Godber
Llangedwyn, Oswestry

fields.headline: The word in bookshops
fields.trailText: Like Jon Harrison (Letters, April 10) I work in a book shop and meet many people. This leads me to conclude that Mary M Scott (also Letters, April 10) is wrong.
fields.body:
Like Jon Harrison (Letters, April 10) I work in a book shop and meet many people. This leads me to conclude that Mary M Scott (also Letters, April 10) is wrong: if we really want our monarch to be more "ordinary" then points should be awarded for conversations that are racist, tedious or patronising, and perhaps a bonus point if they manage to be all three at once.
Simon-Peter Trimarco
London samson9dog@hotmail.com

 So it's official, Prince Edward is not gay. That's one less for my group, Gay Men Who Don't Need To Boost Their Self-esteem By Attributing Gayness To A Bunch Of Tossers That Nobody In Their Right Mind Would Want To Have Sex With Anyway, which was launched through your columns a few weeks ago.
Paul Patrick
Burnley, Lancs PatrickPaul275@aol.com

 Us folk living on the Fylde coast don't meet many Wessex girls. Are they as rum as the ones from Essex?
Steve Little
St Annes, Lancs steve@cliftonco.co.uk

 Perhaps Trading Standards should take their minds off bananas and look at how car tyres are sold (Banana trader slips up, April 10). My car uses 185/65/15, where the 185 equals width in millimetres and the 15 equals wheel diameter in inches. Or pubs, where spirits are sold in millilitres and beer in pints.
Dannie Bonner
Stafford dannie_bonner@hotmail. co.uk

 Who is Julian Hodge trying to kid (Letters, April 10)? The individual whose job it is to carry out the delivery, or service the appliance, will still be paid a pittance.
Cynthia Rees
Purley, Surrey cynthia@rees75.freeserve. co.uk

 Tim Dowling need not be worried about the possible lack of vegetarian schnitzels once the Passover is finished as they can't be eaten during this festival anyway (Don't have a cow, April 10). Since they are coated in breadcrumbs this would rather defeat one of the objects of Passover, which is not to eat bread.
Jeff Mendlesohn
London jeffm@talk21.com

And, as I grow more decrepit with age, might my failing parts be replenished from my neighbour's obesity so that I truly can be said to "live off the fatta the land"?
Bern Geelan
Bolton berngeelan@cwcom.net

webTitle: Letters: The voters have their say

fields.headline: The voters have their say
fields.trailText: The introduction to your fascinating experiment of asking MPs what they themselves felt proudest of achieving (What have this lot actually done in the past four years?, G2, April 10) mentions the "problem of PR" and its threat to the MP/constituent relationship.
fields.body:
The introduction to your fascinating experiment of asking MPs what they themselves felt proudest of achieving (What have this lot actually done in the past four years?, G2, April 10) mentions the "problem of PR" and its threat to the MP/constituent relationship.

It is very true that the majority of MPs do a lot of good casework and have successes of which they can feel deservedly proud. But what of those constituents who are stuck with MPs who neglect their casework? One ex-MP said very publicly that he did not feel his role was to be "some kind of unpaid social worker". With a single MP who refuses to help them, constituents are at a disadvantage, especially if competing for a service with someone from a neighbouring constituency whose MP is prepared to battle for them.

The lesson from Ireland, where a system of proportional representation means that each person has a number of MPs, all chosen by voters rather than imposed by parties, is that constituents receive an even better service, because MPs are fearful that if they fail to provide good support the voter will switch allegiance.

The introduction of PR systems, so long as they are based on constituencies rather than lists, and so long as voters get to choose who represents them, is one which should ensure better service from MPs, not worse; it should not be viewed as a problem.
Alex Folkes
Electoral Reform Society Alex@reform.demon.co.uk

 A quick scan through your website at the MPs responding to your invitation reveals that only Fiona Mactaggart mentions the Asylum and Immigration Act (1999). She is rightly proud of her amendment that retains the right of appeal against deportation for people who have been here for longer than seven years.

No other MPs claim to be proud of the act. Can we expect New Labour quickly to repeal this repellent legislation? Shame on every MP who voted for it, and particular shame on the government for not immediately repealing the act of 1996. Both acts have been profoundly damaging to refugees, asylum-seekers and ethnic minority communities generally and also to our cred ibility as a human rights- respecting democracy.
Jeanette Redding
London jeanette@lredding.fsnet.co.uk

 I was not at all surprised to find that my MP, David Faber, failed to participate in your research. Before long I will receive the obligatory election newsheet telling me what a good job he's been doing and why I must vote Conservative at the next election. Politicians often talk about apathy - I'm sure many people will follow David Faber's lead and simply not bother.
John Bridges
Trowbridge, Wiltshire

 Other MPs take pride in passing legislation, helping constituents, providing tangible benefits to electors. Billy "Bandwagon" Hague takes pride in serving the self-interested desires of a palaeolithic political party. His contribution to the survey clearly betrays the Tory leadership's priorities of power before people.
Craig JL Gershater
Cambridge

 Your statement that relatively few MPs rate the environment as worth a mention is absurd. MPs like Don Foster, Alan Simpson and David Amess mentioned almost nothing but the environment and I counted around 20% of MPs referring to major environmental issues, from the Ilisu Dam, building on greenfield sites to energy conservation and flood defence.
Richard Thomas
London THOMASR@parliament.uk

 Can you please publish a list of when and where politicians will be visiting the countryside over Easter, so we all know how to avoid them?
Dr Alan Bullion
Tunbridge Wells

fields.headline: Judgments on Leeds
fields.trailText: I would like to make a point concerning your leader (April 10), with which I largely agree, on the abandonment of the Leeds trial.
fields.body:
I would like to make a point concerning your leader (April 10), with which I largely agree, on the abandonment of the Leeds trial.

At the conclusion of Friday's proceedings the jury had, I understand, been in retirement considering their verdicts for the best part of three days, at the end of a long and extremely expensive trial. The sensible thing to do at that time would have been to send them to a hotel for the weekend under supervision; and until recently, I understand, it was common in long trials for this to be done.

This practice, however, has now ceased: I believe the official reason given for ending the practice is that it is unreasonable on the jurors, but the more likely explanation is the saving of the hotel bills. In this case, those savings will have to be offset by the £8m the trial has cost.

Am I alone in thinking this sort of behaviour gives incompetence a bad name?
BJ Powell
Cambridge Barrie.Powell@ntlworld.com

While there is currently so much use of the word accountability, it does seem strange that when a newspaper publishes an article which causes a trial to be abandoned after eight weeks and just before the jury has reached a verdict, the worst punishment that the experts anticipate is a fine of, at most, 1% of the total costs of the abortive trial. Surely the probability of an editor being jailed for a few years would concentrate her/his mind wonderfully.
Sam Logan
Portstewart, Co Londonderry

webTitle: Letters: Scant evidence on proof of rape

fields.headline: Scant evidence of agreement on proof of rape
fields.trailText: In the "tests" the police are developing to establish whether or not rape allegations are false, the emphasis is on establishing claims to be false (Police test may expose false rape claims, April 7).
fields.body:
In the "tests" the police are developing to establish whether or not rape allegations are false, the emphasis is on establishing claims to be false (Police test may expose false rape claims, April 7). This treats all women reporting rape with the assumption that they are untruthful, making the process of reporting such a traumatic assault even more difficult.

Such "tests" also make the worrying assumption that all rape survivors will behave and cope with their situation in a similar manner. Treating women in such a way dehumanises the legal process even further by ignoring the individual.

In the "tests", the statement that "fabricators... will not countenance feeling blame" persecutes "strong" women who survive rape and do not blame themselves. By using this "indicator", the message being put across is that women will only be believed if they blame themselves.

The "indicator" that "those who are lying will give a bare account" does not take into consideration the ordeal of reporting a rape. Many survivors experience reporting rape as reliving the attack, and as such may not feel able to recount every detail. The knowledge that rape allegations will be assessed using such guidelines creates even more pressure for women to relate every detail, adding to the existing invasive nature of reporting rape.

Police checks of this kind are just another example of how female survivors of rape - and domestic violence - are treated with little consideration and as insignificant within the male-dominated legal process.
Jenny Ross
Leeds

 Claire Glasman's approach on the appeal against the raising of women's sexual history in rape trials (Letters, April 2) is fundamentally flawed because it pre-supposes a degree of formality in the conduct of sexual relations that simply does not exist.

Most sexual acts, especially between persons who have already been in a relationship, are as likely to be as informal in character as any human encounter one can think of. In such circumstances it must surely be quite unjust for a court to exclude the past history of the parties when determining whether or not the man believed that the woman was consenting. Indeed, a woman's relations with other partners may be equally germane to the reaching of a just verdict, where, for example, the woman is known to have a very relaxed attitude to casual relationships.

During the last quarter of a century there has been a disturbing reduction of safeguards against wrongful conviction in rape cases where consent is the issue. Corroboration is no longer looked for; restrictions have been placed on cross-examination; withdrawal of consent, however late, can still found a valid accusation; alleged victims are afforded the privilege of anonymity - something denied to the accused but also to adult witnesses in far graver cases, such as murder. It is time the trend was reversed.
John Lee
Bell Yard Chambers, London

fields.headline: Fear factor stops Preston in their tracks
fields.trailText: The Preston boss David Moyes remains hopeful of seeing his side secure a play-off position but, having now failed to win in three games following a goalless draw dominated by both defences, they are in danger of losing form at a critical stage of the season.
fields.body:
The Preston boss David Moyes remains hopeful of seeing his side secure a play-off position but, having now failed to win in three games following a goalless draw dominated by both defences, they are in danger of losing form at a critical stage of the season.

As for Huddersfield, their relegation fears will only have been eased slightly with this point, but their manager Lou Macari was pleased. "It was a good point for us - I always felt it would be vital to get something out of this game because of Fulham and Blackburn coming up in our next two games," he said.

Ahead of those fixtures, his team can take heart from a display that left the home side thoroughly frustrated. The Terriers certainly look worthy of another season in the First Division, restricting Preston to half chances during a first-half of few real efforts on goal.

Perhaps the fear factor had seeped into the subconscious of both sides, with Huddersfield's relegation concerns equal to Preston's fear of success. After all, who could blame the Deepdale players for wondering if promotion to the Premiership this season might be a leap too high, this being their first campaign at Division One level for 20 years?

Both Watford and Manchester City have won successive promotions from Division Two to the Premiership in recent seasons. Watford's top flight sojourn lasted one campaign, while City look set to endure a similar sharp exit.

Preston made a concerted effort to break the deadlock in the second half, but striker Richard Cresswell was unable to make the most of the opportunities that came his way. He headed Graham Alexander's cross wide three minutes after the restart and was again unable to hit the target when he received the ball from Mark Rankine on the edge of the six yard box.

But Huddersfield were more than a match for the home side, with Delroy Facey and Ben Thornley in particular causing problems for the home side.

A withdrawn Moyes later reflected: "Whether that is a point gained or two lost, we won't know until the end of the season."

webTitle: Protesters force top broker to pull out of Huntingdon

fields.headline: Protesters force top broker to pull out of Huntingdon
fields.trailText: Private client stockbroker Charles Schwab Europe has stopped taking orders for shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences, leaving investors with just a handful of smaller brokers willing to carry out trades.
fields.body:
Private client stockbroker Charles Schwab Europe has stopped taking orders for shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences, leaving investors with just a handful of smaller brokers willing to carry out trades.

The decision follows months of protest from animal rights activists, including a demonstration yesterday on the roof of Charles Schwab's European head office, in Birmingham. Bub Duste, chief executive of Charles Schwab Europe, said: "The market for Huntingdon shares has just collapsed."

He said the final straw was the withdrawal last month of the last two market-makers prepared to set prices in Huntingdon shares - Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein and Winterflood Securities. This meant trades needed to be executed on the stock exchange's matched-bargain system, Seats, which is much more cumbersome.

The protest group Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty said it would now focus its attention on Bank of New York, which holds shares in the company on behalf of US investors.

An investigation is underway at Canary Wharf to determine how a group of protesters gained access to Bank of New York's offices on the tower's 49th floor twice in two weeks.
