fields.headline: Three sent off as Rangers throw it away
fields.trailText: The journey from adversity to hope and back again can be a rapid one, as Rangers discovered last night when they squandered a two-goal lead in dramatic circumstances.
fields.body:
The journey from adversity to hope and back again can be a rapid one, as Rangers discovered last night when they squandered a two-goal lead in dramatic circumstances.

Just a few days after the announcement that the club had been placed in the hands of administrators, first-half goals from Peter Crouch and Andy Thomson looked to have rekindled Rangers' faint hopes of First Division survival.

But in a stunning act of self-destruction Ian Holloway's side finished the game with nine men and a single point after conceding two goals in the final four minutes.

Holloway looked well placed to celebrate his first win since taking charge until Crouch received his second caution of the night after failing to retreat 10 yards at a free-kick.

Not only did Crouch's dismissal create a numerical disadvantage; it robbed the visitors of their most potent player and the focal point of their determined play.

Crewe sensed the balance of power had shifted and, despite the 62nd-minute sending off of Colin Little, established a foothold on the game through the substitute Dean Ashton's volley.

The collapse was complete when the Rangers defender Karl Ready hauled down Rob Hulse to earn the third red card of the evening and grant Shaun Smith the opportunity to claim a last-minute free-kick equaliser.

Holloway later acknowledged the scale of the task before him. "I've not been here long but I can see there is something badly wrong," he said. "We've thrown away a game we should have won comfortably through our own indiscipline. Peter has apologised but he's only 19 and, if he learns from this, he will become a much better player."

Rangers had strong grounds for optimism after Crouch had set up the 14th-minute opening goal. The gangling centre-forward won an aerial challenge before receiving a return from Thomson and finishing clinically from 12 yards.

The roles were reversed in the 34th minute when Gavin Peacock's deep cross found its way on to Thomson's right boot via Crouch's forehead for the former Gillingham striker to establish what at the time looked a solid advantage. Then the self-destruct button was pushed.

fields.headline: Rovers find a new hero in N'Diaye
fields.trailText: A contest between two sides whose league form has clearly been hindered by cup heroics this season was settled in controversial circumstances by Tranmere's Senegalese striker Seyni N'Diaye last night.
fields.body:
A contest between two sides whose league form has clearly been hindered by cup heroics this season was settled in controversial circumstances by Tranmere's Senegalese striker Seyni N'Diaye last night.

The Birmingham goalkeeper Ian Bennett appeared to have been fouled by Stuart Barlow as he handled outside his area in the 69th minute. City's anger at the decision was compounded when Jason Koumas' free-kick was headed in at the far post by N'Diaye, a signing from Caen by the caretaker manager Kevin Sheedy. N'Diaye had marked his reserve debut against Birmingham last week by being sent off.

The goal kept alive Tranmere's fading hopes of retaining their First Division status but the Birmingham manager Trevor Francis had every right to feel a sense of injustice at the referee Tony Bates' decision. "If you are a goalkeeper and are pushed outside of the penalty area, you are going to feel hard done by.

"I thought the referee had a good game but that one decision was crucial and proved costly for us. He should never have given the free-kick."

A run of one point from 18 had led to a clear-the-air meeting at the training ground on Monday. The initial signs last night suggested those frank exchanges had had the desired effect when Andrew Johnson left two defenders in his wake and crossed for Marcelo, who fired wide from four yards.

But that was the start of a frustrating evening for City in which they failed to turn pressure into clear chances, Bryan Hughes coming closest when he hit the post in first-half injury-time after a quickly taken Nicky Eaden free-kick.

In a frantic finale Richard Jobson headed a David Holdsworth effort off the line but by that stage N'Diaye should have added a second goal when Holdsworth and Bennett combined to scramble away the striker's goalbound shot in the 80th minute.

"We're not dead yet, if we keep playing like that," said Sheedy. "But after that N'Diaye has become a crowd favourite overnight."
